webTitle: The other side of the tracks

fields.headline: The other side of the tracks
fields.standfirst: Even with years of legal training you can still have bad days, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Even with years of legal training you can still have bad days, an employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
I am waiting for the tribunal reception to open when I notice the security guard has his gall eye upon me (actually both his eyes are fairly gall). I am probably looking like hell, what with my summer cold and the accompanying worm trail of loo roll emerging from my handbag. Then there's the fact I haven't really slept for two days on account of the heat, the phlegm and the way that the heat seems to have provoked my cats into a frenzy of noisy nocturnal activity - mostly claw-screeching skid turns on wood flooring whilst in pursuit of (stationary) toy mice.

"Do you find your work interesting?" he asks eventually. I stop scraping at the fine fuzz of loo roll lint on the front of my suit. What do you say to a man whose job consists for the most part in staring at air molecules?

"Umm, about 50% of it?" He laughs enigmatically. I guess that's the thing about being a security guard - you have lots of time to cultivate a lugubrious / sardonic / generally mysterious persona.

The case is in a bit of a mess too. Just before I left for the evening a great wodge of documents came through on the fax. Perusing them in bed from under a leaping duvet of maddened pussycats, I realised they were all highly pertinent to the case and would have to be seen by the tribunal. So I am waiting for my solicitor to arrive so he can go to the 5 p a sheet corner shop photocopying facility to make copies whilst I interrogate our witnesses.

That must be him - about 23 in a tidy three-piece suit which like his hair and teeth is almost sparkling with newness: "Case of X v Y plc?" he enquires.

"Oh, hi, great to meet you", I sweep some loo roll pellets off my jacket and wave the documents "I'm afraid we're going to need copies of these for the tribunal. Would you mind going to the shop and doing that?"

"Uh, ok, fine."

Witnesses arrive and we go through Y plc's redundancy procedure. The case it must be said does not really fall into the allegedly interesting 50% of my work.

"Case of X v Y plc?" says a voice. I look up and there is another crispy fresh 23-year-old in a nice suit.

"Hi, yes, and you are?"

"Your instructing solicitor." The first 23-year-old reappears at this point with an armful of warm photocopies and a vaguely humiliated look on his face. He is, of course, not my solicitor but my opponent. To save him from further shame, I am just going to have to pretend that I knew that all along and that there was nothing odd in my sending him off to do my photocopying for me.

Why did he go, though? Maybe I just looked too scary with my red eyes and red nose to say no to - like turning down Grendel's mother. Maybe he was just in that state of feverish over-preparation you get into when you're new to the job, where any unexpected turn of events leaves you helpless to know what to do. Oh well, we all have to eat a peck of dirt in this life.

fields.headline: BA snubs Air France 'entente' offer
fields.trailText: British Airways has rejected an approach by Air France to establish an "entente cordiale" alliance between two of Europe's largest carriers.
fields.body:
British Airways has rejected an approach by Air France to establish an "entente cordiale" alliance between two of Europe's largest carriers.

BA confirmed last night that an approach was made last month. It turned down the idea because it is still keen to press ahead with an alliance with American Airlines. Air France has an alliance with Delta Airlines and BA was not happy to become associated with another US carrier.

The approach came with BA already in discussions with the Dutch national airline, KLM, with which it is said to be more comfortable. A frenzy for alliances in the airline industry was sparked off when United, the world's largest carrier, announced a link with USAir.

Observers last night suggested Air France got wind of BA's proposed takeover of KLM and mounted a deliberate spoiling operation. Air France said its approach was "well intended and we thought we could do business".

Air France and Delta yesterday unveiled a global alliance, branded Sky Team, to challenge the leading established groups, Star and One World, of which BA is a member.

Sky Team includes Aeromexico and Korean Air as founding members alongside the French and US airlines. They announced their original alliance last June.

Sky Team's passengers will be able to choose from 6,402 daily flights.

In a joint statement, the chief executives of the four airlines said: "As the first global airline alliance created entirely round our customers, we are dedicated to providing the routes and services that best met their needs."

The statement said the alliance was well positioned for growth. Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris and Seoul's new Inchon airport, a future hub for Korean Air, both plan further expansion.

BA said yesterday that a study by Commerzbank suggesting a merger with KLM would cost 16,200 jobs was "premature". The study suggests merger will bring one-off costs of £970m for the two airlines, but increase their value to shareholders by ¤1.1bn.

BA has 62,500 staff and most job cuts would be likely to fall there. But the merger talks are only in the foothills and both companies would have to obtain regulatory approval, which might be difficult.

fields.headline: The image of his grandpa
fields.standfirst:
Hank Williams III
Renfrew Ferry, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
Hank Williams III
Renfrew Ferry, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
What do you do when you're descended from legend? You may inherit the looks but not the talent. So I approached Hank Williams III's UK debut with my expectations muffled by suspicion that he was exploiting his grandfather's reputation. The original Hank became an instant legend when he died in the back of his Cadillac in 1953, drowned in booze and painkilling pills, still cradling his guitar. He was 29, only three years older than his grandson now. When Hank III appears, all thoughts of a hefty guy in a sparkly suit disappear. For fronting the four-piece Damn Band is an eerie reincarnation, lean, sunken-cheeked and hollow-eyed - the image, in fact, of grandpa. A skull tattoo declaring "Risin' Outlaw" flares over his arm -which would be laughable if it weren't for the intensity of his performance, the face as gaunt white as a freeway moon, and the fact that he has inherited his grandfather's voice. The effect is spooky, the cut-glass hard drawl and the high yodel scything through a vast three-hour set of hardcore country. And there is true emotion here, far removed from the saccharine glaze of theme-park Nashville. He reportedly forsook punk and thrash metal and hooked his trailer to the lucrative country wagon because he has child support payments to make, which is about as country as you can get. The set is mostly made up of new numbers, although he introduces a batch of his grandfather's songs with a wry smile and a certain reluctance, his high lonesome wail making it all work despite his evident doubts. The Damn Band are a tight, driving unit, bouncing with stand-up bass and shivering with steel-guitar slides, pushing Williams close to spontaneous combustion in a hyper-fast Cocaine Blues. Shelton Hank Williams III just can't help but be caught in the stormy slipstream of his illustrious forebear. But the talent is filtering through in a rush of punk-country adrenaline. A hypnotic and faintly disturbing performance from a boy picking at his heritage like a scab, equally cursed and blessed.

Hank Williams III plays the Glastonbury festival tomorrow

fields.headline: Shouts  of agony
fields.standfirst:
London Symphony Orchestra/Haitink
Barbican, London
*****
fields.trailText:
London Symphony Orchestra/Haitink
Barbican, London
*****
fields.body: Arguably the greatest of all 20th-century symphonies, Shostakovich's Eighth is certainly the most uncompromising. It was first performed in 1943 as the Nazi armies began to retreat from Russia, and the Soviet authorities, expecting another call to arms after the fashion of the Leningrad Symphony, loathed it. Shostakovich, however, had gone beyond his earlier all- important demand for anti-fascist resistance to contemplate the effects of atrocity and its aftermath. He famously remarked that the symphony was "an attempt to look towards the post-war age", but the end result evokes a physical and cultural landscape gutted and ravaged beyond repair, and explores an emotional territory that passes through the absolute extremes of human suffering into the numbed void that lies beyond pain. It's so intense that some conductors shirk its implications, either by attempting to inject humour into its scherzos or by trying to find some sort of lyrical consolation in the instrumental solos that separate its shouts of agony. Bernard Haitink, however, stares unblinkingly into its depths and offers us no such hope. He takes it extremely slowly, emphasising the subtle ferocity of Shostakovich's harmonic and orchestral palette. The symphony swings not between discord and consonance, but between discord and irresolute emptiness. The denuded spaces that lie between the meandering phrases of the opening slowly fill with excruciating dissonances that seem to hover in the air. Lyricism is relentlessly soured by shrillness. The brass chords that repeatedly silence the screaming woodwind cut into you like knives. The best performance of the work I've ever heard, it was unendurable, as it should be, and I'm not sure I want to sit through its like again for a while. The LSO played as if their lives depended on it and at the end Haitink, desperately moved, looked as if he was about to break down. The shock that the performance generated was intensified by Haitink's decision to juxtapose it with the humane playfulness of Haydn's B Flat Sinfonia Concertante, mischievously written for a curious line-up of soloists - oboe, cello, bassoon, though the lion's share goes to the violinist, who, in the final section, virtually goes it alone and almost turns the work into a concerto. It was done with tremendous warmth and tenderness, coupled with virtuoso playing, particularly from the LSO's leader Gordon Nikolitch and generating throughout an atmosphere of safety and certainty. The contrast with Shostakovich's vision of devastation couldn't have been more telling.

webTitle: Caroline Sullivan's top 10 books on rock and pop

fields.headline: Caroline Sullivan's top 10 books on rock and pop
fields.trailText: Caroline Sullivan is a Guardian feature writer and pop critic. Bye Bye Baby: My Tragic Love Affair with the Bay City Rollers is published by Bloomsbury
fields.body:
Caroline Sullivan is a Guardian feature writer and pop critic. Bye Bye Baby: My Tragic Love Affair with the Bay City Rollers is published by Bloomsbury.
Buy Bye Bye Baby at Amazon.co.uk

1. Billion Dollar Babies by Bob Greene
On tour with Alice Cooper in 1973, by a bemused Chicago newspaperjournalist. Hilarious analysis of spoilt rock-star lifestyle makes it one of the best on-the-road books ever.

2. STP: A Journey Through America with the Rolling Stones by Robert Greenfield
The Stones on their famously excessive 1972 tour. Greenfield had complete access and doesn't hesitate to reveal Jagger and friends in all their whingeing glory. Great sense of time and place, too.

3. Powder by Kevin Sampson
Novel by the former manager of The Farm concerning a fictitious Liverpool band's rise and fall. Lots of really gross sex and drugs details: a salutary tale.

4. Groupie by Jenny Fabian, Johnny Byrne and Jonathon Green
Cultish swinging 60s novel (recently republished) of a London pop fan who's not satisfied with just an autograph. Fabian was a real-life groupie, and got to know some of the era's stars very well indeed. Half the fun is working out who's who behind the pseudonyms.

5. I'm With the Band by Pamela Des Barres
Des Barres is a California version of Fabian - except that she names names and rates performance (Jimmy Page gets five stars). Well-written, too, with a great sense of humour.

6. Everything: A Book About the Manic Street Preachers by Simon Price
The definitive story of the most passionately loved band of the 90s, with lots of hitherto unpublished information about Richey Edwards's disappearance. The best rock biography of the decade.

7. Diary of a Rock'n'Roll Star by Ian Hunter
Mott the Hoople's lead singer is no Dostoevsky, but his story of a 1972 US tour is straight from the poodle-permed horse's mouth.

8. The Rolling Stone Album Guide ed Anthony Decurtis
Acerbic, colloquial dissertations on virtually every album ever released make this worth reading in its own right.

9. Starlust by Fred and Judy Vermorel
This husband and wife pop-culture team analyse fan worship through interviews, diaries and letters. There are some strange people out there, and they all love Nick Heyward of Haircut 100...

10. I Hate Rock' n' Roll by Tony Tyler
A former NME hack who, as the title says, hates rock 'n' roll. Excrutiatingly funny, and probably out of print due to its sacrilegous theme.

fields.headline: Gates launches next net revolution
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft risks new run-in with regulators
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, unveiled his vision of a networked future yesterday with the announcement of a technology platform which he claimed would put the world's largest software company at the centre of the internet for consumers and businesses.
fields.body:
Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, unveiled his vision of a networked future yesterday with the announcement of a technology platform which he claimed would put the world's largest software company at the centre of the internet for consumers and businesses.

In launching .NET - pronounced dot-net - a networking platform that is to act as a foundation to many new services, Mr Gates made no mention of his company's long-running legal battle with the US government yesterday.

However, the new product's emphasis on integration could reignite the interest of regulators concerned about the company's monopoly of personal computers extending to all devices accessing the net. Earlier this month the Seattle-based company was found to have broken US anti-monopoly laws and was told it should be broken up.

Microsoft.NET will act as a software platform that allows users to access their personal information from any device, anywhere in the world.

As an example of its power, the company unveiled a prototype of a new product yesterday named the Tablet PC, a roughly A4-sized flat machine described as combining the "visual qualities of a magazine with the handiness of a notebook and power of a PC".

The new technology will incorporate voice and handwriting recognition technology as well as processing ordinary text. In a presentation to journalists and analysts at the Microsoft campus yesterday, Mr Gates described the platform as the most significant development for the group since Windows, some 15 years ago.

Windows is now used on more than 90% of the world's PCs. The long-awaited and already delayed announcement represented the fruition of years of research and billions of dollars in investment.

Mr Gates said: "It's a bet the company thing. We are putting our resources behind this."

In its fight with the courts, Microsoft has consistently argued that its ability to provide a base language for computers benefits consumers. The government has argued that it has simply used its dominance of the world's operating systems to stamp out competition in other areas. Mr Gates said yesterday that in the "new era" it was vital to have a single platform which could be understood by any machine. The new software, he said, would "allow individual building blocks to be combined together".

He brushed aside the idea that yesterday's launch was as significant as the launch of the Internet Explorer browser, integrated with Windows in 1995 and which ultimately led to the initial government legal action. "It is a new concept of something running out in the internet, out in the cloud, working on your behalf," he said.

Senior Microsoft executives were keen to stress that other developers would be encouraged to provide new services to be used on .NET - just as they had for Windows. They said the company was dependent on hardware manufacturers developing the necessary smart phones and other intelligent devices.

Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, who is to lead the plans to implement the new platform, said: "The internet revolution must now move to its next stage: ensuring that the ocean of information and resources that is out there actually work together.

"By creating a unified platform through which devices and services co-operate with each other, Microsoft will unleash a new wave of developer opportunity and creativity that will move us to a level of power and simplicity."

Microsoft's vision of a networked world echoes that of other companies such as Sun Microsystems and Novell, which have talked about large servers storing information for individuals on the net without the need for a hard disk. Some of the company's "partners" yesterday welcomed .NET.

Marc Andreessen, the co-founder of Netscape, the internet browser company which was largely crushed by Microsoft, was one of the more surprising supporters. The building blocks of the new platform include the XML programming language and the Microsoft passport for extra security.

There was a slightly ironic note to Mr Gates's emphasis on ensuring the privacy and security of the new system yesterday as his own emails became a prime exhibit in the government's legal case against his company. The security provisions built into the .NET system would, he said, "put the user back in control".

Mr Gates said yesterday that many new services would be rolled out over the next year but that it would be 2002 before all of them were complete.

The move aligns Abbey with the Scottish banks, Halifax, Nationwide, the Co-op in the non-charging camp against Barclays, Lloyds-TSB and Woolwich, which intend charging up to £1. HSBC is undecided, while NatWest will only charge its customers for using other ATMs.

Abbey changed its policy after "listening to customers", but there has also been behind the scenes pressure from government and the OFT in the wake of Don Cruickshank's banking report.

webTitle: FSA chief sets out iX ground rules

fields.headline: FSA chief sets out iX ground rules
fields.trailText: Britain's top financial regulator last night set out the ground rules under which a merged London-Frankfurt stock exchange would have to operate.
fields.body:
Britain's top financial regulator last night set out the ground rules under which a merged London-Frankfurt stock exchange would have to operate.

Howard Davies, the chairman of the financial services authority, said the new exchange, iX, would have to preserve market integrity, ensure especially that small investors would not be put at a disadvantage and allow firms to continue raising capital efficiently.

The FSA would also be considering whether the differences in regulatory systems in London and Frankfurt could continue to be "fully justified".

London's stock exchange and its German equivalent, Frankfurt-based Deutsche Börse, announced merger plans earlier this year, with trading in blue chip stocks centred on London but those in hi-tech growth companies shifting to Frankfurt.

The scheme, yet to be approved by either Deutsche Börse shareholders or LSE members, has raised concerns in both financial centres with players in each fearing the other has got the better deal.

webTitle: Diageo plans partial flotation of Burger King

fields.headline: Diageo plans partial flotation of Burger King
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Diageo, Britain's biggest food and drinks company, is planning a partial flotation of Burger King, in a first step towards concentrating its activities on spirits and beer.
fields.body:
Diageo, Britain's biggest food and drinks company, is planning a partial flotation of Burger King, in a first step towards concentrating its activities on spirits and beer.

The group intends to sell a 20% stake in the fast-food chain to investors on the New York Stock Exchange. The move is a response to a chorus of discontent in the City about a perceived lack of focus at Diageo.

However, the news was accompanied by the unexpected resignation of Burger King's chief executive, Dennis Malamatinas. Diageo said Mr Malamatinas wanted to leave the restaurant chain's Miami head office in order to spend more time with his family in London.

Diageo's chief executive John McGrath said: "I am very sorry to see Dennis go but he is completely supportive of the public offering." The decision to spin off Burger King follows a relaxation in American tax laws - in the past, Diageo has argued that a sale would incur a £1bn capital gains tax bill.

Recent legislation means Diageo can sell a fifth of the business without penalties, and the group is likely to spin off the other 80% after December 2002, when the tax liability lapses entirely.

Mr McGrath has admitted for some time that Diageo may have to change its four-division structure. The group consists of spirits and wine, beer, Burger King and Pillsbury, a US food manufacturer.

He said: "I believe in managing for shareholder value and I can't say that Diageo will always be a four-legged stool."

Critics say the business is too thinly spread, and that it should end its exposure to the US food industry.

There was immediate speculation that Diageo could sell Pillsbury next. Mr McGrath said the group would "participate in the consolidation of the food industry", but this could mean through joint ventures.

Analysts valued Burger King at about £12bn. Diageo as a whole is worth £26bn. Graeme Eadie, of Deutsche Bank, said: "This is a big step towards unbundling the group and focusing it on drinks."

Colin Storm, the chief executive of Guinness, will take charge of Burger King in August until a permanent successor is appointed. Mr Storm, 62, is due to retire next year and he will be replaced at Guinness by development director Stuart Fletcher.

Diageo's shares slipped 4.5p to 593.5p.

webTitle: Halifax snaps up Bank One credit card business

fields.headline: Halifax snaps up Bank One credit card business
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Halifax yesterday bought the British credit card business of struggling US bank Bank One for around £50m and disclosed plans to double its share of the plastic card market over the next three years.
fields.body:
Halifax yesterday bought the British credit card business of struggling US bank Bank One for around £50m and disclosed plans to double its share of the plastic card market over the next three years.

The deal will add 200,000 Bank One credit card customers - many acquired through "affinity" deals with football clubs including Manchester City, Bristol City and Cardiff City - to Halifax's 1.2m card holders. The Bank One brand will disappear.

Until now Halifax has been a relatively small player in Britain's credit card market, charging 18.9% on its Visa card compared with 10.9% at the current market leader Egg and 14.6% at rival Nationwide Building Society. Bank One's standard rate is 18%.

Dick Spelman, chief executive of Halifax Retail Financial Services said: "Credit cards will be a key part of Halifax's plans to diversify away from its traditional dependency on mortgages and savings. It's going to be an aggressive part of our strategy."

The sale by Bank One comes only 18 months after it entered the British market and follows the disposal of its Canadian cards operation in May. Bank One is the second largest card issuer in the USA and the fifth largest bank, but saw its profits plunge by three-quarters after problems emerged in its First USA card operations.

Halifax refused to disclose the price paid for Bank One, which has net assets of £18m and outstanding card balances of £180m, but analysts put the figure at £40m-£50m. "This gives Halifax a leap forward in the credit card market, but it is still relatively small and has in the past relied on inertia selling," said one analyst.

Bank One employs 200 people at its Cardiff headquarters but Halifax says the jobs are not under threat. As part of the deal, Bank One UK president James Corcoran will become managing director of Halifax Card Services.

Halifax also said it was planning to close 47 branches at its Birmingham Midshires, subsidiary. The closures may result in the loss of some jobs, but a spokesman at Birmingham Midshires said it expected most of the 220 staff affected to take up roles elsewhere in the group.

fields.headline: Coiled energy
fields.standfirst:
Eliane Elias
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Eliane Elias
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.body: Eliane Elias plays the piano like a slightly manic driver, her bare feet heavily stamping out the beat as she veers into altered and extended territory with the ease of a veteran rallyist. And there were no pit-stops on this outing. The audience were already raring to go, having been warmed up by violinist Omar Puente and his Eclipse band's flares and swoops, snatches of Czardes, wistful violin-guitar duets and witty piano-tag. Elias certainly knows how to pick a good band. Brazilian-born and classically trained, she started out with Eddie Gomez, played with Steps Ahead in the early 80s and worked with Herbie Hancock and Antonio Carlos Jobim, recording two Jobim collections. Marc Johnson on bass and Satoshi Takeishi on drums were clearly in the premier league, but at times they seemed incidental to Elias's compelling journey. Her first two numbers were from her latest album - the Cole Porter title track, Everything I Love, and Charlie Mingus's wonderful Nostalgia in Times Square, which she rendered with slinky chromatic precision. She introduced pieces with a pensive conversation between hands, a dainty, enquiring and impatient dialogue surrendering finally to theme or rhythm. In a Jobim medley, her stride bassline led the way for a splash of brass. Then, in the emotive The Way You Love Me, she got quite jittery with excitement. It was like watching a drunken tramp as we held our breath, waiting to see which way she would reel. A drum solo recovered the balance, to which Elias added - gracefully, mind - the occasional wilful plonk. A Gershwin concoction saw her slamming out slicks of melody, using both ends of the piano to fantastic effect. Later she used her fingers less as hammers than levers, pulling out sounds like a harpist. The Time is Now and Jobim's Desafinado gave Johnson a chance to shine: a low bass refrain in the first gave a sinister underhang to his skittering fingers, and then a high range in the second conjured great musty, moonlit patches of sound. Elias sang only once - a husky ballad, picked out sparingly - but it was a restful interlude in an evening defined by coiled energy.

webTitle: The first wave leaves Dorset beached

fields.headline: The first wave leaves Dorset beached
fields.standfirst:
Glamorgan 333-4
Dorset 194
Glamorgan win by 139 runs
fields.trailText:
Glamorgan 333-4
Dorset 194
Glamorgan win by 139 runs.
fields.body:
Glamorgan began with an opening stand of 246, their best in limited-over cricket. In less than two hours, Matthew Elliott and Keith Newell had passed 200. The match on this historic, much loved parkland ground, where county cricket was played by Hampshire until 1992, was already over as a contest. Spectators with good-natured, if premature, resignation rearranged the day's outing with a stroll down the hill to the beach.

Yesterday's win by 139 runs was perhaps not wholly a matter of celebration for Robert Croft. Heartened by his England retention in the one-day squad, he was then less than hospitably treated by either side. An early six of Newell's crashed through the roof of the press box, perilously near to where Croft had been whispering Welsh words into his mobile just before. Worse still, Newell later aimed a straight six through the rear window of Croft's new Audi.

To compound the personal vagaries, Vyvian Pike took late-afternoon successive sixes off Croft, whose half-a-dozen overs cost him an unlikely 52. There were other Glamorgan talking points, too: the unexplained omission of the promising batsman Michael Powell, and the relaxed self- demotion from captaincy for the match by Matthew Maynard in favour of Steve Watkin.

Newell, who has recently taken over the one-day opener role, hit 14 fours and three sixes in his brisk 129 before being stumped. The left-handed Elliott was out near the end as he slogged to square leg after four sixes and 17 fours. Both batsmen scored at a run a ball as Dorset's bowlers were remorselessly caned. The leg-spinner Pike, who had won the match award in the previous round with five for 10 and seven maidens, conceded a demoralising 82.

There was never any chance of Dorset getting within reach. All the more credit then to Martin Miller and Pike, who smote 82 runs for the eighth wicket. Miller was last to go for a meritorious 81.

 Pakistan's Abdur Razzaq created cricket history against Sri Lanka in Galle yesterday when he became, at 20, the youngest man to claim a test hat-trick. In the 62nd over of the opening day of the second test, Razzaq had Romesh Kaluwitharana caught behind, then trapped Rangana Herath and Karuppiahyage Pushpakumara leg-before. The previous holder was South Africa's Geoff Griffin, who did so at Lord's in 1960 aged 21.

fields.headline: Driver overtakes one-day kings
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 211-8
Worcestershire 212-7
Worcestershire win by three wickets
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 211-8
Worcestershire 212-7
Worcestershire win by three wickets.
fields.body:
Ryan Driver, tall, slender and callow, is known as Bambi to his Worcestershire team-mates. But in his first NatWest match for the county he played an innings of beguiling authority yesterday to end Gloucestershire's remarkable one-day run.

Gloucestershire were going for a double double. Having won both Lord's finals last season, and having already taken this year's Benson and Hedges Cup, they had won 14 out of 15 50-over games and were favourites to triumph here even after scoring a slightly disappointing 211 for eight.

They were hugely confident after reducing Worcestershire to 68 for four on a troublesome surface. Graeme Hick, caught at backward point when he failed to get over his cut off Michael Smith, and Vikram Solanki, perhaps unlucky to be given out lbw to the same bowler, had both departed.

Driver, 21, a left-handed Cornishman who has played in a handful of recent matches only because of injuries to Gavin Haynes, Reuben Spiring and Philip Weston, could not have picked a better moment for his maiden one-day fifty. It was only his second one-day game of the season.

He put on 89 in 20 overs for the fifth wicket with David Leatherdale (53) and then, when three wickets tumbled for one run in 13 deliveries and Gloucestershire's tired nostrils sniffed blood once more, he added an unbeaten 54 for the eighth with Richard Illingworth.

He was dropped by Mark Alleyne off Jeremy Snape on 28 and celebrated the reprieve by clouting a six over midwicket in the same over. There was another six and two fours in his 82-ball fifty and alto gether he faced 93 deliveries for 61 not out. With loose arms and a flowing swing of the bat even Gloucestershire's famously canny bowlers were in difficulty.

He could not have pushed Worcestershire over the line on his own, however, and with 47 needed from the last eight the side were grateful to the veteran Illingworth for his 25 from 29 balls.

Earlier, Gloucestershire had finished about 20 runs short of their expectations. But on a slow, difficult pitch, they crashed the gears whenever they attempted to accelerate.

Rob Cunliffe scored his first one-day fifty and Jack Russell, surprisingly, only his second in this competition, a cheeky, 102-ball 84.

 Warwickshire came closest to suffering an upset as they allowed the Essex Board to within 11 runs of their modest 214 for eight at Billericay. The opener Nick Carlier made 56 for the club cricketers.

fields.headline: Langer unravels Notts
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 274-5
Nottinghamshire 146
Middlesex win by 128 runs
fields.trailText:
Middlesex 274-5
Nottinghamshire 146
Middlesex win by 128 runs.
fields.body:
The incentive of coming back to Lord's in August for the final seemed to have been lost on Nottinghamshire and Middlesex's progress to the fourth round was achieved with such ease that they could have been playing a board XI in disguise.

Not that Middlesex were complaining. It was the first time this season that they had passed 200 in a one-day match and only their third victory in all competitions. A "clear the air" meeting after two defeats last weekend evidently had the desired effect.

There are few players better at exploiting feeble opponents than Justin Langer, who combined aggressive running with judicious placement to reach 100 from 128 balls before being run out.

The Nottinghamshire bowlers must be sick of the sight of him. In last week's championship match between the two sides he made 96 and 104.

Middlesex's total was built around Langer's century partnerships with Andrew Strauss and Owais Shah. Even with the addition of the new signing Paul Reiffel, the Nottinghamshire bowling was wayward and their fielding passionless after the dismissal of Mark Ramprakash in the third over as his off bail was clipped by Paul Franks.

The visitors' remote chance of victory evaporated within 13 overs of their reply, by which time they were 48 for four, and a couple of comical run outs only added to the farce.

webTitle: Lewis flies flag for another England

fields.headline: Lewis flies flag for another England
fields.standfirst:
Cumberland 140
Kent 141-4
Kent win by six wickets
fields.trailText:
Cumberland 140
Kent 141-4
Kent win by six wickets
fields.body:
There has rarely been a more pressing need to retreat into the world of county cricket at its most beguiling. On the NatWest third-round day, big is pitted against small, neat rural grounds throb with anticipation of a turn-up that rarely occurs and life's harsher realities are not allowed to intrude.

Edenside, a charming banked ground, sounded an appropriate setting after a week in which English team sport has again revealed its decay. The England football team is uncultured on the field and an example of cultural philistinism off it; and the England cricket team contrived to justify its overload of experience in the Edgbaston Test by surrendering to two West Indies fast bowlers even longer in the tooth.

At Edenside, no one bothered to slate the Nevilles or berate England's batting as long as the modest fantasy survived that Cumberland, last season's Minor Counties champions, might overwhelm Kent.

Kris Adams, a live left-arm quick, formerly of Lincolnshire and the MCC ground staff, ensured that the dream was short-lived. He returned his best Kent figures of six for 24 and bowled two former county professionals, Yorkshire's Ashley Metcalfe and Durham's John Glendenen, in successive balls as Cumberland crumbled to 22 for five by the 14th over.

Considerable consolation came, though, in the 18 stones of Martin Lewis, a club professional at Cockermouth. Lewis's 65 off 84 balls, characterised by clumping straight drives and meaty pulls, was eminently watchable, so much so that Lord Cowdrey of Tonbridge, presenting the man-of-the-match award, suggested that Lewis had "a touch of Colin Milburn about him".

It was a shame that he was dismissed so ingloriously, run out by Rahul Dravid from deep square leg as he chanced a hazardous second run that would have extended a batsman of more slender means and sent him juddering desperately into his ground.

Cumberland's 140 delayed Kent for 39 overs before a six-wicket win was predictably achieved.

Alongside Lewis, Steve O'Shaughnessy blocked interminably. In his early days at Lancashire, O'Shaughnessy was confidently tipped for England in these very pages by a Lancashire loyalist, who was shocked soon afterwards to read that he had supposedly also called for Bernard Reidy (another Lancashire and Cumberland all-rounder) to win his England cap.

fields.bodyText: There has rarely been a more pressing need to retreat into the world of county cricket at its most beguiling. On the NatWest third-round day, big is pitted against small, neat rural grounds throb with anticipation of a turn-up that rarely occurs and life's harsher realities are not allowed to intrude. Edenside, a charming banked ground, sounded an appropriate setting after a week in which English team sport has again revealed its decay. The England football team is uncultured on the field and an example of cultural philistinism off it; and the England cricket team contrived to justify its overload of experience in the Edgbaston Test by surrendering to two West Indies fast bowlers even longer in the tooth. At Edenside, no one bothered to slate the Nevilles or berate England's batting as long as the modest fantasy survived that Cumberland, last season's Minor Counties champions, might overwhelm Kent. webTitle: South Africans captivated by hero's TV ordeal

fields.headline: South Africans captivated by hero's TV ordeal
fields.trailText: Andy Colquhoun reports as broadcasters cleared their schedules and the audience scrambled to find a place by the tumbril.
fields.body:
South Africa did not quite come to a standstill yesterday. The wheels of industry turned, the Johannesburg Stock Exchange continued to trade and cash registers still rang but just one word was on every lip: Hansie.

Cronje's cross-examination before the King Commission was aired live on national radio and television as broadcasters cleared their schedules and the audience scrambled to find a place by the tumbril.

Even the Springbok rugby team, preparing for Saturday's second test against England, were drawn to the morbidly fascinating public dismemberment of a once great cricket captain.

"The members of the team were gathered in the team room watching it on television and it's certainly a talking point among them," said their media officer Alex Broun. By coincidence the Springboks are in Cronje's home town of Bloemfontein.

Sannietjie Botha lives in the leafy suburb of Bayswater, in which Cronje owned a house until recently. "I was shopping around for a TV today and everyone here has been looking at Hansie," she said."I think everyone has sympathy for him. We all make mistakes and I admire him for owning up. It's painful to watch."

The broadcasters have certainly seen their audience grow as a result of a court decision to allow them access. Josh Dovey, managing director of the largest media-buying company in the country, Media Direction OMD, believes they will have enjoyed bumper ratings.

"When the national radio broadcaster carried Hansie's testimony last week they had their highest ratings ever for that time slot," he said. "It's too early for official figures on the cross-examination but I would estimate that the audience would have been up by about 50 to 60%."

That would give the commission a combined audience exceeding that of South African TV's biggest soap opera, Generations (tonight "Queen battles to share the limelight with the new addition to the Moroka family while Sonny struggles to keep his eyes off new, attractive Baba").

Of course most people were unable to devote their day to the spectacle of the iron man of cricket being moved to the point of tears but the tea room on the 22nd floor of Shell South Africa in Cape Town, which has a TV, was doing unusually brisk business.

It is a sports story but that didn't keep sports-mad South Africans from their exercise, although the Health & Racquet Gymnasium in the Claremont suburb of Cape Town reported an unusual rush for exercise bikes placed under a bank of TV screens.

Talk radio stations carrying the proceedings live reported silent phone lines while the cross-examination was under way but a flood of calls at every break.

Only in the England rugby camp in Johannesburg was interest down to a modest 40 watts from the 100 watts lighting up every other conversation.

"We've been more concerned about the England football and cricket teams," admitted their coach Clive Woodward gloomily.

fields.headline: Cronje unbowed by public humiliation
fields.standfirst: Disgraced former South African cricket captain surprisingly upbeat as match-fixing commission's cross-examination is broadcast live to a disbelieving nation
fields.trailText: The disgraced former South African cricket captain Hansie Cronje was surprisingly upbeat as the match-fixing commission's cross-examination was broadcast live to a disbelieving nation.
fields.body:
Amid a barrage of television cameras and radio microphones, the public humiliation of Hansie Cronje reached a climax yesterday at the Centre for the Book, the old national archive in the heart of the city's legal district.

South Africa was transfixed by live coverage of the King Commission's cross-examination of its disgraced former cricket captain, broadcast on television and radio after a successful high court application by the Live Africa Network News radio group.

At the start of the day, Cronje's psychiatrist Dr Ian Lewis had warned that his patient was prone to "memory loss and an inability to concentrate" as a result of the clinical depression he was suffering. Yet Cronje's demeanour was surprisingly upbeat throughout, and his recollection of facts and figures nothing short of outstanding.

Asked by his own defence counsel Malcolm Wallis to detail how much money he had earned during his playing career, he easily recalled all the figures and where it was invested, from his NatWest bank account in Leicester to an overseas investment account with Merril Lynch in London.

This made his later claim that he knew nothing of a payment of R139,000 (£13,500), made to his South African building society account on January 15 1997, extraordinary. Cronje said simply that he "wasn't sure" where the money had come from.

It had, in fact, been deposited into the account only five days after another sum of R231,000 was paid into it by the Indian jeweller-cum-punter Mukesh Gupta. Cronje last week admitted that the first amount was a "cut" of winning bets placed by Gupta as a result of information provided by the captain on the first two tests between South Africa and India in Durban and Cape Town.

Cronje also maintained that his decision to "make a game" of the Centurion Park test against England this year, which South Africa lost by two wickets, was based far more on the belief that it would improve his public image than on the R50,000 payment, speci fied at the time as a "gift", that he was promised by the professional gambler Marlon Aronstam in return for agreeing to forfeit the innings.

Aronstam also gave Cronje a leather jacket along with the payment, which was intended to be a Valentine's present for the cricketer's wife. "But it won't fit her now," Cronje added ruefully. "She has lost six kilograms since her husband caused her all this trouble."

Cronje, supported in court by his father Ewie and brother Frans, admitted receiving an additional R3,000 from Aronstam during this year's triangular one-day series between England, Zimbabwe and South Africa, for, according to Aronstam's lawyer Itzie Blumberg, "providing a particularly accurate forecast before one of those matches".

At his lowest point yesterday, Cronje said words could not describe his love of the game of cricket, his team-mates, his country - and, his voice cracking, "my unfortunate love of money. I do love money but I assure you, every time I walked on to the field I gave my all." It was a crushing admission of character failure, and he knew it.

With scant regard for his reputation, which Cronje clearly believes will never be repaired, he detailed the frugality of his lifestyle. He said his team-mates would vouch for the fact that he "was never the first to bring his wallet out for a round of drinks". In fact, he said, his cost of living was "very low, because I lived at home with my parents and because of the generosity of South African restaurant owners and friends".

Recounting the day in 1995 when the mysterious figure known as "John" first asked Cronje if he was interested in fixing a match result - the final of the Mandela Cup against Pakistan in Cape Town - Cronje said: "I wish I could say I told him to get lost, or jump off the building, because if I had my life would have been very different and I would not find myself in this terrible position today. But I didn't. I said I would go back to my room and think about it."

He did not take the money on that occasion, but in the world of sports betting, where bookmakers and pun ters will stop at nothing to gain an edge, word spread quickly that Cronje was weak and was a definite target for the future.

As the day's cross-examination went on, Cronje's demeanour improved markedly, and by the end he was even making attempts at humour. Today, however, the pressure will intensify again as the commission's chief "prosecutor" Shamila Batohi takes her turn to cross-examine him.

She was distinctly unimpressed by Dr Lewis's warnings of Cronje's mental frailty, wondering aloud whether his depressed state had prevented Cronje from playing cricket or, cuttingly, "golf at Fancourt", the luxury country-club estate on which he purchased a house recently after transferring funds from bank accounts around the world.

Nevertheless, Cronje's performance in the stand yesterday suggests that further dramatic revelations are unlikely today.

webTitle: Johan and Dennis conjure memories of Cruyff

fields.headline: Johan and Dennis conjure memories of Cruyff
fields.trailText: When Johan Micoud was born, in 1973, his father named him after the man who had recently taken over from Pele as the world's greatest footballer.
fields.body:
When Johan Micoud was born, in 1973, his father named him after the man who had recently taken over from Pele as the world's greatest footballer.

Today, almost 27 years later, Micoud plays for Bordeaux and is Zinedine Zidane's understudy in France's team of world champions. Like almost all the French understudies he was in action last night at the Amsterdam Arena, which is where Johan Cruyff's old team, Ajax, nowadays play their home games.

Micoud also wears No14, which was Cruyff's shirt, and he honoured his namesake by producing the fine corner-kick which Christophe Dugarry headed home to give France's de luxe version of a reserve team the lead in the eighth minute. But it was Dennis Bergkamp, given his Ajax first-team debut by Cruyff at the age of 17, who produced a sequence of lovely touches, many of them reminiscent of the master, to bring Holland level.

Bergkamp, too, is named after a famous footballer, but Denis Law's repertoire did not habitually encompass the kind of long diagonal pass the Dutchman hit out of the centre circle in the 14th minute into the path of Patrick Kluivert's velvety run, inspiring a majestic shot past Bernard Lama.

It was a good thing the centre-forward finished that one off, since he had just spurned the opportunity to profit from two of Bergkamp's patented short chips over the defence.

Holland took the field last night with a starting line-up including only five former Ajax players, which must be one of very few times the complement has fallen below 50% since Cruyff's heyday. But the club's heritage was evident in the way Bergkamp teased the ball around Marcel Desailly with the toe of his boot before dinking the ball just wide of the post.

After Dugarry had joined in the exhibition with a rather too ornate version of the Cruyff turn, it was Micoud who struck back with another stroke of audacious technical skill, forcing Sander Westerveld to tip the ball over his bar with a lob from fully 45 yards. Micoud again took the resulting corner, from which Sylvain Wiltord's shot and David Trezeguet's deflection sent France back into the lead.

Quite a contrast, really, with the hectic goings-on in Bruges earlier in the day and in Charleroi the night before. In essence, all that was at stake was the decision over who goes where for the quarter-finals. The rest of the second half was less diverting, but Frank Rijkaard will have gone to bed last night less interested in the result than in the feeling that at last, after their desperately erratic performances in their victories against the Czech Republic and Denmark, his team are finally beginning to turn their flashes of brilliance into the sort of sustained explosion Cruyff and his pals taught us to expect back when Micoud was a twinkle in his father's eye.

fields.headline: Ribbeck quits the fallen champions
fields.trailText: Erich Ribbeck bowed to the inevitable yesterday, resigning as Germany's coach after the humiliation by Portugal that sealed his team's fate. But if that defeat hurt him, the same could not be said of those players who reportedly spent Tuesday night drinking on their hotel terrace until the small hours.
fields.body:
Erich Ribbeck bowed to the inevitable yesterday, resigning as Germany's coach after the humiliation by Portugal that sealed his team's fate. But if that defeat hurt him, the same could not be said of those players who reportedly spent Tuesday night drinking on their hotel terrace until the small hours.

Ribbeck looked almost relieved as he announced the end of 22 turbulent months in the job. "I feel I have been let down," he said, though he shouldered the blame for the decline of a side who came as European champions but leave without a win.

"The decision is a consequence of the team's catastrophic elimination for which I take full responsibility," he said. "I want to clear the way for my successor so he can start immediately with the reconstruction of the team."

The rebuilding job is huge, with little outstanding young talent available. The German Football Federation holds a meeting on Saturday to discuss Ribbeck's replacement, with Bayer Leverkusen's coach Christoph Daum, Jupp Heynckes and Giovanni Trapattoni the leading candidates.

The statistics - 10 wins, six draws and eight defeats - make Ribbeck Germany's least successful coach, but there has been a steady decline since Euro 96. The meek defeat on Tuesday told its own story, as Portugal exposed how Germany's ageing side have been left behind. No longer powerful enough to impose their physical game, and lacking the verve and imagination so important today, they have sunk to new depths.

"You're Europe's football twits!" Bild newspaper declared. Ribbeck, who came out of semi-retirement to take a job several others turned down, can go back to his life of leisure.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.trailText: Norwegian "Buttocks Boys", Danish career changes, Thai enthusiasm, Belgian fashion
fields.body:
Those Norwegians, they may not play good football, but they know how to have a good time. The most painful aspect of their early elimination is that they will be leaving their hotel, La Butte aux Bois ("The Wooded Hillock", since you ask), a posh Belgian establishment that boasts a natural spa. It's just a shame about its unfortunate name - the English-speaking members of the squad have taken to calling it "Buttocks Boys".

 That's not the end of their fun. In an homage to the great Egil Olsen, when Tore Andre Flo celebrated his 27th birthday last week, Everton's Thomas Myhre gave him a pair of Wellington boots.

 They may be neighbours, but they take their sport much more seriously in Denmark. The 30-year-old Miklos Molnar, who plays for Kansas City Wiz, has decided to retire from professional football at the end of the US season in September - when he plans to become a triathlete. fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Tournament organisers, while breathing a sigh of relief at the exit of England and Germany and their accompanying hooligans, have said they will continue with the policy of zero tolerance towards any football-related unrest. The Belgian newspaper La Dernière Heure echoed the sentiments of many in Brussels and Charleroi with its front-page headline of Hooligans, Go Home!
fields.body:
 Tournament organisers, while breathing a sigh of relief at the exit of England and Germany and their accompanying hooligans, have said they will continue with the policy of zero tolerance towards any football-related unrest. The Belgian newspaper La Dernière Heure echoed the sentiments of many in Brussels and Charleroi with its front-page headline of Hooligans, Go Home!

"Taking account of the numerous incidents in the last few days," the paper continued, "it is with some relief that we see the English players and above all their supporters going home."

Monique de Knop, an official from the interior ministry, said: "After the incidents we saw before the tournament and at the start, there was tension in several towns. I presume that tension will be much less now.

"That is not to say that these [Germany and England] are the only countries that cause problems. There are hooligans from many nations, so we will not be letting our guard down."

 Gheorghe Popescu, stretchered off after 32 minutes of Romania's 3-2 victory over England, will miss the rest of the tournament with an injury to his left thigh. The defender ruptured a muscle and Romania's coach Emerich Ienei said that he would need four weeks to recover. Also definitely out of Romania's quarter-final against Italy on Saturday evening are the striker Adrian Ilie, wing-back Dan Petrescu and defender Cosmin Contra, who all picked up their second yellow cards of the tournament on Tuesday.

 Filip de Wilde, largely blamed for Belgium's premature exit from the tournament they are co-hosting, has been given a two-match suspension by Uefa for being sent off in his side's 2-0 defeat against Turkey on Monday. The goalkeeper rushed out of his area and crudely took out the Turkish attacker Arif Erdem with six minutes of the match remaining. Earlier in the game, De Wilde had misjudged a bouncing through-ball to allow Hakan Sukur to give Turkey the lead and in the opening match of the tournament he trod on the ball to gift a goal to Sweden.

 Coventry's defender Tomas Gustafsson will be out of action for at least six months after injuring his knee in Sweden's 2-1 defeat to Italy on Monday.

fields.headline: Odds fellow
fields.standfirst: Options galore in the new betting market
fields.trailText: How to bet if you are not near a bookies.
fields.body:
A number of readers have written in to express their frustration at finding themselves living in an area where their only bookmaker is Hill's or Ladbrokes and they want to know how they can take advantage of the wider range of odds available on Euro 2000. The answer lies in the dramatic increase in telephone and on-line betting.

Smaller bookmakers often offer more generous prices than those quoted by the big two firms. There may be more independent bookies in your area than you realise and it is worth checking through the phone book to find out. Football punters should also check the pages of the Racing Post, where they will find regular odds displays by independent bookies, all of which list the free telephone numbers at which they can be contacted. All of them will accept bets over the phone, online or both, with debit and credit cards. High-stakes gamblers may bet on credit but ordinary punters will be allowed to open a deposit account with as little as £20.

The same procedures apply with the Irish bookies like Paddy Power and Cashmans, who are able to offer British punters bets at Ireland's 5% tax rate, as opposed to the UK's 9%. And it is perfectly legal for British citizens to contact an offshore bookie or the offshore offices of the big British firms in places like Gibraltar, Alderney and the Isle of Man to place a bet tax-free.

Sporting are running a market (Last Orders) on the number of times the ball hits the bar during the tournament. There were nine hits in the first 20 matches, when the quote was trading at 14-15. The market will be updated today when a small buy should be worth a risk.

webTitle: Banks: violence has ruined cup bid

fields.headline: Banks: violence has ruined cup bid
fields.trailText: The former sports minister Tony Banks has blamed widespread media coverage of the English fans' violence in Brussels and Charleroi in addition to Uefa's threat to throw the national team out of Euro 2000 for the probable failure of England's World Cup 2006 bid.
fields.body:
The former sports minister Tony Banks has blamed widespread media coverage of the English fans' violence in Brussels and Charleroi in addition to Uefa's threat to throw the national team out of Euro 2000 for the probable failure of England's World Cup 2006 bid.

Banks, who is on the bid committee, added that hopes of winning the 2006 World Cup for England were not yet entirely dead. "I have to travel optimistically and I don't rule it out," he said.

The 24-member Fifa executive committee meet on July 5 to decide who will stage the next World Cup, with England hoping to bring football's biggest event back to this country for the first time since 1966.

But they face strong competition from Germany and South Africa, with the latter thought to be the preferred choice of the Fifa president Sepp Blatter, who has frequently spoken of the importance of holding a World Cup in Africa.

England's own bid is based on its long tradition in football, backed up by its successful hosting of Euro 96 and claims that the hooligan problem has been eliminated in the domestic game. But the bidding committee, which includes the former World Cup 1966 stars Bobby Charlton and Geoff Hurst, has constantly had to field questions about England's violent travelling fans. Some 850 were detained in Brussels and Charleroi before and after England's 1-0 victory over Germany last weekend.

But despite Banks's fears, England's first-round elimination from Euro 2000 after Tuesday's 3-2 loss to Romania may actually have helped the bid slightly because there is no longer the danger of repeated fan violence.

Furthermore England's fans behaved impeccably at the game in Charleroi, although whether this was due to depression over their team's defeat or because of the Uefa threat to throw England out if there was any further trouble remains unclear.

webTitle: Shearer cuts his ties with pride and regrets

fields.headline: Shearer cuts his ties with pride and regrets
fields.trailText: Roy Collins hears an emotional Alan Shearer bow out with the words, “This was not the script I wanted to end with”.
fields.body:
As if to emphasise the finality of his demobilisation from national service, Alan Shearer, for the first time, appeared at a press conference in mufti, eschewing the normally de rigueur England tracksuit for expensive slacks and a tailored shirt with gold cufflinks.

If his clothes were a brave attempt to send out a message that he had already adjusted to his new freedom, a lump in his throat the size of a Maxply revealed that he was not finding it so easy to discard his emotional ties on a dressing-room peg along with his kit.

Shearer, who likes to portray himself as cooler than The Man With No Name, has too much self-control to descend into Gazza-style public exhibitionism. But there was no disguising the tremolo in his vocal cords. “I am bowing out very, very proud to know that only three Englishmen have scored more goals than me,” he said. “And I am honoured to have been captain of my country.”

Shearer also unashamedly offered up his patriotism as the reason his last game ended with a booking for diving. Normally he would have ignored the question, made a weak joke or pleaded the fifth. But this time he felt compelled to confess: “I dived out of desperation at wanting to do something for my country, to help us win the game. If that is a blank on me, so be it.”

At the end of his days, of course, a man cannot help remembering his beginnings. And thus, as Shearer tried to focus his thoughts on the future, his mind rewound to his days as just another green teenager with big, impossible dreams at Newcastle’s Blue Star Academy. Speaking with painful eloquence, he said: “When I first joined those boys, I never thought that one day I would be sitting here, feeling so empty and hurt. This was not the script I wanted to end with.”

Shearer guards his emotions so jealously that you can imagine a psychiatrist sitting by his couch for an hour without making a single note. Journalists have often made the same complaint but one thing he cannot be accused of is ducking a challenge.

Uncomfortable with the mea culpa speech of Kevin Keegan, who was sitting beside him, Shearer insisted that it was the players, including himself, who should carry the can for the abysmal perfomances here. “The players have to take responsibility. Even though we beat Germany, we didn’t play well and we have got exactly what we deserved at this tournament, an early plane home.”

Shearer also provided a fascinating insight into the detailed thoroughness, not to mention the devious ness, with which he pursues his professional goals. Practising in the Charleroi stadium on Monday night he finished with five penalty kicks, burying them all in the right-hand corner, the opposite side to where he slotted the real one the following night.

“I was sure someone would tell the Romanian keeper that I put them to the right, and it worked,” he said. “My hand was the first up for the penalty but then I thought, Jesus, I’ve got to take this. The referee wanted me to go and fetch the ball but I didn’t want to, I just wanted to get my mind right.”

Shearer reiterated his reasons for quitting England: to spend more time with his family, to prolong his career with Newcastle and, perhaps most impor tant of all, not to cling on to the point where critics could justify telling him that he should have retired years earlier.

Despite claiming to have a duck-like back to cope with the flood tides of criticism, he is both proud and sensitive, pointing out that no Premiership player scored more goals than he did last season.

When he hangs up his boots for good, he said, he would like to stay in the game, which prompted Keegan to tip him as a future candidate as England coach. But his farewell yesterday was marked by the extraordinary sight of journalists applauding him with hands that had previously wielded so many knives. Shearer looked genuinely touched. And so did most of the journalists.

webTitle: Cruel reality dawns late on Keegan

fields.headline: Cruel reality dawns late on Keegan
fields.standfirst: Coach embarks on a quest to find a passing style, writes  Martin Thorpe
fields.trailText: Coach embarks on a quest to find a passing style, writes Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
Some 12 hours after watching his team have a nightmare, Kevin Keegan looked like a man who had woken from a dream. Gone was the fairyland view with which he began the tournament, convinced that his England squad was packed with so much quality that they could actually win Euro 2000.

Instead Keegan looked yesterday like someone who had seen the cold light of day, forced to accept that England's players were not as good as he thought and that his famed gifts of communication had failed to make up the difference.

"Things we talked about on the training ground haven't quite found their way on to the pitch," he said. "I have to take responsibility for that."

However, his admission of failure was made in the comforting knowledge that it would not count against him. He still believes he is the man for the job, and more importantly the Football Association does not disagree.

But Keegan needs to improve his act if he is not to be booed off the stage. One tournament failure constitutes a yellow card at this level, and one more almost certainly means red.

The impression Keegan offered the media yesterday as he shuddered at the way his players failed to pass the ball properly all tournament was of a man who had not quite realised what he was letting himself in for when he took the coach's job amidst a tide of national relief last season.

It was as if no one had told him that it basically entailed shaping a successful England purse from a collection of sows' ears to compete at a standard of football that has surprised even this seasoned international. "I've played in big games at club level but this is another level again," he said.

Much of the future hopes for England's improvement rest on whether Armthorpe's eternal optimist can assimilate the torturous lessons learned against the ball-lovers of Portugal and Romania and come up with an answer. He insists he will. "I've done my very, very best here, and I will certainly be better for the experience. I've learned a lot."

The cry at such moments of national navel gazing is normally for a clear-out of the team to make way for youth. But with a World Cup qualifying campaign beginning in October with another collision against Germany, Keegan needs to be careful to throw out only the bathwater.

Though he will be keen to bring in fresh legs, the experience offered by the likes of Martin Keown, David Seaman and even Tony Adams in defence is likely to be utilised in the short term. Turning wholesale to youth is no panacea and Keegan did not give the impression of a coach about to wield the axe.

"We've got some very good players in this squad who will retain their positions until the next World Cup," he said. "I'll look at all the current squad and if they're fit and playing well for their clubs they will be in contention."

Some experimentation will be required to blend in the younger players needed for the finals two years hence, but it offers no guarantee that the passing will improve. Keegan pointed out that his players pass the ball well in training and for their clubs. But there is no pressure attached to the former, and the latter is usually executed while orbiting the foreign stars who do most of the creative work in the Premiership.

Regardless, what the country demands now is action. And on that score even the main juror is out. "I've asked myself whether I am the right man for the future and the answer is yes," Keegan said. "But until I prove that, there are always going to be question marks."

fields.headline: Jewell unveiled as Owls manager
fields.trailText: Paul Jewell was installed as the new manager of Sheffield Wednesday yesterday less than 24 hours after walking out on Bradford City.
fields.body:
Paul Jewell was installed as the new manager of Sheffield Wednesday yesterday less than 24 hours after walking out on Bradford City.

Although Jewell refused to be drawn on the problems that had precipitated his surprise departure from Valley Parade five weeks after ensuring the club's Premiership status, it is clear that his working relationship with Bradford's chairman, Geoffrey Richmond, suffered serious damage during the course of last season.

Indeed, it seems highly probable that Richmond's decision to enter the club for the Intertoto Cup was the straw that broke the camel's back. City were due to return for pre-season training on July 9 but are now scheduled to open their Intertoto campaign on July 1, well before Jewell had planned to recall his players for light training.

Now Richmond may risk further alienating the players by overlooking the managerial claims of the veteran midfielder Stuart McCall. Although McCall is considered by many to be the obvious successor to Jewell, Rich- mond may now install Chris Hutchings as the new manager even though he was a rather anonymous member of Jewell's back-room staff last season.

Jewell was unveiled as the successor to Danny Wilson at Hillsborough yesterday despite the fact that Bradford City and Wednesday have still to settle the amount of compensation payable for a manager who still had two years left to run on his contract.

"I think I know exactly what it will take to get this club back up into the Premiership where, quite clearly, it belongs," he said. "But we will need a lot of hard work and passion."

Peter Shreeves, who was installed as Wednesday's caretaker manager in the wake of Wilson's sacking in March, is to stay on at the club as senior coach.

fields.headline: Cardiff striker faces the sack
fields.trailText: A professional football player faces the sack after being caught on film with thugs in Belgium. The Cardiff City forward Dai Thomas, 24, was filmed by BBC's Panorama programme mixing with hooligans who chanted racist abuse and fought at Euro 2000.
fields.body:
A professional football player faces the sack after being caught on film with thugs in Belgium. The Cardiff City forward Dai Thomas, 24, was filmed by BBC's Panorama programme mixing with hooligans who chanted racist abuse and fought at Euro 2000.

Thomas, who was not arrested, could now be sacked for breach of contract from his £1,000-a-week job. Cardiff City's chairman Steve Borley said he was "shocked" to see the striker inolved with the mob.

fields.headline: Spain find greatness in lateness
fields.trailText: Does anyone know the Spanish for Great Escape? Jose Camacho and his players live to fight another day, but whether their nerves will have recovered in time for the quarter-finals is another thing entirely.
fields.body:
Does anyone know the Spanish for Great Escape? Jose Camacho and his players live to fight another day, but whether their nerves will have recovered in time for the quarter-finals is another thing entirely.

On a night of exhilarating highs and excruciating lows Spain were trailing 3-2 going into stoppage time. The white handkerchiefs were fluttering among their supporters and the obituaries written.

But then the seemingly impossible happened. Gaizka Mendieta levelled with a penalty but it was still hypothetical until, with virtually the last kick of the match, Alfonso lashed home the winner.

The late, late finale dumped Norway out of the competition and left Spain as Group C winners with Yugoslavia runners-up. Any of them could have won the group as the final round of matches kicked off but, then again, when have Spain ever made life easy?

For the best part of four decades they have been trying, and more often than not failing, to translate their club form into the international arena. But time and time again they have finished with paella, or at least egg, on their faces. This time they just may get it right.

It was enthralling stuff inside the Jan Breydel stadium and for long, gut-wrenching spells the Spanish were almost overcome by an all-too-familiar sense of nausea.

The blood-thirsty Spanish media were sharpening their pencils from the moment Ljubinko Drulovic crossed in the 30th minute for Savo Milosevic to head his fourth goal of the tournament. But Camacho's team dispelled the gathering stench of pessimism by equalising seven minutes before half-time and the game never looked back.

The equaliser was manufactured by Raul's weaving run into the penalty area and when the ball broke to Alfonso the Real Betis striker manoeuvred his feet to clip a neat left-foot shot beyond Ivica Kralj.

With Raul as elusive as ever and Gaizka Mendieta ubiquitous in midfield, the Spaniards were finally showing the world what they are capable of. Yugoslavia, too, were displaying the more aesthetic side of their Jekyll and Hyde make-up, Sinisa Mihajlovic an imperious presence in defence and Dragan Stojkovic at the hub of everything in the centre.

The game continued at a relentless pace after the interval and was lit up by two breath-taking goals within the space of 60 seconds. Dejan Govedarica, a half-time substitute for the Yugoslavs, put them back ahead on 53 minutes, curling an exquisite right-foot shot from just outside the penalty area and in off the underside of the crossbar.

But their joy was shortlived. From the re-start Spain broke upfield, and the substitute Pedro Munitis dropped his shoulder, drew back his left foot and caressed a brilliant shot into the top right-hand corner of Kralj's goal.

Yugoslavia played the final 26 minutes with 10 men after Slavisa Jokanovic's second yellow card but it hardly seemed to matter when Slobodan Komljenovic exploited some ball-watching in the Spanish defence to put them 3-2 ahead.

But then came the grand finale. Munitis went to ground in a clutch of bodies for Mendieta's penalty and, with only a win being good enough, Alfonso barged through to have the final word over seven minutes into injury-time and two minutes after it was due to have ended.

Alfonso's sense of timing came to good use again after the final whistle when he fended off a Yugoslavia fan who had scaled the perimeter fences to attack the referee Gilles Veissière. The French official was also struck below his left eye by a coin thrown as he left the pitch. But even if there will be possible ramifications for the Slavs, this was still a night to stand back and admire.

fields.headline: Lethargic Norway miss wake-up call
fields.trailText: The unconfined joy of Norway's hordes of supporters at the conclusion of this dismal match swiftly turned to despair when they learned that their team had failed to qualify for the quarter-finals.
fields.body:
The unconfined joy of Norway's hordes of supporters at the conclusion of this dismal match swiftly turned to despair when they learned that their team had failed to qualify for the quarter-finals.

When the final whistle sounded Spain were trailing to Yugoslavia in Bruges and Norway were home and dry. But the Spanish scored twice in stoppage time to win Group C and Yugoslavia claimed the runners-up berth because they had beaten Norway in Liège on Sunday. It was hard to feel any sympathy for the Norwegians because they made little effort to win this game. They will go home upset - but with only themselves to blame.

Norway continue to play to their strengths, that is to say they pour forward, often recklessly and usually, as their goalkeeper Thomas Myhre would readily testify, with a callous disregard for their own safety.

It was a curious game for, despite enjoying long periods of possession, Norway created very few chances. Indeed, Myhre was by far the busier of two under-employed goalkeepers and had Slovenia been capable of adding just a dash more thought to their football, they might have edged their way in front before the first half had run its course.

Certainly they had their chances. Miran Pavlin went close with a fine header and Ermin Siljak was unfortunate with a rising drive as Norwegian nerves threatened to be the afternoon's defining emotion.

The last Englishman professionally employed at the com petition, the referee Graham Poll, managed to keep lethargy at bay by punctuating play at every opportunity. Indeed, the suspicion was that had Poll not delivered sharp bursts of the whistle at regular intervals he would have succumbed to the inevitable and slept the sleep of a very bored man.

Slovenia showed more adventure but their attacks were predictable and one-dimensional. Even so Mladen Rudonja must have felt aggrieved when Myhre dropped to gather his low drive just before the hour.

It took the withdrawal of the wretched John Carew midway through the second half to instill even a semblance of urgency into Norway's wooden football. His replacement, Leeds United's Erik Bakke, at least chanced his arm - hardly revolutionary but a welcome development.

Long before the most welcome of Poll's whistle blasts - the final one - it was clear Norway were content to hold what they had, a tactic that did not win favour with their fans at the Gelredome and that was to prove so very costly.
