fields.headline: Holland secure home comfort
fields.trailText: France's spare parts caused Holland considerable angst last night. Roger Lemerre fielded a team almost entirely made up of reserves but the French led twice before the Dutch achieved the win which keeps them in their own country for the quarter-finals.
fields.body:
France's spare parts caused Holland considerable angst last night. Roger Lemerre fielded a team almost entirely made up of reserves but the French led twice before the Dutch achieved the win which keeps them in their own country for the quarter-finals.

As winners of Group D Holland will meet Yugoslavia in Rotterdam on Sunday. France, the runners-up, go to Bruges to play Spain.

If France considered this match a rehearsal for the final it was only as a chance for their understudies to learn some lines. Such crucial players as Fabien Barthez, Zinedine Zidane, Laurent Blanc and Lilian Thuram were rested. David Trezeguet, not Thierry Henry, led the attack. Of the regular French side only Marcel Desailly and Patrick Vieira started the game.

With Holland it was different. They needed to top the group to stay on home soil for the quarter-finals and the tournament still awaited something approaching their best form. So the Dutch team was more recognisable, with Dennis Bergkamp and Edgar Davids still there to link up with Patrick Kluivert.

France's reserves are not exactly in the Doc Martens category but in the fifth minute as Bernard Lama, having half-come for Bergkamp's free-kick, managed to get out of trouble by blocking Phillip Cocu's far-post header with his legs, it was tempting to wonder whether a change really was as good as a rest.

Not for long, however, for the French soon indicated that they were there for real. After eight minutes Sander Westveld advanced a fraction late to meet a corner from Johan Micoud and was left stranded as Christophe Dugarry headed the ball into an inviting net.

Going behind to France's second XI had the effect of a cold douche on the Dutch. Suddenly Bergkamp the mystic was Bergkamp the alchemist. After 11 minutes the Arsenal player's pass released Kluivert for a shot Lama saved without difficulty, another three and the same combination saw Holland draw level.

This time Bergkamp found the cutest of angles to send Kluivert on a dash for goal from the halfway line. As the striker took the ball wide on the left Frank Leboeuf moved across to close him down, but before he could do so Kluivert had swung back inside to drive a shot into the far corner.

With neither side seriously setting out to stop the other playing, the match was always going to be a fluctuating affair. Midway through the first half Bergkamp met a centre from Boudewijn Zenden with a shot which he drove into the ground. The ball then bounced over Lama but only to bounce back off the crossbar.

Holland needed that one to go in. Just past the half-hour another corner saw France regain the lead. Micoud won it with a bold attempt to lob Westerveld from 35 yards. Then, after the goalkeeper had touched the ball over the bar, Micoud's corner was followed by a well-struck shot from Sylvain Wiltord which Trezeguet deflected into the net.

Another French goal very nearly came three minutes into the second half. A prodigious long ball from Desailly sprung the Dutch offside trap, leaving Dugarry with only Westerveld to beat but he shot straight at the goalkeeper.

Yet again a miss at one end was swiftly followed by a smile at the other. In the 51st minute Frank De Boer unleashed a swerving rocket of a 35-yard free-kick to which Lama could only get a touch before the ball went in off the underside of the bar.

If this really was a foretaste of the final then Euro 2000 could begin to think seriously of complimenting the chef in advance. Even allowing for the fact that both sides were secure in the knowledge that they were already in the last eight it was still a good game to watch.

So was the goal a minute before the hour with which Zenden put Holland in front for the first time. Gathering a long clearance from Westerveld, the winger dashed between Christian Karembeu and Desailly to drove the ball low past Lama. This was a tree-lined version of route one.

webTitle: Pot-bellied army ease pain of elimination

fields.headline: Pot-bellied army ease pain of elimination
fields.trailText: One major question arising from Panorama was whether it was the team that got the fans it deserved, or the other way round.
fields.body:
Watching the depressing scenes from Belgium this week, I am sure I was not alone in asking why the government didn't do something to stop these people travelling abroad and shaming our country. I mean, they have been caught on camera often enough, and we even know their names: Neville, Shearer, Keegan, Ince . . .

Thankfully they are all safely back now in the comfort of their mock-Tudor mansions, where they can do no more damage to our international reputation. Unfortunately they have been followed home by the pot- bellied army of neanderthals we saw polluting the Low Countries in the Panorama Special that followed the football on Monday; and that is not such an edifying prospect.

It was a felicitous piece of scheduling to follow the Romania match with Gavin Hewitt's report on the behaviour of some of England's fans, because for the armchair audience it helped lessen the pain of elimination. If it means the Italians will not have to suffer venomous references to "Eyeties", tasteless taunts about Heysel and witless chants about Mussolini and the war, the early return of Kevin's dunderheads seems a small price to pay.

I found the Panorama programme far more effective and thus more dispiriting than the recent McIntyre Undercover show which covered similar ground. McIntyre, you may recall, infiltrated a gang of Chelsea hooligans who spent their time and not inconsiderable resources organising fights against rival supporters, and although they appeared every bit as ugly, brutish and racist as the human sewage that has washed up in Brussels this week, there was at least an element of cloak-and-dagger derring-do about their activities, which you could see would add something to their lives.

But the rancid lard buckets in the centre of Brussels and Charleroi singing "I'd rather be a Paki than a Turk" were no thrill-seekers. These were drunken racist thugs, plain and simple, who inspired in me, and I suspect others, two very unGuardianlike thoughts: first, what a shame the Belgian riot police were not equipped with real bullets, and second, can nothing be done to stop these people reproducing, should their appearance not be a sufficiently effective contraceptive?

One major question arising from Panorama was whether it was the team that got the fans it deserved, or the other way round. To the untutored eye, we certainly seem to have taken a step or two backwards under Kevin Keegan, although the BBC's panel - Martin O'Neill, Johan Cruyff and Alan Hansen - stopped short of saying as much.

Keegan, I suspect, gets a relatively easy ride from the pundits because of his impressive PR skills, but I cannot help feeling that all that spin would be more appropriate to our cricketers. As the antediluvian nature of England's three performances in Euro 2000 sinks in, more commentators, I suspect, will come round to the view of Graham Kelly, who told Nicky Campbell on Radio 5 Live yesterday that his former employers at the FA acted too hastily in discarding Glenn Hoddle. And Terry Venables and Bobby Robson, for that matter.

I have pointed before in these pages to the disturbing tendency to ditch perfectly serviceable and reliable talents in pointless pursuit of the modern. Saint and Greavesie, for instance, tossed aside like an old dishcloth by ITV, are now reduced to doing almost anything, however demeaning, in order to appear on TV. At least I assume that is the case, as they turned up on Celebrity Ready Steady Cook with Ainsley Harriott this week.

I did not catch the whole show, but its football theme was presumably to tie in with Euro 2000 - and to allow Harriott the requisite number of single entendres based around the word "balls".

In case you felt Jimmy Greaves and Ainsley Harriott were not enough "personality" for one show, the "very special guest referee" was Stuart Hall. My first thought, seeing Stuart, Greavesie and Harriott jostling over the mixing spoon and the camera was that I was in the middle of some sort of TV nightmare, but I had forgotten how naturally funny Greavesie can be.

He told Harriott how his catchphrase "It's a funny old game" was invented for Spitting Image. "These days we don't need the puppets," he lamented. "We go on live." He never was as fit, he said, as the modern footballer, being unable to run a marathon. "I could eat one, though," he added.

Now that the England coach's job is largely about running a decent press conference, I wonder if Greavesie fancies it.

webTitle: Ostrich scam pair found guilty of fraud

fields.headline: Ostrich scam pair found guilty of fraud
fields.trailText: The two men behind the "ostrich farming" scam of the mid-1990s were convicted yesterday of fraud charges relating to attempts to exploit public fears about "mad cow disease". They will be sentenced later today .
fields.body:
The two men behind the "ostrich farming" scam of the mid-1990s were convicted yesterday of fraud charges relating to attempts to exploit public fears about "mad cow disease". They will be sentenced later today .

Their convictions mark the end of the "ostrich mania" that followed official admissions of the potential danger of eating British beef.

Brian Ketchell and Allan Walker, founders of the Ostrich Farming Corporation (OFC), had been charged with conspiring to defraud investors in an ostrich breeding scheme. Their trial at Leicester crown court began in March.

Walker and Ketchell initially denied the charge, but changed their pleas to guilty on March 28. Both men, from Nottinghamshire, set up the business in 1994/95, promising investors huge rates of return from buying ostriches which they said would become a popular source of food. The business eventually attracted more than 2,800 customers and within 15 months had a turnover of £21m.

Instead of buying ostriches, however, millions of pounds of investors' money was siphoned into offshore accounts. Neither of the convicts bought ostriches themselves as a personal investment, but between them they received more than £5.5m.

Two men were acquitted of helping to run the alleged scam, brothers, Kevin and Russell Jones.

The company took many orders, but in many cases the ostriches were non-existent. Of the 3,456 birds sold to customers or allocated under the farm's guaranteed chick scheme, at least 925 did not exist.

OFC was wound up in early 1996 by the Department of Trade and Industry on public interest grounds. The SFO began its investigation just over four years ago.

Members of the public bought ostriches at prices ranging from £1,400 for a chick to £14,000 for a mature breeding bird. According to the SFO, "The sales literature promised significant rates of return on breeding birds".

Instead of buying ostriches, however, millions of pounds of investors' money was siphoned into offshore accounts. Neither of the convicts bought ostriches themselves as a personal investment, but between them they received more than £5.5m. Two men were acquitted of helping to run the alleged scam, brothers, Kevin and Russell Jones. The company took many orders, but in many cases the ostriches were non-existent. Of the 3,456 birds sold to customers or allocated under the farm's guaranteed chick scheme, at least 925 did not exist. OFC was wound up in early 1996 by the Department of Trade and Industry on public interest grounds. The SFO began its investigation just over four years ago. Members of the public bought ostriches at prices ranging from £1,400 for a chick to £14,000 for a mature breeding bird. According to the SFO, "The sales literature promised significant rates of return on breeding birds".

webTitle: How the Dead Live by Will Self

fields.headline: How the Dead Live by Will Self
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical response to Will Self's How the Dead Live
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Will Self may not have been too pleased with the reviews of his novel, How the Dead Live (Bloomsbury £15.99), but there was one consolation: Julie Burchill, in her reliably crazed Guardian column, announced to the world that she no longer fancied him.
fields.body:
Will Self may not have been too pleased with the reviews of his novel, How the Dead Live (Bloomsbury £15.99), but there was one consolation: Julie Burchill, in her reliably crazed Guardian column, announced to the world that she no longer fancied him.

"To get the full clout of this," she explained, "you've got to understand what Will Self represented, sexually, in the 90s. Despite his drug and alcohol intake, to us London media babes he was a sexual icon packing the oomph of Jimi Hendrix, Robbie Williams and Gordon Brown all rolled into one. Every man wanted to be him and every woman wanted to have him. They usually did, too."

Burchill picked up on the rebranding of Self ("no more the junkie stud, instead the funky dad"), which was seen to best effect in Lynn Barber's interview with him in theObserver. The Demon Barber's vitriol was kept firmly in its bottle. "Normally, he would celebrate the delivery of a manuscript by going on a bender," she cooed. "This time he took his seven-year-old daughter to buy presents in Hamleys."

Self, not surprisingly, used the interview to tell us how good the book was: "I didn't get any sense of completion until I was very near the end, when suddenly I could look back and see that it was working. But up till then I was in the dark wood."

Unfortunately, Adam Mars-Jones, who reviewed the book for the same paper, found it entirely wooden. "It may seem a perverse criticism of a book like How the Dead Live to say that it lacks vitality. But a book about fish doesn't have scales and a book about death needs a pulse as much as any other, perhaps more than most." (The book is narrated by a dead woman called Lily Bloom and deals, in part, with an area called Dulston, the centre of what Elaine Showalter in the Guardian called "necropolitan" London and home to an animated spirit community.)

Mars-Jones, along with most critics, admired the ambition but attacked the execution. "At the heart of the novel is a desire to tackle big themes and extreme situations, coupled with an absolute unwillingness to risk being uncool. The tone is one of unvarying contempt... a dutiful nihilism which over hundreds of pages becomes mysteriously vanilla for lack of anything to contrast with it."

Tom Deverson, in the Sunday Times, was even more combative. His opening set the tone: "It takes more than average chutzpah to write a long novel in which peregrinations around a city are interspersed with literary allusions, inner monologues, phantasmagoric episodes, mythological references, a funeral and daytime sex - and to call your main character Bloom. But then nobody would accuse Will Self of literary modesty."

It got worse: "The verbal excess is a thin would-be impressive membrane over an inner tissue of more commonplace commentary. There are incidentally interesting thoughts, such as the affinity of addicts with the dying, both of whom 'operate within tiny windows of temporal opportunity'. There are brief moments of enchanting imaginative transformation, as when Lily's duvet pattern dissolves into the grid of Manhattan. But more frequently, the look-at-me-mum metaphors and the compulsive alliteration are striking without being enlightening."

Robert Hanks, in the Daily Telegraph, also thought the book showy and chaotic: "Self's creative consciousness seems to have become a no-go area for the forces of law and order, the mental equivalent of a really rough inner-city estate... The ingenuity and moral depth detectable in parts of the book only make its overall failure more frustrating.

"Self's gifts as a writer are undeniable; they shriek from every page. But he is a talent entirely without discipline or discrimination. The book is packed with puns, assonances and alliterations; polysyllables, jargon and slang run amok; metaphors and similes blunder about, crashing into one another. After the first 40 pages, I was ready to give in, to say:'All right, Self, you're bloody marvellous. Now can't you just shut up and leave me alone?' But no, he keeps on going for another 360 pages."

Katie Owen, in the Sunday Telegraph, found similar faults, but was a good deal more forgiving. "The unruliness and extravagance of Self's writing is both his strength and his failing. His exorbitant imagination is stimulating, his word-play dazzling, but in his longer fiction he seems carried away by his own powers, his satirical effect blunted. Here, his enthusiastic elaboration of the dead way of life becomes long-winded, its deliberately challenging grotesquerie reduced to absurdity. For all these faults, however, this is Will Self's strongest and most moving novel so far, and Lily Bloom his most complex and memorable character."

Elaine Showalter, writing in the Guardian, also sought to accentuate the positives: "What How the Dead Live lacks in economy and structure, it repays in lavishness of feeling and characterisation. Lily is a colossal heroine, a night-town Molly Bloom... What begins as a satiric novel of ideas ends as a surprisingly moving elegy." But she rather weakened her case by saying that the plot and chronology were almost impossible to understand. ("There is a lot for the reader to sort out in this ambitious but often confusing narrative," was her more polite formulation.)

But there was one other source of succour for Self, apart from the fact that Burchill is no longer in hot pursuit of his body - the rave review that Mark Sanderson gave the novel in the London Evening Standard. No quibbles or clenched-teeth plaudits for flawed ambition here.

"How the Dead Live is the work of a novelist writing at the height of his powers,"said Sanderson. "It is a horror story, a love-me-do story, a full-frontal assault on the seven deadly sins - and a celebration of them. Lily may be an old cow, but she's good company. Whether attacking combat trousers, mirror-clad buildings or Steven Spielberg, she hits where it hurts and the result is hilariously shocking. Self's verbal fireworks are fuelled by real anger and grief. Life may be grotty but he has proved that literature can still be great." A reviewer in ecstasy is a rare thing indeed.

fields.headline: Bush's death row dilemma
fields.standfirst:
Related story: Bush could halt Texas execution
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Thursday, 3.45pm: At a time when American confidence in the death penalty is wavering, presidential hopeful George W Bush faces a difficult choice over today's planned execution of Cary Graham, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
The case of Gary Graham on death row in Texas has put presidential hopeful governor George W Bush in a dilemma at a time when American acceptance of capital punishment is wobbling.

Graham is scheduled to die tonight, depending on what the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles decides. Mr Bush has come under intense pressure to show clemency in a case that illustrates with brutal clarity why capital punishment is such a lethal lottery.

In 1981, at the age of 17, Graham was found guilty of killing a man before going on a rampage of ten robberies. His lawyers argue, however, that evidence was meagre and his defence woefully inadequate. The witness who said that she saw him pull the trigger has never changed her story, but jurors at his original trial say they now doubt his guilt.

Death row is full of such cases where mostly poor black men have been convicted because they lacked the money for a decent defence. The hit and miss nature of death penalty cases was confirmed in a devastating study from the Columbia University earlier this month. The report concluded that more than two-thirds of convictions are so flawed, they are overturned on appeal and criticised America's capital punishment system as fraught with errors. The fault lies in part, the study said, with the prosecutors who refuse to share vital evidence with defence lawyers.

When a life is at stake in a system so prone to fatal blunders, doubt is bound to creep in about the death penalty and there are signs of a rethink among Americans. Although a Gallup poll in February found that 66% of Americans still back capital punishment, that is down from 80% in 1980. Fifteen of 38 states that have the penalty are assessing its effectiveness and Illinois has placed a moratorium on executions after it released 13 men wrongfully sent to death row. The injustices came to light thanks to digging by journalism students from Northwest University.

Over 130 prisoners have been executed in Texas since Mr Bush became governor and he is not shy of his record. In response to heckling that has dogged him in recent days on the Graham case, the governor said last night: "No case is an easy case, but I also keep in mind the victims, and the reason I support the death penalty is because it saves lives. That's why I support it, and the people of my state support it too."

Normally the death penalty hardly emerges as an issue in presidential election campaigns. It's one of those facts of political life that is taken for granted in the US, although it has been junked in most industrialised countries. But as capital punishment becomes an issue in this presidential election, Americans are showing that even the most ingrained attitudes can change.

fields.headline: Welsh back £30m assembly home
fields.trailText: June 22 2000: The Welsh assembly yesterday ended months of dithering over its future home by voting in favour of a £30m debating chamber on land next to its existing offices in Cardiff Bay.
fields.body:
The Welsh assembly yesterday ended months of dithering over its future home by voting in favour of a £30m debating chamber on land next to its existing offices in Cardiff Bay.

Members threw out proposals for a smaller, cut price chamber favoured by the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, and the assembly cabinet.

Opponents - some of whom derided the cabinet plan as a "lean-to conservatory" and a "£20m bog on stilts" - claimed the scaled down project was a face saving ploy to allow Mr Morgan to distance himself from the grander, Richard Rogers designed glass building that is thought to be unpopular with sections of the electorate.

Mr Morgan surprised the assembly three months ago by putting the Rogers building on hold. His decision to seek a review of the costs of a project that had already been approved while Alun Michael was first secretary earned him the nickname "doddery Rhodri" and prompted speculation that he planned to shift the assembly to the Cardiff city hall.

He subsequently asked Lord Rogers to examine the idea of building a smaller extension in the assembly car park. The decision to recommend a project that Lord Rogers had warned would not represent value for money was felt by some in the assembly to have been damaging to Mr Morgan's credibility. In a free vote 12 members of the Labour group voted against the cabinet option.

The Conservative group, which has previously called for the money to spent on a children's hospital, voted against the idea of a new building.

The party's spokesman, Glyn Davies, claimed the cut price option was a vain attempt to save the first secertary's face.

"It will be a decision that will hang around your necks like dead albatrosses. The first secretary's idea for a new landmark building for a new democracy is that it should look like a toilet block raised on stilts about a car park."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Mike German, said members were not voting for a building for themselves but for a national building where the people of Wales would have free access to those who had been elected to represent them.

Lord Rogers said last night that work on the building would be able to begin almost immediately and would take about two years to complete.

webTitle: Nasa photographs show signs of water on Mars

fields.headline: Nasa photographs show signs of water on Mars
fields.standfirst:
Nasa's Mars Exploration Program
Nasa homepage
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Nasa astronomers said on Thursday they had found convincing evidence that water flows on the surface of Mars, a finding that makes it much more likely that life could exist or could have existed on the planet.
fields.body:
Nasa astronomers said on Thursday they had found convincing evidence that water flows on the surface of Mars, a finding that makes it much more likely that life could exist or could have existed on the planet.

Photographs from the orbiting Mars Global Surveyor show gullies and landslides that look like they only could have been formed by large amounts of seeping water, the scientists, Michael Malin and Kenneth Edgett, said.

"Relatively young landforms on Mars, seen in high-resolution images acquired by the Mars Global Surveyor Mars Orbital Camera since March 1999, suggest the presence of sources of liquid water at shallow depths beneath the martian surface," they wrote in a report published in the journal Science.

"Gullies within the walls of a very small number of impact craters, south polar pits, and two of the larger martian valleys display geomorphic features that can be explained by processes associated with groundwater seepage and surface runoff," they wrote.

The findings are astonishing because scientists had believed that water on Mars could only exist in frozen form, beneath the soil or tied up in polar icecaps, and as extremely sparse clouds in the thin martian atmosphere.

The new conclusions will have to be confirmed. The paper does not say that water itself has been detected - only structures that, if found on Earth, would have been formed by water seeping up from underground.

The findings are, however, a huge boost to Nasa, which lost two Mars missions in a row late last year. The space agency is planning missions to Mars in 2003 and 2005 which will include the use of a robot to sample the planet's surface.

Several missions have found what look like dried-up gullies, canyons and even lakes or seas on Mars, but no evidence that any water is left. That is not surprising, as the average temperature on Mars is far below freezing at minus 63 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 53 C), although it can rise as high as 80 degrees Fahrenheit (27 C) on a blazing midday at the planet's equator.

The thin atmosphere and roaring dust-storms that sweep the planet are also not conducive to placid lakes and trickling streams.

And the structures that have been seen are missing the little "feeder" elements of an earthly river, such as the rills and small channels that feed into a stream.

"Whatever the explanation for the absence of these features, the possibility that liquid water flowed across the martian surface in a sizable volume for an extended period of time, and especially in the recent past, seems quite remote," Malin and Edgett wrote.

They took a closer look at some of the features that had looked like seepage, found for the most part on crater walls. It would be in the partially protected craters that water would be most likely to last for any length of time before evaporating, scientists agree.

The structures look like seepage gullies and classic landslides found on Earth, they said. Even more interesting, although much of the surface of Mars has been pocked by craters, these structures do not have craters in them, suggesting they formed quite recently.

The scientists said they had looked for other explanations for the structures. "However, it is unlikely that 'dry' mass movement processes (such as granular flows or avalanches fluidized by atmospheric or soil gases) can explain the observed landforms," they wrote.

They said it looked to them as if water had percolated up from below the surface and perhaps a frozen barrier of ice had built up and slowed its evaporation.

They are not sure how much water is involved, but they did an estimate on one structure that suggests there would be 250 million litres or 66 million gallons. "For reference, if fully accessible, this would be enough water to supply 100 people for nearly 20 years (without recycling)."

fields.headline: Dover: manslaughter charge
fields.trailText:
Driver charged with 58 counts of manslaughter.
Audio: did Belgium send migrants to their deaths?
Migrants turned away from full death truck
Interactive guide: asylum seekers in the UK
Special report
fields.body:
The Dutch driver of a lorry found carrying the bodies of 58 illegal immigrants at Dover has been charged with 58 counts of manslaughter, Kent police said tonight.

Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, Holland, was also charged with one count of facilitating the illegal entry into the UK of two people and one count of attempting to facilitate the illegal entry of 58 people, police said.

The grim discovery was made by customs officers at Dover docks just before midnight on Sunday. Two out of the sixty immigrants on the lorry survived and are now under police guard at an unknown location. The police fear that the traffickers who brought them to Britain may try to stop the two men talking.

fields.headline: Hutchings the new Bradford manager
fields.trailText: Chris Hutchings, 42, assistant to former manager Paul Jewell, has been handed a two-year contract, with City's veteran midfielder Stuart McCall set to be offered the number two role.
fields.body:
Bradford have appointed Chris Hutchings as their new manager following the departure of Paul Jewell to Sheffield Wednesday.

Hutchings, 42, was assistant to Jewell and has been handed a two-year contract, with City's veteran midfielder Stuart McCall set to be offered the number two role.

McCall is currently on holiday in the United States, but club chairman Geoffrey Richmond said he wanted to maintain continuity in the management set-up at Valley Parade.

"Chris has been offered the job as the Board consider that continuity has served the club well in the last two managerial appointments," said Richmond.

"Chris Hutchings has in many ways been the unsung hero at Bradford City in recent years. "He was assistant manager in the Second Division and First Division promotion campaigns and last season's Premiership survival season.

fields.headline: Bush doubles lead over Gore
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Republican presidential candidate George W Bush has built a commanding lead over Al Gore in a new poll, scoring highly on economic issues and among the key groups his democratic rival needs to win over.
fields.body:
Republican presidential candidate George W Bush has built a commanding lead over Al Gore in a new poll, scoring highly on economic issues and among the key groups his democratic rival needs to win over.

Mr Bush, the governor of Texas, won 52% support in Voter.com's poll of 1,000 likely voters, with vice president Gore on 40%. Mr Bush also led Mr Gore 49% to 41% in an NBC-Wall Street Journal poll released yesterday.

Advisers at Mr Gore's Tennessee campaign headquarters claimed they were unworried, saying the poll was completed before the launch of his "progress and prosperity" tour of key states to tout the economic record of the Clinton-Gore years. They also highlighted the past three days of generally positive news coverage of Mr Gore's retirement savings plan and denunciation of huge oil company profits at a time of soaring gas prices.

"Al Gore has the right message," said communications director Mark Fabiani. "He's an experienced, determined candidate and the campaign is ready for the election in the fall."

Voter.com's "battleground" poll highlighted several areas of concern for the vice president, who is not performing well enough among key groups, such as women and union members, he needs to win in November.

Mr Gore and Mr Bush enjoyed almost equal support among women, a group Mr Gore very much needs to win the presidency. Both were also level among union members, another constituency Mr Gore needs to win. And Bush was getting the support of more than nine of 10 Republicans, while Gore was getting the support of just under eight in 10 Democrats.

"Who are these Democrats who aren't supporting Gore?" said Vanderbilt University presidential scholar Erwin Hargrove, who surmised that "a lot of them are probably blue-collar workers".

"A Democrat cannot win the presidency unless he can win the support of these ordinary working people," Mr Hargrove said. He recalled the Democratic nominee in 1956, Adlai Stevenson, who never connected with working-class voters and lost by a big margin to incumbent President Eisenhower.

When asked which candidate gave them more confidence they could keep the country prosperous, Mr Bush was favoured by 12 points. They also said he shared their values, and would do a better job of keeping taxes down and dealing with the gun issue.

When asked about presidential qualities, Mr Bush, who enjoyed a massive 23-point lead among men, was favoured on the characteristics of strength, trustworthiness and vision, while Mr Gore had a lead on experience.

"The political junkies have concluded that polls this early are meaningless," said Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a Washington thinktank. "But if I were a candidate, I'd sure rather be ahead than behind."

fields.headline: Regulating nurses
fields.trailText:
What has happened?
After scandals surrounding Harold Shipman, the doctor who murdered a number of elderly patients, and gynaecologist Rodney Ledward whose botched operations caused considerable discomfort to patients, now a nurse has been suspended from an Essex NHS trust as police investigate the deaths of 18 children aged between eight weeks and 17 years.
fields.body:
What has happened?
After scandals surrounding Harold Shipman, the doctor who murdered a number of elderly patients, and gynaecologist Rodney Ledward whose botched operations caused considerable discomfort to patients, now a nurse has been suspended from an Essex NHS trust as police investigate the deaths of 18 children aged between eight weeks and 17 years.

How did the children die?
That is what the Essex Police are anxious to find out. They were called in after South Essex Health Authority launched its own inquiry into the conduct of a community nurse who had treated all the children. According to this morning's Sun newspaper, officials believe the nurse may have "accelerated" the deaths of the children, all of whom had been terminally ill.

What is known about the children?
They all died between 1996 and May last year. There were nine boys and nine girls, aged between eight weeks and 17 years when they died. Twelve of the bodies were subsequently cremated. Those of the other six may have to be exhumed for post mortem examination.

And the nurse?
She has not yet been named, but is said to be in her 40s, with some 30 years of experience, some of it in Great Ormond Street children's hospital. She was suspended in September last year, apparently on an administrative issue unrelated to the children's deaths. When officials began an inquiry into that initial issue, they began to discover other matters which led them to call in the police, at the end of last year. The Sun claims to have seen an internal inquiry report referring to her severe mood swings, aggression, and "self-isolatory behaviour".

Why has the inquiry remained under wraps?
Police said today that it was "an amazingly complex investigation", involving 20 officers. They have yet to interview the suspended nurse, or any of the parents of the dead children. The families were told of the investigation only last night, when it became known that the Sun was about to publish its exclusive story.

Are nurses allowed to prescribe potentially lethal drugs?
Yes. Their authority to do so has been extended and is backed by the Royal College of Nursing. But there is deep unease among health professionals and the Patients' Association alike, that there is inadequate monitoring of treatments in the National Health Service.

Isn't there a government agency overseeing drug and medicines policy?
There is indeed a Medicines Control Agency, but it is concerned with issues of cost and effectiveness, rather than clinical use and practice.

Who is responsible for regulating nursing?
The UK Central Council for Nursing is the overall training and regulation of the profession. Day to day supervision is the responsibility of the local health authorities.

Department of Health
National Health Service Confederation
The Nursing Standard online
The General Medical Council
Guardian Unlimited special report: Harold Shipman

webTitle: PC fined £500 for racial insults to colleague

fields.headline: PC fined £500 for racial insults to colleague
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A police officer was yesterday fined and could lose his job for calling a colleague - the aunt of supermodel Naomi Campbell - a "flat-nosed monkey".
fields.body:
A police officer was yesterday fined and could lose his job for calling a colleague - the aunt of supermodel Naomi Campbell - a "flat-nosed monkey".

PC Peter Ferguson, 42, was fined £500 and ordered to pay £300 costs after being found guilty at Tower Bridge magistrates court, London, of using threatening or insulting words or behaviour which were racially aggravated to PC Sonia Campbell, 36.

Stipendiary magistrate Shamoon Somjee was told that Ferguson pushed his nose down and made racial insults to Ms Campbell at a charity police quiz night in Kensington, west London, in November.

The officers were off duty at a wine bar with more than 50 colleagues from Kensington police station when Ferguson also told her that she looked like "she could have gone six rounds with Mike Tyson".

The court heard evidence from three other officers who witnessed the incident but made no reference to it. Only the wife of another police officer gave evidence backing Ms Campbell's complaint.

Mr Somjee said the officers were "deliberately selective" in what they heard.

After the verdict Ms Campbell, who has been a police officer since 1993, said: "It has been a traumatic eight months waiting for this trial to come and to be dealt with. I'm pleased with the outcome and the support that I have been given by my colleagues."

Ferguson had denied using threatening or insulting words or behaviour which were racially aggravated. He told the court his comments had been intended as "banter" between friendly colleagues.

He now faces an internal Metropolitan police tribunal where his future will be decided.

After the verdict Steve Otter, borough commander for Kensington and Chelsea, said: "We dealt with this within a day of it happening which demonstrates our commitment to not tolerating in any way racist insults or behaviour by any of our officers."

fields.headline: Fixtures, Fits and Five-year deals
fields.trailText: EURO SCHMURO
fields.body:
EURO SCHMURO

Since England were knocked out of Euro 2000, the quality of football in the tournament has dropped dramatically. It's as plain as the nose on your face. The Fiver for one won't be wasting any more of its precious time on this futile nonsense, so while the so-called cream of Europe pointlessly pass the ball to each other and score their silly goals, we're going to look forward to August 19, when the real football starts again.

Yes, the opening-day fixtures for the Premiership have been announced. Manchester United start their tediously predictable procession to the title at home to Newcastle, while the only team likely to get within 35 points of them, Arsenal, are away to Sunderland. Leeds, Liverpool and Chelsea entertain Everton, Bradford and West Ham respectively - not that any of these matches will have a bearing on the top of the table come May, of course.

Charlton and Manchester City get a taste of what Premiership football is all about by, er, playing each other at the Valley. This means we rely on Ipswich to spring a comedy opening-day result - they're at Spurs. Peter Taylor's Leicester play host to Aston Villa, Middlesbrough have been - pffft! - sent to Coventry, and Derby play Southampton at Pride Park. It all sounds very exciting, but... it's not quite the same without Wimbledon, is it?

CHRIS OFF

Chris Waddle was as near-as-goddammit certain as a man could be. One day - and one day soon - a dream team of Peter Shreeves and himself would be appointed to steer Sheffield Wednesday into the promised land. Well, the play-offs, anyway. It was only a matter of time. 'But aren't the club speaking to Joe Kinnear?' queried his disciples, worriedly. 'Don't worry, I have seen the future, and it is plentiful!' Waddle reassured them. And he was right, and so he was reassured.

But yesterday Chris's little world collapsed. Because not only was Paul Jewell was appointed manager, but - worse still - he picked Shreeves as his number two, leaving nowhere for Waddle to go except the Hillsborough Ladies reserve team. And so he resigned. Angrily. Or so we thought.

"People are trying to blow this up, but all I'm saying is that they could have informed me two or three weeks ago," a volcanic-faced Waddle stormed earlier today. "I think I've earned respect in the game and I deserved to be told what the situation was, but I've been sitting around waiting for six weeks." Then, at last, acceptance seemed to set in. "Looking back I suppose I could have seen a while ago that I wasn't going to be in the frame."

So what now for the floppy-haired wonder? "At this moment in time I'm waiting to see what comes along, but I'm still fit enough to play," he said, quickly tucking in his beer belly. "I'm not looking to get back into the England team or anything, but I played quite a lot of football last season and I still feel I've got something to offer as a player." That's the spirit, Chris... but don't sell yourself short! You're only 39, and the way Kelvin Koogan is thinking at the moment you're a shoo-in for Japan 2002. Get training!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Matches against Spain are always close but we are better than them in all parts of the pitch" - Frank Leboeuf tries modesty. He fails.

SUPER MARIO MART

Chelsea have a proud tradition of buying ever-so-slightly past it Serie A rejects. And long may it continue! But despite Gianluca Vialli's best efforts to persuade Dino Zoff to put his gloves back on, this summer looked like being as barren as Chris Sutton. But earlier this week Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson received a telephone call from a man in an Italian accent, which excited him immensely. "Do you want to sign Croatian international Mario Stanic from Parma for £5.6m?" asked the man. "Does he play in Serie A?" wondered Colin. "Well, sometimes," said the man. "OK, we'll take him!"

And so earlier today Hutchinson was proud to announce that Stanic, a 28-year-old attacking midfielder who also plays up front (and, judging by his record at Parma, can also sit on the bench) is close to signing a five-year deal. "We first saw him when he was playing for Bruges against us in the Cup-Winners' Cup," said Hutchinson. "We also tried to sign him last year, but Parma did not want to sell. So we are delighted to have agreed a fee to sign him."

If Stanic does put pen to paper it will take Chelsea's summer spending to nearly £25m - and it's clear that somebody will have to make way. In the short term it could well be Tore Andre Flo, although Hutchinson again made it clear Chelsea want to keep him. In the longer term, however, Vialli himself must be under threat if he doesn't deliver. After all, he's making some brave but expensive moves. But we're sure Luca knows what he's doing - just don't mention that lanky English bloke, alright?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Roma have joined Lazio and Barcelona in the chase for Marc Overmars. They are also ready to pay Leeds £6m for skipper Lucas Radebe.

Chris Hutchings is expected to be appointed as manager of Bradford City later today.

Gareth Southgate is a target for Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna, claims Planet Football. But the Daily Mail reports that Chelsea are confident of tying up a £5m deal for the Aston Villa defender in the next few days.

Leicester are interested in Carl Cort, but will not meet Wimbledon's £7m valuation. Peter Taylor is only prepared to pay £5m.

Derby have offered Sheffield Wednesday £3m for Gilles De Bilde.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Liverpool, who have announced plans to leave Anfield for a 70,000-seater stadium 200 yards away on Stanley Park, have received a boost as the chairman of their supporters' club welcomed the idea. "We have to move with the times," said Richard Pedder. "Manchester United are getting a capacity of up to 67,000 and we have got to move on. I would obviously welcome the new idea. I believe it is a step in the right direction for the future."

Christoph Daum, the favourite to succeed Erich Ribbeck as manager of Germany, has ruled himself out of the running for the position. "I say here and now: Christoph Daum is not available for the position of national trainer. That eliminates me from this discussion," he told Kicker magazine.

West Ham have signed Nigel Winterburn from Arsenal on a two-year contract. The 36-year-old left-back has joined the Hammers after moving for an undisclosed fee.

Leicester have made a £3m bid for Birmingham defender Gary Rowett. Trevor Francis, who has already turned down bids of £2.5m for the 26-year-old from Charlton and Southampton, told the club's website: "If he does want to speak to Leicester that's the next part of the equation."

Pierre van Hooijdonk is to join Benfica from Vitesse Arnhem in a £3.5m move.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.30am) Maybe we should watch this and learn something.

Channel 5: US Major League Soccer (4.30am) Maybe we should watch this and learn something.

Sky Sports 2: Fifa TV (7.30pm, 10.30pm SS1) Poor Sepp. Everyone's gone to Lennart's party and no-one's interested in the spread he's laid on.

Sky Sports 3: World Cup Classics (10pm) Footage from the days when Germans could play football.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 (8pm, 11.15pm, 11.30pm, 12midnight, 1am, 2am) Basically on all the time, even though there's nothing happening.

fields.headline: Winterburn joins West Ham
fields.trailText: Veteran defender Nigel Winterburn is determined to prove age is no barrier after starting a new chapter in his career and joining West Ham at the age of 36.
fields.body:
Veteran defender Nigel Winterburn is determined to prove age is no barrier after starting a new chapter in his career and joining West Ham at the age of 36.

The left-back spent 13 glorious years at Arsenal as a member of the much-vaunted Highbury back four which guided the club to three league titles, including the Double in 1998.

But after seeing centre-half Steve Bould quit the club and join Sunderland with some success last season, Winterburn has bowed to the inevitable and agreed a two-year contract with the Hammers.

Brazilian Silvinho ousted him from Arsene Wenger's first-choice line-up, while the other members of the Gunners' great rearguard - Tony Adams and Lee Dixon - are in the twilight of their careers.

But Winterburn, who has switched London clubs for an undisclosed fee after making 584 appearances for Arsenal, insists there is plenty left in the tank yet as he joins another veteran of the Premiership - 38-year-old Stuart Pearce - in the Upton Park ranks.

"I still feel as fit as I did three or four years ago so I don't think that's going to be a problem," he said.

"I had some great times at Arsenal and I'm not just going to sweep them under the carpet, but now I've got West Ham to look forward to and hopefully there'll be some exciting times over the next three or four years for me.

"If you feel that you're good enough you don't have to worry about contracts," he told Sky Sports.com.

Winterburn joined Arsenal for £407,000 from Wimbledon in May 1987 but was capped only twice by England - ironically because of his new club-mate Pearce's vice-like grip on the left-back slot - during a splendid career for Arsenal.

webTitle: How much can you pay for ...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for ...
fields.standfirst: ... a can of Coca-Cola
fields.trailText: ... a can of Coca-Cola
fields.body:
You don't need to have been born with a silver spoon in your mouth to enjoy the decadent, some might say vulgar, experience of sipping pop through a silver straw - just barrowloads of dosh, and nouveau will do nicely. It's £595, for a set comprising a can of Coke, regular or diet, a sterling silver can holder and matching straw. It'll fit happily into the hamper for Henley. Or Ascot. So why bother to come up with such a frivolous objet in the first place, especially when there are starving and homeless people in the world? It's intended to mark the 100th anniversary of the arrival of Coca-Cola in Britain. There are various events in the pipeline, all of which are likely to be more affordable. Starting tomorrow in Ipswich, the "enjoy" tour is giving away a million glass bottles of Coke completely free.

Call Asprey and Garrard on 020 7493 6767.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Beauty products

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Beauty products
fields.body:
Undeterred by the demise of Boo.com, the Swedes have turned their attention to grooming online. www.snowdrops.com was set up by two Stockholm hair stylists and claims to be "Europe's largest and most well stocked beauty boutique online". It offers a studio where you can get information about fashion, beauty and hair care and a shop which sells "quality" international brands - some, such as Face Stockholm, Nouba and Bain de Terre, you might not have heard of, but others, such as the Diesel Perfume range, you will have. Simplicity and purity are the bywords here. The personalised start page lets you build up a profile of hair colour, skin and hair type, so that suitable products will be suggested on return visits. Delivery is within five days and is free on orders over £20.

www.beautyspy.com went live in the UK and Germany yesterday, selling a range of "high-end and hard-to-find" beauty products. Colourful and funky, the names say it all; Luxury Chicks, Valerie of Beverley Hills, Dirty Girl and the Lippmann nail varnishes named after classic Jazz songs. The anti-depression lipsticks (£14) from the "vibrational remedies" by Tony &Tina, hi-tech serums (£48) from Cellex C and luxurious bath products by Get Fresh (from £5) are also well worth checking out.

Helen Brooks

webTitle: Show night-time news earlier, ITV told

fields.headline: Show night-time news earlier, ITV told
fields.standfirst:
The ITC
ITC press release
fields.trailText: ITV has been told to move its late night news bulletin to an earlier slot by the Independent Television Commission, which has rejected the network's plans to boost audiences.
fields.body:
ITV has been told to move its late night news bulletin to an earlier slot by the Independent Television Commission, which has rejected the network's plans to boost audiences.

The industry regulator is insisting channel bosses bring forward their 11pm nightly news programme to help revive falling audiences following last year's axing of News at Ten.

Plans to boost ratings by injecting extra cash into popularising the peaktime 9pm to 11pm schedule on ITV were ruled out.

Today's ITC decision comes a month after it gave ITV extra time to arrest the plunging audience figures suffered since News at Ten was dropped in spring last year.

It comes on the back of fierce criticism from MPs, including prime minister Tony Blair, who want to see the long-running bulletin restored.

An ITC spokesman said today's announcement meant ITV was effectively being ordered to move the Nightly News. If it refused to do so, its only recourse would be to appeal through the courts.

"If ITV choose not to come forward with a proposal for a bulletin earlier in the evening, we are in a position to direct them to move it," he said. "We have statutory powers which enable us to order ITV to bring forward the news."

He added: "This is all about public service broadcasting. It's about scheduling for the benefit of the viewers, and at the moment people are going to bed before the Nightly News goes out at 11pm."

Sir Robin Biggam, ITC chairman, said: "ITV has a public service obligation to deliver national and international news to viewers. About 60% of the population still don't have access to multi-channel television, so they rely on terrestrial services to get their news and information."

When News at Ten ended last year it was attracting nearly twice as many viewers as its successor, which currently brings in an average of three million.

The spokesman said the ITC was being open-minded about how much earlier the Nightly News should be scheduled.

As research showed 30% more viewers were available at 10.30pm than at 11pm, the station was not necessarily being told to bring back News at Ten.

Gerald Kaufman, chair of the culture select committee, said he was "very pleased" with the ITC's ruling and hoped it would signal the return of News At Ten.

"It is now for ITV to take note of the very strong feeling across the country and bring back News At Ten," he said.

ITV's original decision to scrap News at Ten was attributed, in part, to its wish to show uninterrupted films, dramas and live sports coverage at peak time.

Responding to today's announcement, a statement from ITV read: "ITV regrets the ITC's rejection of its proposals for improving the audiences for national and international news programmes.

"ITV is considering its position in the light of the ITC's statement and will respond in full in due course."

webTitle: Police launch investigation into child deaths

fields.headline: Police launch investigation into child deaths
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Police have launched a "major investigation" into the deaths of 18 children aged between eight weeks and 17 years. A nurse has been suspended from an Essex NHS trust.
fields.body:
Police have launched a "major investigation" into the deaths of 18 children aged between eight weeks and 17 years. A nurse has been suspended from an Essex NHS trust.

The investigation centres on suspected overdoses of painkillers given to terminally ill children over a three-year period between 1996 and May 1999, reports today's Sun newspaper.

An Essex police statement said: "We are investigating allegations made against a nurse from the former Southend community care services NHS trust - now replaced by the South Essex mental health and community care NHS trust - concerning care of patients."

"The police were called in by the trust following concerns raised by an unrelated internal investigation. The nurse is currently suspended by the trust.

"Police officers and clinicians from the trust have visited families involved in the investigation and given them information about it and offer any support required."

Police denied that any bodies of children would have to be exhumed as part of the inquiry. "I am not considering exhumations at all," said detective superintendent Ian Weaver at a lunchtime news conference.

The nurse, who is in her 40s and has worked in several hospitals during a long career, including London's world-famous Great Ormond Street hospital, was suspended last September in an unconnected matter, the NHS trust confirmed. Police were called in and picked up the current line of inquiry.

According to the Sun, the suspension was triggered after the mother of one boy wrote a letter of complaint about her to health bosses.

The letter is said to have complained of "serious misgivings" about the professional conduct of the nurse which, the parent said, had "jeopardised and compromised" her son's treatment.

A spokesman for the UKCC, nursing's regulatory body, said it was sending the woman a letter today telling her she faced interim suspension from the nursing register.

The nurse would probably be formally suspended for the interim within the next three weeks, the spokesman said.

"We have to give people notice of interim suspension and a committee has to consider the case but we have moved to act very quickly today," he said. "She will face interim suspension while the police investigation is carried out."

The move will stop the nurse from working anywhere in the country, as well as at the hospital trust where she was employed and from which she has already been suspended.

The Sun reports that Essex police have been in contact with colleagues in Manchester who investigated Harold Shipman and police in Lincolnshire who helped convict hospital nurse Beverley Allitt.

Allitt was dubbed The Angel of Death after killing four young children while she worked at Grantham hospital in the early 1990s. She also attacked and injured a further nine young children, leaving some of them severely disabled.

She was arrested after a major investigation and later sentenced to 13 life sentences at Nottingham crown court and told there was no chance that she would ever be released. Her case led to tighter checks on the mental state of applicants for nursing.

 Helpline for parents concerned about their children's hospital care in Southend: 0800 169 1619.

webTitle: Teachers' pay: a triumph of pragmatism over principle

fields.headline: Teachers' pay: a triumph of pragmatism over principle
fields.standfirst: It comes as little surprise that most teachers have taken up the government's offer of a £2,000 pay rise, writes education correspondent Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: It comes as little surprise that most teachers have taken up the government's offer of a £2,000 pay rise, writes education correspondent Rebecca Smithers.
fields.body:
So - the cat is out of the bag. After months - if not years - of opposition from teacher unions and weeks of poring over the complicated forms, the government revealed earlier today that more than three-quarters of the teachers eligible for a £2,000 performance-related pay rise have applied for the extra money.

Most of the 197,000 teachers in England who applied are expected to get the rise, in addition to the 3.3% rise for all teachers announced in the spring. This will automatically give them access to a new pay scale which could see their salaries rise to £30,000 within a few years, depending on the extent to which they improve their pupils' attainment.

The government scored a public relations coup, deliberately announcing the news on the day when teaching union leaders Doug McAvoy and Nigel de Gruchy had hoped to grab the headlines through their members' decision to go ahead with a work to rule in protest at growing bureaucracy.

Significantly, ministers have won teachers round to a new pay system which was considered radical and even shocking when unveiled two years ago as a key plank of the government's drive to modernise the teaching profession. Education and employment secretary David Blunkett felt it was important to recognise and reward good teachers. In particular, he wanted fairer treatment for those who want to stay in the classroom, where their scope for extra pay is severely limited. Under the old system, for example, the most a teacher could earn without taking on extra responsibilities was likely to be £23,958.

The unions protested loudly at the proposals, worried that the new system would be divisive and pit "teacher against teacher". It was also feared that it would discriminate against teachers working in "challenging" schools with poor academic performance, where there was limited scope for improvement of pupils' results. They branded the system a crude system of payment by results which harked back to Victorian times. They said it would be costly to administer and a bureaucratic nightmare which would pile extra work on to busy head teachers.

The unions did win some significant concessions in the detail of the proposals. But by this year's Easter conferences, the protests became limper and it was clear that the issue was no longer the hot potato it was 12 months ago. Individual teachers simply realised that they would be mad not to apply for an automatic pay rise and the chance to get on to a higher scale.

Hailing the results today, school standards minister Estelle Morris said: "It shows the importance of our determination to introduce the new system despite opposition from those who said few teachers would apply. It also shows the value of our work with headteachers and some teaching associations to develop a system which is fair, robust and has a minimum of bureaucracy."

Fortunately the application to pass the threshold is not a one-off event. No doubt there will be a stampede next year from the teachers who sat back on the sidelines this time around.

Once Farley had watched his former wife suggest to her sister that she wasn't giving her one-year-old daughter enough attention. The sister had been looking out the window, and, hearing this rather mildly stated reproach, had turned her head to look at Marlise, whose own two-year-old (with Farley) was babbling at her feet. What really happened was that the sister's head swung around in surprise with a definite wrecking-ball look to it, and after screaming at one another for ten minutes, causing both the children to cry, and startling both the husbands out of two years of prospective longevity, the sisters didn't speak until their children were six and five. And they lived in the same town, and saw each other at nearly every family dinner. It was with this in mind that Farley never offered any suggestions to other trainers about their horses. But now he said, "Buddy, you should have that horse's stifles X-rayed. I had a filly who moved like that in the hind end, and she"

"He moves fine. He had an abscess. That's why he's been off. But the gravel erupted two weeks ago."

"Maybe, but"

"Watch this work."

The horse shot past them. You could see the exercise boy gritting his teeth, the horse was pulling so hard. Buddy said, "That horse loves to run, and I'm not going to stand in his way. In fact, I'm going to provide him with an opportunity to do what he loves to do."

"Buddy" But in the end, he couldn't bring himself to say what he was thinking, which was that the horse was going to break down.

"You know what?"

"What?"

"These horses are here to race and win. Their owners pay me seventy bucks a day and all they fucking care about is racing and winning. But that's not even it. The owners don't: care as much about racing and winning as I do. If the fucking horse falls over two steps after the finish line, he's done his job that he was born into this world to do."

"I don't think"

"What? A Thoroughbred is not a natural phenomenon. His mommy and daddy didn't fall in love, get married, and decide to have a baby. None of these horses would be here if they weren't meant to race and win. The reason Tiffany Morse left her purse on the bench in front of the clothes dryer in the Spankee Yankee Laundromat in Lowell, Massachusetts, was that she had to run out the door into the dank November cold to catch her niece Iona, and in the panic of that, she forgot where her purse was. Then she had to make Iona look at her and understand that she was not to ever ever ever go outside without Tiffany ever again, but of course, Iona was too young to understand thatshe was only three. Fast, though. Anyway, when she came back to dryer number four ("John Adams"all the dryers were named after famous Massachusetts politicians, right down to "Michael Dukakis," number sixteen), her purse was open and her money was gone. The Laundromat was empty, too. The worst thing was that she hadn't fed any quarters into the dryer yet, and her wet clothes were sitting inside in a lump with the door open. It actually would have been easier if the thief had stolen the clothes as well as the money, since now she had to cart all those wet things back to her apartment and try to corral Iona, too, but he hadn't. Tiffany could not say that she was having a good day. She certainly could not say that.

But Tiffany didn't really require good days anymore. She was always willing to settle for a good morning, or even a good hour. And she and Iona had had a good hour just that evening, before coming out to the Laundromat. What happened was, Tiffany picked Iona up at her mother's on her way home from work because she had agreed to take Iona for the night while her mother went to choir practice and then out with some of the other choir members, and her mother had been making pork stew, and when she got there, tired and hungry, her mother had been in a good mood, and had sat her down at the table and given her a big plateful. Iona had been a good girl, so there had been no ill-tempered references to Iona's father, Tiffany's brother, Roland, who was up to no good in Ohio somewhere, or maybe Texas. The stew had lots of potatoes and carrots in it, and nice chunks of pork. In the larger war that was Tiffany's relationship with her mother, they had made a truce. The next thing that happened was that, when Tiffany got home, she saw that the Christmas cactus in her window was starting to bloom. Between them, the stew and the flowers made her feel good enough to endure the Spankee Yankee, but now, in retrospect, she saw that they had been bad, or at least false omens, because if she hadn't had that good hour she would have stayed home watching TV, and would not have lost her money and had to hang all her wet clothes around the apartment. By the time she did that, and got Iona to bed on the couch (never an easy task), she was exhausted and even more blue than she'd been when she first discovered the money missing.

It was more than the money, it was what the theft meantthat you couldn't afford to be happy, because being happy made you do things that then ended in greater unhappiness than you had been feeling before you got happy. Everyone knew that that's the way it was with love and sex and menthe happier you were when you fell in love, the more crushed you would be when it didn't work outbut what was even more depressing was that that was the way it was with simple things like pork stew and flowers. The whole depressing idea made your life pretty impossible, especially since all the time you were telling your mom that (1) things were fine and (2) everything was going to be all right. Tiffany had always told herself and her mother that she wasn't going to end up where her mother hadalways saying things like "Don't count on that," and "There's many a slip 'tween the cup and the lip" (an assertion that everyday experience showed to be patently untrue) and "If wishes were horses," a phrase of her mother's that made no sense at all.

Another thing her mom always said was "Good-looking ain't necessarily good-acting." She usually said this in reference to guys Tiffany had turned up here and there, and in reference to Iona's father and Tiffany's brother, Roland. But often Tiffany expected that she was saying it in reference to her, because everyone said, and Tiffany herself knew, that she was a knockout, a fox, a babe, you name it. She was so used to being a drop-dead gorgeous black woman no matter what she wore or how she did her makeup that she didn't even care anymore. Where had it gotten her, now that she was twenty-one with very little to show for it? Iona was drop-dead gorgeous, too, the way tiny things are especially gorgeous because you can't believe they are so small and perfect, but Tiffany never complimented her. Drop-dead gorgeous was just a thing, like sleet or snow or flowers, that happened. And you had to be drop-dead gorgeous to know what a trivial thing it was. Tiffany often wondered what she would exchange her looks for, if she could. Something more interesting to do than working as a checker at Wal-Mart would be one thing, but the fact was, she couldn't think of what that interesting thing to do would be. That was her problem, she thought. She knew perfectly well what others wanted her to do and what she didn't want to do, but when she tried to pull up from her depths something she herself wanted to do, the bucket came up empty. Once in a while she did some research. There were programs on TV that showed you what other people did. They worked in offices or police stations or bars. Lots of them worked in show business. But none of them really did anything except sit around and make jokes, which was what Tiffany herself did all day at Wal-Mart, and so all of them looked as idle as she felt herself to be. Or she bought a magazine, but all the women's magazines made it seem as though everyone was either working full-time on her appearance, which Tiffany could afford to disdain, or else making different recipes all day, which seemed nearly as boring. There was a channel on the TV called the Discovery Channel, which Tiffany sometimes monitored, but those shows didn't focus on what the people did, only on the results of what they did. She didn't ever see how they had made the move from, say, Lowell, Massachusetts, to the plains of the Serengeti. If those people were calling out to her, then they were calling across an abyss of space that she didn't see how anyone could cross. Especially now that she had no money at all, not even bus fare to get to work tomorrow. She turned off the TV and went into the living room to check on Iona. Here Iona was, already three, already having her own ideas about stuff she wanted to do that weren't the same as your ideas about stuff Iona was supposed to do. That sort of thing made you think about how fast time went. But, then, here she was, here her mother was, doing the same things year after year, having the same arguments, not getting anywhere. That sort of thing made you think just the opposite, that time went all too slowly. She covered Iona and picked up the girl's shoes, which she set on the corner of the table so she could find them easily in the morning.

After she had gotten into bed and turned out the light, she thought that all she had was the same prayer she had uttered before. She lay on her back and looked at the ceiling. She whispered, "Please make something happen here." Tiffany sighed. This was a prayer that always worked. Unfortunately, it didn't always work as she hoped. For example, she had prayed for a job, and gotten hired at Wal-Mart. She had prayed for a boyfriend, and attracted the deathless interest of Lindsay Wicks, her dampest, palest co-worker. She had prayed for a couch, and her mother had decided to buy a new one, passing the seventeen-year-old brown thing on to Tiffany, who was required to appear grateful. She continued, "This time, I mean it."

webTitle: FA seek talks to salvage 2006 bid

fields.headline: FA seek talks to salvage 2006 bid
fields.trailText: England's 2006 World Cup campaign director Alec McGivan is to seek urgent talks with the 24-man Fifa executive to see if the bid stands any chance of success when the final vote is taken in Zurich on July 6.
fields.body:
England's 2006 World Cup campaign director Alec McGivan is to seek urgent talks with the 24-man Fifa executive to see if the bid stands any chance of success when the final vote is taken in Zurich on July 6.

The violence which erupted on the streets of Belgium last weekend ahead of England's 1-0 victory over Germany in Charleroi is believed to have ended any hopes of winning the right to stage soccer's most famous tournament for the first time since 1966.

Ominous noises were sounded by Uefa in the immediate aftermath of the fighting and yesterday, former sports minister Tony Banks claimed the outlook for the bid, which has been universally acclaimed for its technical superiority, to be "bleak". New Zealand's Charles Dempsey last night reaffirmed his support for England, but, along with Scotland's David Will, he is one of just two members of the Fifa panel who can be relied upon for their votes. "Clearly the incidents of last weekend have not helped us," admitted Mr McGivan. The argument that the 2006 event should be awarded because fans can be controlled if they stay at home is not likely to sway opinion back in England's favour.

England's 2006 World Cup bid has been forced to operate without the backing of Uefa, who believe that Mr McGivan and his team have gone back on an agreement made by former chairman Bert Millichip to support the German campaign in exchange for their backing to host Euro 96.

fields.headline: Bush could halt Texas execution
fields.standfirst: Which state kills the most?
fields.trailText: Republican presidential candidate George W Bush could grant a reprieve today to a convicted murderer due to be put to death tonight, in a case which has brought the issue of capital punishment to the heart of the election campaign.
fields.body:
Republican presidential candidate George W Bush could grant a reprieve today to a convicted murderer due to be put to death tonight, in a case which has brought the issue of capital punishment to the heart of the election campaign.

Gary Graham, convicted of murdering a man 19 years ago, could be granted a pardon, a commutation or a reprieve by Mr Bush, the governor of Texas, if the state's 18-member board of paroles and pardons recommends it at a meeting today. Legal experts have queried the validity of Graham's conviction. A self-confessed robber, he denies committing the murder, a view upheld by some witnesses and legal experts.

"I'm going to uphold the law of the land... If it costs me politically, it costs me politically," Mr Bush said last night. "I'll treat this case no differently than any other case that has come across my desk. I'll ask two questions: Innocence or guilt, and whether this person has had full access to the courts of law."

The governor of Texas appoints the parole board but is barred by law from halting the execution without a majority nod from the panel. The governor does have the power to grant one 30-day reprieve in death penalty cases but cannot in this case because Graham received one in 1993 from Mr Bush's predecessor, Democrat Ann Richards.

The debate over Graham's case comes amid growing questions around the US about the death penalty. Illinois governor George Ryan has placed a moratorium on state executions and Mr Bush and Vice-President Al Gore have been forced to deal with the issue as they campaign for the presidency.

The civil rights campaigner Jesse Jackson has urged Mr Bush to delay the execution. The case has prompted the loudest protests since convicted pickaxe killer Karla Faye Tucker was executed in 1998, the first woman put to death in Texas since the civil war era.

Graham - who now goes by the name Shaka Sankofa - was 17 when Bobby Lambert, 53, was killed in 1981. Graham pleaded guilty to 10 aggravated robberies but argued that the eyewitness at his trial was mistaken when she identified him as the gunman who struggled with Mr Lambert before shooting him.

Several other witnesses, who have not been heard in court, have reportedly said that Graham was not the killer. Professor Lawrence Marshall of Northwestern University School of Law in Chicago has called for a new hearing, saying: "The Gary Graham case is significant because if he is executed... he will be the case that will be the most frail, the weakest evidence to justify any execution in the past 27 years."

Opponents of capital punishment have also used the Graham execution to focus on capital punishment in Texas, which by far outpaces other states in executions. Texas has executed 22 inmates this year and 134 during Bush's five and a half years in office.

Graham promised to "fight like hell" on the trip to the death chamber and urged 10,000 supporters to converge on Huntsville, about 80 miles north of Houston, to protest against what he called his legal lynching and assassination. If he is not granted a reprieve or pardon, he is due to die by lethal injection at 2300 GMT tonight.
