webTitle: Zimbabwe keeps foreign observers out of elections

fields.headline: Zimbabwe keeps foreign observers out of elections
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe today refused to budge from its decision to keep out more than 200 foreign observers to monitor this weekend's elections which will see President Robert Mugabe fight for his political life.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe today refused to budge from its decision to keep out more than 200 foreign observers to monitor this weekend's elections which will see President Robert Mugabe fight for his political life.

Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party remained defiant despite a barrage of international criticism. Jonathan Moyo, a Zanu-PF campaign manager, said only Zimbabweans would determine whether their elections were free and fair.

"There is no requirement that international observers must ensure anything of this sort. It's the voters that decide," he told the BBC. He added that some foreign observers had shown bias by criticising election conditions in Zimbabwe before the vote. "In the face of such kind of conduct, you would expect us to accredit organisations with such bias?"

Election organisers yesterday refused to accredit over 200 monitors from foreign non-governmental organisations to enter polling stations or interview election officials. "[They] are free to move around the country, but will not be accorded the rights and privileges provided by [the Electoral Act]," Mariyawanda Nzuwah, chairman of the National Election Directorate, said in a statement. Zimbabwe has authorised 300 monitors from the Commonwealth, European Union, Organisation for African Unity and the Southern Africa Development Community to observe.

The US yesterday joined others in criticising the Mugabe government, saying it had failed to create a climate conducive to credible elections. The US said Harare had extended a ban to staff from the American and other embassies, and this would detract from the credibility of the polls.

Philip Reeker, a state department spokesman, said in Washington: "We strongly disagree with such actions to limit observation efforts, and we really...deplore the government of Zimbabwe's failure to create a climate conducive to credible elections."

The head of the 150-strong EU electoral observer group yesterday said the election campaign was the most violent he had seen.

"We have never encountered so many problems with accreditation anywhere in the world," Pierre Schori said during a tour of Zimbabwe's second city, Bulawayo. "And we have never seen such violence. Intimidation and violence have no place in a democratic environment and must be condemned."

Violence has been rampant in the runup to Saturday and Sunday's vote with more than 13,000 rural people fleeing to the relative safety of the cities, according to the Human Rights Forum.

But true to form, Mr Mugabe, who has led Zimbabwe for the past 20 years, was contemptuous of criticism. He told an enthusiastic rally of 40,000 supporters in a Zanu-PF stronghold yesterday: "We want this election to be peaceful, (but) I am not saying that if the opposition provokes you, you must fold your arms. If they attack you, you hit them back with an axe."

Mr Mugabe predicted that his party would trounce the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), the opposition group that has emerged as the most credible threat to Zanu-PF in 20 years. The president has sought to tar the MDC by accusing it of receiving financial support from Britain, the former colonial power in Zimbabwe.

"The MDC has won abroad, especially in Britain. That is where they are conducting their election. Here, this is Zanu-PF land," Mr Mugabe said. "We rule the roost here. These British puppets are not going to win here."

But the MDC appears likely to win at least 30, and perhaps 60, of the 120 elected seats in parliament. Some optimists believe that, even if the 30 Mugabe-appointed MPs are included, the opposition may win the 76 seats required for an overall majority.

fields.headline: Warning: turbulence ahead
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The travelling public can expect more disruption from the air traffic control service this summer following last week's collapse of its computer at West Drayton, near Heathrow - and that's official.
fields.body:
The travelling public can expect more disruption from the air traffic control service this summer following last week's collapse of its computer at West Drayton, near Heathrow - and that's official.

While heavily stressing that the public's safety was not threatened and would not be threatened in future, Bill Semple, the service's chief executive, has apologised to the airlines. But he has admitted that he cannot guarantee that it will not happen again, and that flights over Scotland could continue to be subject to delay.

Britain's state operated, air traffic service, or NATS to give it its official title, is never far from public scrutiny. It rightly has a reputation for being one of the best run services in the world, controlling heavily crowded skies through which 25,000 aircraft pass each day, either to and from our airports, or passing over on their way to other parts of the world.

For the past three years. the government has been promoting the part privatisation of the service at a cost of £500m, money which it patently does not need, but a move which has landed it in hot water with back bench rebels. Against all the odds it appears to be pressing ahead, even though by doing so, it has been putting its entire transport legislation under pressure.

The failure of the NATS computer, which provides automatic write outs of the position of every aircraft over Britain, meant that the job had to be done manually, thus holding up the landing and departure of hundreds of aircraft. The failure has thrown up new facts: that the computer will have to suffice for another seven years.

This means the air traffic service will have to make do and mend when West Drayton begins to shut down in 2002, and the state of the art centre at Swanwick in Hampshire starts operating.

Bit by bit the cost of the Swanwick operation is steadily rising. Its bill has almost doubled in less than 10 years to around £700m, and the government is looking for a private buyer. With so much public disquiet about public transport safety, particularly in rail, this is probably not the best time to press ahead with a privatisation which is not popular, and which is still fraught with problems, as last week's computer breakdown proved.

In the lead up an election, ministers could be exposing themselves to unnecessary problems.

webTitle: Dave Stewart to direct again, honest

fields.headline: Dave Stewart to direct again, honest
fields.trailText: Dave Stewart is to go ahead with plans to direct a second movie, undeterred by the appalling reception received by his directorial debut, the All Saints-starring Honest
fields.body:
Dave Stewart is to go ahead with plans to direct a second movie. The former Eurythmic seems undeterred by the appalling reception received by his directorial debut, Honest (pictured).

Not only were the reviews of the All Saints-starring film dreadful, but cinemas around the country removed it from their schedules only days after its release because of lack of interest from the public.

This time around Stewart plans to hightail it to India to shoot his second masterpiece. It is apparently called Jaggernaught, tells the tale of an assassin, and will have an all-Indian cast.

His assistant Pru Miller explains Stewart's determination: "It's business as usual for Dave. If he let the UK success of Honest, and the negative coverage of the British press affect him, he'd never do anything."

Pathe pictures, Stewart's UK distributor, are right behind Dave with his new project. According to Pathe spokesperson Geraldine Maloney: "If the story's strong and the movie looks good then yes we would buy the rights for another of Dave's movies. We often work with people whose releases haven't been successful. There's so few people writing scripts in the UK you can't rule anybody out."

webTitle: 'Lucky migrants turned away from full death truck'

fields.headline: 'Lucky migrants turned away from full death truck'
fields.trailText: Kent police are today continuing to quiz three people arrested after the bodies of 58 illegal immigrants were found in a lorry at Dover as it emerged that the death toll could have been higher.
fields.body:
Kent police are today continuing to quiz three people arrested after the bodies of 58 illegal immigrants were found in a lorry at Dover as it emerged that the death toll could have been higher.

A solicitor acting for five families who believe their relatives were among those who died said that eight more people had been due to board the lorry in Holland.

They were turned away because there was not enough room in the refrigerated compartment.

Wah-Piow Tan said the family of one of the eight lucky survivors had contacted him.

He said: "One of them called his family in China when he heard of the deaths to let them know that he was all right.

"He was swearing and cursing when he wasn't allowed on the truck but he soon realised how lucky he was."

The bodies of 58 people were found in the Dutch-registered lorry when it was inspected by Customs officers at Dover just before midnight on Sunday. Two survivors were taken to hospital.

Kent Police have been given an extension by Dover magistrates to continue quizzing the Dutch lorry driver who was arrested on suspicion on manslaughter.

Two more people arrested in connection with the Dover incident are being held in custody at Canterbury police station.

Two men arrested in the Netherlands are also being quizzed by police there, including Arie van der Spek, the 24-year-old who registered the trucking company.

webTitle: June 22: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 22: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Kevin Spacey considers The Mask, Joe Nussbaum to direct first feature film, Elisabeth Perkins joins Like Cats and Dogs, Native American Navajo wooed for Windtalkers, and no Apes for Charlton
fields.body:
 Rumour has it that Kevin Spacey has been asked to consider the lead role in a sequel to the Jim Carrey hit, The Mask. Ain't it cool news reports that New Line films have "gone out" to Spacey about the role. According to the site however, this doesn't necessarily mean that he is attached to the film, or even that he is at all interested.

 Joe Nussbaum, director of the cult short George Lucas in Love is to direct his first feature film. A year after the debut of his Shakespeare In Love parody of the Star Wars creator's college years, Nussbaum has signed a deal to direct an adaptation of the children's story, How to Eat Fried Worms.

 Elisabeth Perkins, currently co-starring in 28 Days, is to join the cast of animated picture Like Cats and Dogs. The comedy, set for release in the States next summer, has already confirmed Susan Sarandon and Jeff Goldblum to provide voices for the animals, and Larry Guterman, who headed the SKG Dreamworks production Antz, is on board to direct.

 Mission: Impossible 2 director John Woo has found another lead actor for his next movie, the second world war drama Windtalkers. Roger Willie, a Native American Navajo who has never acted before, has been cast as a Navajo code talker opposite Christian Slater, who will play a Marine bodyguard.

 It has been confirmed in no uncertain terms that Charlton Heston, who starred in the original Planet of the Apes in 1968, will not even be given a cameo in the forthcoming remake of the film. According to Richard Zanuck, producer on the film: "There is no part for Heston."

webTitle: 58 die trying to enter UK illegally

fields.headline: 58 die trying to enter UK illegally
fields.trailText: Although he could not see right inside, the customs officer knew something was terribly wrong the moment he opened the heavy swing doors. The container on the white Mercedes lorry was a refrigeration unit, yet the air that belched out was warm and smelled putrid.
fields.body:
Although he could not see right inside, the customs officer knew something was terribly wrong the moment he opened the heavy swing doors. The container on the white Mercedes lorry was a refrigeration unit, yet the air that belched out was warm and smelled putrid.

In the half-light he saw two Chinese men sprawled in front of him, gasping for breath. Behind them the officer saw what a colleague described as a scene "out of a nightmare". Fifty-eight bodies lay on the metal floor in between crates of tomatoes.

Police suspect that the 54 men and four women found dead during the routine inspection at Dover last Sunday were illegal entrants from the Fujian province of China, who paid a criminal gang thousands of dollars for the chance to start a new life in Britain.

A driver called Perry Whacker, probably a false name, had picked up the load of tomatoes in Rotterdam in the Netherlands. The company name on the lorry was Van Der Spek Transportation. Its address is a nondescript flat in the suburbs of Rotterdam. Dutch police spent much of Monday questioning the company's owner, Arie Van Der Spek.

As the police started their cross-border inquiry and continued to question the lorry driver, the British Home Secretary, Jack Straw, led a chorus condemning the trafficking that had caused "a most terrible human tragedy". Those who perished "must have died a terrible death", he said during a statement to the Commons. "Let no one be in any doubt that this is a profoundly evil trade whose perpetrators have no regard for human life."

Tony Blair, who is at a European Union summit in Portugal, called it a "dreadful incident".

As detectives moved the two men who survived from hospital to a police station ready for questioning, there were urgent calls for a reassessment of the Goverment's policy towards illegal entrants.

According to recent figures, the Chinese are the second-largest group - after Sri Lankans - applying to stay in the UK. Many of them arrive without documents, and China refuses to take them back.

Last year's Immigration and Asylum Act, which introduced a $3,000 fine for drivers for each illegal entrant found in their vehicle, led to a 26% fall in the number of people being caught at the docks. However, Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said: "It is virtually impossible for people fleeing persecution to enter Britain legally, and they are therefore forced to resort to such desperate measures in their search for sanctuary."

Customs sources said that they thought the lorry had stayed near the dock all day in temperatures of up to 32C, and that its refrigeration unit was turned off.

Some reports described how the Chinese, who were locked in from the outside, were already suffering in the extreme heat at Zeebrugge, in Belgium, and had tried to raise the alarm by banging on the doors and walls, screaming for help. It would have been difficult for anyone to hear their cries; the container is like a giant, airtight fridge.

The gangs who organise Chinese illegal migration are believed to have targeted western Europe in greater numbers after a recent clampdown in Canada and the United States. The 58 who died on their way to Dover may have been assured that Britain was a safer destination.

Experts in illegal emigration from China said on Monday that it was much harder to control the land and air routes to Europe than those across the oceans to north America.

The smugglers have been known as snakeheads for many years: their clients are described as "human snakes".

The International Organisation for Migration estimates that in 1996 global immigration racketeering was already worth as much as the drugs trade, with annual profits of $7bn. There is little doubt that it has grown larger since then.

It would have been difficult for anyone to hear their cries; the container is like a giant, airtight fridge. The gangs who organise Chinese illegal migration are believed to have targeted western Europe in greater numbers after a recent clampdown in Canada and the United States. The 58 who died on their way to Dover may have been assured that Britain was a safer destination. Experts in illegal emigration from China said on Monday that it was much harder to control the land and air routes to Europe than those across the oceans to north America. The smugglers have been known as snakeheads for many years: their clients are described as "human snakes". The International Organisation for Migration estimates that in 1996 global immigration racketeering was already worth as much as the drugs trade, with annual profits of $7bn. There is little doubt that it has grown larger since then.

fields.headline: Rich pickings fuel Africa's wars
fields.trailText: In a small, dingy room above the Diamond Bourse in Antwerp, one of the biggest dealers expressed regret over the mutilations and deaths in the African civil wars in Sierra Leone and Angola. But business was business. "Human beings are greedy. I am among them. If you have $150, you want to make it $300," said the veteran dealer.
fields.byline: By Ewen MacAskill in Antwerp and David Pallister
fields.body:
In a small, dingy room above the Diamond Bourse in Antwerp, one of the biggest dealers expressed regret over the mutilations and deaths in the African civil wars in Sierra Leone and Angola. But business was business. "Human beings are greedy. I am among them. If you have $150, you want to make it $300," said the veteran dealer.

His assessment was widely shared in Antwerp. In the shadow of the archaic but magnificent central station, dealers, polishers and jewellers are crammed into five streets. Here dealers spill on to their desks diamonds worth not $150 or $300, but millions of dollars.

This is the centre of the world trade in diamonds: it is a crossroads for the gems dug up, often at terrible human cost, in Africa and for the onward journey to jewellers' shops in the United States, Japan and Europe.

The diamond merchants were dismissive of attempts this month to regulate the trade and, in particular, the proposal by the British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, to extend sanctions already imposed on diamonds from rebel-held fields in Angola to those held by the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) in Sierra Leone.

In spite of the brash expressions of confidence in their ability to run their own affairs, there is a growing sense of unease within the diamond industry.

Pressure groups such as Global Witness, which has condemned the way diamonds have fuelled conflicts in Africa, have sought to introduce an ethical dimension. The fear among dealers is that campaigners could undermine consumer demand: dealers react with horror at labels such as "blood diamonds". The diamond as a symbol of eternal love is in danger of being replaced by one identified with lost limbs and death.

Diamonds and arms present a tangled story. The journey to Antwerp begins in the mud of rebel areas in Angola and Sierra Leone, and often from there passes through a third country. The Angolan rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, used Burkina Faso as a staging post, and the country's government smoothed the way.

Karrica - the nom de guerre of Mr Savimbi's roving ambassador, Marcelo Moises Dachala - would be met at the airport, cleared through customs and provided with special armed protection for his valuable luggage. A scheduled Sabena flight from Brussels would deliver the Antwerp dealers.

Last year in meetings like this, as well as in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, Unita earned an estimated $150m to buy arms, medicines, diesel fuel, mining machinery and other commodities.

Investigators working for the United Nations sanctions committee on Angola have identified an international network of smuggling, with rebel stones being shifted through half-a-dozen western and southern African countries. Parcels of diamonds were often traded directly for weapons, with diamond dealers and arms brokers travelling to Unita areas or friendly capitals.

Overwhelmingly, the arms come from eastern Europe - either directly into Unita territory or via third countries such as Togo and Burkina Faso, whose leaders provide false end-user certificates in exchange for diamonds, according to Unita's former procurement chief, General Jacinto Bandua. Bulgaria has long been the main source, though shipments from Ukraine have been noted.

The pattern in Angola is repeated in Sierra Leone and the Democratic Republic of Congo. The air cargo companies that fly the weapons into the war zones can be both deliberate sanction-busters or mainstream operators taken in by apparently legitimate paperwork.

One of the principal sanction- busters for Unita has been a former Russian KGB officer, Victor Bout, who runs a fleet of ex-Soviet planes out of Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates. According to the Bulgarian government, his company, Air Cess, has been responsible for at least one of 19 suspect arms shipments to Togo since 1997.

Another example involved an Antonov 124 operated by Air Foyle, based in Luton near London. In March last year it carried a 67-tonne consignment of arms from Ukraine to Burkina Faso which, according to the regional peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone, were transferred via Liberia to the RUF. Air Foyle said it was unaware that the weapons were to be transferred.

The number of rough diamonds going to Antwerp from the conflict zones are a matter of dispute. The Diamond High Council insisted that it was considerably less than campaigners claimed.

The council also said that its import regulations were much tougher than those elsewhere in Europe. In spite of that, it was taking note of the complaints made by the UN and by campaigners.

Campaigners are pressing for some way of unravelling the tortuous journeys made by those trading in diamonds. Proposals include tests to determine the origin of the diamonds as well as marking them as proof that they did not come from conflict zones.

"The problem in Sierra Leone is that diamonds are all over the place," says Chief Superintendent Tamba Gbeke as he contemplates the safe in Freetown's central police station.

In little packets wrapped in tissue are a few of the objects that have made Sierra Leone's war far worse than it might have been - and without which some believe the war might never have happened.

A huge swath of diamondiferous gravel - 20,000sq km - sweeps from the east to the south of the country, and the stones can be dug, as another policeman put it, "by anyone with a bucket and spade".

Regulating trade in objects so small, so valuable and so widely dispersed was a headache even in colonial days. The few diamonds seized from smugglers that end up in the police safe are a minute fraction of the total.

Chief Supt Gbeke had arrested a man trying to smuggle diamonds that included a 45-carat stone - not the most valuable but still worth a tidy sum - but he knows that most seizures, like this one, follow denunciations by rivals. In any case the bulk of the illegal trade goes through Liberia, where President Charles Taylor takes a huge cut, with some passing through Guinea and the rest through Freetown.

Despite the multi-million dollar trade, however, even the dealers admit that diamonds themselves have no inherent value, other than limited industrial use as drill bits. One said: "The value of the diamond is what any fool will pay for it."

webTitle: Teachers back industrial action - but rule out strikes

fields.headline: Teachers back industrial action - but rule out strikes
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Education Unlimited
fields.body:
Teachers have voted overwhelmingly in favour of industrial action in protest at what they see as the mounting burden of red tape imposed on schools.

The National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said 94% of its 120,000 members in England and Wales have backed a "blitz on bureaucracy".

The union is acting with the National Union of Teachers. Both unions stress industrial action will not involve strikes.

The industrial action will begin on June 30 and should be well-established by the time the autumn term begins.

The NUT held a ballot two years ago in which 93% voted in favour of action to cut the amount of time spent on tasks not directly related to teaching and the result is still in force.

Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, said: "The Government should note the common purpose of the two unions - by focusing on teaching and learning, members of the NUT and NASUWT will be devoting their energies to improving education. Pupils can only benefit."

Both unions feel the Government has not acted on its own recommendations for cutting teachers' workload. The joint guidelines include:

Producing one school report a year for each pupil and ensuring they are no longer than 400 words.

Limiting after-school meetings to one 60-minute session a week.

Banning clerical and administrative tasks such as photocopying, filing, writing standard letters and chasing absent pupils.

Schools Standards Minister Estelle Morris said a blanket ban on teachers performing administrative tasks would not work.

"The risk of a blanket ban on administration is that it will make it more difficult for teachers to do their job in the classroom and because of that they will do some administration."

She said she agreed, however, that teachers' paperwork needed to be cut down.

fields.headline: Ben Nevis
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Britain's tallest and now unprivatised mountain on the net
fields.trailText: All you need to know about Britain's tallest mountain and biggest real estate bargain on the net.
fields.body:
1. At 4,406ft, Ben Nevis must be Britain's biggest real estate bargain. It has been sold to the John Muir Trust for £450,000. That is just over 100 quid per foot.

2. The owner, Duncan Fairfax-Lucy, sold at less than the going rate for mountains, because he wanted to secure the future of the region. The trust is now appealing for funds to pay for the management and protection of Ben Nevis.

3. The trust is named after a Victorian pioneer of wilderness conservation who emigrated to the USA from Scotland as a boy. It has a clutch of remote and wildly beautiful properties in the Highlands and Scottish islands.

4. Unlike the lairds and absentee landlords who still own much of the land, the trust aims to restore and conserve the wilderness, while making it accessible to the public.

5. It is also playing a leading role in reforestation of Scottish landscapes blighted by generations of tree-felling and overgrazing by sheep and deer. One of the most exciting projects, run by the Borders Forest Trust, is to recreate an ancient forest in the breathtaking Carrifran Valley, in the southern Uplands.

6. Many other associations, trusts and voluntary bodies are working to conserve the ancient glories of the Scottish landscape. Among them are the National Trust for Scotland and Scottish Natural Heritage.

7. A quarter of a millennium on, hopes are even stirring that the Highland clearances, an early exercise in ethnic cleansing which saw the clans of Scotland's Highlands disbanded after the Jacobite rebellion of 1745-46, may at last be reversed, with the restoration of the land to those who live there.

8. Recent years have seen a new community spirit of resistance to the absentee landlords and would-be exploiters of the land. The Isle of Eigg has been bought by the people who live on it, and the even tinier community of Knoydart has taken back control of much of the peninsula.

9. The Knoydart Foundation has ambitious plans for sustainable development, and hopes to build a modest number of homes for newcomers.

10. After years of malign neglect, the Scottish wilderness regions are likely to depend for many years on the decidedly mixed blessing of tourism.

webTitle: Jurassic Park 3 on its way, but without Spielberg

fields.headline: Jurassic Park 3 on its way, but without Spielberg
fields.trailText: A third film in the Jurassic Park series is being made, and is due to arrive in cinemas in summer 2001
fields.body:
A third film in the Jurassic Park series is being made, and is due to arrive in cinemas in summer 2001.

The original Steven Spielberg adventure took more than £300m following its release in 1993 and its sequel, The Lost World, scooped another £400m in 1997.

Now the master film-maker is taking a step back into the shadows in order to allow another director to take charge of the third movie - and the last - in the series.

To date, only Sam Neill is on board to re-visit the infamous park where DNA-created beasts roamed out of control.

Jeff Goldblum, who played his offbeat sidekick, is believed to be interested in joining him but there are no signs of Laura Dern who played Goldblum's romantic interest or Julianne Moore from The Lost World.

Director Joe Johnston who made Jumanji with Robin Williams is putting JP3 together for Universal Studios with a reported budget of £60m.

Richard Attenborough, who played the scientist responsible for creating the dinosaur 'playground' in Jurassic Park is also being approached to appear in a cameo role.

A production insider said: "Steven Spielberg would never have made the sequel unless he felt there was a very good reason.

"There is certainly room for a third movie. The public have shown through their fascination with BBC shows like Walking With Dinosaurs that there is a lasting curiosity."

Added to that, the huge success of Disney's animated Dinosaur, released in the US earlier this month, also illustrates to the public's insatiable demand for prehistoric pics.

webTitle: Schools fail English test, says Ofsted

fields.headline: Schools fail English test, says Ofsted
fields.standfirst: The Teaching of Writing in Primary Schools - Could Do Better. (You need Adobe Acrobat to read this file).
fields.trailText: The government will fail to meet tough national targets for achievement in English unless standards in children's writing dramatically improve over the next year, the schools watchdog, Ofsted, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The government will fail to meet tough national targets for achievement in English unless standards in children's writing dramatically improve over the next year, the schools watchdog, Ofsted, warned yesterday.

The Office for Standards in Education blamed teachers in primary schools for concentrating on reading rather than writing in the daily literacy hour. In a discussion paper published yesterday on its website, Ofsted said the teaching of writing was "unsatisfactory" in a quarter of all such lessons, with guided writing supervised by teachers taking place in only half the literacy hours seen by inspectors.

Teachers were also criticised for an "over-reliance" on duplicated worksheets and for failing to supervise their pupils as they were starting to compose a sentence.

The warning is expected to be taken seriously by the department for education and employment because the government has staked its reputation on meeting two key educational targets for 11-year-olds. The education secretary, David Blunkett, has said he will resign if 80% of final year primary school pupils fail to reach the expected standard in literacy for their age by 2002, and 75% fail to achieve the same standard in numeracy. The annual national tests were devised and introduced under the Tories but are now central to Labour's drive to raise standards in schools.

In the discussion paper the watchdog said it had many "concerns" about poor lessons. Drawing on last year's Key Stage Two English test results, it said that only 54% of pupils reached level 4 or above in writing - the standard expected for their age - compared with 78% in reading.

The results also reinforce the gender gap, with only 47% of boys achieving level 4 in writing in 1999, compared with 62% of girls.

The study's conclusions of "unsatisfactory" teaching in a quarter of all lessons was borne out by an inspection of 300 literacy hours, where there was no shared writing.

Guided writing - involving pupils working under supervision - took place in half the literacy hours seen, whereas shared or guided reading were found in almost all lessons.

Teachers were also criticised for relying on worksheets, and "the belief that providing pupils with a stimulating idea is enough to encourage good writing, without the necessary teaching before and after the writing process."

fields.headline: The rights stuff
fields.standfirst:
What can you do if you've bought a dud - are you entitled to your money back? Anna Tims provides a guide to the minefield of consumer law

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: What can you do if you've bought a dud - are you entitled to your money back? Anna Tims provides a guide to the minefield of consumer law
fields.body:
There's something faintly disturbing about cereal packets, something you may not have noticed. It's that reassurance at the bottom of the blurb promoting special offers: "Your statutory rights are not affected." Rights? What rights? Ignorance can be costly. In this consumer age, which has just invented a pill to treat shopaholics, most of us are likely to make a dud purchase at some point, whether from a shop, by mail order or by a salesperson on the doorstep. Without knowing our legal rights, we may not even realise we've been had.

Statutory rights

These are the laws that help customers to complain about substandard goods. They stipulate, for instance, that a purchase must be of satisfactory quality, taking into account price and how they were described in the shop. If goods are scratched, warped or break down after a short period, you are entitled to a refund, provided the salesman didn't point out the fault before you paid. Even if the condition is fine, you can still demand a refund if the item is not fit for its purpose. Say, for instance, you had requested a printer cartridge to fit a specified printer and the shopkeeper sold you the wrong size, he would be obliged to take it back. However, you would have no such prerog ative if a dress you chose is the wrong size or simply decided you don't like it. Stores which refund in such cases are motivated by goodwill, not legal necessity. Third, goods must be as described correctly, so if the display sign or the salesperson tells you a jumper is 100% wool, you can make a fuss if it contains polyester.

Getting redress

Speed is of the essence. It's no good sitting on a new toaster for a year then taking it out of its box and discovering that it doesn't work. The law gives you "reasonable time" to examine a purchase and to complain if you find a problem. It doesn't define how much time is reasonable - just make sure that you try purchases out as soon as possible and make the complaint immediately. You don't need a receipt, although it makes things easier to have one. Don't let the shop- keeper fob you off with a replacement, repair or credit note if you don't want one. You are entitled to your money back and shops which claim a policy of no-refunds are committing a criminal offence. Nor should you listen if the vendor blames the manufacturer; under law it's the vendor's responsibility. If, however, you let a certain amount of time slip by, you lose your right to a refund and will probably have to agree to a repair or replacement.

Where possible, pay by credit card, especially for mail order: under the Consumer Credit Act the credit card company is jointly liable if things go wrong and may be obliged to refund the money if the goods or service cost more than £100. This also applies to hire purchase.

Guarantees

Many manufacturers offer these and they are useful after "reasonable time" has elapsed and statutory rights no longer apply. Beware extended guarantees or warranties, however. These promises of "peace of mind" are dangled when you buy electrical goods. However, the word "warranty" is not recognised in law; each contract depends on the conditions drawn up by the seller and while ostensibly for the benefit of the customer, the clauses often favour the dealer who may earn big commissions on policies. Check exclu sions and claim limits before signing and if these are not on the explanatory leaflet, ask to see a list. A car warranty, for example, might specify that mechanical parts are covered but not electrical ones, but it could be that a mechanical part fails because of an electrical problem. Even if the insurer pays up, your policy premiums are likely to have cost up to four times the amount you would have paid for a one-off repair.

Mail order

Your statutory rights apply here as they would in a shop, plus you have the right to cancel your order if it fails to show after 28 days or within the timescale specified. Most newspapers and magazines have mail order protection schemes which refund money paid for goods advertised on their pages if the supplier goes out of business. If a firm sends goods that you didn't order you don't have to accept or pay for them. They become yours after 30 days if you write to the company rejecting them and the company fails to collect them. If you don't write you can claim them after six months. Any company which hassles you for money is likely to be breaking the law and should be reported to your local Trading Standards authority.

Doorstep selling

If you sign up to a deal costing more than £35 you are entitled to a seven- day cooling-off period in which to change your mind, provided that the seller called uninvited and the contract was signed in your home (it's extended to 14 days if the salesman is a member of the Direct Selling Association). It's too bad, though, if you invited the dealer to call, and that includes responding to an advertise ment. In that case you have no automatic right to cancel. If, on the other hand, you agree to a visit after being cold-called, you are entitled to those seven days. There's an additional escape route if you pay more than £50 on credit - you may back down within five days provided you discussed the deal face-to-face with the seller and weren't on his business premises at the time.

In this consumer age, which has just invented a pill to treat shopaholics, most of us are likely to make a dud purchase at some point, whether from a shop, by mail order or by a salesperson on the doorstep. If goods are scratched, warped or break down after a short period, you are entitled to a refund, provided the salesman didn't point out the fault before you paid. Even if the condition is fine, you can still demand a refund if the item is not fit for its purpose. Say, for instance, you had requested a printer cartridge to fit a specified printer and the shopkeeper sold you the wrong size, he would be obliged to take it back. However, you would have no such prerog ative if a dress you chose is the wrong size or simply decided you don't like it. Third, goods must be as described correctly, so if the display sign or the salesperson tells you a jumper is 100% wool, you can make a fuss if it contains polyester. fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Cowboy country

It's small wonder that DIY is up there with sex and football among the nation's favourite pastimes. It can be easier to master the management of a hand drill than to find a builder whom you know you can trust. The safest option, if the hand drill cannot be tamed, is to ask friends and neighbours for a company that they can recommend or, if that doesn't work, to choose someone who is registered with a trade association. John Davenport and Anne Rogerson of London made sure that the builder whom they hired was a member of the Guild of Master Craftsmen (GOMC), but claim that the work was substandard and the man threatening. They complained to the GOMC, which offers a conciliation service, and conclude that the guild was "obstructive and unwilling to take the case seriously", a charge the guild naturally refutes.

The interesting thing about this is a letter from the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, sent in response to a query from the couples' MP. "We have considerable doubts," says Raynsford, "whether membership of the Guild of Master Craftsmen can be taken in any way as a badge of quality or reliability on the part of the firm concerned. There are a large number of different trade associations with differing standards and procedures for monitoring the performance of their members. This makes it very difficult for members of the public without experience of the sector to form a sound judgment on which builders are likely to prove satisfactory."

Glum stuff indeed as far as already nervous householders are concerned, but, says Raynsford, salvation is at hand. The government is currently trying out a new scheme to hand-hold consumers through this perilous territory. Top-notch builders will bear a quality mark representing a uniform set of standards, a code of practice, an effective complaints procedure and an insurance warranty so that customers can be sure that they know what they're getting.

The GOMC meanwhile feels wounded. "We are a badge of quality and reliability and all our members are vetted before they come on board," says general manager, Fiona Gram. "In fact, the government has invited us to take part in its better regulation taskforce which is working on the quality mark because they see us as self-policing the building industry."

In the meantime, DIY buffs who are unsure of their ground with builders should abide by the golden rules: get detailed quotations from three or four contractors; insist on a written agreement including the work to be done, the price and the length of the job; if you want the work completed by a certain date make sure it's written into the contract and that you agree compensation should it take longer, and never pay for work until it's been completed to your satisfaction.

Different standards

The Scottish parliament is noisily proud of its equality policies, a form of enlightenment which will hopefully leak into other national institutions. It has not so far reached the Edinburgh-based assurance company Standard Life, which has just held a vote on demutualisation. Jenny Rimmer and Helen Walker have both written in to point out that they have joint policies with their husbands, but the voting papers were addressed to the latter only. Standard Life's response was that as joint policy holders only have one vote between them, the correspondence is sent to the first name on the policy. This, of course, is traditionally the man's. "The way it stands the vast majority of voters will inevitably be male and female customers will be disenfranchised," says Walker.

The spokeswoman from Standard Life sounds a little perplexed herself as she repeats the official line. But, she says consolingly, if wives want to vote instead of their husbands they can write to ask for a nomination form. Would it not be easier for the documents to be sent out in both names and to allow the policy holders to nominate the voter? "I asked that," she says, "And they told me that it would require a 75% vote from our members to change the system." Ah well, equality may be lacking, but you can't fault the democracy.

Nasty package

One of the more mysterious aspects of modern consumerism is how package tour operators price their holidays. We've already touched on the sore point of single person supplements levied by hotels; now RF Bardner of Bath has found that the hotel where he recently holidayed made no charge for young children who share a room with their parents, yet Inghams Holidays had billed him £525 for his infant granddaughter (including the flight). Ingham's response was that "our own contractual rates do not necessarily bear any relevance to the hotel's public charges".

Inghams warns Consumer that "it is very dangerous, and indeed almost impossible to compare tour operators' rates with prices charged by hotels for 'direct' bookings". "There's no such thing as a free lunch," says a spokeswoman. "Some hotels may say that they offer 'free' accommodation for children, but their adult rates are always significantly higher than our rates allow to make up for it." Instead, Inghams says it secures reduced rates for all its package customers and the Bardner family thus saved £200 per adult head during their week-long stay.

Ironing out problems

P Brimson of Northampton ordered a £34.74 ironing stool from Health & Beauty Direct, a Hull-based mail order company, last December. The cheque was promptly cashed, but in March she was told that the item had been discontinued and that a refund would be sent. It never came and her letters were never answered. "The stool would have been most useful - but so would the £34.74," she says.

Alas, Health & Beauty Direct has ceased trading, according to Hull Trading Standards. Even more unfortunately, it is not to be found at the forwarding address which the authority had requested. Brimson and others must count their losses and take note: a different company based in Thornton Heath has apparently bought the company's name and database, so you may receive overtures from a familiar, but unrelated source.

Don't call us . . .

The debate about how to muzzle persistent telesales people runs ever onwards. Robin Benson and Enile Snirkette have both hit upon the same strategy - to inform "Wayne from Wacky Windows" that the property is rented. "The caller usually rings off before I have time to say goodbye," says Snirkette. Cold-callers are invariably coy when asked for their own details, and several of you suggest beleagured householders demand their home number so that they too can be disturbed at dinner.

Edward Cabrera has a more gracious tactic. "I told a persistent BT salesperson that I was sorry I couldn't talk to him just then, but if he could give me his name and number I'd call him back when I was free. There was a stunned silence followed by 'I can't give you my number...' from the other end." Don Brownlow of Berwick-upon-Tweed declares himself an undischarged bankrupt and invites them to call back when he has a bank account again.

Tony Powell preferred to invest in a caller line indentification device (CLI). "All these pests withhold their phone numbers (think what fun you could have if they didn't) so every time the phone rings and the CLI shows 'withheld' you let the answer machine take the call," he says. "These people never leave a message."

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer talk boiled in a bag and served with a knob of butter
fields.trailText: Gareth Southgate is a target for Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna, claims Planet Football. Not so, reckons the Daily Mail. They say Chelsea are confident of tying up a £5m deal for the Aston Villa defender in the next few days.
fields.body:
Gareth Southgate is a target for Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna, claims Planet Football. Not so, reckons the Daily Mail. They say Chelsea are confident of tying up a £5m deal for the Aston Villa defender in the next few days.

Leicester manager Peter Taylor has admitted an interest in Carl Cort - but says he won't meet Wimbledon's £7m valuation. "I rate Carl and I'd love to work with him again as we worked well together with England," said Taylor. "But they are talking quite high figures." The Daily Mail believes Leicester won't budge on their £5m offer.

But Leicester are confident they will sign Birmingham's Gary Rowett. Taylor rates the 26-year-old right-back highly and has made a £3m bid. Trevor Francis will put the offer to the player when he returns from holiday.

Sunderland manager Peter Reid has confirmed his interest in Czech Republic midfielder Radek Bejbl, reports Planet Football. "We've got an interest in Radek but deals are always complex nowadays," Reid admitted. "He's a player I rate highly but I can't say too much more at the moment."

Roma are ready to pay Leeds £6m for skipper Lucas Radebe, claims Teamtalk.

Derby have offered Sheffield Wednesday £3m for Gilles De Bilde.

fields.headline: Ken Loach: Kes
fields.trailText: In his best movies, Loach is able to turn the particular into the universal and to appeal to audiences the world over. Kes was such a film
fields.body:
Ken Loach, the most modest of directors, would probably say he had a lot to be modest about - that his team deserves as much praise as he does. And it is certainly true that you don't look for visually imaginative work from Loach - though a writer in Sight and Sound who suggested not long ago that Loach couldn't even frame a shot properly was talking through the wrong hole. In fact, Loach has always said that if you notice the camerawork, there's something wrong with the story.

What he struggles to find is the truth of any given situation through good casting, scripts that often seem improvised but are not, and the courage of his strong and unwavering left-leaning convictions. In his best movies, Loach is able to turn the particular into the universal and to appeal to audiences the world over. Kes was such a film, as were Riff-Raff and Raining Stones.

Kes is undoubtedly one of the most remarkable films about education, or the lack of it, ever made. Its main theme is perhaps naive - that if you give a so-called dunce some kind of chance, the result can surprise him and certainly his teachers. The film's incidentals are as good as its main thrust, which is never sentimentalised and maintains the right to be angry as well as touching and funny.

Kes is the kestrel found and trained by a young Barnsley boy from a broken home. The boy, marvellously played by David Bradley, virtually refuses education at the local school, which, though inadequate, is never shown as wholly awful. Encouraged by a sympathetic teacher, he finds some sort of hope in his new interest, even though social deprivation is always likely to stamp it out.

What adds immeasurably to the film's power are the incidental scenes of school life. There are two I'll never forget. One has a tiny boy lining up outside the head's study, probably for a beating, and crying his excuses. The tenderness displayed here mixes with hilarity in a way very few directors could even begin to achieve. The other has the ex-wrestler Brian Glover as sports master taking his boys out on to the field and, to the strains of the BBC's old Sports Night signature tune, acting out a football fantasy that has him behaving more like a child than his charges.

It's this sort of thing that proclaims Loach a nearly great and certainly cherishable director, since it does so much more than merely leaven his political points with humour. Who, for instance, can forget Ricky Tomlinson as a building worker in Riff-Raff, climbing naked from a bath in a new building to face a posse of surprised clients brought in by one of the besuited developers?

This is not to downgrade the serious - some say over-earnest - side of Loach's work, which invariably deals with the injustice of uncaring capitalism and invokes a properly socialist alternative. It's just to emphasise what a very good film-maker he is when encouraged by good writers such as Barry Hines (Kes) or Bill Jesse (Riff-Raff).

He is a director admired, and often loved, all over the world. I remember once presiding over the International Critics' Jury at Cannes and, as the British representative, gingerly suggesting that one of Loach's films should at least be on the shortlist. "What?" said several members of the jury in unison. "On the shortlist? He's got to win!" One of them, a Latin American, added, "Who else can make you laugh and then cry in the space of two minutes?"

webTitle: Hague to champion NHS and schools in centre bid

fields.headline: Hague to champion NHS and schools in centre bid
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader launches attempt to woo voters alienated by stance on asylum and crime

Special report: the Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague is to attempt to steal Tony Blair's thunder as the saviour of Britain's public services by launching a high profile campaign to persuade voters that health and education will be safe in Tory hands.
fields.body:
William Hague is to attempt to steal Tony Blair's thunder as the saviour of Britain's public services by launching a high profile campaign to persuade voters that health and education will be safe in Tory hands.

Taking a leaf out of the book of Republicans in America, who have "reclaimed" areas such as education from the Democrats, the Tory leader will outline a series of policies in the coming weeks to distance his party from its Thatcherite past.

Mr Hague's initiative on health and education is designed to appeal to voters on the centre ground who have been appalled by his recent interventions on asylum seekers and the case of the jailed Norfolk farmer Tony Martin.

One senior Tory source said: "We will be making it clear that we will fight the next election on broad issues and not just on pledges to lock up the criminal next door."

Deserted

Mr Hague will reassure voters who deserted the Tories at the last election that he would stick to Labour's spending plans on health and education. But central office sources insist: "This is not just about money."

The Tory leader will attempt to reach out to parents in middle Britain by developing his "free schools concept" in which funds will be channelled directly to schools, bypassing local education authorities. David Blunkett, the education secretary, is implementing similar plans, but Mr Hague believes there is scope to save up to £2bn.

Under the Tory plans, schools will be allocated their entire budget directly. It would then be left up to head teachers and the governors to decide whether to buy services in from LEAs. One Tory source said that the experience of a school in Mr Hague's Richmond constituency had taught him the importance of giving schools greater autonomy. The source said: "The school is losing a teacher just at the time that the LEA is spending £98,000 giving it new windows which it does not need. It is far more effective to let the schools use the money."

Disciplined

Mr Hague hopes that the creation of free schools would lead to more religious schools and other schools set up and run by parents. One source said: "William has been struck by the success of Jewish schools in Manchester which are well disciplined and produce exceptional results."

The Tories have underlined their new approach to the heath service through their silence in recent weeks on private health care. "We've been a bit quiet on that one," one source said, in an admission that relentless championing of the private sector turns off voters.

Mr Hague, who is treated on the NHS, will attempt to demonstrate his commitment to the health service by spelling out in greater detail his "patients' guarantee". One idea, which he floated in the Commons yesterday, is to establish an "exceptional medicines fund" to bring an end to "postcode rationing".

Doctors would apply to the fund, which would be administered centrally, for highly expensive medicines, such as beta interferon and anti-cancer drugs, which are being withheld by some health authorities on cost grounds. One Tory source said: "Some people are having to blow their life savings on anti-cancer treatments which are being denied to them. That is pernicious and it is the responsibilty of the health service to treat these people."

Ministers will seize on the Hague initiative on health and education as evidence of a panic u-turn after his failure to overtake Labour's lead, despite the mild improvement recently in Conservative poll ratings. Tory sources insist there is no u-turn because they say Mr Hague wants to combine his tough stance on issues such as crime with a "caring" approach to key public services.

One senior Tory source said that Mr Hague, who is deeply influenced by the experience of Republicans in Bill Clinton's America, was hoping to combine the approach of "compassionate conservatives", such as the Florida governor Jeb Bush with rightwingers such as the former congressional leader Newt Gingrich.

"Republicans have gone into the Democrats' third way territory and claimed it back, notably in education," one senior Tory said. "The real prize would be to combine the doctrines of Gingrich and Bush."

Mr Hague believes he can appeal to natural Thatcherite voters with his hardline message on crime. "Some of the people who agree most strongly with us on crime and asylum and so on are people who voted Labour in the past," one source said.

Asylum

Labour would privately accept some of this analysis because the party's own polling shows that the government has lost ground to the Tories in recent months over asylum.

But Mr Hague accepts that political point scoring on issues such as asylum is not enough to win elections. "People want a rounded agenda," one source said. "Elections are not about battles between left and right - they're about getting things done."

Central office believes that Mr Hague is in a strong position to launch a new phase of his leadership because he has overcome four crucial barriers. They are:

 Settling internal divisions over Europe, through the party ballot which overwhelmingly endorsed Mr Hague's hardline position on the single currency.

 Ending the factional in-fighting of the Major years to restore a team spirit among frontbenchers. "Only three members of the shadow cabinet were in John Major's last cabinet," a Hagueite said pointedly.

 Winning elections, most notably in last year's European elections and in this year's local elections.

 Identifying and exploiting chinks in the government. "Oppositions cannot prosper unless governments do badly - we date their difficulties from New Year's Eve," one source said.

Unease

Despite the new spring in Mr Hague's step, his aides insist there is no room for complacency. In a sign of the continuing unease at central office, the party commissioned a private poll to establish why it lost the Romsey byelection in what should have been its heartland. The poll found that 77% of Tory voters who abandoned the party were attracted to the Lib Dems' local candidate.

"We still have a very realistic understanding of what people think of the Tory party," one source said. "Just because there has been an improvement in public esteem does not mean we are top of the pops. We are not opening the champagne yet."

webTitle: Gabriel Byrne set for Star Wars role

fields.headline: Gabriel Byrne set for Star Wars role
fields.trailText: Rumours about the casting of the new Star Wars film are coming thick and fast, and it now seems likely that Gabriel Byrne could be the latest big name to sign up for the Phantom Menace follow-up
fields.body:
Rumours about the casting of the new Star Wars film are coming thick and fast. Following the news that British horror legend Christopher Lee may play a "spooky" role (see our story), it is now rumoured that Irish actor Gabriel Byrne could be the latest big name to sign up for the Phantom Menace follow-up.

Byrne says the producers for Episode 2 - which has not yet been given a title - are keen for him to join the cast, which already includes Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman and Samuel L Jackson.

In an interview with ShowBiz Ireland, the star of the Usual Suspects and End of Days says: "The people from Star Wars called the other day to offer me something but I don't know what it is yet."

He reveals that one of the reasons why he might accept is to court popularity with his children: "My children are too young to see most of my films so they'd probably prefer for me to do a Star Wars picture."

 According to the newly revamped official Star Wars website, filming for Episode 2 will begin on June 26.

Director George Lucas has arrived in Australia where work on the special effects photography has already started and principal photography on location will begin in a few days time. The film will stay in Australia for two months, before relocating to Italy, Tunisia and Spain for an extra month's work.

webTitle: Row as Holocaust defender wins prize

fields.headline: Row as Holocaust defender wins prize
fields.trailText: Germany faces another public row about its Nazi past after several prominent academics questioned the award of a prestigious literary prize to a historian who attempts to justify the Holocaust.
fields.body:
Germany faces another public row about its Nazi past after several prominent academics questioned the award of a prestigious literary prize to a historian who attempts to justify the Holocaust.

Eight academics from the Institute of Contemporary History in Munich, which is dedicated to researching German's Nazi past, bitterly criticised a decision by the conservative Konrad Adenauer Foundation to present its annual prize to the rightwing historian Ernst Nolte.

Mr Nolte, 77, claims that Hitler had "rational" reasons for attacking the Jews, and denounces the "collective accusation" levelled at Germany since 1945. He has never denied that the Holocaust took place.

Awarded the foundation's prize for "contributing to a better future" earlier this month, Mr Nolte said: "We should leave behind the view that the opposite of National Socialist views is always right."

In an open letter to the Hamburg weekly die Zeit yesterday, the Munich academics rounded on the foundation and their institute's director, Horst Müller, who had delivered a speech praising Mr Nolte's work.

"We are extremely concerned by the loss of respect that our house has suffered as a result of Horst Müller's directorship," the academics wrote.

"His praise of the controversial historian Ernst Nolte is not compatible with the tradition of our institute."

Their criticism followed a similar public attack by the Berlin historian Heinrich Winkler, who accused Mr Nolte of "making no excuse for his proximity to rightwing extremism".

The Konrad Adenauer Foundation's decision to award Mr Nolte the prize embarrassed many in the conservative Christian Democratic Union, which has traditionally supported the right-wing think tank.

The CDU's new leader, Angela Merkel, refused to attend the prize-giving ceremony on June 4, saying she had "personal difficulties" about Mr Nolte.

webTitle: Cronje as captain and a trip to the Caribbean

fields.headline: Cronje as captain and a trip to the Caribbean
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: What was Hansie Cronje's record as captain in one-day internationals? asks Vineet Sarat
fields.body:
What was Hansie Cronje's record as captain in one-day internationals? asks Vineet Sarat

In a word, excellent - despite what we now know. Cronje captained South Africa in 138 one-dayers between 1993-94 and 1999-2000. He won 99 of them (71.7%), lost 35, and tied one (that unforgettable World Cup semi-final last year), with three no-results. He made 4070 runs as captain at an average of 37.68 with no hundreds but 31 half-centuries, including 79 in what looks likely to have been his last international innings, against Pakistan in Sharjah in April.

I'm thinking of celebrating my 40th birthday in style next January by going to the West Indies. Do you know who will be touring the Caribbean early next year? asks Dick Wearmouth

South Africa will be touring the West Indies early next year for what should be an exciting five-Test series - South Africa won all five Tests of their home series in 1998-99, so West Indies will be looking for revenge in the first series between the sides in the Caribbean (where they have met only in the one-off Test of 1991-92). There will also be several one-day internationals. January may be a little early though - the exact dates have not been announced, but the tour is expected to last from February to April.

In the recent three-day match between Glamorgan and the West Indian tourists, there were an inordinate amount of lbws. Has there been an international where all ten wickets have been given out leg-before? asks Paul Canham

There were 17 lbws in all in that match at Cardiff, and that's the Test record too. It was set in the match between West Indies and Pakistan at Port-of-Spain in 1992-93. The overworked umpires were Steve Bucknor, who raised the fatal finger 12 times, and Dickie Bird (five). The record for a Test innings is six lbws, which has happened 11 times. In one-day internationals the record is five lbws in an innings (five instances) and eight in a match (two).

To settle a bet, what was the nickname of Allan Border? asks Gavin Chesher

In the later stages of his career Border was known simply as "AB". Earlier he was known for a while as "Captain Grumpy" - but that name became less and less appropriate as Australia started winning regularly. And before he became captain he was briefly known as "Pugsley", because of a supposed resemblance to one of the characters in the Addams Family!

Where was Fred Trueman born? asks Ken Main

Frederick Sewards Trueman was born in Scotch Springs, Stainton, near Maltby in Yorkshire, on February 6, 1931. He made his debut for Yorkshire in 1949, and played his first Test in 1952. In 1964 he became the first bowler to take 300 wickets in Tests, and he finished up with 307. For The Observer's interview with him about his new-ball partner Brian Statham, who died this month, click here.

Sixteen years ago I used to play for Hoddesdon Cricket Club in Hertfordshire, and would like to catch up with them again. Do you know how I could contact the club? asks M Hick

Hoddesdon CC do seem to be still going strong. According to the Club Cricket Conference, their secretary is Mr DG Sutherland, 8 Burnside, Hoddesdon, Herts EN11 8PG.

Have England confirmed where they will be touring this winter (2000-01)? asks Pete Whittaker

England will start with their first tour of Pakistan since 1987-88, and will be making a nervous return to the Iqbal Stadium in Faisalabad, scene of the incident between Mike Gatting and umpire Shakoor Rana which disfigured that tour. There will be three one-day internationals - at Karachi (Oct 24), Lahore (Oct 27) and Rawalpindi (Oct 29) - followed by three Tests, at Lahore (Nov 15-19), Faisalabad (Nov 29-Dec 3), and Karachi (Dec 7-11). After a break for Christmas, England undertake a similar programme in Sri Lanka. The Tests will be at Galle (Feb 22-26), Kandy (March 7-11) and Colombo (March 15-19), and the ODIs will all be in Colombo (March 23, 25 and 27).

Who was the England player who broke his kneecap on tour in the early 1990s? asks Peter Drake

The unfortunate man was David "Syd" Lawrence, the big-hearted Gloucestershire fast bowler. He had just started his third over in the closing stages of the drawn third Test against New Zealand at Wellington in February 1992 when he fell to the ground in agony. Other players spoke of hearing a noise like a gunshot as his kneecap broke in half. Lawrence, who was 28 at the time, never played for England again (this was his fifth cap), although he did make a brave but short-lived comeback for Gloucestershire.

I've got stuck on a crossword question: The New Ball (Cricket) - six letters (starts with C, fifth letter R). Can you help? asks Tony French

I think the word you're looking for is "cherry" - that's what some of our more poetic commentators and even players call the ball when it's a bright shiny red.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous column and find out when Player Trueman took on Gentleman Dexter,click here

webTitle: Smicer's slick double leaves Danes pointless

fields.headline: Smicer's slick double leaves Danes pointless
fields.trailText: As dead rubbers go, this was one where rigor mortis had set in, both sides having already packed their bags following defeats in their opening two games.
fields.body:
Vladimir Smicer ensured that the Czech Republic did not go home empty-handed when he struck twice in the second half to earn them a consolation victory here last night.

This was not so much a dead rubber as one showing signs of rigor mortis, both sides having already packed their bags after defeats in their opening two games. But the Danish fans, at least, refused to leave without a proper farewell party, swaying like drunks on the terraces and keeping up such a terrible din that you would have thought their team were about to be crowned European champions.

They even had the good manners to say thank you to the departing manager Bo Johansson, hanging a banner over the side of the stands which read: "Tak for Alt, Bosse."

There was, in any case, a bit more to this game than met the Euro 2000 eye since these teams are drawn in the same World Cup qualifying group. Unfortunately the players did not catch the mood, going through the motions so sluggishly in the first half that a forensic expert would have struggled to detect a globule of sweat on some shirts.

It livened up in the second half, particularly when Karel Poborsky and Jesper Gronkjaer got involved in a little sparring match which was broken up by Peter Schmeichel.

Poborsky then provided a delightful exhibition of what he can do when roused, sliding almost to his knees to control a diagonal ball from Jan Koller before standing up, steadying himself and picking out Smicer on the far post for the easiest of goals.

That was in the 64th minute, and three minutes later Smicer ran on to Koller's flicked header to score again, leaving Schmeichel with one of those quizzical expressions so familiar to Manchester United fans. It left Denmark as the only team at Euro 2000 not to gain a point and wondering how they can claim a first ever victory over the Czechs in World Cup qualifying.

fields.headline: Too busy teaching to learn?
fields.standfirst: Business English may be lucrative, but it must also match the professional status of the rest of ESP, argues Duncan Baker
fields.trailText: Business English may be lucrative, but it must also match the professional status of the rest of ESP, argues Duncan Baker
fields.body:
A divide has evolved over recent decades between those who teach business English (BE) "in service" - where people work - and those who teach business English, and any other strand of English for Specific Purposes (ESP), within established academic institutions such as universities and business schools. This differentiation has long been an area of contention, fuelled by suspicion and mutual envy. But now in-service business English practitioners, like myself, can no longer afford to set ourselves apart. We are missing out on the fruits of valuable academic research, and we are squandering our professional status.

To understand why in-service BE has been left behind by the rest of ESP one simply needs compare the two. A typical ESP teacher or trainer is usually employed full-time or on a continuing basis by his or her institution. They may well have worked in academia for a while and have a degree, a further degree or a doctorate. Their salary may not be magnificent, but they do not have to bear the overheads of their establishment, which also provides most of their teaching materials; they may be sponsored to go to conferences, have paid holidays and a sabbatical from time to time.

BE practitioners, in contrast, seldom have full-time or permanent jobs. Even in Britain most schools rely on freelance teachers, which means that when those teachers are not working, they are not earning. So to attend a conference or enrol on training means not only to temporarily forgo an income, but also to incur outgoings on fees, transport and accommodation. The typical freelance BE teacher, or small BE institution, has to bear all the costs of promotion, transport, materials and tax. For most this has been a firm incentive not to bother with training. But do they really need training and qualifications? It often appears not.

Many teachers of business English have dropped into the profession almost by accident. They may have been general English teachers called upon to "teach a business course next week"; or they may have been native speakers who find themselves living abroad and turning to teaching English to bring in some cash (the "you speak English, you must be able to teach it" conundrum).

But in a self-regulated or non-regulated industry like BE, our strength lies in our weakest link. So while many practitioners in the field of BE teaching are hard-working, experienced, competent and dedicated, a few are not. We have our fair share of charlatans and hot-air merchants. There are those who charge little and provide a bad service, and those who charge a lot to justify overblown claims, and they all risk giving BE a bad name.

How then can we learn from and emulate our colleagues in other areas of ESP? I believe it is essential to establish stable professional credentials within the BE fraternity. This is important for our own self-confidence, but also for the image that we portray to potential clients.

One significant advantage enjoyed by teachers in ESP is the respect in which they are held by their clients or students simply by virtue of their position or qualifications. But all too frequently the typical BE client is ignorant of or unconcerned about academic qualifications. I recently gained an MA in teaching English, which may have enhanced my standing among my colleagues but still means very little to the human resources manager to whom I would like to sell my courses. Another way we BE practitioners can change is to overcome our instinct to compete with one another and instead pool our skills and knowledge. We should also devote more time to learning about current ELT research.

BE practitioners in Britain are lucky to have an accreditation scheme run by the British Council that maintains teaching standards, and which is supported by associations such as ARELS and BASELT. Now we have BIELT, the British Institute of English Language Teaching, which aims to bring professional status to ELT in general. We also have ABC, the ARELS Business Charter group, which promotes business English and specialist training within Britain. ABC was set up with a small voluntary steering group, but is now seizing the nettle and is establishing a part-time salaried executive under the umbrella of ARELS.

Elsewhere, however, it can be harder for BE practitioners to find dedicated and professionally run networks. Some countries have associations of training managers, as is the case in Germany, or groups linked to local chambers of commerce. The best hope for an international body for BE is presented by BESIG (http://www.besig.org), the business English special interest group affiliated to IATEFL (International Association of Teachers of English as a Foreign Language). To date BESIG has been run by a voluntary committee, but it is well placed to negotiate support from IATEFL to enable it to move forward and become the focal point for internationally recognised quality and professionalism in business English teaching. This is the lesson that we need to learn from our colleagues in the wider world of ESP.

 Duncan Baker is a partner at Lydbury English Centre in England and a former coordinator of BESIG
