webTitle: First and second languages do battle for the classroom

fields.headline: First and second languages do battle for the classroom
fields.standfirst: Robert Buckmaster on the debate that is challenging the dominance of the English-only methodology
fields.trailText: Robert Buckmaster on the debate that is challenging the dominance of the English-only methodology
fields.body:
The 20th century saw massive growth in English language teaching, dominated by the United States and Britain. Now the demographics of English are changing, and this is influencing the debate about how English is being taught. One area where debate is now raging is over the use of the learner's first language (L1) in the classroom rather than the second language (L2, here, English). In the methodology proposed by the core countries - the US and Britain - the use of L1 was strongly discouraged, but times have changed and there are now two opposing camps.

Supporters of only L2 claim that children do not learn with reference to another language. This model has been the basis of all 20th century teaching methodologies. Using L2 meant that learners got lots of practice in speaking and listening to English and had to "negotiate" meaning if they did not understand.

Many of the teaching techniques were developed for use in multi-lingual classes in Britain, where the use of L1 was not an option, and then exported. The exclusive use of L2 also meant the supremacy of the native speaker. Cynics in the opposing camp pointed out that while the methodologists themselves only spoke English, their assertions also meant that coursebooks could be published in English and sold around the world, and that native English teachers were a great export. The dominant methodologies of the 20th century were direct methods (like the Berlitz Method) and the audio-lingual methods, which involved carefully controlled practice and repetition of sentences - all in English. In some schools translation was, and still remains, a sackable offence.

In recent years, however, even native speakers, who would seem to have a vested interest in the continuing exclusive use of L2, have started to challenge this legacy. Professor Guy Cook of Reading University has given lectures challenging the dominance of 20th-century fashions. Philip Prowse, author of highly successful coursebooks, suggests that native speakers are a useful resource, and that "every school should have one", but that they are not much more useful than that.

Reformers claim that, by trumpeting the benefits of native speakers you devalue non-native speakers. By insisting only L2 is used you neglect the advantages that using L1 can bring. By applying teaching techniques developed in one situation to another situation you are blindly following ideology.

It is now recognised that learners learn in different ways, and that some learners prefer to learn through L1 - who is to say that they shouldn't? Indeed most learners do use L1, and rather than creating a new language store, they mentally map the L2 on to the existing L1, drawing connections, contrasting ideas and viewing the L2 through their L1.

The changing demographics of global ELT have sharpened the debate. Most English teachers are non-natives. Most people in the world already speak more than one language. Soon more people will speak English as a second or foreign language than speak it as a first language. So why should native speakers of English, who often speak only one language and are a minority, dictate how English is taught? A more balanced view is needed.

Non-native speakers have a choice: they can use L1 or they can play a game of "Let's pretend I don't speak it - only use English". There have been cases of successful teachers going on training course in Britain and, on their return, abandoning all they did before in favour of communicative language teaching using only L2. They were seduced by the fun and gloss of teaching techniques developed in an entirely different teaching context than their own. This is tragic, as non-native speakers should value themselves and their techniques. This includes the use of L1. While activities should be conducted in English so as to give practice using English, much can be done in L1. Learners can discuss their problems with their teachers. The L1 can be contrasted with L2, a knowledge of the L1 gives the teacher an enormous advantage in predicting problems and difficulties in learning the L2 and translation - another 20th- century taboo - can be used. Using the L1 in a principled way is the key.

Choices have to be made: when to use L1, and how much to use. Can this be usefully done in L2? Is this a waste of an opportunity for practice or communication?

Native-speakers do not have this choice, and the lack of knowledge of the learners' L1 is a handicap - to teach a simple word such as "garlic" involves a great deal of description or use of a picture (does every teacher have a picture of garlic?). It is much simpler to translate such words. Garlic is garlic.

Of course native speakers have other advantages: learners have to use L2 to talk to them. But how stressful is that when there is a problem? By using the learners' L1 badly the teacher can show that making mistakes is not a big deal. By trying to learn their L1 the teacher shows respect for their language and culture, and it can also make your students laugh.

The pros and cons of using L1

In an ideal world learners will want to use English as much as possible. Teachers should try to encourage learners to choose to use English even when they could use L1. L1 should only be used as a tool to achieve specific aims. Although it is possible to learn a language only using L2, it's probably easier and less stressful when L1 is used in a disciplined way.

When L1 is useful...

 Translating some words - especially concrete nouns.

 Highlighting false friends, collocations and partial synonyms between languages.

 Discussing grammar differences between languages.

 Discussing abstract grammar ideas with learners - especially at lower levels.

 Explaining teaching approaches to learners.

...and when it's not

 Over use can mean dependency. Learners may not feel they understand unless they understand exactly in their L1. Exact translation can blur a word's many meanings and different collocations in different languages. It can also lead to a loss of useful language practice.

 Learners should know that they are using L1 for a specific reason: it is the most appropriate technique for that situation.

 All teachers should talk to their class socially in English - for realistic listening and speaking practice, and to show that the teacher values English.

 Robert Buckmaster is an EFL teacher working for the British Council in Poland

fields.headline: ELT Diary
fields.trailText:
HK test revolt

A controversial benchmark test for English language teachers in Hong Kong's state schools should be postponed, says an education pressure group, Education Convergence, which has surveyed 500 teachers. Only 6% said they would be willing to take the test, the rest said that they should be judged on their existing qualifications alone or by attending training courses. The test, required for more than 14,000 English teachers in primary and secondary schools, will be launched in October. All teachers must meet the minimum standard by 2005 either by passing the test or by completing a recognised training course.
fields.body:
HK test revolt

A controversial benchmark test for English language teachers in Hong Kong's state schools should be postponed, says an education pressure group, Education Convergence, which has surveyed 500 teachers. Only 6% said they would be willing to take the test, the rest said that they should be judged on their existing qualifications alone or by attending training courses. The test, required for more than 14,000 English teachers in primary and secondary schools, will be launched in October. All teachers must meet the minimum standard by 2005 either by passing the test or by completing a recognised training course.

Japan tongue-tied

A survey by Japan's Daily Yomiuri newspaper has revealed that up to 80% of adults think English is too difficult to use, and they would not try to converse over the telephone with an English speaker. Nevertheless the same number wished they had better English communication skills. The telephone survey of 3,000 adults adds weight to the view that while many Japanese recognise the importance of English and are keen that their children learn the language, they are not motivated to use it themselves.

US waives English

A new law will allow Hmong immigrants who fought for the United States in the secret war in Laos during the Vietnam war, to take the US citizenship test with the aid of an interpreter. The legislation waives the English-language requirement for as many as 45,000 Hmong immigrants, who have found it hard to learn English because they have had no written language of their own.

Skills for N Korea

Britain plans to send two English language teachers to North Korea as a first step to improving relations between the two countries. British and North Korean officials met in Pyongyang last month to discuss the exchange programme under which two North Korean teachers attended ELT courses in Britain in 1998.

webTitle: New Zealand moves to allow spelling of choice

fields.headline: New Zealand moves to allow spelling of choice
fields.trailText: Proposals have been put before English teachers in New Zealand to allow their students to pick and choose from the language's American and British orthographies: color or colour, program or programme, and so on. If the proposals are adopted conventional British variants of the words could be dropped altogether, and the local version of the language as it is taught switched to the American vernacular.
fields.body:
Proposals have been put before English teachers in New Zealand to allow their students to pick and choose from the language's American and British orthographies: color or colour, program or programme, and so on. If the proposals are adopted conventional British variants of the words could be dropped altogether, and the local version of the language as it is taught switched to the American vernacular.

The suggestion has been made at the behest of the New Zealand Association of English Teachers, whose president, Phil Coogan, is impressed by the "phonetic logic" of American spelling and, thanks to the internet, its global ubiquity.

The issue, he believes, "is going to become increasingly important, especially with the widespread use of electronic language."

Opinions were recently canvassed in the organisation's newsletter, sent to hundreds of teachers and departmental heads in New Zealand. The subsequent debate spilled over into the national news media, and even on to the website of Britain's Simplified Spelling Society, which has long campaigned against what it calls the public nuisance of non-American spellings.

Many of the New Zealand teachers surveyed said that English spelling in any form was a poor cousin to imagination and creative thought on the part of students, although some remained unsure whether the time is yet right for the Kiwis to bid farewell to British English.

In a syndicated column on English usage, Frank Haden, a local writer who styles himself as an Anglophile curmudgeon, predicted mayhem in the local classrooms if either of the proposals are adopted.

"Take a deep breath," he wrote, "introduce American spellings, declare them the correct ones, deduct marks from any pupil who tries to smuggle through an English spelling, then stand back. Chaos will naturally follow."

In Haden's view many of the stateside variants introduced to the language only ever happened because the Americans "didn't know any better". New Zealanders, he feels, do.

The call for change comes at a time when local-language educators are grappling with both an upsurge of general interest in American language themes and a general decline in the overall popularity of English as a subject. According to figures released this year by the country's education ministry, the number of senior secondary school pupils studying English has fallen over the past decade from nearly 100% to about 92%.

At university entrance level the number stands at 60%, down from 70% in 1990. At the post-secondary level the country's eight universities and 35 polytechnics are increasingly concerned about the literacy levels and communication skills of incoming students, according to Frances Kelly, a policy manager with the ministry.

The decline parallels New Zealand's overall national literacy rate, which, as measured by international agencies, has decreased over the past 10 years from a perfect 100% to today's 98%.

Coogan, who believes his association will indeed ratify one of the proposed changes later this year - a move that would then need to be endorsed by the country's governing qualifications authority - insists that standards of communication are not at issue, and that there will never be room among his colleagues for an anything-goes attitude to teaching English.

"A mistake in written English is still a mistake," he says. "This is not about lowering standards, nor is it about issues of national identity. It would be a shame if the subject gets clouded over in either of these ways."

webTitle: Women find new voice in English

fields.headline: Women find new voice in English
fields.standfirst: Helen Brown on how schools in Papua New Guinea are tackling discrimination
fields.trailText: Helen Brown on how schools in Papua New Guinea are tackling discrimination
fields.body:
"I'm learning a lot at college, and, being a girl, I understand how it is for girls at school," says Helen, a student at St Benedict's Teacher Training College in Papua New Guinea's East Sepik province. "When I qualify I want to go back to teach in my village - I feel it's important." Helen's commitment to education is evidence that recent reform of the country's school system is starting to raise the status of women in a society that has traditionally treated them as second-class citizens and improve their access to education and jobs.

In 1989 a survey carried out by the Education Commission of Papua New Guinea showed that of the 26,788 girls (45% of girls of school-entry age) enrolled throughout the country in the first year of primary school, only 308 remained by the time they reached grade 11, aged 16. Factors contributing to the high drop-out rate included the value placed on women's role in agricultural production and bringing up children, especially in rural communities, sexual harassment at school, desire for early marriage, failure in exams, the financial burden and the need for girls to look after younger siblings at home.

In 1996 the government of Papua New Guinea, supported by the Australian Agency for International Development, introduced education reforms leading to a restructuring of the upper secondary system. The curriculum was rewritten, examination procedures revised and provincial high schools expanded to take on the 16-to-18-year age group.

To help implement these reforms the government asked Voluntary Services Overseas (VSO), to work specifically in the English language programme for the 14-to-18 age group, where there had been a lack of trained national teachers. VSO was also invited to participate in teacher training programmes with the specific aim of increasing the numbers of marginalised rural poor and female students within the education system.

There is now evidence that this strategy is starting to have an impact on a new generation of women. It is opening up a greater degree of opportunity and providing an alternative to marriage and economic dependency. The widespread existence of domestic violence, for example, has recently become an issue for public debate, with articles written by women in the national press. Topics on the role of women and men, including domestic violence, now form part of the secondary English language syllabus.

In the Highlands, where traditional roles are strongly enforced, VSO teacher Gerard Witham has found that the subject of domestic violence can be debated in a structured classroom environment. The girls are able to make their voices heard, advocating mutual respect between husband and wife. Yet there is still some way to go to change opinions. Some of the boys in Witham's class remain convinced that violence is an acceptable way of dealing with a lazy or disobedient wife.

At Divine Word University in Madang, Jane has embarked on a journalism degree and contributes articles to her university paper. When she graduates she is eager to work on one of the national newspapers.

"Things are really changing for women," she says. "There are more opportunities than even 10 years ago, and more women want to get into the media. In my class we even have more girls wanting to be journalists than boys."

In Papua New Guinea, as in China, Pakistan, Thailand, and throughout Africa and Southeast Asia, gender issues are high on government and development agendas. Sixty five percent of the World Bank's education projects now contain gender specific initiatives, compared with 11% in 1988.

webTitle: Only one author in seven can afford to live on their writing

fields.headline: Only one author in seven can afford to live on their writing
fields.trailText: Almost half British authors earn less than the £5,000 yearly minimum wage and three quarters make less than the national average of £20,000, a survey found yesterday.
fields.body:
Almost half British authors earn less than the £5,000 yearly minimum wage and three quarters make less than the national average of £20,000, a survey found yesterday.

The survey - the first to be carried out for nearly 20 years - shows that the universal creative dream of self-sufficiency through writing is receding farther than ever.

Despite publishing hype about a tiny number of high earners, only one writer in seven can now afford to live on earnings from writing.

This number has been shrinking steadily for some 40 years. In 1966, nearly half of authors could rely on their output as a sole source of income. By 1971, this had fallen to less than a third. By the time of a survey conducted by the Society of Authors in 1981, it was down to less than a sixth.

"The trend continues down," says the new survey in the society's journal, The Author. Hopes that writing for the internet would generate new income have been dashed. One author wrote after completing a questionnaire: "I must be mad - like many others."

Another said: "Last week someone came to tile our kitchen and earned more for that morning that I earned from two years writing a major academic work."

The experience brought to mind a remark by the Danish composer Carl Nielsen: "If I could have my life again, I would whip all artistic whims out of my head and be apprenticed to a trade".

The academic commented: "A terrible thing to say, but I know exactly what he means ... I've twice been offered a £50 advance for a 30,000 word piece of work".

By contrast, one anonymous writer told the society of being paid £1.2m for a four-book deal - and added that his most recent book had taken only three months to write.

Other astronomic publishing deals have stirred hope and envy for the last decade. In 1995 Delia Smith made £3m from three cookery books. In 1996, a London bus driver, Magnus Mills, signed a £1m deal for his first novel. More recently, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe got £100,000 for The Clematis Tree; Jenny Colgan £200,000 for Amanda's Wedding; and Zadie Smith a rumoured £250,000 plus an Orange Prize nomination for White Teeth. Nick Hornby changed publishers in a transfer worth £2m.

But the overall figures, from 1,700 authors, a quarter of the society's members, prove how rare a dream this is. Average income was £16,000. Only 3% of writers earned £40,000-£50,000; only 4% got £50,000-£75,000; only 2% got £75,000-£100,000; and among the highest earners only 3% made over £100,000.

Nearly 90% of writers of academic and reference books made under £20,000. This earnings band also included 62% of crime, thriller and mystery writers, 70% of general fiction, educational and children's writers, and 75-80% of writers in all other fields.

Lowest earners were in the fields of genre fiction, specialist non-fiction, and academic and lifestyle books. Romantic and historical fiction writers were among those finding it "noticeably harder than any others to get a publisher", the survey says.

More than 62% of authors earned under £100 a year from library loans through the public lending fund. The survey results will spur authors in their campaign next month, backed by a 4,000-strong petition, to get the government to increase the fund from £5m to £7m a year.

The arts minister, Alan Howarth, has conceded that a rise in the fund is "highly desirable".

fields.headline: It's a mad world
fields.standfirst: Television programmes are dead: they're filled with names we already know doing the things we expect them to.  Iain Sinclair, whose new work Asylum hits our screens tonight, says it's time to bring some life back to a medium in crisis
fields.trailText: Television programmes are dead: they're filled with names we already know doing the things we expect them to. Iain Sinclair, whose new work Asylum hits our screens tonight, says it's time to bring some life back to a medium in crisis
fields.body:
The problem with a commissioned-to-vanish film like Asylum is that there is, simultaneously, too much and too little. Of everything. Too much to say, narrative shouting down narrative, and too little time to satisfy yourself that you have arrived at the essential form. The paradox at the heart of this Faustian bargain (with the men in the Glass Tower) demands that you deliver something original which is also perfectly safe. News that is already familiar. Names which are in the book but instantly accessible to those who don't read books.

Content expands as space contracts. We struggle to hold on (in something approaching real time) to those pre-dawn drives through Bastrop, Texas, to the woman promenading slowly around the roof of a multi-story car park in Whitechapel, sunlight reflected in the swimming pool of the Holiday Inn at Phoenix, Arizona. Editor Emma Matthews (who has taken the rogue virus theme of the film to heart and who is visibly wilting at her Avid) moans as another drifting, meditative passage is brutally abbreviated.

Loss hurts. I know, because I've watched the full 60 hours of out-takes, that there are spellbinding conversations with Black Mountain poet Ed Dorn; a poetry reading in Bristol, a leisurely debriefing, the following morning, in a wild Bath garden. What remains? Spectral glimpses of a man in a nicely deconstructed white jacket signing a book, a ghost among green profusion. The Xerox of a Xerox. TV is absence. Posthumous whispers. Flaring images. Refilmed evidence rescued from the catalogue of privileged material that must remain beyond the reach of the distant viewer. Asylum is an animated version of one of those chalk outlines drawn on a sticky pavement around the body of an imagined victim.

After the frets and frolics (generated by the film's subject), the last time Chris Petit and I worked together (on The Falconer), nobody at Channel 4 was taking any chances. Ed Dorn's eminently debatable proposition - that off-shore oil leases in Kuwait owned by the "Bush boys" might have had some bearing on the conduct of the Gulf War - was red pencilled.

Very well. Then could we substitute Dorn's lucid improvisation on Kosovo, his sketch of Madeleine Albright as heading up a band of roving international busybodies? Absolutely not. Those who are unknown, not part of the corporate sensorium, the Mediadrome, are, by definition, fictional. Hence the confusion about what is or not legitimate comment. A number of films that served up indifferently faked reality as a form of documentary truth queered the pitch for those working in the opposite direction: playing old footage, over and over, until a mythical structure declared itself.

Petit, in one of the letters that stood in for a more conventional script wrote: "We have a film of fragments which work best in a pre-edited state or when the image has passed beyond recall. Say the date is 2180 and the footage has been unearthed and someone has to try and make sense of it and piece it together, but it conforms to nothing that is known of late 20th-century television, which was concerned with biography as embalming.

Formaldehyde-TV is still the preferred cultural mode - with Lord Bragg's South Bank Show as the flagship (precursor of all those other Thames-side millennial disasters). Promotion is the name of the game. Only the known are allowed to be known. A media-blitz on behalf of a puntable commodity such as the Amis franchise (product place ment for roll-ups) will climax, somewhere past the permitted fuck-hour on a Sunday night.

"Set foot outside the house in a shirt that colour and I'll shoot you", my wife said, dazzled by Melvyn's plunging pink décolletage; the way he massaged his Adam's apple. Formulaic writer-puffs have an assembly-line feel, talking heads banged together with an audible clunk. The living and the dead share an equal status. The current Melvyn Bragg (twinkly gravitas) seems to interrogate an earlier, tousled version of himself, like the ghost calling up Hamlet. Lingering reaction shots last longer than the sound-bites. There are no surprises. Writers shouldn't have to put themselves through this terrible self-impersonation, but that's the price of staying at the table. Here is the single teardrop brushed manfully aside. Here is the anthology of hair gestures, accidents and rethinks. Here is the conceptually unflashy sofa, the wife and the kiddies. Here is much more than we need or want to be told.

Petit, a fine film essayist, interested in awkward weather, neurotic journeying, rumours of the reforgotten, suffers in this culture of compulsory amnesia. Asylum isn't sure how to present itself, as science fiction, commentary or discontinued thriller. It exists to justify its paranoia, its failure to give the audience the time to hear - in full - Michael Moorcock's stories, the revelation of how this epic English novelist found himself exiled to a small Texas town. And why was Marina Warner lurking in the bushes out by Heathrow, intoning fables about mysterious twins and acoustic doubles?

It's the deleted shots that stay in my mind: the King George VI reservoir, removed at the commissioners' request, because it was "confusing". It looked too much like the sea. As Ed Dorn said: "Just because the record's still there, it doesn't mean that it hasn't been lost."

Asylum, tonight, 11.40pm, C4

fields.headline: East side story
fields.standfirst: When Omana Gangadharan wrote a novel based around her London home, she never imagined her life would be threatened.  Raekha Prasad reports
fields.trailText: When Omana Gangadharan wrote a novel based around her London home, she never imagined her life would be threatened.  Raekha Prasad reports
fields.body:
The eggs are still there. Caked on to the front of Omana Gangadharan's house, a 70s brick terrace with a neat front lawn, the dried yokes are the only evidence of several ugly things that have recently been hurled at the woman inside. It's not locks or barbed wire that keep Omana Gangadharan trapped inside her home but the words that have fallen through her letterbox and been spat down her telephone.

It began on February 25 this year. Gangadharan answered the phone in her family home in East Ham, east London, to hear a man's voice telling her he was going to rip out her uterus. She was so shocked that she hung up. Earlier that evening, her house had been pelted with stones and bottles. No one inside was hurt but the timing was significant: it was the eve of the launch of Gangadharan's novel, The Final Phase, at the local town hall.

The novel tells the story of the postwar immigration to East Ham of Malayalees (the people of Kerala, south India). It was a departure from the writer's previous work, which had been set in India and serialised in various regional publications, and it was published with the aid of a grant from the Peabody Trust.

A week before the launch, Gangadharan gave a copy to a friend and it began to circulate in East Ham's Malayalee community. "The story relates to the life of every immigrant who has come here," she explains. "I wanted to write about the experience of being invited but not welcomed." Set on the Poet's Estate, home to 10,000 of Newham's Malayalees, the novel fictionalises the arrival of a generation of men who came to Britain in the 50s from India and Singapore. Gangadharan, a 46-year-old mother of two who arrived in East Ham from Kerala 27 years ago, chose Newham, she says, because "it's where I've spent more than half my life".

But the setting turned out to be too close to home: outraged by what they saw as caricatures of individual members of the community, some locals began a campaign to stop the book's launch. Phone calls were made asking speakers Gangadharan had invited to the event not to come and leaflets were circulated telling people to stay away. Protesters picketed the town hall. While Gangadharan was inside, her car was vandalised. So, too, were the cars of her best friend and her daughter. Gangadharan says some of the protesters were chanting that she was a prostitute and telling her 26-year-old daughter she'd slept with other members of the family.

After the launch, the threats escalated. A message on the answerphone informed Gangadharan's husband and son that they would be stoned to death. The family received death threats through the post. One night, three minicabs were sent to her home in succession. After sending them all away, she received an anonymous phone call. "He told me the cabs were intended to take me to Epping Forest where I would be stripped, gang-raped and burnt," she says. "He went into detail about how he intended to remove my clothes."

Even before publication of her book, Gangadharan was well-known within the community, due in part to one of her earlier novels having been made into a Malayalee film. But primarily it was because she got involved, volunteering for an Aids charity and a women's refuge, as ward secretary of the local Labour Party and a translator at the town hall. Then overnight, she became infamous for rubbishing her own community.

"It's clear who she's talking about," says Sreejith Sreedharan, cultural secretary of the Malayalee Association of the UK Trust. "The characters are based on real-life people." The shopkeeper who sells "mouldy vegetables" and his "moustached wife", he says, are based on local people.

He objects, too, to Das, a character who develops a penchant for Soho's sex shows: "The novel gives the impression that the community is illiterate, dependent on the state and has no sexual morals." Sreedharan says he condemns intimidation and violence but he is campaigning for the book to be withdrawn and "an unconditional public apology" to be made to the Malayalee community "for the insult, distress and discomfort" they say she has caused.

Gangadharan is unrepentant. "When there are 10,000 people in the community and 200 characters in my book, what name could I possibly have used that didn't belong to someone?" she asks. "They say: 'That character must be so-and-so because he's got a gold tooth.' I can think of four people in the community with gold teeth."

Most of the threats have been sexually violent or have made insinuations about Gangadharan's sexual conduct. Lurking insidiously within the threats, she says, is a potent objection to a woman telling men's stories. "Until the 70s, immigration to Britain was largely male, so I've written about men's lives - looking for work at Dagenham's Ford factory and, yes, visiting strip joints in Soho. I've written from a male angle and they've said a man helped me. I've never been to Singapore but I spoke to those who have and I visited the Ford factory so that I could describe it. I was not here in postwar Britain, I'm a middle-aged Asian woman sitting at home, so the attitude is: 'How could she write about that?' I'm supposed to remain a housewife, not a person who writes about public life."

On East Ham's High Road, black, Asian and white residents all claim to care little for the controversy. A white newsagent who has owned the shop for over 20 years argues the case for freedom of speech: "Otherwise you'll get restrictions that disregard the intelligence of the reader." A young Malayalee woman adds: "People are saying all sorts of things but until I've read it, I can't have an opinion."

The manager of Newham Bookshop says she received a letter from the Malayalee Association "suggesting I don't stock the book and asking me to speak to them". She is remaining neutral, she says: she sells the novel but chooses to keep it under the counter. "I've sold 15 copies, which is 15 more than I would have sold without the controversy," she adds.

Meanwhile, Newham Library is still assessing whether it will stock copies. "Reading the book from outside the community, we see no reason not to stock it," a council spokeswoman says, "unless it has been legally established that it libels individuals. Saying 'I don't like it' is not a good enough reason for us not to keep it."

Plaistow police have arrested two men for threats to kill Gangadharan, though no one has been charged. She is now too afraid to leave her home. She has stopped her community work and her health has deteriorated, she says, but she insists she will not apologise. "When I write, I have to be free," she says. "I'm living in London and I write for the whole community. I can't be confined to writing about an Indian woman looking after children and going to the temple."

Sreedharan says he condemns intimidation and violence but he is campaigning for the book to be withdrawn and "an unconditional public apology" to be made to the Malayalee community "for the insult, distress and discomfort" they say she has caused. Gangadharan is unrepentant. "When there are 10,000 people in the community and 200 characters in my book, what name could I possibly have used that didn't belong to someone?" she asks. "They say: 'That character must be so-and-so because he's got a gold tooth.' I can think of four people in the community with gold teeth." Most of the threats have been sexually violent or have made insinuations about Gangadharan's sexual conduct. Lurking insidiously within the threats, she says, is a potent objection to a woman telling men's stories. "Until the 70s, immigration to Britain was largely male, so I've written about men's lives - looking for work at Dagenham's Ford factory and, yes, visiting strip joints in Soho. I've written from a male angle and they've said a man helped me. I've never been to Singapore but I spoke to those who have and I visited the Ford factory so that I could describe it. I was not here in postwar Britain, I'm a middle-aged Asian woman sitting at home, so the attitude is: 'How could she write about that?' I'm supposed to remain a housewife, not a person who writes about public life." On East Ham's High Road, black, Asian and white residents all claim to care little for the controversy. A white newsagent who has owned the shop for over 20 years argues the case for freedom of speech: "Otherwise you'll get restrictions that disregard the intelligence of the reader." A young Malayalee woman adds: "People are saying all sorts of things but until I've read it, I can't have an opinion." The manager of Newham Bookshop says she received a letter from the Malayalee Association "suggesting I don't stock the book and asking me to speak to them". She is remaining neutral, she says: she sells the novel but chooses to keep it under the counter. "I've sold 15 copies, which is 15 more than I would have sold without the controversy," she adds. Meanwhile, Newham Library is still assessing whether it will stock copies. "Reading the book from outside the community, we see no reason not to stock it," a council spokeswoman says, "unless it has been legally established that it libels individuals. Saying 'I don't like it' is not a good enough reason for us not to keep it." Plaistow police have arrested two men for threats to kill Gangadharan, though no one has been charged. She is now too afraid to leave her home. She has stopped her community work and her health has deteriorated, she says, but she insists she will not apologise. "When I write, I have to be free," she says. "I'm living in London and I write for the whole community. I can't be confined to writing about an Indian woman looking after children and going to the temple."

fields.headline: Ruud's frankly unacceptable moustache
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan needs to sort things out; as do the FA; but Ruud Gullit has everything under control.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"We should have scored more in the first half" - Spanish coach Jose Antonio Camacho's verdict on his team's match against Yugoslavia, arguably the greatest game of all time. Some people are never happy.

THE EURO-TORIAL

What now for England? According to most pundits the omens are ominous. Our best players lack technique. And our manager - all heart and no head yet again! - lacks any sort of tactical acumen. The only consolation is that our World Cup group rivals Germany have it much, much worse. Well that's just great.

Obviously much needs to be sorted out. It was a bit rich for Kevin Keegan to criticise the lack of passing ability in his side, for instance, when he picked two ball winners, Ince and Wise, barely played Barmby or McManaman, and left Rio Ferdinand at home.

Another problem Keegan must address is his continuing loyalty to ageing players. Perhaps because he was unceremoniously dumped himself by Bobby Robson in 1982, he has stuck with players like Ince, Wise, Shearer, Adams, Keown and Seaman - and gives the impression that he will continue to do so, even though most will be 35 or over by the time the next World Cup comes round. Again that has to change: youth must be given a chance.

And finally Keegan must learn to trust his attacking instincts again. For years he's been criticised for being "too gung-ho", but for England he seems to be overcompensating. He should remember that he led an average Newcastle side into third place in the Premiership in their first season back in the top flight and then nearly won the title a couple of years later - which is much than tactical experts like Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle ever managed at Spurs or Chelsea. So Kevin, no more picking ageing ball-winners. No more hauling off England's brightest talent early in every game. And no more craven tactics - send a statement of intent to the opposition: attack, attack and attack.

THINGS NOT LOOKING THAT GREAT HERE, EITHER

The FA is to seek urgent talks with Fifa to assess whether England's knackered old bid to stage the 2006 World Cup is in a complete state of disrepair or just a bit jiggered. This latest desperate move comes in the wake of the English Hoodlum Show in Charleroi last week.

Alec McGivan, the bid's campaign director, will ask Fifa apparatchiks if the bid stands any chance of success when the final vote is taken in Zurich on July 6. "Clearly the incidents of last weekend have not helped us," admitted the hapless organiser. "But we owe it to ourselves to spend the last two weeks of the campaign sitting down quietly to see how the Fifa executive have reacted. It is easy to jump to conclusions but we need to see how our bid stands."

However, England's bid is in such an abject state that even former sports minister and professional optimist Tony Banks thinks the outlook is "bleak". Not that McGivan is giving up hope. "Our problems need to be compared to those of our rivals," he told Radio 4. "Our bid is still a very strong one - and there is only one issue which has affected it." Well, if it's only one major misdemeanour, they should forget about it, don't you think?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

Football and beer. They go together like... well, top sporting action and a tasty liquid beverage. Win a crate of beer from Lastorders.com for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com and click on the link on the left hand side.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Turkey striker Hakan Sukur has a twisted left ankle and may miss Saturday's quarter-final against Portugal.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hello boysh and girlsh, it's Ruud Gullit here. I just popped in to advise Karel on haircuts, but it looks as though he's moved out. Weird. Anyway, do you like my new trim? Pretty trendy, huh? Now that I look so good, perhaps everyone will forget that at the height of my playing powers I sported a frankly unacceptable moustache.

Hey, while I'm here I better have a flick through these rumours to make sure nobody's trying to sign Alan - spit - Shearer.

Chelsea are leading the race for Gareth Southgate. The England defender will move to Stamford Bridge in the close season providing Gianluca Vialli can offload Frank Leboeuf.

AC Milan have added Dennis Bergkamp to a shopping list which already includes David Beckham.

Heh! Not a bid for baldy in sight!

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football (8.30am)

Slovenia v Norway. Why are we suddenly telling you about every single Euro 2000 programme on Eurosport?

Euro 2000 Football (10.30am)

Yugoslavia v Spain. Well, it's certainly not because there are no other Euro 2000 programmes on television.

Euro 2000 Football (3.30pm)

France v Holland. And it has nothing to do with the fact that there isn't a radio programme about the tournament on today either.

Euro 2000 Football (8pm)

We wouldn't fill this section of the Euro up with stuff just for the sake of it, you know.

Euro 2000 Nightclub (11.15pm)

We wouldn't waste your time.

Euro 2000 Football (11.30pm)

Look, we wouldn't.

fields.headline: Chancellor denies 'psycho-political' obstacles over euro
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown today denied that politics are preventing Britain from joining the euro.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today denied that politics are preventing Britain from joining the euro.

Speaking on BBC Breakfast news, Mr Brown cast off accusations from president of the European Central Bank Wim Duisenberg that only "psycho-political" obstacles stand between Britain and the single currency. The chancellor insisted that the government would recommend membership of the euro to the British public when the economic conditions were right.

The chancellor has "five economic tests" that form his criteria for making a decision on the single currency. He will assess if there is sustainable convergence between Britain and euroland, sufficient flexibility to cope with economic change, and the euro's impact on investment, employment and the financial services industry.

"These are the tests that we set down in 1997, these are consistently held tests that we will pursue over the next period of time, and that is how the decision will be made, with the people, in the end, having the final say," Mr Brown said.

"Mr Duisenberg knows that this is a decision that is going to be made not by him, but being made in Britain."

Lord Haskins, chairman of Northern Foods and a prominent supporter of the pro-euro Britain in Europe group, said there were political issues involved. "The anti-euro movement here is much more than an anti-euro movement, it's an anti-Europe movement, and that issue has to be addressed," he said.

webTitle: Blair courts the little guys of Europe

fields.headline: Blair courts the little guys of Europe
fields.standfirst: Portugal Summit
fields.trailText: Tony Blair made the most of the Feira summit to press home his policy of cultivating new tactical alliances with the minnow states of a Europe no longer in the grip of a dominant Franco-German axis.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Santa Maria da Feira
fields.body:
Tony Blair made the most of the Feira summit to press home his policy of cultivating new tactical alliances with the minnow states of a Europe no longer in the grip of a dominant Franco-German axis.

Whitehall insiders call the strategy "step change". Increasing the sheer volume of bilateral contacts with small and medium-sized EU members, the theory goes, is helping Britain set agendas and win arguments.

Mr Blair's warm relationship with Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, is the most conspicuous example of step change. With differences over Gibraltar put to one side, the Spanish conservative and Britain's New Labour pioneer of the third way have become powerful and increasingly visible allies.

But Portugal, Belgium, the Netherlands, Ireland, Sweden and Denmark have also become important partners across a range of issues.

Step change emerged from a brainstorming session in Downing Street in late 1998 as the government sought ways to live up to its pledge to be "at the heart of Europe".

British officials insist it is not about competing with the Franco-German axis, far weaker now than in its François Mitterand-Helmut Kohl heyday.

Step change is as much about economics as politics for the largely centre-left governments - Aznar's Spain is the exception - that now run the 15-member union.

Relations with Portugal's Antonio Guterres were crucial in turning March's Lisbon "dot.com" summit into a showcase for the structural reforms needed to help Europe catch up with the more dynamic US - and neatly sidestepped the ever neuralgic question of whether Britain would join euroland.

Blair has also cultivated Belgium's Guy Verhofstadt, the boyish Liberal prime minister whose "active welfare" policies matter more in London than his country's traditional commitment to European integration.

Next door in the Netherlands, prime minister Wim Kok is seen as a useful Blair ally on third way issues, even though he too backs EU reforms that his British colleague could never accept.

Sweden figures prominently on the list of step change priorities not only because Social Democratic leader Goran Persson will be running the EU's rotating presidency in the first half of next year but also because Stockholm shares Britain's enthusiasm for enlargement to the east. "Scandinavians are like us," says one diplomat. "They didn't invent the EU either but look at it as a means to an end. They're not ideological or emotional about it like the founding members."

Looking further ahead in time and space, Foreign Office efforts are starting to focus on Poland, the leading candidate for the next step of EU enlargement. But there is increasing concern that the timetable is slipping.

None of this diplomatic creativity solves Blair's enduring problems about what to do about the single currency, with Greece now the 12th member and Denmark and Sweden due to make their choice before any British referendum.

Nor does it mean that Britain will get its way in this year's intergovernmental conference, with Paris and Berlin coordinating closely and keen on writing a new agreement on "flexibility" into the Treaty of Nice in December.

But it does help explain the claim, made by a delighted prime minister as he left Portugal for home yesterday, that Feira marked the end of an era of "Britain versus the rest" in Europe.

What the papers say

'Schröder and Chirac are expecting too much from the EU by burdening it with the row about strengthened cooperation. The Paris-Berlin plan is like Fischer's vision: it is right but it is premature' Der Tagesspiegel, Germany

'In one respect, European politics degenerated into farce in Feira: being tied down by unilateral decisionmaking forced the Union to vote for a solution that is no solution. The minority will in future have to bend to the decision of the majority. Otherwise the EU will turn into a lame duck giant' Sueddeutsche Zeitung, Germany

'The summit in Portugal served to highlight the profound identity crisis suffered by the EU, which appears incapable of making progress on its two key medium term goals: enlargement and institutional reform' El Mundo, Spain

'In the face of a revitalised Franco-German axis, Aznar has been poorly served by his close relationship with Blair and euro-unenthusiastic Britain. It would be wise for Mr Aznar to review his alliances . . . he runs the danger of becoming Mr Niet' El Pais, Spain

'Behind yesterday's agreement lies the objective of a unified fiscal policy: without majority decisions we will never achieve it, not even via decade-long postponements' La Stampa, Italy

'A bottle of port, vintage 1981, and all-round smiles on the faces of government officials with the successful conclusion of Greece's entry into the Eurozone is not enough to automatically solve, as if with a magic wand, the country's huge economic and social problems' Ta Nea, Greece

'Schüssel can go home to Austria with his head held high. The compromise he accepted at the last minute contains enough safety nets for Austria to be able to change its mind tomorrow, and at the same time the country has its ticket back into the EU fold virtually in the bag' Libération, France

fields.headline: Nurse suspended over children's deaths
fields.standfirst: Emergency contact number: 0800 169 1619
fields.trailText: A nurse has been suspended from an Essex NHS trust as police investigate the deaths of 18 children aged between eight weeks and 17 years.
fields.body:
A nurse has been suspended from an Essex NHS trust as police investigate the deaths of 18 children aged between eight weeks and 17 years.

The investigation centres on suspected overdoses of painkillers given to terminally ill children over a three-year period between 1996 and May 1999, says today's Sun newspaper.

"We are investigating allegations made against a nurse from the former Southend community care services NHS trust [now the South Essex mental health and community care NHS trust] concerning care of patients," Essex police said in a statement.

"The police were called in by the trust following concerns raised by an unrelated internal investigation. The nurse is currently suspended by the trust.

"Police officers and clinicians from the trust have visited families involved in the investigation and given them information about it and offer any support required," Essex police said.

Police would not comment on whether any bodies of children would have to be exhumed as part of the inquiry.

The nurse, who is in her 40s and has worked in several hospitals during a long career, including London's world-famous Great Ormond Street hospital, was suspended last year four days after the mother of one boy wrote a letter of complaint about her to health bosses.

The letter is said to have complained of "serious misgivings" about the professional conduct of the nurse which, the parent said, had "jeopardised and compromised" her son's treatment.

A spokesman for the UKCC, nursing's regulatory body, said it was sending the woman a letter today telling her she faced interim suspension from the nursing register.

The nurse would probably be formally suspended for the interim within the next three weeks, the spokesman said.

"We have to give people notice of interim suspension and a committee has to consider the case but we have moved to act very quickly today," he said. "She will face interim suspension while the police investigation is carried out."

The move will stop the nurse from working anywhere in the country, as well as at the hospital trust where she was employed and from which she has already been suspended.

The Sun reports that Essex police have been in contact with colleagues in Lincolnshire who helped convict hospital nurse Beverley Allitt.

Allitt was dubbed The Angel of Death after killing four young children while she worked at Grantham Hospital in the early 1990s. She also attacked and injured a further nine young children, leaving some of them severely disabled.

She was arrested after a major investigation and later sentenced to 13 life sentences at Nottingham crown court and told there was no chance that she would ever be released. Her case led to tighter checks on the mental state of applicants for nursing.

 Helpline for parents concerned about their children's hospital care in Southend: 0800 169 1619.

fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: PC hell | More floppies, vicar?
fields.body:
In PC hell with Kakworm
I appear to have picked up Kakworm, or a variant of it, this all despite having PC-cillin virus-scan on my PC and updating it every week. It would seem that the virus is responsible for some of my outgoing emails being mysteriously blocked and/or "firewalled due to presence of Kakworm virus" - whatever that means, and also for weird error messages that keep on appearing at boot phase like "driver memory error", "Windows cannot access kak.registry" and "Kagou-Anti-Kro$oft says not today!". So, help please! I'm desperate to get rid of this virus and get on with my life, and I have no idea what to do next. David Kidman
dave@kidman.fsnet.co.uk

Jack Schofield: The appropriately named PC Hell website has a good explanation of how to remove the virus at www.pchell.com/internet/kakworm.shtml. If you scroll down the site, it provides a program to do the job for you.

The manual removal involves finding a file called Autoexec.bat (it's in C:\) and deleting it, then renaming AE.KAK back to Autoexec.bat (the virus renamed it). You must also find and delete the KAK.HTA file in your StartUp directory and any other files with the same extension (use Start|Find|Files or Folders and search for *.HTA).

The virus also makes changes to the Windows Registry. Note that the virus, written in JavaScript, works when you view an HTML message in Outlook or Outlook Express, so you need to find and delete the original message to avoid reinfection.

More floppies, vicar?
I work from home (as a vicar) and I have lots of floppies with different stuff on them. Please, is there any way of printing the list of files that I have on each floppy. Even my children can't do this! Martin Leigh
m.leigh@btinternet.com

JS: The simple answer is to open a Dos session (Start|Programs|MS-DOS Prompt) and switch to the drive you want to catalogue (A:). Then type dir /o /a>sermons.txt and press Enter. This will create an alphabetical list of files and save it as a text file (ie sermons.txt). You can then print it out and/or load it into a spreadsheet to add comments, sort and store it.

However, there are dozens of much better ways to catalogue disks, and many of them are free. For example, NoNags offers numerous free alternatives at www.nonags.com/nonags/disku32.html. Both MeowCAT 1.2 (330KB) and Disk Catalog 2.0 (350KB) look as though they will do what you need.

Alternatively, why not buy a secondhand hard drive? Prices start at about £5.

More closure, please
My Windows 98 PC keeps giving me a message during the shutdown process. After using Wordpad, Wordstar and Paint, I often get a box headed "Ebrr" that says "This program has performed an illegal operation and will be shut down".
Peter Stead
steadies@talk21.com

JS: "Fast shutdown" is enabled by default in Microsoft Windows 98 and perhaps your problem will be cured by disabling it. To do this, go to Start| Programs|Accessories| System tools and select System Information. On the Tools menu, click System Configuration Utility. On the General tab, click Advanced. Then click on the Disable Fast Shutdown box to select it. Finally, click OK twice, and restart your computer as prompted.

If you are using Windows 98 Second Edition (you don't say), this has known shut-down problems. There is a trouble-shooting guide and a bug-fix to download on the Microsoft Web site at www.microsoft.com/windows98/downloads/contents/WURecommended/S_WUFeatured/Win98SE.

Yahoo! You've got mail
I changed my internet account to NTL and do receive their email in the Inbox of Outlook Express. I also have an email address with Yahoo, but I cannot see the email on this address in the Inbox. How does one manage to do that? I have read and tried various ways without much luck.
Suresh Dhingra
sureshdhingra@yahoo.co.uk

JS: You can get Yahoo mail in Outlook Express, but first you have to change the settings at Yahoo. Log on to your Yahoo mailbox, click the Options link and choose POP Access & Forwarding (the bottom of the middle column) to set up a POP3 mailbox. Do this and log off.

Next run Outlook Express and choose Tools|Accounts. On the resulting tabbed dialogue box choose Add|Mail and go through the Internet Connection Wizard. When you come to the page called Email Server Names, enter the following:
Incoming Mail (POP3) Server: pop.mail.yahoo.com
Outgoing Mail (SMTP) Server: smtp.mail.yahoo.com
You should now be able to pick up Yahoo mail.

You can use the same Wizard to set up a Hotmail account with Outlook Express 5, but you don't need to change Hotmail.

Music to your Mini-Disc
What kind of equipment would I need to download files from Napster to my portable Mini-Disc recorder?
Jon Sutton
jonsut@bps.org.uk

JS: I haven't done this myself but I'm told it's easy ;-)

Most MiniDisc recorders have a digital optical input port so ideally you need a PC or Mac with an optical digital output port, such as the MIDIman Delta DiO or a SoundBlaster Live card with an optional Digital Optical daughter card. You'll also need a TOSlink cable to connect the two devices.

Set the MiniDisc player to sync record and use Soritong or a similar MP3 player to play your 74 minute playlist. (Alternatively, you should be able to make recordings by connecting the line out on your sound card with a line in port on the MiniDisc recorder, if fitted, though you'll have to set the record level.)

Why Soritong? It lets you put gaps between tracks.

Xitel, an American company, is about to launch an MD-Port DG1 add-on that connects a PC's USB port to a MiniDisc player or other digital device, see www.xitel.com/f_DG1.htm which may make it even easier.

webTitle: School's teachers resign after damning report by Ofsted

fields.headline: School's teachers resign after damning report by Ofsted
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: All 12 teachers at a primary school have resigned in the wake of an inspection by the Office for Standards in Education.
fields.body:
All 12 teachers at a primary school have resigned in the wake of an inspection by the Office for Standards in Education.

Moor Lane junior school in Chessington, south-west London, was found to have "serious weaknesses" by inspectors last April.

The headteacher, Jane Wright, announced she was retiring, blaming the pressure of paperwork. The deputy head, Peter Sainsbury, and five other teachers found jobs elsewhere. All are due to leave at the end of this term.

Ofsted returned for a follow-up inspection last month and told Ms Wright and school governors chairman, John Heamon, that "insufficient progress" had been made.

"Teaching staff considered that their efforts over the past 12 months had not been recognised in the progress report and consequently the remaining staff tendered their resignations," Kingston local education authority said in a statement. The chairman of the governors, John Heamon, said the school had been "wrecked" by the decision. Parents were told by the authority on Monday.

The council said the past 12 months "have been a stressful period for staff at the school". A head and deputy head have been seconded from other schools and three teachers appointed. Interviews for the other jobs are being carried out over the next three weeks.

A spokesman for Ofsted said the resignations were "unfortunate" and would "leave the school facing a very difficult situation". He said: "It's not something we welcome. It's clearly a matter for them and their consciences and it's something that the governors and the LEA are going to have to address. What matters is the education of the children - that's what inspections are about. It's keeping parents informed about what is going on in the schools."

The school had made "negligible progress" in implementing its action plan after last year's inspection, and was not doing enough to address serious weaknesses.

It emerged this week that 23 of 55 teachers at Kingswood high school, a "fresh start" school in Hull, have handed in their notice.

 The government will fail to meet national targets for achievement in English unless standards in children's writing is dramatically improved over the next year, Ofsted warned yesterday, writes Rebecca Smithers .

It blamed teachers in primary schools for concentrating on reading rather than writing in the daily literacy hour. In a discussion paper published on its website, Ofsted said the teaching of writing was "unsatisfactory" in a quarter of all such lessons.

The education and employment secrtetary David Blunkett has said he will resign if 80% of final year primary school pupils fail in the national tests to reach the expected standard in literacy by 2002, and 75% fail to achieve the same level in numeracy.

fields.headline: Meeting a business need
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
First Tuesday
fields.trailText: Nick Pascoe and engineering looked like a marriage made in heaven. By the time he was in his late 20s Mr Pascoe had established a firm in Sheffield and a reputation as one of the sharpest young engineering designers in the region.
fields.body:
Nick Pascoe and engineering looked like a marriage made in heaven. By the time he was in his late 20s Mr Pascoe had established a firm in Sheffield and a reputation as one of the sharpest young engineering designers in the region.

He had played a part in designing the world's largest welding machine. Then, in October 1998, the bottom fell out of the market and the beautiful relationship ended. "It was devastating. In three weeks we went from having an order book worth £3m to £300,000," said Mr Pascoe, aged 32.

Stuck for an idea of what to do next he decided get into the internet. It was an area he had had some experience of when he put many of his design projects on-line to allow clients to monitor them.

At that time First Tuesday, the networking group for internet entrepreneurs, was burgeoning in London so he contacted them and asked if he could effectively franchise a northern version. "We held our first meeting at Old Trafford in September and 60 people turned up. It's snowballed from there and a community is building across the north. In May 600,000 emails were sent between 2,500 members."

Quid Pro-Quo, a bar in Leeds, attracts about 200 to each monthly meeting with live video links to meetings in Sheffield, Manchester, Newcastle and Liverpool.

Several entrepreneurs are breaking through - Sheffield graphics firm Kazoo 3D raised $19m on AIM recently after meeting their advisers at a First Tuesday event.

Mr Pascoe is going through the uphill task of raising £5.5m for his own start-up, Twinset, an online marketing firm aimed at pop fans. But it will force the firm to relocate south. "The headquarters of the European music industry is London. If it was Grimsby we'd be going there. Sadly it's not."

fields.headline: Coca-Cola finally conquers N Korea
fields.standfirst: Korea: special report
fields.trailText: It may have seemed that North Korea's half-century of isolation ended last week with a handshake between its Dear Leader Kim Jong-il and South Korea's Kim Dae-jung, but the "real thing" happened yesterday when the first lorryload of Coca-Cola pulled up at the borders of the reclusive communist state.
fields.body:
It may have seemed that North Korea's half-century of isolation ended last week with a handshake between its Dear Leader Kim Jong-il and South Korea's Kim Dae-jung, but the "real thing" happened yesterday when the first lorryload of Coca-Cola pulled up at the borders of the reclusive communist state.

The consignment came from China and arrived at the border near the town of Dandong.

Robert Baskin, a company spokesman, said: "I got a message this morning, confirming that we had actually moved in.

"We've been aware there might be some movement with respect to North Korea and other countries, so we had a contingency plan ready to go.

"We had a plant not far from the border and an agreement with a North Korean organisation that was going to distribute [it]."

Until now Coca-Cola and other multinational corporations have been kept out of North Korea by a US government embargo, but most of those sanctions were lifted on Monday, following last week's groundbreaking summit between the two Kims.

Bemused North Koreans, who have been sheltered from much of the modern world by the quixotic regime in Pyongyang, may not know what to make of the black sticky drink, but for Coca-Cola it is another important step towards global dominance.

The company's ubiquitous red and white logo can now be readily seen in shops just about anywhere in the world, with the exception of a handful of such US enemies as Cuba, Iraq, Iran and Libya - which have to rely on smuggled supplies.

fields.headline: Hooligans? I didn't see any
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Along with my fellow American correspondents here, I licked my chops at the prospect of reporting on the soccer hooligans at Euro 2000, reports TR Reid, the Washington Post's London bureau chief.
fields.body:
Along with my fellow American correspondents here, I licked my chops at the prospect of reporting on the soccer hooligans at Euro 2000. After all, Europeans in general, and Britons in particular, are constantly stereotyping my country as a dangerous and violent place to live. But Euro 2000 offered the prospect of a uniquely European version of loutish violence - one that Americans have never known. Somehow, we manage to go to our own football games without any lethal brawls.

So it was that I looked forward to some rich editorial hooligan-bashing when I set out last weekend for the grimy steel-making town of Charleroi in Belgium and the England-Germany match. I knew I'd never get into the game, but I wasn't there to watch football. I was there to watch football hooligans.

Then something unexpected happened: I became a hooligan sympathiser. I remained sympathetic even after watching the ugly outburst of screaming and chair-throwing that has been characterised as a "riot."

I met a bunch of English football nuts that hot afternoon, and saw the circumstances they were forced to put up with. Virtually all of the so-called "hooligans" I met were actually decent fans who had been shafted outrageously by Uefa and by the host city of Charleroi. Many of them were "detained" for a few hours by chip-on-the-shoulder Belgian police for no crime other than showing up in a relentlessly unhelpful host city and trying to find a spot to watch the game.

One such unfortunate was a 31-year-old Arsenal fan. He told me he had sent off his application for Euro 2000 tickets on the first day of sale last year, requesting seats for any England game. Months later, he received two tickets for a match between Yugoslavia and Slovenia. Thanks a lot, Uefa. The Arsenal man told me that when he went to a website to try to arrange a swap - on the theory that Uefa had probably pulled a similar trick on some poor Slovenian fan - he received an officious email warning him that his tickets would be voided, without refund, if he passed them to any other person.

"It's the real fan who gets passed over," the Arsenal man told me. "The guys in suits and the corporate sponsors get big blocs of seats, and there's nothing left over for me and my mates."

Uefa, in its wisdom, made things even worse by putting the England-Germany match - a high-profile contest between two of the tournament's most populous nations - in one of the smallest venues available. That bizarre choice created a large cohort of potential "hooligans" - thousands of fans who wanted to go to the game but couldn't get anywhere near the stadium.

If I were a fan and found myself with no ticket and no chance of getting one, I wouldn't dream of heading off to Charleroi just to be near the team. But the English fans I met felt differently. Several told me it was even more patriotic to show up and wave the colours when you knew you would never get into the stadium.

And what did Charleroi do to accommodate them? Zero. In Place Charles II, the big central square where the "riot" occurred, there were no outdoor television screens, no loudspeakers, not even a scoreboard. (There was a traffic sign flashing the phrase "Be Fair Play", whatever that means.) The only way the ticketless England fan could see the game was to find a bar that had a TV set, grab a chair, and stay in it. Since the bars had no tolerance for customers who weren't spending money, you had to keep on buying beer, hour after hour, to hold your place until game time.

Some people in the square that Saturday afternoon, perhaps 100 or more, were swinish thugs who seemed to be looking for trouble from the beginning. They seemed to enjoy stripping to the waist and showing off their tattoos for the TV cameras. But even those real-life hooligans would have been easier to handle if the overall situation hadn't been managed so badly.

I concluded that a good portion of the hooligan problem in Charleroi was a Uefa creation. The lords of football steered thousands of English fans into a hot, crowded area where they were essentially required to keep consuming beer all day just to see the soccer game. Over time, the heat and the beer and the general frustration exploded into the chair-throwing melée that everyone has now seen a hundred times on the television news.

Uefa and the mayor of Charleroi responded with pious pronouncements that put all the blame on "les hooligans Anglais". But that's not the way I wrote it for my newspaper.

Euro 2000 Official site
Football Unlimited
Football Association
National Criminal Intelligence Service

 TR Reid is the Washington Post's London bureau chief

webTitle: With a gabble, gabble here and a cluck, cluck there

fields.headline: With a gabble, gabble here and a cluck, cluck there
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister had given his account of the European summit meeting in Portugal. It was a download rather than a statement; Mr Blair spoke at around 9,600 baud, letting the words tumble out as if he had an urgent appointment with a dirty nappy.
fields.body:
The prime minister had given his account of the European summit meeting in Portugal. It was a download rather than a statement; Mr Blair spoke at around 9,600 baud, letting the words tumble out as if he had an urgent appointment with a dirty nappy.

Mr Hague rose to agree with some parts of this sustained gabble: the single market, the campaign against drugs and so on. Then he added: "May I also congratulate him on the fact that after many years of difficult negotiations, carefully crafted compromises and repeated isolation, he has finally got the foreign secretary and the chancellor to talk to each other?"

This is becoming the standard, template Hague joke: a three-section series of cliches, followed by a punchline which reverses the listener's expectation. It's fairly amusing, but it is becoming predictable; he may soon hear MPs chanting along with him.

Anyhow, Robin Cook turned to Gordon Brown and smiled incredulously, as if it were the most hilariously misbegotten joke he had ever heard. The very thought, he seemed to imply, that we might not be the closest of friends! Why, his heartfelt grin seemed to say, we are famous as the David and Jonathan of British politics!

Mr Brown's facial response was slightly less enthusiastic. For there is no reason to believe that this rift is at an end. Like those Sherlock Holmes stories in which it turns out that the murder was committed because of events in Utah 50 years earlier, this feud dates back to a dark Caledonian revenge tragedy.

Back in 1972, young Robin, having been secretary of the Edinburgh Labour party, moved to seek his political fortune in London. Gordon, five years younger, and then the student rector of Edinburgh university, went to ask for his backing as the next party boss.

"I'm sure you'll be very successful," said Robin, but refused to give him his public support. Gordon has neither forgotten nor forgiven. Periodically, kind friends and colleagues try to mortice them together, but after a short chat, this invariably fails.

All this may seem bewilderingly trivial to you, especially compared to the question of the euro, or events in Sierra Leone, but that is to underestimate the sheer swirling maelstrom of hatred which is the Scottish Labour party, upon which umbrage lies as thick as winter snow on Ben More.

Earlier, during prime minister's questions, Mr Hague tried to stir up trouble over the probable decision not to let the NHS prescribe beta interferon for multiple sclerosis sufferers. Mr Blair had done his homework - it turned out, to nobody's surprise, that the Tories had also rationed expensive drugs - so Mr Hague contented himself with one of those soundbites which he and his team pray will make the early evening news: "He is blaming everybody else for every problem which ever comes into his view."

The smartest riposte came from David Amess, the Tory MP who took the "chicken run" from Basildon to Southend before the last election. Two weeks ago his question was greeted by loud and sustained avian noises from Labour MPs. Yesterday they started again. "Quurrrp!" someone said as he rose. "Order!" yelled the Speaker. "Farmyard noises are not allowed in this house!"

Mr Amess said gently: "I've got some food for them," and waved what appeared to be a bag of corn. It was a neat reply, and I suspect he won't have much trouble now.

What a pity some other mild, conciliatory gesture could not solve the quarrel between Messrs Cook and Brown.

webTitle: BBC1 chief under fire for below par product

fields.headline: BBC1 chief under fire for below par product
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The future of the BBC1 controller, Peter Salmon, looked bleak last night after the corporation's governors said that his channel's output was not up to scratch.
fields.body:
The future of the BBC1 controller, Peter Salmon, looked bleak last night after the corporation's governors said that his channel's output was not up to scratch.

In their annual report, the governors said the average quality of programmes on the channel was "still not good enough": it was the third year of criticism for BBC1. In general, standards at the BBC "were simply too variable". The director general, Greg Dyke, announced more money for programmes, but avoided a direct endorsement of Mr Salmon.

Presenting the report, the BBC chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, said: "BBC television programmes as a whole did not reach a high enough level of quality and ambition and the average quality of programmes across the year on BBC1 needs to be improved."

Mr Dyke said the problem was partly to do with money and announced an extra £15m for television this year, to be achieved through efficiency savings. "No one sets out to make a real bummer," Mr Dyke said. "BBC1 had some outstanding programmes last year, more than previous years, but what we need to do is spread them across the year." There would be "fundamental change".

Asked if the fault lay with Mr Salmon, Mr Dyke skirted the question. He did not want to be drawn into a "football manager" scenario, he said, implying that a team boss is condemned when the club chairman voices his confidence. Sir Christopher said: "The answer is that we're satisfied with nobody's performance at the BBC. There are areas where everybody can get better."

BBC chiefs confirmed that they were considering big changes for the TV channels. In a speech approved by Mr Dyke, the director of television, Mark Thompson, last week raised the possibility of turning BBC1 and BBC2 into "genre based" channels, with entertainment on one and serious programmes on the second. Two more networks could air youth and cultural programmes.

But the plans could run into problems with the government, which yesterday announced a tough set of criteria which would have to be met by the BBC if it wants to change the nature of its public service commitments, such as launch new channels. The culture sec retary, Chris Smith, said: "The BBC should do what it does well and continue to act as a benchmark for quality in broadcasting, but it should not attempt to do everything."

The comments follow sustained lobbying from the BBC's commercial rivals. Sky News claims that BBC News 24 has an unfair advantage and is not a truly public service station, since it does not provide something that the open market fails to deliver. Equally, the BBC's long-term plans to launch a children's channel are opposed by Nickelodeon and the Cartoon Network.

Under the last director general, Sir John Birt, the BBC launched a plethora of new services: Mr Dyke effectively admitted that BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge - which may develop into the third and fourth BBC networks outlined by Mr Thompson - were launched with insufficient funding.

The report also revealed that Sir John received nearly £800,000 in his final year. He was paid a £456,000 salary and a "termination payment" for his early retirement, worth £328,400. He is entitled to a pension of £130,000 annually.

The BBC's woes were alleviated with the announcement that the children's show Tweenies has repeated the success of Teletubbies by generating more than £40m in the past year. The series Walking With Dinosaurs has made £2.3m in programme sales. The turnover of BBC Worldwide, the corporation's commercial arm, is up by 15% from £446m to £514m.
