webTitle: Two held over lorry deaths of immigrants

fields.headline: Two held over lorry deaths of immigrants
fields.standfirst:
As net starts to close on racketeers on the continent, Belgians admit they detained 'similar group' to those who died

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Two Chinese men suspected of being members of the gang responsible for the deaths of 58 illegal immigrants in a lorry at Dover have been arrested, Kent police revealed last night.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso, Jeevan Vasagar, Vivek Chaudhary in Puurs and Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
Two Chinese men suspected of being members of the gang responsible for the deaths of 58 illegal immigrants in a lorry at Dover have been arrested, Kent police revealed last night.

The pair, alleged to have played a junior role in the operation, are from London and surrendered to police in Kent on Tuesday evening.

A police source confirmed that the men, who are being held in Canterbury, were not the two survivors, but two suspected gang members involved at a low level. "We're not talking about Mr Big here," he said.

Police were continuing to question the driver of the lorry, and have until the early hours of tomorrow to charge or release him.

Meanwhile in Rotterdam, the Dutch port where the lorry was registered, the justice ministry revealed that it had made a second arrest.

Dutch police confirmed the man they arrested on Tuesday night was Arjan van der Spek, 24, the owner of the white Mercedes lorry, while a second unnamed man also in custody is believed to be van der Spek's 55-year-old father.

A source said: "We are holding them for questioning as long as is necessary. They will be brought before the magistrates on Friday. We don't exclude further arrests."

As the net began to close on the racketeers, it emerged the death toll in the Dover tragedy could have been even greater.

Eight more people tried to board the doomed lorry before it left Rotterdam last weekend, according to a solicitor acting for Chinese asylum applicants.

Wah-Piow Tan said the eight were unable to board because the vehicle was already overcrowded, and remained behind in the Netherlands.

Five families in the UK, who believe relatives of theirs could be among the dead, have contacted the solicitor. Mr Tan will meet Home Office officials to discuss how his clients can come forward without endangering their immigration status.

"My clients are in a grey area. Some of them are awaiting the result of asylum applications and others have been refused asylum but have not yet departed," he said.

"What is required of the Home Office is a political, humanitarian decision to grant exceptional leave to remain to anyone who comes forward with information that can help the police identify these people."

The Belgian interior ministry yesterday admitted that it may have briefly detained some of the 58 who died but had let them walk free because its detention centres were full.

In an admission which is likely to spark a debate about just how effective European cooperation on asylum really is, the Belgian authorities disclosed they had detained a similar group of Chinese asylum seekers just two months ago.

It is customary Belgian practice for asylum applicants to be held in a detention centre, and if their application fails, to be flown back to their country of origin.

In this case, police simply told the Chinese to leave Belgium and put them on a train to the port city of Antwerp unescorted.

Controversially, the group was told to steer clear of countries which along with Belgium have signed up to the Schengen open borders agreement - the UK has not.

No Belgian official bothered to check what became of them and the episode has drawn criticism from Kent police.

A source complained: "The Belgians openly send people out of Belgium without escorting them, which obviously opens up the opportunity for them to come into the UK."

Another source said: "I would say that we have an excellent relationship with their police. But the sort of decision we are looking at is a political issue."

Belgium's interior ministry yesterday said that it had fingerprinted the Chinese group, intercepted on April 16 in two villages near Antwerp called Bornem and Puurs.

These fingerprints have been passed to the British police who are trying to establish a match. Officers hope for results later today.

A Belgian police spokesman admitted that the country's immigration service had been aware at the time that the group was involved in "illegal people trading". The country's interior ministry was yesterday adamant, however, that it had done absolutely nothing wrong.

Pascal Smet, a ministry spokesman, told the BBC: "Belgium is not a police state where we put a police agent against every person and where we follow people."

A British Home Office spokesman said: "Immigration by its very nature is a cross-border problem and it's important for us all to work together."

Film footage of the Chinese immigrants taken by a Belgian TV station shows a smartly dressed group of young people, occasionally smiling, and chatting to each other.

It is unclear why they chose to use the sleepy town of Puurs (population 16,000, one pub and zero crime) as a stopping-off point. The exclusively white community of Puurs first noticed two Chinese men arrive in March. They rented a one-bedroom flat which had no furniture and rarely went out.

Greetye Mouton, 35, a baker, said: "They seemed to have a fair amount of money on them, but they spoke no French and very little English.

"All they could say was 'Can we have some bread' or 'give me a Coca Cola'."

But they would buy eight loaves of bread every day which I thought was strange for just two people. But now I realise why they were buying them."

Weeks after the first two arrived a trickle of other Chinese people appeared and within 48 hours the number in creased dramatically. Eventually local residents complained to the authorities. When officials came to have a look they found nine Chinese men asleep inside the flat.

Sixteen more were found wandering around the village, 20 were picked up trying to hitchhike along the busy N16 motorway near Mechelem. Others were rounded up within the vicinity.

In all there were 59 people, 52 men and seven women. Ten were boys aged between 14 and 18.

Three were arrested and the remaining 56 were sent to Antwerp.

fields.headline: Belfast blast increases tensions
fields.standfirst:
Explosion injures two in dissident republican area

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A father and son were badly injured yesterday when an explosive device tore through a garden shed in an area of west Belfast inhabited by republican dissidents, fuelling tensions in Northern Ireland.
fields.byline: Maggie O'Kane  in Belfast and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
A father and son were badly injured yesterday when an explosive device tore through a garden shed in an area of west Belfast inhabited by republican dissidents, fuelling tensions in Northern Ireland.

Both victims were rushed to the Royal Victoria hospital where they were treated for injuries to their head and legs. The younger victim, who is in his 30s, was bleeding heavily and slipping in and out of consciousness.

An RUC spokesman said that neither man's injuries were life threatening. Detectives will interview the men when they have recovered.

Neighbours in the nationalist White Rock area described how they were disturbed by a loud explosion at around 1.30pm yesterday. "The windows shook but we don't know the cause," one neighbour said.

Father Denis McKinley, the local Catholic priest, said that the wife of the victims had told him the two men were in the shed at the time of the blast.

Fr McKinley said: "She told me the men were in the back garden. They were clearing something from the shed, or something like that, and the next thing she heard was the explosion. There was some rumour that one of them lifted a pipe, but it is all bit garbled at this stage and nobody really knows exactly what happened."

Government sources indicated that the two men were known to the police as republican dissident sympathisers. One source said that police will want to interview the men about the injuries they suffered to their fingers during the blast which was caused by one security source described as a "some sort of explosive device".

The explosion heightened tensions in Northern Ireland on the day after loyalist paramilitaries threatened to shoot Catholics in Belfast unless an alleged campaign of intimidation against Protestants is ended. A renegade member of the Ulster Freedom Fighters in west Belfast was being blamed for the warning which appeared to cast doubt over the loyalists' six-year-old ceasefire.

The UFF threat was read out hours after a bomb was found in the grounds of the Queen's official residence at Hillsborough Castle, Co Down. Republican dissidents were blamed for the bomb.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, attempted to strike an upbeat note yesterday despite the threat of continuing violence.

Speaking in the Commons, Mr Mandelson said that he was encouraged by the "comprehensive condemnation" of the UFF statement. "Disturbing as it was, the response to it was actually very encouraging indeed," he told MPs. "It was condemned right across the political spectrum from loyalism to republicanism as well as by the mainstream political parties."

Mr Mandelson was also optimistic that the IRA would give the peace process a boost by living up to its promise to allow international inspectors access to its arms dumps. "I maintain my confidence that the IRA, having made com mitments, will honour those commitments," he said.

However, Mr Mandelson warned paramilitaries on both sides that he would halt the early release of their prisoners if they resorted to violence: "I will be watching very carefully indeed to see if, in the coming weeks and months, there are any paramilitary organisations involved in violence of any kind whether it be in Belfast or Drumcree or elsewhere."

One of the next flashpoints will come on Saturday when an Orange parade makes its way through the mainly Catholic Springfield road area of west Belfast, close to the scene of yesterday's explosion. Sinn Fein has called on the Parades Commission to reverse its decision to allow the Orange march to go ahead.

fields.headline: T-entrapment ploy for festival thieves
fields.standfirst:
Glastonbury 2000: special report
Quiz: Find yourself at the festival
fields.trailText: Glastonbury's canvas city has traditionally been a happy hunting ground for the sneak thief, but this year police are hoping to snare nimble fingers with the help of "undercover" tents.
fields.body:
Glastonbury's canvas city has traditionally been a happy hunting ground for the sneak thief, but this year police are hoping to snare nimble fingers with the help of "undercover" tents.

With spare clothes, personal stereos, and perhaps the odd wallet around, the trap tents will look like any other - but they will be bristling with the latest monitoring equipment.

The first sign of a thief at work will alert police officers , and it is hoped that publicising their presence will help deter crime in the first place. The initiative follows more than 1,300 thefts from tents at last year's festival.

Det Insp Gary Davies, of the Avon and Somerset force, said: "There will be clothes and rucksacks and it will look like anybody else's tent. There might be some goods around that are quite tempting to steal, but if we see a thief we'll spring the trap."

Gates were opening yesterday at Worthy Farm, Pilton, near Glastonbury, Somerset, and 100,000 revellers are expected by the time the main events begin on Friday, by which time 30,000 tents are expected to be erected.

webTitle: Greeks called on to defend faith

fields.headline: Greeks called on to defend faith
fields.trailText: In the biggest demonstration of the Orthodox faithful since the restoration of democracy in 1974, hundreds of thousands of Greeks crammed in and around Athens's central square last night to hear Archbishop Christodoulos implore them to give their all in the battle "to save our faith".
fields.body:
In the biggest demonstration of the Orthodox faithful since the restoration of democracy in 1974, hundreds of thousands of Greeks crammed in and around Athens's central square last night to hear Archbishop Christodoulos implore them to give their all in the battle "to save our faith".

The row over religious affiliation being dropped from national identity cards assumed dramatic proportions as the country's spiritual leader came close to calling a holy war.

Standing on a platform emblazoned with the words "Hellas-Europe-Orthodoxy", the archbishop gave a speech that puts the church on a collision course with the state.

"First they will take religion off the IDs, then they will take the cross off the Greek flag and religion will not be taught in schools. Enough is enough," he said from a podium in Syndagma Square, overlooking the parliament building.

"We are against the homogenisation of Europe... we should resist changes that strip us of our national traits," he thundered as the crowd cheered.

"They have used this issue," he said, referring to the prime minister Costas Simitis's decision to abolish the tradition of recording religious beliefs on official documents, "as an excuse to divide the nation".

"But I say we are a small religious minority in Europe and we want to declare our faith... whoever thinks that Europe has to be one and the same thing is condemned," he boomed.

He said the reform was tantamount to stripping Greeks of their identity, given the church's historic role in safeguarding Hellenism through 400 years of Ottoman overlordship.

Government officials fear that the massive turn-out, only two days after Greece was formally inducted into the EU's cherished Eurozone, could derail the socialist government's determination to press ahead with badly needed reforms.

Even worse, many are afraid that the archbishop - who is backed by a "parliament" of 80 bishops and has mass appeal among Greek youth - has political ambitions.

webTitle: Fashion magazines agree to ban use of unhealthily thin models

fields.headline: Fashion magazines agree to ban use of unhealthily thin models
fields.trailText: Fashion magazines are to adopt a self-regulatory code under which they will refuse to use unhealthily thin models and blacklist agencies which persistently provide them.
fields.body:
Fashion magazines are to adopt a self-regulatory code under which they will refuse to use unhealthily thin models and blacklist agencies which persistently provide them.

In a pioneering move, which follows growing pressure from readers amid alarm at an escalation in the numbers of women suffering from eating disorders, the planned code is also aimed at encouraging the fashion industry to produce and promote clothes for a wider range of body sizes and shapes.

Advertisements which use images of ultra-thin women, or which promote plastic surgery in an unacceptable way, could also be banned.

Meanwhile, in a further move prompted by the government-organised body image summit yesterday, the broadcasting standards commission is to monitor media images on television in an attempt to evaluate whether a sufficiently diverse group of women appear as presenters and guests.

The full details of how the study will be conducted are yet to be decided. But Conservatives were quick to criticise it as "fatty monitoring".

The offer to adopt a code of self-regulation - similar to the code covering privacy adopted by newspapers - was put forward by magazine editors at yesterday's summit.

Ministers are concerned at evidence that media images of super-thin models are stripping women of their confidence and self-esteem.

Although the government will not issue its own prescriptive regulations on the issue to the media or fashion industries, Tessa Jowell, the minister for women, is concerned at the potential influence of images such as the superwaif and "heroin chic" shots in fashion magazines.

Around 1m people in the UK are estimated to suffer from an eating disorder, the majority of them women.

Teenage girls are particularly at risk, according to recent research, but children as young as six are also conscious of pressure to lose weight.

According to a study on body image, eating disorders and the media published this year by the British Medical Association, models and actresses today generally have 10-15% body fat whereas the average body fat for a healthy woman is 22-26%.

The self-regulatory body will be made up of top magazine editors, fashion stylists, photographers and young readers who will monitor the contents of fashion pages and keep a check on the model industry.

The editor of Marie Claire magazine, Liz Jones, said: "The fashion industry is a very rarefied world and I think it has become a bit divorced from reality recently.

"A code of self-regulation would mean that if an agency sent us a very thin model whose bones were showing through her skin, then we would send her back and write to the agency as well as other magazines telling them not to use her."

The Conservatives attacked the BSC monitoring of women on television as ludicrous. The shadow minister for women Theresa May said: "This is political correctness gone mad.

"What is Tessa Jowell going to do - sit there holding cut out shapes at the screen? Or is she going to insist that Vanessa Feltz puts her weight back on?"

fields.headline: Cash crisis threat to Labour
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour is struggling to raise money from wealthy business people in the latest signal that industry's love affair with Tony Blair is over.
fields.body:
Labour is struggling to raise money from wealthy business people in the latest signal that industry's love affair with Tony Blair is over.

Party officials charged with creating a war chest to fight next year's election are finding it increasingly difficult to persuade would-be donors to part with their money - a clear sign that the broad coalition which swept Labour into power is under severe strain.

The head of Millbank's business unit is to quit his post next month as well-heeled sympathisers and former supporters refuse to back the party financially. Labour said Tim Bush, 38, a former PricewaterhouseCoopers accountant, wanted to "return to a commercial career for personal reasons" after working for the party for two and a half years.

His departure underlines the problems faced by Mr Blair. "They've either not got the money, don't want to donate any more or can't stand the hassle," said a key figure involved in discussions with donors. "The climate has definitely changed since 1997 and the honeymoon after the victory."

The reluctance of wealthy figures to fill the party's coffers leaves Labour more heavily dependent on the unions, which will shortly promise around £8m for the election war chest. But they are also proving troublesome; the Communications Workers Union is refusing to increase its political levy to raise an extra £200,000.

Labour is also haemorrhaging members. Officially the total has fallen from 405,000 to 387,776 since the election. However, senior party figures believe the true membership is nearer the 305,000 inherited by Mr Blair from John Smith in 1994.

Three years ago defeating the Tories cost Labour £26m but the pressure will be eased next year by the proposed £20m cap on election spending for each party. Ministers and Labour officials are now confident the proposed ceiling will be law by the election, even if Mr Blair sticks to his original plan and calls a spring poll.

The bill imposing the cap is currently becalmed in the House of Lords where a legislative logjam is building up.

Recent speculation suggested that ministers would not mind jettisoning the bill, which would postpone the cap until the following election. That would have given Labour the freedom to spend far more than £20m in order to ensure a historic second term for the party.

But ministers and officials, aware of the uphill task to raise £20m, let alone £26m, have decided to make the cap a priority.

Labour is also aware that the finances of the Conservatives, which are currently reliant on Lord Ashcroft, could be transformed by the decision of Paul Sykes, the Yorkshire Eurosceptic multimillionaire, to rejoin the Tory party.

He had been planning to give the anti-single currency Democracy Movement as much as £20m and has already hinted he may be willing to give the Tories a minimum of £2m.

Labour's relationship with big business has cooled after a series of clashes over employment rights, the high pound, the minimum wage and new business regulations.

The party's decision to name all donors over £5,000 - copied by the Tories after the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, declared it would be enshrined in law - has put off some supporters who fear the attendant publicity.

"The system needed cleaning up and we have done it," said a Millbank source. "If we were to take a short-term hit as a result, creating some sort of short-term problems, we just have to say it was the right thing to do. We needed to restore public trust in politics."

Labour's target is to raise 40% of its funds from small donors, 30% from unions, 20% from big donors and 10% from commercial activities.

Party accounts for last year, due to be published next month, are expected to show Labour operating a small surplus. It is the election fund that is worrying party bosses .

Ahead of the 1997 election, Labour pocketed six donations of £1m or more plus another two worth £500,000. Lord Sainsbury of Turville was one of the £1m donors and, after becoming science minister, disclosed last year that he had handed over another £2m.

But Bernie Ecclestone, the Formula One magnate, is unlikely to donate again after Mr Blair sent back his seven-figure gift during the row over tobacco advertising. Another member of the £1m club, Matthew Harding, the deputy chairman of Chelsea football club, died in a helicopter crash.

The party has also fallen out with the former boss of Creation records, Alan McGee, once a favourite at Downing Street receptions, after he accused Mr Blair of copying Conservative policies.

A trawl of the accounts of 3,000 public and private companies by the independent Labour Research Department before Christmas found only 10 had donated £200 or more to the party.

fields.headline: Victims of 'criminal complacency'
fields.standfirst: Life support failure: 200 children an hour die in vain
fields.trailText: Children in the world's poorest countries are dying at the rate of almost 200 a hour as a direct result of the failure of governments to fulfil their pledges to slash global poverty by 2015, the charity Oxfam will warn this week.
fields.body:
Children in the world's poorest countries are dying at the rate of almost 200 a hour as a direct result of the failure of governments to fulfil their pledges to slash global poverty by 2015, the charity Oxfam will warn this week.

Amid growing controversy over whether the fruits of globalisation are reaching impoverished nations, Oxfam is accusing politicians in both the rich North and the poor South of "comprehensively reneging" on international development commitments made in Copenhagen five years ago.

Its study found that child mortality was declining at less than half the rate needed to meet the target of cutting the number of child deaths by two-thirds by 2015. In 15 year's time, 8.5m children under 5 would be dying, compared to a UN target of 4.7m.

"This is not a future crisis. If governments were on track for meeting the 2015 target there would be 1.7m fewer child deaths this year," said Kevin Watkins, Oxfam's senior policy adviser and author of the report. "The figures reflect a criminal complacency on the part of governments willing to tolerate mass poverty in the midst of rising global prosperity."

He added that governments in the North had cut aid budgets, kept their markets closed and "put debt repayments before the lives of children", while southern governments had failed to give priority to the poor in their budgets.

Governments are meeting at a United Nations conference in Geneva next week to assess what has happened to the Copenhagen commitments since 1995. Officially, the conference is expected to conclude that the picture has been mixed with progress being made on some indicators of poverty. But Oxfam said the review bore "all the hallmarks of a face-saving exercise designed to mislead public opinion. The real record is shameful."

Clare Short, the international development secretary, said Britain had led the cam paign to focus aid policies on meeting the 2015 targets. "Progress has been made between 1980 and 1999; for example, malnutrition was reduced. The proportion of underweight children fell in developing countries from 37% to 27% and that of stunted children from 47% to 33%. What we need now is stronger pressure, particularly on developing country governments that are not focused on poverty reduction, so that we can achieve faster progress in more countries."

Ms Short is planning to bring out a government white paper on globalisation this year. An early draft backs the idea of using further trade liberalisation as a prime tool in the fight against poverty.

Despite the setback to the globalisation agenda caused by the failure of last year's trade talks in Seattle, Britain is backing behind-the-scenes attempts to secure an early resumption of negotiations for a new trade round as soon as possible after this year's US presidential elections.

The department for international development is also looking at a recent World Bank paper which argues that the world's poor will benefit as much as any other group from the policy prescriptions associated with globalisation - free markets, control of inflation and trade liberalisation.

However, Oxfam said that growth alone was not enough to combat poverty. "Contrary to the claims of the World Bank, there is clear evidence that globalisation is intensifying income inequalities. At a national level, poor people are excluded from market opportunities by inadequate access to assets, poor health and limited education. At a global level, the benefits of increased trade and investment are be ing captured by rich countries."

Mr Watkins said there was no chance of hitting the 2015 targets unless there was redistribution in favour of the poor. He condemned the bank's "return to the failed trickle-down policies of the 80s".

The charity's study showed that in addition to the backsliding on child mortality, world governments were also lagging well behind on their promises to provide universal primary education by 2015 and to halve the number of people living on $1 a day or less.

The charity said it was not too late to make up the ground lost since 1995. "The world doesn't lack the resources to prevent unnecessary child death, or get children into school, it lacks the leadership and political will needed to translate commitments into concrete action."

webTitle: Missing son's family fear the worst

fields.headline: Missing son's family fear the worst
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: A Chinese family who fear that their youngest son may have died in the Dover container tragedy have been located in Fujian province, where the group of illegal migrants is thought to have originated.
fields.body:
A Chinese family who fear that their youngest son may have died in the Dover container tragedy have been located in Fujian province, where the group of illegal migrants is thought to have originated.

Liu Yide, a poor villager living in Tantou, says his son Liu Yifeng, 25, phoned home on June 14 from Europe, saying that he would cross to England on June 19 from Holland.

Liu's family paid a deposit of 20,000 renminbi (£1,500) to a "snakehead" gang of human smugglers to transport their son to England from Fujian. The remaining fee of 220,000 renminbi (£16,540) was to be paid from his earnings once he found a job in England.

There is no direct evidence so far connecting Liu Yifeng with the container deaths, but the date of his expected arrival coincides with the discovery at Dover. The Liu family are said to be desperate for news.

Fujian province has a long tradition of migration abroad and has been the focus of the Chinese government's efforts to curb human trafficking.

A Hong Kong journalist who located Mr Liu was harassed by thugs, apparently connected with a snakehead gang, who tried to seize his equipment.

The details which he obtained of the son's travel from China, published in yesterday's Ming Pao newspaper, throw expose the ease with which illegal migrants can move from Asia to Europe.

The Liu family lives on the estuary of the Min river downstream from the provincial capital of Fuzhou. The area has been a traditional source of emigration since the last century. Government slogans are pasted on village walls urging the inhabitants to "take responsibility for cracking down on illegal emigration".

In March, the Fujian government said that it had detained 171 snakeheads since the beginning of the year, and claimed it had "successfully eliminated human smuggling from this part of the coast".

Liu Yifeng was keen to follow the example of successful migrants from the village who have reached Japan or North America.

The Liu family house is described as bare and dilapidated. But many other houses have been built to western standards with money sent back by successful migrants.

England was chosen as a destination mainly because the snakehead fee for the US has risen to an exorbitant 400-500,000 renminbi (£30,000-37,600), following tougher measures by the US authorities last year.

The family waved off Liu Yifeng on March 23 at Fuzhou airport, when he flew via Beijing to Belgrade. The snakehead organisers had obtained a legitimate Serbian tourist visa for him.

Liu Yifeng then crossed into Hungary where he remained for two months, phoning home regularly until the call which was received last week.

"If I don't get to England," Liu Yifeng told his family, according to the Ming Pao report, "I'll have to return to Beijing because my money has run out."

The Chinese foreign ministry has said it will renew its crackdown on snakehead gangs following the latest tragedy. A spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said on Tuesday that China is "willing to cooperate with the governments of relevant countries to crack down on this cross-border crime".

The Chinese press has published some details of the container deaths including the news that all of the migrants were Chinese. The People's Daily said yesterday that members of the Chinese community in England were "rushing to Dover to establish whether they had relatives among the dead".

But yesterday's Fujian press carried no further details beyond what had been printed nationally.

This is a sensitive subject for China, involving both border security and its international reputation. It remains to be seen whether Chinese journalists are sent to tackle the snakeheads in their lairs.

In Hong Kong yesterday, a Chinese official at Beijing's liaison office, Wang Fengchao, said the mainland and Hong Kong were stepping up surveillance of suspected snakehead activities, but that the problem could never be entirely eliminated.

Border guards at Beijing airport are said to have intercepted 3,000 would-be migrants seeking to leave with false documents last year.

The Liu family are said to be desperate for news. Fujian province has a long tradition of migration abroad and has been the focus of the Chinese government's efforts to curb human trafficking. A Hong Kong journalist who located Mr Liu was harassed by thugs, apparently connected with a snakehead gang, who tried to seize his equipment. The details which he obtained of the son's travel from China, published in yesterday's Ming Pao newspaper, throw expose the ease with which illegal migrants can move from Asia to Europe. The Liu family lives on the estuary of the Min river downstream from the provincial capital of Fuzhou. The area has been a traditional source of emigration since the last century. Government slogans are pasted on village walls urging the inhabitants to "take responsibility for cracking down on illegal emigration". In March, the Fujian government said that it had detained 171 snakeheads since the beginning of the year, and claimed it had "successfully eliminated human smuggling from this part of the coast". Liu Yifeng was keen to follow the example of successful migrants from the village who have reached Japan or North America. The Liu family house is described as bare and dilapidated. But many other houses have been built to western standards with money sent back by successful migrants. England was chosen as a destination mainly because the snakehead fee for the US has risen to an exorbitant 400-500,000 renminbi (£30,000-37,600), following tougher measures by the US authorities last year. The family waved off Liu Yifeng on March 23 at Fuzhou airport, when he flew via Beijing to Belgrade. The snakehead organisers had obtained a legitimate Serbian tourist visa for him. Liu Yifeng then crossed into Hungary where he remained for two months, phoning home regularly until the call which was received last week. "If I don't get to England," Liu Yifeng told his family, according to the Ming Pao report, "I'll have to return to Beijing because my money has run out." The Chinese foreign ministry has said it will renew its crackdown on snakehead gangs following the latest tragedy. A spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said on Tuesday that China is "willing to cooperate with the governments of relevant countries to crack down on this cross-border crime". The Chinese press has published some details of the container deaths including the news that all of the migrants were Chinese. The People's Daily said yesterday that members of the Chinese community in England were "rushing to Dover to establish whether they had relatives among the dead". But yesterday's Fujian press carried no further details beyond what had been printed nationally. This is a sensitive subject for China, involving both border security and its international reputation. It remains to be seen whether Chinese journalists are sent to tackle the snakeheads in their lairs. In Hong Kong yesterday, a Chinese official at Beijing's liaison office, Wang Fengchao, said the mainland and Hong Kong were stepping up surveillance of suspected snakehead activities, but that the problem could never be entirely eliminated. Border guards at Beijing airport are said to have intercepted 3,000 would-be migrants seeking to leave with false documents last year.

fields.headline: Pioneer got £1 for hyperlink discovery
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
BT
fields.trailText: When the next list of net pioneers graces the pages of an influential, glossy magazine, one name might stand out as rather odd, because 73-year-old Desmond Sargent is no pony-tailed dot.com billionaire, nor is he a tech-talking academic.
fields.body:
When the next list of net pioneers graces the pages of an influential, glossy magazine, one name might stand out as rather odd, because 73-year-old Desmond Sargent is no pony-tailed dot.com billionaire, nor is he a tech-talking academic.

But Mr Sargent can, according to US patent 4,873,662, claim to have invented one of the world wide web's building blocks. His work for the Post Office in 1976 led to a crucial breakthrough by creating "hyperlinks" - the technology that allows web users to move from one page to another by clicking on text or pictures.

The patent is now the property of BT, which analysts say will reap hundreds of millions of pounds from Mr Sargent's work."I can't see me making much money out of it - I was an employee of BT at the time," he says. "American law says the chap who writes the patent actually has to have a dollar. So all you get is a dollar."

Mr Sargent got his money - and still has the two postal orders he was sent to prove it. But Mr Sargent, who worked for the Post Office and then British Telecom for 42 years, is philosophical about his lack of reward, even in the face of the multi-billion dollar economy his creation may have helped to create and the windfall it could hand his former employers. "At the time I was a bit fed up. I felt the inventions definitely had more value."

His advances were strikingly prescient. Mr Sargent's hyperlinks underlie the web, which is regarded as having been invented by academic Tim Berners-Lee. He built the first web server and browser in 1990 while working at European Particle Physics Laboratory in Geneva.

Mr Sargent says he recognises many of the functions of the web. "We were limited by the fact we had a telephone keypad to give answers back to the system, and so were limited to 0-9, rather than words used on the net today. It's a bit more polished now."

Although Mr Sargent's work was completed in the 1970s, BT was not granted a patent until 1989. But the company's move to capitalise on his research has been in the pipeline for two years.

"BT got in touch with me some time ago just to sort of tell me they were considering doing it, so it has not come as a complete surprise. I think they were just checking I was still alive," he said.

He admits that it feels strange that his technology is creating such a fuss a quarter of a century after its development, and years after Prestel - the British online information service launched in the 1980s - was closed. "It is rather nice that it is being followed up, because I've always been a bit disappointed with Prestel - it never really took off properly."

Mr Sargent, who was in charge of the then precious resource of computers used for experimentation, became involved with Prestel after a discussion over lunch with his boss at the Post Office's Martelsham research site. "My boss had written out the sort of thing he wanted to do with this information service, but he couldn't actually get it implemented. Over lunch one day I said 'why don't we call it an experiment and share it among everyone else', and that is how I got involved.

"It went on from there and we demonstrated it all over the world. Every nation pretty well knew about it [Prestel]. We'd demonstrated it all over the world. The Canadians and the Americans didn't really want to use our system - they wanted to use their own, and so did the French. They used the same system, but with a minor quirk, just so they could call it French.

"The idea from the research department's point of view was simply to get people to use more telephone time. Here was a method by which we could do it."

Mr Sargent sees the irony in the fact, even now, he uses his telephone more for talking than hooking up his PC, although this week's furore may begin to change that. "I don't use the web very much, really, although all this has prompted me to do a bit more and learn what it is all about."

webTitle: Malaise at the heart of football

fields.headline: Malaise at the heart of football
fields.standfirst: As calls are made to limit foreign players, analysts blame lack of style and structure
fields.trailText: As calls are made to limit foreign players, analysts blame lack of style and structure.
fields.byline: Jamie Wilson, Patrick Wintour  and  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.body:
The government yesterday urged British football to introduce a voluntary quota on the number of foreign players, blaming England's premature departure from Euro 2000 on the influx of foreign stars to the Premier League.

The call to show restraint was made by the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, who is responsible for overseeing work permits for foreign stars. She insisted that a voluntary curb could be implemented by English clubs and the Football Association without breaching EU laws on the freedom of movement of labour. "It is unrealistic to think European labour market rules can be changed just for football, but there is absolutely nothing to stop football bodies taking control of this themselves," Ms Hodge said. "There is a lot to say for football authorities agreeing among themselves they will only play a proportion of players from abroad. Football clubs do not have to go out and buy foreign players and the European court cannot intervene."

The influx of foreign players has often been highlighted as a contributing factor to the decline of the national side, with claims that footballing mercenaries are taking the places of promising English youngsters who find it increasingly difficult to break into the top sides. The England manager, Kevin Keegan, has himself called for a cap on the number of foreigners, saying his pool of talent is smaller than it should be.

But last night the Premier League sharply disagreed with Ms Hodge, saying quotas would break the Bosman ruling of the European court of justice in 1995 which ruled they were unlawful.

Whatever the outcome of the government's demand, a growing body of opinion in the game believes the national side's poor performance at Euro 2000 had little to do with the number of foreign players in the Premiership, and more with the structure and style of football in England.

On the surface English football has never been in ruder health. The Premier League has just signed one of the most lucrative television deals in football history, bringing £1.6bn into the game over the next three years. Even on the continent few would argue that England has one of the most exciting leagues. Top stars can earn anything from £20,000 to £50,000 a week. In financial terms the Premiership is the biggest league in the world, with a turnover of £169m more than its nearest rival, Italy's Serie A.

But despite the huge sums of money that have been injected into domestic football, the national side has consistently failed to make it at the highest level, displaying skills far below that of its supposedly poorer counterparts. According to some analysts, at the heart of the problem is the massive discrepancy between the biggest clubs and the grassroots.

The Premier League, formed in 1992 when the top clubs broke away from the rest of the football league to secure more revenue from television, is a money making machine for the top clubs, which have become multimillion pound businesses in their own right.

Grassroots problems

According to accountants Deloitte and Touche, football has been growing over the last decade at a rate that other businesses would die for, but only a small percentage of the money has filtered down.

The problems at the grassroots level were illustrated by the news yesterday that non-league club Deal Town, who won the amateur FA Vase at Wembley last month, have given their supporters three weeks to raise £20,000 to save the club from folding, a sum for which David Beckham would barely kneel to tie a bootlace.

Alex Fynn, a football consultant who was one of the architects of the Premier League, said that while the rest of Europe operated a pyramid system, with a semi professional level rising up gradually to a showcase top division, in England all the power and money is concentrated at the top. The result is that the national team is seen as a hindrance by many top clubs, who resent the fact they have to release players for international duty. Clubs are unlikely to accept a self imposed quota on foreigners to help the national side when continental players are some of their most important stars.

"Clubs in Europe play fewer games than in England and they play them in such a way as to give the national team time and space to play," Mr Fynn said. "In England the national team has to be fitted around domestic fixtures because of the power and money of the Premier League."

But the problems of English football are not purely financial. According to John Williams, lecturer at the Sir Norman Chester centre for football research at Leicester University, the national team's failings can be attributed to "an almost wilful desire not to modernise".

"English football has always had a fear of thinkers and tacticians, preferring instead to rely on size, speed, brute force and team spirit. But when it comes to international football you need to be able to think on the ball."

Competitive matches are played at a very young age by footballers whose skills have not been properly developed. In many countries, including Holland, Spain and Romania, the emphasis until the age of 11 or 12 is on ball skills rather than playing competitive matches.

The one possible light on the horizon for English football are the 40 youth academies set up across the country by Premier and football league clubs. The FA hopes the academies will be a breeding ground for future international stars.

The academy system has allowed clubs for the first time to have sole power over the footballing programme of children as young as nine years old. But even at academy level the clubs appear to be set on a collision course with the needs of the national team that is likely to bring them into conflict with the Football Association. Premier League first teams do not observe national boundaries, and there is little reason to imagine their youth academies will either. According to Mike Kelleher, the administrator of the academies for the Premier League, at some point the clubs are going to want to bring young players from all over the world into their academies, forcing out promising English youngsters.

But whatever happens it will be at least six years before the first recruits to the club academies begin to filter through to the national team. Roll on Euro 2008.

Why huge sums of money are no guarantee of success
The star

Phil Neville (Manchester Utd)
Estimated earnings £1.25m and forecast to rise

His mistake may have catapulted his country out of Euro 2000, but that will not prevent Phil Neville thriving. Although he cannot command a regular place in his club side, he is contracted to stay there until 2005.

The 23-year-old earns an estimated £20,000 a week, with endorsements on top. Four years ago he was on £1,000 a week.

Players like Phil Neville, a talent in the English if not the world game, are the fruit United bore from their youth scheme, which produced players such as his brother Gary, David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Nicky Butt.

He captained Manchester United to win the youth cup, making his debut for the first team aged 18 in 1995. A year later he was first picked for England.

The import

Massimo Taibi (Manchester Utd)
Estimated earnings £1m

Taibi's move to Old Trafford represents what can go wrong with big money transfers. He joined United for £4.4m, but his reign as first choice keeper was short-lived after blunders in matches against Chelsea and Southampton, including letting a ball slip through his legs into the net. He was allowed to return to Italy on loan to Serie A team Reggina.

The huge sums involved highlight how much cash some of the top clubs have to spend, but also shows that spending such sums does not guarantee success.

Undeterred, Manchester United have now spent £10m on Fabien Barthez to plug a hole in their defence.

The chairman

Peter Boizot (Peterborough Utd)
Football earnings Nil

After making a £40m fortune from the Pizza Express chain, Mr Boizot took control of his home town club Peterborough United four years ago and last season the team won promotion to Division Two for the first time in six seasons.

It is Boizot's large pockets, not the trickle down of the Premiership's riches, that keeps the club in business.

Despite having the best attendences in Division Three last season and the fact that all its players earn less than £1,000 a week each, the club runs at an estimated loss of £20,000 a week and had to sell two of its best young players last season. Boizot hopes Peterborough's football academy will turn his club into "the Manchester United of East Anglia".

The fan

Ed Saunders, 33
Football earnings Nil

Dedicated football fans are, if Manchester United's board is to be believed, the people who pay the players wages, yet their influence on the development of the game is minor.

Mr Saunders, a QPR fan from London, believes that the English players' lack of technical ability, the number of foreign players and a paucity of resources for non-Premiership clubs are hampering the British game.

"The difference between the Premiership and the other leagues is vast. If you don't have the money then it's very difficult to improve," he said.

The failure

Chris Sutton (Chelsea)
Estimated earnings £1.25m

A season of failure with his club and a probable transfer at a reduced fee is unlikely to damage Sutton's earning power.

Last summer he moved from relegated Blackburn Rovers to Chelsea for £10m, hoping that success there would get him back in contention for an England place.

Instead this summer Sutton, 26, is being linked to a £6m move to Middlesbrough or Celtic after failing to impress at Stamford Bridge. In a side packed with continental stars with greater technical prowess, he struggled to score goals, getting one in the premiership. His manager had expected 20.

This summer's arrival of the Dutch striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink for £15m left Sutton surplus to requirements.

The hopeful

Jon Harley (Chelsea)
Earns £250 a week

Started as an apprentice at Chelsea and broke into the first squad in April 1998. His spell in the first team was short-lived, however, some would say due to the influx of the "foreign legion". But it is a claim he is quick to dismiss.

"If you're good enough you will get your chance," he said. "It just shows that, if young players are ready, they will come through."

He said that the quality of the imports was beneficial to everyone at the club. "It might be an issue if they were buying players who aren't that great and were blocking English players just as good."

The 20-year-old has signed a new three-and-a-half year deal and got back into the first team last season with a run in Chelsea's FA Cup squad.

The coach

John Robinson, 31
Coaches kids voluntarily
Football earnings: Nil

Football coaches, whether they run a local youth team, or simply help develop children's skills, are at the bottom of the football funding food chain.

"It's important to improve skills, but there's not the funding available," said Mr Robinson, of Coventry. "The money that is around goes no further than the football clubs because the FA is trying to put money into academies. Children's teams don't really get any funding."

Football Unlimited
Football Association
National Criminal Intelligence Service

webTitle: Nats warns of more delays to flights

fields.headline: Nats warns of more delays to flights
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A warning that flights over Britain might still be subject to delay this summer has been issued to airlines by Bill Semple, head of national air traffic services, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A warning that flights over Britain might still be subject to delay this summer has been issued to airlines by Bill Semple, head of national air traffic services, it emerged last night.

This follows last weekend's failure of the flight data processing system at West Drayton, near Heathrow, which caused chaos and delays to thousands of passengers.

A spokesman for Nats said that the fault had been located and was not likely to occur again. He rejected suggestions the computer was "clapped out" but confirmed that it would eventually be replaced in 2007.

It will continue to play "a pivotal role" in the much delayed new air traffic control centre at Swanwick, which should have opened four years ago, but is now due to come on stream in 2002.

The magazine Computer Weekly says today that ministers appear unaware that the computer's software is based on programming which dates back to the 1970s. It says that controllers will still receive their flight data information from the old computer system when Swanwick opens.

webTitle: Entrepreneur with more than ee, bah gum

fields.headline: Entrepreneur with more than ee, bah gum
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
VData
fields.trailText: Peter Wilkinson is Yorkshire to the core. He likes watching Leeds United, visiting his weekend place on the moors and values his privacy - so he will not have his picture published.
fields.body:
Peter Wilkinson is Yorkshire to the core. He likes watching Leeds United, visiting his weekend place on the moors and values his privacy - so he will not have his picture published.

He would rather not face travelling to London and you would probably have to put a gun to his head to persuade him to visit Silicon Valley. But despite all this, the Harrogate based 46-year-old has become one of Britain's most successful internet entrepreneurs.

In 1998 he sold Planet Online, the internet service provider he and colleague Philip Taysom founded three years earlier with backing from Yorkshire property tycoon Paul Sykes, to Energis for £75m.

He then engineered Dixons' hugely successful Freeserve internet access provider, from which he still receives substantial royalties. Last month he agreed to sell Sports Internet, in which he is a 44% shareholder, to BSkyB for £301m.

Now Mr Wilkinson and Mr Taysom are back with another business. They are planning to roll the former's computer company Storm in with their remote data storage business VData and possibly float the combined group.

VBak is an online back-up service for large companies in case disaster strikes their systems. Mr Taysom points out that big firms do not adequately back up their data. "Businesses are relying on computer technology and information more and more but when did you last back up your computer?" he asks.

More than 300 people work for Mr Wilkinson's various businesses in Harrogate and VData is expanding so fast he has taken over National Power's former central computing site next door to house all its data security units.

Nearly all his employees are from Yorkshire and very few leave once they arrive. Many of them worked for Systime with Mr Wilkinson back in the 1970s when it was based in Leeds and was one of Britain's largest computer firms.

"Up here it's a different mindset to London," says Mr Wilkinson. "We're not all ee, bah gum. Wages aren't that much lower and good technology people may be becoming thin on the ground but the quality of life is much higher. You're minutes from some of the most beautiful countryside in the country. It doesn't take you two hours to crawl home through the traffic.

"There's a culture of loyalty. You never see people reading the job pages of the technology press in their lunch hour. They don't feel they have to move south to further their careers. If anything we're taking on people moving north. As long as the dust we keep sprinkling continues to turn to gold I'm hopeful our staff will stay with us.

"Sure there are disadvantages of being up here. If you're running a public company you don't get as much time to schmooze with the analysts and brokers as you would like."

Planet started out in Leeds and Mr Wilkinson is confident the city will continue to go from strength to strength. "Leeds is a go-ahead city. It's a well regarded commercial centre and technology companies grow up around centres like that."

fields.headline: Vocalis ambition pushes up losses
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Vocalis, a developer of speech recognition technology, has formed a joint venture with BT to produce software for people to talk over the internet and listen to emails.
fields.body:
Vocalis, a developer of speech recognition technology, has formed a joint venture with BT to produce software for people to talk over the internet and listen to emails.

Charles Halle, Vocalis' chief executive, said the development of a software speech recognition product, targeting call centres, could deliver the industry big cost savings and improve staff efficiency.

The Vocalis product range includes SpeecHTML that enables companies to offer a phone number which people can call to find information on a website where they can access email messages and reply and delete using voice commands.

SpeechMail is being used by more than 70 internet service providers in the UK, including BT Internet. Vocalis has primarily marketed this product to the consumer market and is now about to target business customers.

However, Vocalis's investment in what is next generation software, and its attempts to build a market leading position, have taken a severe toll on the company's earnings.

The group yesterday reported that its pre-tax loss for the year had grown from £1.1m to £4.5m as Vocalis more than doubled its research and development budget to £2.2m in the year.

Mr Halle added that further investment in staff, systems and infrastructure had also led to the deterioration in earnings. "Following the steps we have taken, we are now well positioned to capitalise on the expected rapid expansion of these markets to create volume businesses," he said.

Even so, the company said it had not received as many equipment orders for its SPEECHtel product in the year, resulting in sales falling 44% to £2.7m.

Shares in Vocalis shed 30p to 240p.

fields.headline: Catalyst for online hot spot
fields.standfirst:
In the final part of our series we report on how the Freeserve concept provided momentum to turn Leeds into an internet capital and how an unemployed engineer turned to helping other people start e-businesses

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: When 42 The Calls, the chic hotel located in three converted corn and flower mills overlooking the old waterfront area on the edge of Leeds city centre, was voted business hotel of the year in 1998, Ajaz Ahmed was working as store manager in the local PC World.
fields.body:
When 42 The Calls, the chic hotel located in three converted corn and flower mills overlooking the old waterfront area on the edge of Leeds city centre, was voted business hotel of the year in 1998, Ajaz Ahmed was working as store manager in the local PC World.

It was his 16th year with the Dixons group and having spent most of that time in the Huddersfield branch of Britain's largest electrical goods retailer, the move into Leeds and the new responsibility it brought with it was a welcome opportunity. However, it was unlikely to bring the 34 -year-old into contact with the local suits who regularly flexed their expense accounts on lunches at the smart brasserie inside 42 The Calls.

Two years on and Mr Ahmed can eat just about anywhere he wants. As business development director of Freeserve, one of the FTSE 100's highest profile companies, he has joined the upper echelons of the Yorkshire business community. His loftspace office overlooks 42 The Calls and if he wants to pop across the road for a quick lunch they are hardly likely to refuse him a table.

A large part of the Leeds economy depends on the internet and technology and Mr Ahmed is one of its leading lights. "Leeds is becoming an internet capital and I think that surprises a lot of people," Mr Ahmed says. "People assume Manchester or Birmingham are likely to be the hot spots outside London but they're not. It's us - 30% of all UK internet traffic is routed through this city. It's a town on the move."

Much of the dot.com momentum has come from Freeserve. Britain's largest internet service provider was founded in Leeds in late 1998. There is some dispute over who came up with the original concept but the story goes something like this: Mr Ahmed, a humble store manager, buys a PC for home but finds that neither he nor anyone who works in his branch is able to access this new thing called the internet.

Banging on doors

Realising that most consumers face the same problem and that the majority of Britain's PCs are sold through the Dixons group, he thinks the chain has an unrivalled chance to become a leading internet player by pre-loading net access on to its computers. Armed with his idea he goes banging on doors at head office only to be dismissed by everyone except corporate development executives John Pluthero and Mark Danby.

Together they work on a concept but cannot make it work until Peter Wilkinson, founder of local internet services company Planet Online, devises a way to offer the service to customers for free, not have to worry about collecting subscriptions and rely on a share of the resulting telephone call charges to generate revenue.

Freeserve was born and the rest, as they say, is history. Today Freeserve's corporate head office is based in the Dixons main office in Hemel Hempstead, Berkshire and Mr Pluthero is its chief executive. But the company's heart still beats from Leeds. A team of 35 designers, producers, engineers and business development staff operate out of a converted warehouse by the docks striking the content deals and building the portal.

Heavily incentivised through equity they spend much of the day checking their online share portfolios to see how the latest takeover speculation is affecting Freeserve's share price. "The success of companies like Freeserve and Planet [now a key subsidiary of telecoms group Energis] has acted as a catalyst to others," says Mr Ahmed, relaxing in an armchair in an open plan office complete with CD rack and inflatable basketball hoop.

"Leeds has always been a very service orientated town full of banks, building societies and call centres. The transport is good as well. I can jump on the train and be in London for a meeting inside 2 hours."

The strength of the local service industry sector and the city's history of innovation - First Direct set the telephone banking revolution rolling from Leeds - has encouraged several hi-tech firms to open offices in the area. More than 10,000 people now work in the Leeds new media industry for companies including Teamtalk, the Press Association, Totalise and Sports.com, according to local e-business consultancy Evaxyx. A further 15,000 people work in call centres for companies like Direct Line, First Direct and BT Cellnet.

The city is now Britain's third largest manufacturing centre and third largest financial centre. In education terms Leeds is second only to London with 45,000 students studying at local institutions.

Citria, which is a London-based e-business solutions company, said it was that skills base which encouraged it to choose Leeds over Birmingham, Liverpool and Manchester when it recently opened its first regional office. "Building e-business isn't possible without the right people and we will move wherever the talent is," said chief executive Chris Potts.

The emergence of the likes of Freeserve and Planet has been a huge relief to locally based professional advisers. "A few years ago businesses were being taken private and we were talking about the death of the PA in Leeds," said Phil Evans, partner at Arthur Anderson. "Now there are several new businesses looking to float. The focus of our work has changed dramatically as a result."

Local development agencies have been keen to replicate the success Leeds has enjoyed in attracting new economy companies in other areas of Yorkshire and the Humber region in need of regeneration. The subsequent emergence of several new firms has led some locals to dub the region Silicon Dale.

Fantastic work force

Steel and coalworks used to belch out fumes across the countryside surrounding Manvers, on the edge of Wath-upon-Dearne in south Yorkshire. Today the heavy industry is largely gone, replaced by acres and acres of call-centres, car parks and cavernous warehouses. EuroTelecom Communications, an AIM listed firm that specialises in building and managing fully networked buildings for hi-tech firms, moved on to the site six weeks ago. "The whole area is buzzing," says chief executive Phil Derry. "The workforce resource here is fantastic, the infrastructure links are excellent and costs are lower than down south."

Further north in Harrogate is the home of Sports Internet, recently bought by BSkyB for £300m. Across in York several biotech and computer companies are conducting pioneering research in the city science park. Sheffield, the steel city, is also catching up and recently spawned Kazoo 3D, a computer graphics firm which listed on AIM less than a year after starting up.

Nick Pascoe, an entrepreneur who runs the northern branch of networking group First Tuesday, says: "The northern business climate comes from manufacturing and is still a bit dour and cynical in places. The old boy network and the grey hairs are still a bit impenetrable, but you only have to walk through Leeds to see how it is changing and becoming more vibrant. That can only be a good thing."

fields.headline: Orchestream Holdings
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Software developer Orchestream Holdings' proposed £213m float was nine times oversubscribed in the initial public offering. The company placed 42m shares at 185p apiece with institutional investors who will own 37% of Orchestream when it floats on June 28.
fields.body:
Software developer Orchestream Holdings' proposed £213m float was nine times oversubscribed in the initial public offering. The company placed 42m shares at 185p apiece with institutional investors who will own 37% of Orchestream when it floats on June 28.

The remainder of the company's share register will be split between management, owning 21% of stock, chip maker Intel and Reuters holding 6% and venture capital firms such as Atlas, Quester, Celtic House and Deutsche Bank.

Investors have been wary of technology stocks which have suffered stomach turning gyrations on Nasdaq and the poor performance of stocks such as Interactive Investor International.

However, Orchestream has proved attractive to investors as it is considered an "infrastructure" stock for the internet and technology sectors.

The company has developed a piece of software which ensures the reliable transmission of data along computer companies' networks using internet protocol (IP) the technology that enables computers to communicate with each over the internet.

The ability to prioritise the transmission of data and ensure its reliability and swiftness is critical. In some companies' call centres, that may mean dealing with customer requests and the need to access data from their computer screens quickly.

However, the explosion in data transmission has meant that IP traffic has become erratic and slow, causing call centres long and costly delays in responding to customers.

Orchestream's technology ensures that less time-sensitive data, such as office emails, are given lower priority over more important services.

Orchestream is expected to use the £49m it raises from its flotation to invest in expanding its research and development team and also increasing and internationalising its staff in sales and marketing.

fields.headline: A pauper prince's palatial quest
fields.trailText: An impoverished German prince will begin the final round of a battle today to inherit £100m-worth of castles, property and a Mediterranean island denied to him by his family because he married a "bourgeois" socialite who later converted to Islam and left him for the Aga Khan.
fields.body:
An impoverished German prince will begin the final round of a battle today to inherit £100m-worth of castles, property and a Mediterranean island denied to him by his family because he married a "bourgeois" socialite who later converted to Islam and left him for the Aga Khan.

The tale of clannish feuding, iron Teutonic principle and divorce involves Prince Karl Emich zu Leiningen, 48, who hopes to convince a "princes' court" in Munich this afternoon of his right to inherit his family's fortunes.

A panel of three German aristocrats, including a judge and the deputy president of the Berlin parliament, Prince Hermann Otto zu Solms-Hohensolms-Lich, will decide whether to overrule the 103-year-old family edict which has prevented him gaining access to his inheritance for nine years.

The merciless squabbling over the Leiningen family assets started in 1991 when Prince Karl chose to defy his 72-year-old mother Princess Eilika and marry the German society beauty and steel magnate's daughter Gabriele Thyssen.

Princess Eilika and her husband, Prince Emich Kyrill, refused to attend the wedding in Venice and formally disinherited their son shortly afterwards. Prince Karl's crime was to have broken a 1897 family edict which stipulates that its members may only marry aristocrats of equivalent status.

"From the very beginning of our marriage I was turned into an enemy. We were both subjected to enormous pressure. No marriage can withstand that sort of thing in the long-term," Prince Karl said in a recent interview,

"I had hoped that things would improve when our child arrived.

"But after our daughter was born, nothing happened. My mother has refused to speak to me since the wedding."

The prince insists that the strains imposed on the marriage by the family feud led his wife to desert him in 1998 when, in a blaze of publicity, Princess Gabriele converted to Islam and ran off with the Aga Khan, who she later married after divorcing the prince.

Since then the prince has been involved in a desperate legal battle to gain the rights to his inheritance, which includes the Mediterranean island of Tago Mago, near the Spanish island of Ibiza, which is used as the family's summer retreat; two stately homes, in Bavaria and the Rhineland Platantinate; and estates in Africa and Canada.

His attempt to gain his in heritance was first thwarted 1991, when his father, then dying of cancer, flew to Munich and instructed his lawyers, from a wheelchair on the airport runway, to cut his son out of his will.

Since then he has been through the German courts, which have ruled against him. The final blow came when the constitutional court in Karlsruhe rejected his appeal.

Every attempt by the prince to gain access to the family fortune has been vehemently opposed by his mother and his brother Prince Andreas, 44.

As a result, he has been left with no option but to resort to the princes court- an aristocratic body which occasionally arbitrates in matters of blue-blooded strife.

"We will do our best to ensure that the two brothers reach an agreement," said the court chairman, Prince Ludwig Eugen zu Wied.

The case will inevitably involve the court making some difficult decisions about the prince's welfare.

Prince Karl has never been equipped to enter a profession: his education consisted purely in being schooled to run the Leiningen family affairs.

He currently lives in a three-storey forester's house on the family estate, which he says he may be forced to leave because he is so short of cash.

Family fortune

Tago Mago - a Mediterranean island close to Ibiza which family and friends use as their summer retreat. The island residence comprises a villa and swimming pool

Amorbach Palais - a 72-room late 19th-century turreted stately home in the Bavarian town of Amorbach

Schloss Waldleiningen - a castle of the same period near Waldleiningen in the Rhineland Palatinate

Estates and farmland in Africa and Canada.

Total assets: £100m.

His attempt to gain his in heritance was first thwarted 1991, when his father, then dying of cancer, flew to Munich and instructed his lawyers, from a wheelchair on the airport runway, to cut his son out of his will. Since then he has been through the German courts, which have ruled against him. The final blow came when the constitutional court in Karlsruhe rejected his appeal. Every attempt by the prince to gain access to the family fortune has been vehemently opposed by his mother and his brother Prince Andreas, 44. As a result, he has been left with no option but to resort to the princes court- an aristocratic body which occasionally arbitrates in matters of blue-blooded strife. "We will do our best to ensure that the two brothers reach an agreement," said the court chairman, Prince Ludwig Eugen zu Wied. The case will inevitably involve the court making some difficult decisions about the prince's welfare. Prince Karl has never been equipped to enter a profession: his education consisted purely in being schooled to run the Leiningen family affairs. He currently lives in a three-storey forester's house on the family estate, which he says he may be forced to leave because he is so short of cash. Family fortune Tago Mago - a Mediterranean island close to Ibiza which family and friends use as their summer retreat. The island residence comprises a villa and swimming pool Amorbach Palais - a 72-room late 19th-century turreted stately home in the Bavarian town of Amorbach Schloss Waldleiningen - a castle of the same period near Waldleiningen in the Rhineland Palatinate Estates and farmland in Africa and Canada. Total assets: £100m.

webTitle: Red faces as autumn schedule gets an unofficial preview

fields.headline: Red faces as autumn schedule gets an unofficial preview
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Salmon, the beleaguered controller of BBC1, is unlikely to be feeling very comfortable this morning. For the third year in a row, his channel has received a roasting from a board of governors who seem to be as perplexed as everyone else that licence fee payers' money is disappearing into a black hole sucking in docu-soaps, dreary sitcoms and poor quality drama.
fields.body:
Peter Salmon, the beleaguered controller of BBC1, is unlikely to be feeling very comfortable this morning. For the third year in a row, his channel has received a roasting from a board of governors who seem to be as perplexed as everyone else that licence fee payers' money is disappearing into a black hole sucking in docu-soaps, dreary sitcoms and poor quality drama.

After hauling the BBC over the coals last year - and demanding a complete rethink of output on BBC1 - it returned to the theme by saying that a key objective to deliver programmes and services of the highest quality, range and ambition had been "only partly met".

In an 80-page report presented to an audience of "representative licence fee payers", the BBC indulged in its annual festival of self-flagellation. "Standards were simply too variable," the governors said of BBC1. "The Royle Family, Dinnerladies and the Vicar of Dibley were not matched by pre-watershed sitcoms of comparable quality."

While the channel was praised for providing a much wider mix of shows in peaktime than ITV, the governors added: "The average quality of programmes across the year on the channel is still not good enough, particularly in the pre-watershed period." Autumn and winter schedules were praised but "insufficient funding" was highlighted as one cause for failing to sustain standards for the year.

If that was not bad enough, a new marketing tool - approval ratings - has shown that the perception of the corporation as the much-loved "Auntie Beeb" is not matched by reality. "BBC1 is not held in the same degree of affection by the public as it once was. Winning that affection back is vital to the future success of the whole BBC," the governors said.

One of Mr Salmon's triumphs at the BBC has been his promotion of the new genre of popular factual programming: docusoaps such as Driving School, Hotel and Airport; and consumer shows such as Changing Rooms have proved huge hits with viewers.

But the governors have detected the sound of dead horses being flogged around White City: the early evening schedules rely too heavily on light factual shows at the ex pense of drama, comedy and serious factual programmes, they said. And sensitive to the argument of cultural snobbishness, they were at pains to point out that it was not that the BBC was too populist, but that the programmes were not "truly distinctive" enough to serve viewers.

This is a recurring problem for the BBC. Does public service broadcasting mean that it should provide programmes that others do not? Or does it have a responsibility to compete in the market with its commercial rivals? Clearly, the answer is both, and the BBC at the moment is failing to get the balance right.

Greg Dyke, BBC director general, announced an extra £15m for BBC1 and BBC2 for this financial year, but recently Mr Salmon said that he needed £100m more and his counterpart at BBC2, Jane Root, pitched for £50m.

Yet while the governors put down BBC1's failures "substantially" to lack of cash, it is not as if the BBC is short of money. The latest licence fee settlement has turned it into a £3bn organisation. Money is not the key to making programmes: imagination and ambition are, say programme makers.

Yet it would be unfair to paint the governors' report as a doom-laden document. The BBC's chairman Sir Christopher Bland said the corporation could be proud of its performance during a tough year: the "distinctiveness, ambition and range" of programmes and services had been maintained "during a year of unprecedented challenge" to the organisation.

The BBC's discomfort over its governors' criticisms of BBC1 were deepened when details leaked on the internet of its "secret" autumn schedule.

Plans for a variety of new shows and returning favourites - kept confidential to prevent rivals from stealing a march - were revealed on the news website annanova.com.

This showed that the BBC has convinced the writer of the hit comedy One Foot in the Grave to pen a new series, and that the corporation has lined up the historian Simon Schama to front a 16-part series, History 2000: the History of Britain, costing £6m.

It is hoped that the series, an ambitious project to document the nation's history, will become a "landmark" programme of the type recently advocated by the culture secretary, Chris Smith. It will also please the BBC's governors, who are determined to see the corporation make more high quality programmes.

Equally, persuading David Renwick to write a new series of the show, starring Richard Wilson as the crotchety Victor Mel drew, is being seen as a coup. "We are thrilled that Victor is back. The character is a legend," said a BBC comedy source quoted by the website.

Among other highlights for the new season is a £3m production of Love in a Cold Climate, Nancy Mitford's comedy of manners. It has been adapted by Deborah Moggach, and follows the fortunes of three upper class girls who dedicate their lives to the pursuit of love.

Filming is already under way, with a cast including Celia Imrie, Frances Barber and Alan Bates.

The three heroines are played by newcomers Elizabeth Dermot Walsh, Rosamund Pike and Megan Dodds.

Drama favorites also figure in the new schedule: Casualty, Holby City, Silent Witness and The Scarlet Pimpernel.

There is new comedy with the Rab C Nesbitt star Gregor Fisher; Caroline Aherne returns in the Royle Family. The creator of Common as Muck has written a new comedy drama, The Sins, in which Pete Postlethwaite plays an ex-con struggling with life on the outside.
