webTitle: Royal building bill goes through roof

fields.headline: Royal building bill goes through roof
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The spiralling costs needed to protect Her Majesty's wardrobe from collapsing through the floor of Buckingham Palace are revealed today in an official report.
fields.body:
The spiralling costs needed to protect Her Majesty's wardrobe from collapsing through the floor of Buckingham Palace are revealed today in an official report.

It reveals that the Queen, like many of her subjects, suffers the same problems with builders - asked to do one job, they do three and the bill goes through the roof.

The original proposal was a simple one. Design and build wall-to-wall wardrobes in three rooms in the palace to hang up the Queen's outfits and official robes.

But the carpenters called in had to abandon the work after they discovered that the floor would collapse if they went ahead. No sooner had this been put right than electricians had to be employed to rewire the rooms.

Security experts were then also summoned to ensure that nobody was able to steal any of the costumes.

The cost of providing the new wardrobes escalated from an original figure of £51,000 to a final £70,000, with £9,000 spent on redesigning them to new standards.

The 37% cost overrun is the highest quoted in a national audit office report published today.

The report is the first in which auditors from parliament's financial watchdog have been given access to the royal accounts.

The report into some £7.2m spent on building work at Buckingham Palace, St James' Palace, Clarence House, Kensington Palace and Windsor Castle actually concludes that too little may be being spent by the taxpayer on the maintenance of the royal family's official residences.

Maintenance costs have been reduced from £19m a year in 1991 to £7.2m last year.

The report reveals that altogether some £87,000 has been spent on double glazing windows and installing long-life lightbulbs in the royal palaces and some £1.67m has been spent on health and safety measures. These included large rewiring jobs and fire measures after the fire that burnt down parts of Windsor Castle.

Another £3.1m was spent on re-roofing buildings and resurfacing roads.

Staff in the palace have also had new and refurbished offices as part of a £1.3m modernisation programme.

The report also praises the royal household for cutting overall costs to the taxpayer form £29m a year to £15.8m a year between 1992 and 1999.

It also points out that visitor charges at Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace have brought in £25.9m which has been spent on renovating the fire damaged at Windsor Castle without having to charge the taxpayer more money.

webTitle: Fonda sorry for Hanoi Jane image

fields.headline: Fonda sorry for Hanoi Jane image
fields.trailText: The reinvention of Jane Fonda as an all-American conformist gathered pace yesterday with the abandonment of one of her longest-cherished positions, support for the Viet Cong during the Vietnam war.
fields.body:
The reinvention of Jane Fonda as an all-American conformist gathered pace yesterday with the abandonment of one of her longest-cherished positions, support for the Viet Cong during the Vietnam war.

"I will go to my grave regretting the photograph of me in an anti-aircraft carrier, which looks like I was trying to shoot at American planes," said the 62-year-old Oscar-winning actress, referring to a 1972 picture of her with North Vietnamese soldiers which earned her the soubriquet of Hanoi Jane.

"It hurt so many soldiers. It galvanised such hostility. It was the most horrible thing I could possibly have done. It was just thoughtless."

Fonda has rethought large areas of her life recently, splitting up with her husband, the CNN cable news founder Ted Turner, and embracing Christianity.

"You have to be able to say 'I was wrong'. You have to be able to accept responsibility for your mistakes and learn from them," she said in an interview with the chat show personality Oprah Winfrey in O magazine.

Fonda said that at the time of the Hanoi picture she was living a "fun but rather empty life" in France with her first husband, the late film director Roger Vadim.

Ed Croucher, executive director of the Vietnam Veterans of America, was unimpressed by her change of heart. "There are many of us who will never forgive her for what she did," he said.

"Because of her, prisoners were tortured or denied basic necessities.

"She could start by helping the groups she harmed the most, such as surviving prisoners of war or the families of those who died in captivity."

Fonda said of her conversion to Christianity: "It's been difficult. People come up to me in airports and throw their arms around me."

The former apostle of the 1980s fitness video-tape industry also said that she was bulimic up to the age of 36. "I think I lived on apple peels and the crust of bread because if I went any further into the food there'd be no stopping.

"It has something to do with living a lie. Not being authentic. Faking it. It's like becoming a woman and then rejecting it. Like alcoholism, it's a disease of denial."

webTitle: Latest modernising delay angers Labour MPs

fields.headline: Latest modernising delay angers Labour MPs
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Labour MPs are accusing the cabinet minister heading moves to modernise the Commons of pandering to the Conservatives rather than backing Labour backbenchers over the need to speed up the pace of reform.
fields.body:
Labour MPs are accusing the cabinet minister heading moves to modernise the Commons of pandering to the Conservatives rather than backing Labour backbenchers over the need to speed up the pace of reform.

One Labour member of the modernisation committee denounced the leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett, as an "absolute disgrace", after a report setting out agreed reforms, including an end to voting in the early hours of the morning on key issues, was not finally agreed as expected yesterday.

MPs who are backing change have learned that the Commons will now not have the chance to vote on the modernisation measures until the autumn.

This will be during the "spillover period" after the summer recess.

A vote had been expected before the break, allowing a special order to permit planned reform of timetabling to be passed before the end of the parliamentary session in October.

The order will now not be passed until after the start of the new session, delaying the implementation of change.

Labour members on the committee have argued for changes to voting times and for improved timetabling of legislation, in the face of strong opposition from some Conservative members.

The plans would mean that no key votes will take place after 10pm, with votes falling after that time being taken during a designated period the following day.

The plans would also give the government powers to set out a fixed time for a bill's passage through the Commons, while allowing the opposition to decide how much time was allocated to each clause, in order to permit the challenging of ministers on controversial elements.

The committee has agreed the changes, but a report confirming them is now not due to be agreed for a further fortnight, after Ms Beckett once more permitted delays.

Two Labour members of the committee are understood to be considering stepping down after progress stalled again.

One MP said: "This is a delay too far.

"There is pressure from Labour members and those outside the Commons for far more radical change, but we have kept our MPs on board by reassuring them the report was imminent.

"But Margaret is listening more to the Tories than her own backbenchers. We have been taken for a ride - we are lecturing business about efficiency and effectiveness, and yet it has taken us four months to get an agreed report out."

Many Labour MPs will not be satisfied with the committee's proposals in any case. They had hoped for more radical change, with some advocating "office hours", in which the Commons would sit from 9am until 7pm.

fields.headline: Super jumbo ready for take-off
fields.trailText: Airbus Industrie is expected to give the go-ahead for its A3XX super-jumbo tomorrow, coinciding with the launch of the campaign to promote the flotation of the European Aeronautics, Defence and Space company - the biggest partner in the aircraft building consortium.
fields.body:
Airbus Industrie is expected to give the go-ahead for its A3XX super-jumbo tomorrow, coinciding with the launch of the campaign to promote the flotation of the European Aeronautics, Defence and Space company - the biggest partner in the aircraft building consortium.

The announcement could be accompanied by news of agreement on changing its structure from a partnership into an integrated corporate entity, according to German and French sources.

Eads - formed by the merger of Germany's DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, France's Aerospatiale Matra and Spain's Casa - is due to announce details of its planned market flotation in Amsterdam, with analysts expecting up to 30% of the shares to be offered, worth up to euro3.5bn (£2.2bn).

Sentiment towards the offer could be helped if both the issue of the A3XX and the corporate structure at Airbus - where Eads is in partnership with BAE Systems - were to be resolved. Eads has around 80% of Airbus with BAE holding the rest.

Airbus executives believe that turning the operation into a conventional corporate structure could generate cost savings of up to euro250m a year.

"There is a good chance the authorisation to offer will be announced on Friday. The talks have been coming along nicely over the last few days. At the same time you are likely to have an announcement on Airbus Integrated Company," according to one source.

Moves towards a corporate structure are understood to have been held up by the process of valuing the assets the partners are putting into Airbus, while the decision on moving to the stage where Airbus can sign up customers for the A3XX have been delayed by disagreements about how the work on the plane would be divided up.

fields.headline: Welsh back £30m assembly home
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: The Welsh assembly yesterday ended months of dithering over its future home by voting in favour of a £30m debating chamber on land next to its existing offices in Cardiff Bay.
fields.body:
The Welsh assembly yesterday ended months of dithering over its future home by voting in favour of a £30m debating chamber on land next to its existing offices in Cardiff Bay.

Members threw out proposals for a smaller, cut price chamber favoured by the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, and the assembly cabinet.

Opponents - some of whom derided the cabinet plan as a "lean-to conservatory" and a "£20m bog on stilts" - claimed the scaled down project was a face saving ploy to allow Mr Morgan to distance himself from the grander, Richard Rogers designed glass building that is thought to be unpopular with sections of the electorate.

Mr Morgan surprised the assembly three months ago by putting the Rogers building on hold. His decision to seek a review of the costs of a project that had already been approved while Alun Michael was first secretary earned him the nickname "doddery Rhodri" and prompted speculation that he planned to shift the assembly to the Cardiff city hall.

He subsequently asked Lord Rogers to examine the idea of building a smaller extension in the assembly car park. The decision to recommend a project that Lord Rogers had warned would not represent value for money was felt by some in the assembly to have been damaging to Mr Morgan's credibility. In a free vote 12 members of the Labour group voted against the cabinet option.

The Conservative group, which has previously called for the money to spent on a children's hospital, voted against the idea of a new building.

The party's spokesman, Glyn Davies, claimed the cut price option was a vain attempt to save the first secertary's face.

"It will be a decision that will hang around your necks like dead albatrosses. The first secretary's idea for a new landmark building for a new democracy is that it should look like a toilet block raised on stilts about a car park."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Mike German, said members were not voting for a building for themselves but for a national building where the people of Wales would have free access to those who had been elected to represent them.

Lord Rogers said last night that work on the building would be able to begin almost immediately and would take about two years to complete.
fields.bodyText: The Welsh assembly yesterday ended months of dithering over its future home by voting in favour of a £30m debating chamber on land next to its existing offices in Cardiff Bay. Members threw out proposals for a smaller, cut price chamber favoured by the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, and the assembly cabinet. Opponents - some of whom derided the cabinet plan as a "lean-to conservatory" and a "£20m bog on stilts" - claimed the scaled down project was a face saving ploy to allow Mr Morgan to distance himself from the grander, Richard Rogers designed glass building that is thought to be unpopular with sections of the electorate. Mr Morgan surprised the assembly three months ago by putting the Rogers building on hold. His decision to seek a review of the costs of a project that had already been approved while Alun Michael was first secretary earned him the nickname "doddery Rhodri" and prompted speculation that he planned to shift the assembly to the Cardiff city hall. He subsequently asked Lord Rogers to examine the idea of building a smaller extension in the assembly car park. The decision to recommend a project that Lord Rogers had warned would not represent value for money was felt by some in the assembly to have been damaging to Mr Morgan's credibility. In a free vote 12 members of the Labour group voted against the cabinet option. The Conservative group, which has previously called for the money to spent on a children's hospital, voted against the idea of a new building. The party's spokesman, Glyn Davies, claimed the cut price option was a vain attempt to save the first secertary's face. "It will be a decision that will hang around your necks like dead albatrosses. The first secretary's idea for a new landmark building for a new democracy is that it should look like a toilet block raised on stilts about a car park." The Liberal Democrat leader, Mike German, said members were not voting for a building for themselves but for a national building where the people of Wales would have free access to those who had been elected to represent them. Lord Rogers said last night that work on the building would be able to begin almost immediately and would take about two years to complete.

fields.headline: Syria's muted opposition lies low
fields.standfirst:
A rare interview with three of the last dissenters in a country emerging from 30 years of brutality

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Fateh Jamous sat in shorts and vest at his kitchen table on Monday supping beer with two friends in his home by the Mediterranean shore. An unremarkable scene, except that the three are just about all that is left of Syria's political opposition, the others dead or still in jail after 30 years of murderous repression.
fields.body:
Fateh Jamous sat in shorts and vest at his kitchen table on Monday supping beer with two friends in his home by the Mediterranean shore. An unremarkable scene, except that the three are just about all that is left of Syria's political opposition, the others dead or still in jail after 30 years of murderous repression.

This was Syria under the dictatorship of the Hafez al-Assad, praised by foreign dignitaries at his funeral last week for achieving "stability", and it is still Syria today, one of the most ruthless police states in the world.

Enjoying a beer is a fairly novel experience for Mr Fateh. He was released only last month after 18 years in jail. Sharing it with him was Aslan Abul Kerim, a former teacher of Arabic, who was released the same day, May 4. The third member of the group asked not to be identified.

All three were jailed for membership of the Labour Communist party, a non-violent group campaigning for free elections and a more equal society.

Mr Fateh recalled the dread he felt the moment he was seized by the secret police, the Mukhabarat, on February 2 1982. "If they arrest you in Syria, you have to know you are going to hell." And he was.

In the climate of fear that exists in Syria, it can be difficult to track down former political prisoners and, once found, it is rare for them to speak openly about their experiences.

In Damascus members of the Muslim Brotherhood, a broken militant group which suffered appallingly in prison, provided hours of interviews, all of it unpublishable after they decided, in a wild panic, that they wanted no details to appear that might identify them.

Mr Fateh was relaxed by comparison, though he was curious about who had provided his telephone number and sought repeated guarantees that a Syrian companion was definitely not from the Mukhabarat.

He knew that an interview with a western newspaper could mean trouble, but he welcomed the chance to speak out.

"There is a very small opposition in Syria," he said. "Some people can speak, as I am doing now. Of course, I fear they will punish me, but it is important to seize the period and what it can give us."

Mr Fateh, 52, lives in a modest house - the inside walls are of grey plaster, unpainted and uncovered - in Bisnada, an old village near Latakia on the Syrian coast. His wife Malaki, 49, is stoically cheerful after a hard life bringing up alone their two children, a son, Izar, who was seven when his father went into prison, and a daughter, Maia, who was only four-and-a-half months.

He has all the certainty that communists in other countries used to have. He refers to his friends as "comrades" and, with the help of an Arab-English dictionary, throws phrases like "revisionist" into the interview. His dogmatism is softened by a Mediterranean warmth and humour, gently teasing his reunited family, who clearly have much affection for him.

Before jail, he studied mechanical engineering at the University of Aleppo, in the north of the country.

He was attracted first to George Habash's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and then the Arab Socialist party before turning his back on nationalism to help found the Labour Communist party in 1976, immediately forced underground.

Within months of his arrest, he was sent to jail at Palmyra, a town that is Syria's top tourist attraction because of its well-preserved Roman ruins.

Built by the French in colonial days, with a modern wing added by the Syrian government, the prison is described by everyone interviewed as the worst in the country. "It is very, very bad," Mr Fateh said, describing cramped conditions made worse by the savage desert heat. He was tortured for three days when he arrived and was then left alone because, by chance, a relative was the warden.

What gives Palmyra its notoriety among Syrians is the executions. No international observers were allowed in, then or now, so no reliable figures are available.

"Even God does not know," Mr Fateh said. The estimate most widely accepted is about 5,000-6,000 killed at the prison between 1980 and 1985, a period of tension because of an assassination attempt on Assad and a rising by the Muslim Brotherhood.

One former inmate interviewed in Damascus, a Muslim, who was left partially paralysed from a beating, recalled how prisoners watched through cracks in the cell walls what he referred to as "hanging parties". He said these executions, mainly of Muslim Brotherhood members, were carried out on Saturdays, Mondays and Tuesdays, with between 40 and 100 prisoners killed at a time.

With that kind of regime, a gradual drop in the number of political prisoners from a high in the 1980s to an estimated 1,000 today was inevitable. Public dissent is non-existent.

There is no voice for opposition because television, radio and newspapers are all state-controlled. International newspapers are heavily censored, but news from the outside world gets through.

Although satellite dishes for television are theoretically illegal, the Damascus skyline reveals them on almost every rooftop. The government is struggling too to control mobile phones and the internet.

Opposite one of the few internet cafes, in a shaded alleyway near the Old University of Damascus, is the office of Haitham Maleh, a lawyer and another former prisoner, given six years for supporting a call for democracy by the Syrian Bar Association.

Aged 70, he does what he can to represent those inside. He urged the US and Britain to take up political prisoners with the Syrian government: a request by the French government had brought some releases.

Was the human rights situation better now compared with the 1980s? "Things are not better. They are less bad. There is no better here," he said.

Mr Fateh, who was transferred from Palmyra to Sydnaya prison in 1987, was 10 years in jail before he received a trial. He said there were 40 communists still inside, three of whom had been in since 1975.

Latakia is close to Assad's home village and the area had even more black banners of mourning for the dead president than Damascus.

Hardly surprisingly, Mr Fateh, was not among those mourning the death of a man he described as "the head of a dictatorial system".

He was unsure about Bashar, Assad's son and president-in-waiting. He did not expect him to end the one-party state but, if he could avoid a power struggle, he might "offer Syria some new things".

Mr Fateh, who described himself as "an enthusiastic communist", will pursue a radical campaign, at least in Syrian terms, for free elections and hopes to open a bookshop. He was struck by many changes when was released, many of them for the better, but as for the country's political situation, "it is not only no change, it is worse".

In spite of the years he lost watching his family grow, he was free of remorse. He said: "I do not regret about anything at all. Freedom requires many sacrifices."

 A Lebanese military court has sentenced a man to one year in prison and fined him £390 for vilifying Assad by telling friends and relatives that his death was cause for celebration.

fields.headline: Future Network keeps up charge
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Future Network, the video game and personal computer magazine publisher, yesterday said revenues from its internet operations had increased 300% in the past five months.
fields.body:
Future Network, the video game and personal computer magazine publisher, yesterday said revenues from its internet operations had increased 300% in the past five months.

Greg Ingham, chief executive, said the growth in its online activities meant the company registered 4.9m unique visitors per month, almost double that of a year ago. He said Future Network's websites were also now at 83m page impressions a month.

"I am pleased to report that our online revenues have continued to grow month on month so far this year," Mr Ingham said at the company's maiden annual meeting. "We are very confident of meeting our online revenue targets for the year as a whole."

Future Network floated in June last year at 385p a share after being sold by media firm Pearson in a £142m management buy-out. Its shares fell 17.5p to 785p yesterday.

However, the company's high share price and heavy investment programme as it builds its online offering and magazine stable, has worried some analysts.

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has said the computer games market is maturing and the magazine market is fiercely competitive. Additionally, the company's rapid expansion into new countries may "place a considerable burden on management's ability to continue its track record of exploiting a fast growing niche area", the stockbroker said in a report.

Still, Future Network does believe it can capitalise on the growing increase of computers in the home as the internet becomes a more commonplace and important technology for communicating.

Future Network has 127 magazines, which include the publication for Manchester United and the Official Play Station Magazine. The launch of Sony's Play Station 2 console in the autumn is expected to boost magazine sales. The internet arm of the business provides websites for some of its magazine titles.

It also runs a network of websites that answer any computer-related question and offer a forum where techheads can exchange views and tips. It offers auctions for computer and related products and is expected to extend this service with an online shopping version.

The forecasts on the group's 2000 earnings vary, with Schroder Salomon Smith Barney forecasting a pre-tax profit of £23.6m while Merrill Lynch is expecting £12.2m.

Mr Ingham did not comment on profit forecasts yesterday, but said "trading in the first five months of 2000 has continued the trends of late 1999."

In 1999, Future Network reported a pre-tax profit of £19.2m.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: There was a lethargic feel to trading in London, with the big telecoms and banking stocks dragging the leading index lower. Volume of just over 1.1bn shares indicated that private investors and some big institutions have dropped into summer mode.
fields.body:
There was a lethargic feel to trading in London, with the big telecoms and banking stocks dragging the leading index lower. Volume of just over 1.1bn shares indicated that private investors and some big institutions have dropped into summer mode.

The FTSE 100 ended the session well above its worst level, but was still showing a 49.1 point deficit at the close at 6477.8. The move in Vodafone AirTouch, down 7p at 314p, was worth almost 20 points off the blue chip indicator, while a fall in the price of British Telecom, from 974p to 940p, was worth another 10 Footsie points.

Investment bankers Salomon Smith Barney were partly to blame, issuing advice to clients to be overweight in technology, but specifically underweight in telecoms stocks over the coming weeks as the UMTS licence auctions roll through Europe.

Salomon became cautious of European technology, media and telecom stocks in March, but it does now expect the recent outperformance of US equities by continental European shares to continue.

Over in the banking sector, analysts' downgrades kept the pressure on the likes of Lloyds TSB, which ended the session 18p lower at 618p, while mortgage lenders Woolwich and Halifax fell 10p to 269p and 39p to 568p, respectively.

Against this, hints at a compromise agreement in Vienna at the Opec meeting encouraged a bounce in the oil sector, with BP Amoco up from 624.5p to 630p and Shell 13p firmer at 563p.

P&O gave up 36p to 580p after its American cruise industry rival issued a profits warning. A string of broker downgrades is expected over the coming days.

Meanwhile, Christian Salvesen surged 19p to 180.5p after the hint here that some sort of corporate action was imminent. The freight company has turned down a 180p-a-share offer from a consortium led by its biggest shareholder, Swedish investment group AB Custos.

Lower down the corporate scale, some speculative money was heading in the direction of Fitness First. Dealers could only point to hopes of an upbeat trading statement with next week's year-end results. The shares came to rest at £11.10, up 105p on the day.

Dmatek, the Israeli company specialising in electronic monitoring devices, leapt from 164p to 188p in the morning before settling 6p higher at 170p. The excitement seemed to be caused by news that the company has won orders from two US prison authorities - in Maine and New Mexico - to supply home detention systems.

webTitle: Murdoch feels a touch of fear

fields.headline: Murdoch feels a touch of fear
fields.standfirst: New rivals setting pace
fields.trailText: The figures, $40bn (£25bn) upwards, are impressive. The names, such as Sky, have a household ring. But there is a view that this week's confirmation that News Corp will be spinning off its satellite businesses into a separate New York-quoted vehicle marks the beginning of the end for Rupert Murdoch's empire.
fields.body:
The figures, $40bn (£25bn) upwards, are impressive. The names, such as Sky, have a household ring. But there is a view that this week's confirmation that News Corp will be spinning off its satellite businesses into a separate New York-quoted vehicle marks the beginning of the end for Rupert Murdoch's empire.

His organisation might be bigger and more diverse than ever, but as News Corp's sprawling assets are rejigged to cope with the internet age and the emergence of massive new rivals, this awesome financier is looking weak.

It is a matter of time and technology. At the age of 69, and with the question of succession as unanswered as ever, it must be fair to question whether Mr Murdoch actually has the energy and speed of thought to go head to head with the likes of AOL's Steve Case.

Mr Case probably understands new media better than anyone else, which is why the newly forged AOL Time Warner machine attracts a market value 10 times Mr Murdoch's.

Whatever his methods, or the quality of the end product, the Australian has always had an intrinsic understanding of the news paper industry. He has also shown himself to be a master of risk, as his move into and subsequent domination of satellite TV has shown.

Suddenly, however, he is reported to be offering stakes in the new Global Sky Networks to the likes of Microsoft, Yahoo! and Nokia. An agreement, even, seems to have been reached with Jean-Marie Messier to wrap Vivendi's stake in BSkyB into the new venture, giving the French a stake of at least 10%.

Three months ago, Mr Murdoch was not even on speaking terms with Mr Messier and the British competition authorities were being pressed to order a reduction of Vivendi's Sky stake.

Mr Messier has transformed an old economy firm into a new(ish) economy power; Mr Case has swallowed both old and new rivals. Mr Murdoch may finally be experiencing fear.

Firepower

It is clearly a growth industry. Examples are everywhere. Whether it is as perceived champions of consumers or simply in a desperate attempt to protect traditional revenue flows, big governments are throwing every possible resource at getting a handle on supra-national corporations.

In Washington, the battle over whether the world's fourth largest company should be divided into, say, the world's seventeenth and twentieth biggest firms is nearing its end game. In Brussels, the EU competition authorities are threatening to block one of the world's most ambitious telecoms mergers - between two American companies. In London, a multi-billion pound tax dodge by Britain's biggest firm has been scuppered by the treasury.

And now, over in New York, the mini-state run by mayor Rudolph Giuliani has set off on a course of action which, inevitably it seems, will hasten the total dismemberment of one of Britain's great (but thoroughly out of fashion) conglomerates, Tomkins.

Mr Giuliani and his team of city council lawyers have filed a suit against its Smith and Wesson subsidiary and a long list of other gun manufacturers and distributors al leging negligent sales practices and deceptive advertising. New York has spent a lot fighting gun-related crime, and shelled out plenty more fixing or processing bodies with bullet holes in them. Now it wants its money back, together with unspecified punitive damages on Tomkins and its ilk.

These companies deserve everything they are going to get, according to one of the city's attorney's Lorna Goodman, after all: "They could make safer guns."

Greg Hutchings and his colleagues at Tomkins could do themselves serious damage laughing at this action, but for the existence of that other umpteen billion dollar joke called the tobacco industry.

In London, a multi-billion pound tax dodge by Britain's biggest firm has been scuppered by the treasury. And now, over in New York, the mini-state run by mayor Rudolph Giuliani has set off on a course of action which, inevitably it seems, will hasten the total dismemberment of one of Britain's great (but thoroughly out of fashion) conglomerates, Tomkins. Mr Giuliani and his team of city council lawyers have filed a suit against its Smith and Wesson subsidiary and a long list of other gun manufacturers and distributors al leging negligent sales practices and deceptive advertising. New York has spent a lot fighting gun-related crime, and shelled out plenty more fixing or processing bodies with bullet holes in them. Now it wants its money back, together with unspecified punitive damages on Tomkins and its ilk. These companies deserve everything they are going to get, according to one of the city's attorney's Lorna Goodman, after all: "They could make safer guns." Greg Hutchings and his colleagues at Tomkins could do themselves serious damage laughing at this action, but for the existence of that other umpteen billion dollar joke called the tobacco industry.

fields.headline: Nomura to raise Hyder bid
fields.trailText: Nomura, the Japanese bank, is set to raise its £403m bid for Welsh multi-utility Hyder as pressure mounts for the rival £464m offer from US group Western Power Distribution to be referred to the competition commission.
fields.body:
Nomura, the Japanese bank, is set to raise its £403m bid for Welsh multi-utility Hyder as pressure mounts for the rival £464m offer from US group Western Power Distribution to be referred to the competition commission.

Rhodri Morgan, the Welsh first secretary, backed by the national assembly, has urged Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, to "repatriate" the WPD bid from Brussels.

Assembly members have threatened to use their powers to veto it - the first time a British takeover has faced such a hurdle under devolution.

Supporting the referral moves, Mike Kinski, Nomura's transactions director and designated chief executive of Hyder, indicated that the bank would increase its 260p-a-share offer even before regulatory issues surrounding the WPD bid were cleared.

"We gave a number of undertakings to the assembly," he said yesterday. "I am assessing whether to increase the bid. If we did that it would be against that backdrop - and whether we can get more value from a higher bid."

Nomura has undertaken to retain Hyder, which owns Welsh Water and electricity distribution company Swalec, as an integrated group based in Cardiff and to limit job losses to the 1,000 already planned by the Hyder board. This has ensured it has the backing of the assembly and local unions.

Mr Kinski said: "I am quite confident we can honour those commitments and still move forward but we have not yet made a decision to raise the bid."

He indicated strongly that an increased bid could come soon. The former Stagecoach chief executive said he aimed to propel Welsh Water into the top-performing ranks of the sector, especially by managing its £1.1bn capital spending programme more efficiently, and secure a more favourable outcome for prices in the next regulatory review from industry watchdog Ofwat in 2005.

Under Nomura, Hyder could then decide whether to expand via acquisition or divest the water business, while Swalec would be given up to three years to improve its performance before a similar decision was taken.

"I think we can untangle a very complex business [Hyder], get it back to basics, drive the performance and grow those businesses," Mr Kinski said.

"I do believe you can still get a reasonable return from a regulated business provided you are one of the better performers."

He said: "We really want this business. A utility is a bit like a gilt, giving a good, steady return if you put the investment in. It's not a growth stock."

In a recent letter to Mr Byers, seen by the Guardian, Mr Morgan said he shared the concerns of two assembly com mittees about the WPD bid, especially on jobs, future management of the water and electricity businesses in Wales and the uncertain prospects for Hyder's non-regulated operations.

WPD plans to hand over the management and operation of Welsh Water to United Utilities but Mr Morgan indicated that the assembly reserved its powers under 1991 legislation to veto these proposals.

"I would urge you to take such action as is necessary to enable the bid to be considered within the UK and under the relevant UK legislation," he wrote.

fields.headline: Terror rules in Mugabe's laagers
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: James Zhou has two gaping wounds where his buttocks used to be. For supporting Zimbabwe's opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), he suffered unspeakable torture and his brother Finos was beaten to death.
fields.body:
James Zhou has two gaping wounds where his buttocks used to be. For supporting Zimbabwe's opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), he suffered unspeakable torture and his brother Finos was beaten to death.

"I thought I had the right to support any party of my choice," the visibly terrified Mr Zhou said in his hospital bed. "But now I think these politics are dirty. It's not good."

Violence and torture are rampant throughout rural Zimbabwe before the crucial parliamentary elections this weekend. Teachers, doctors and nurses have been picked on. More than 13,000 rural people have fled to the relative safety of the cities, according to the Human Rights Forum.

Confronted by swelling support for the MDC, President Robert Mugabe's government is also using new voting regulations and restrictions on observers in a frantic attempt to reduce the size of the opposition vote.

These aspects of intimidation are evident in Mataga, 250 miles south-east of Harare.

The Zhou brothers were abducted from their home near Mataga on June 4 by 18 supporters of President Mugabe's Zanu-PF party. They were taken to Texas Farm, where they were beaten and burned for more than 24 hours.

The violence was prompted by the fact that Finos had signed nomination papers for the local MDC candidate for parliament.

Finos died of internal injuries on June 6. James will need extensive skin grafts and reconstructive surgery to restore his backside.

Despite numerous identifications, the police have not arrested anyone for the Zhous' murder and torture. They have not gone to Texas Farm which, war veterans and other Zanu-PF supporters have taken over for use as a torture centre.

The Zhou brothers' horrific story is depressingly familiar in Mataga. Another man was wrapped in plastic bags which were set alight.

More than 150 cases of assault, rape, genital mutilation and other torture of opposition supporters have been recorded, yet the police have taken virtually no action.

At first glance the town appeared normal to three visiting journalists, with people going to the shops along the main street. But just minutes after we got out of our car at the post office we were surrounded by about a dozen youths, some wearing Zanu-PF T-shirts.

They questioned us and ordered us to stay where we were. We decided to move on. We went to some shops owned by opposition supporters which had been vandalised and burned by Zanu-PF.

A truck roared by filled with young men waving iron bars, clubs and machetes. They shouted and jeered at us. One pointed at us and pulled his machete across his throat as if to slit ours.

The people at the shops were obviously frightened and would not speak to us.

At the Mataga police station the officer in charge assured us that the situation was calm and normal and that opposition parties were free to campaign. He admitted that the MDC offices had been burned down and he knew of no MDC people we could meet.

A few minutes later we found the officer laughing with the leader of the gang that had surrounded us. They were clearly in league with each other.

It was getting dark so we decided to leave. The truck with youths waving crowbars and clubs followed us to the edge of town.

We came to a crossroads and stopped to decide way to go. A man leaned into the car and demanded to see our Zanu-PF cards and to search our vehicle. We said he was not a policeman and he had no right to demand anything.

He shouted and eight men approached our car. We sped off and they threw stones at the car. We came to another group setting up an illegal roadblock and drove right through it. Once again stones were thrown at us.

The intimidation we encountered was minor, and it was clear that if we had been local Zimbabweans much more serious assaults could have occurred.

But Mataga is not all menace and fear. It is also full of heroic resistance. The MDC candidate for the Mataga area is a courageous woman called Sekai Holland. She was held by the Mataga police without charges for two nights and then taken away to the nearest city, Zvishavane.

She has not been able to return to Mataga because of the roadblocks. Her car was burned and more than Z$85,000 (£1,460) was stolen from her by Zanu-PF supporters.

"They are terrorising our area," said Lewellin Sibanda. "But we go back to campaign at night and to put up posters. They cannot stop us because the people want change."

fields.headline: Salvesen snubs Custos
fields.trailText: Transport and logistics group Christian Salvesen found itself firmly in the bid spotlight yesterday after confirmation that it had turned down a takeover approach from its biggest shareholder.
fields.body:
Transport and logistics group Christian Salvesen found itself firmly in the bid spotlight yesterday after confirmation that it had turned down a takeover approach from its biggest shareholder.

The approach came from a consortium that includes the Swedish investment group AB Custos, which specialises in taking significant stakes in mainly Scandinavian companies. Custos has a holding of just over 10% in Salvesen.

The firm's shares surged more than 11% on the news as investors speculated that Custos remains interested or that the move could flush out other suitors.

Custos confirmed at the end of May that it had proposed making a recommended cash offer of 180p a share - a near 50% premium to the then market price but the offer had been rejected on June 6.

Custos said yesterday that it was now considering its options in the light of the rejection but is understood to want further discussions with the Salvesen board.

For its part, Salvesen confirmed that it had rejected the approach, adding that it "believes that the company's strategy remains the optimal route for delivery of value to shareholders.

Salvesen has endured several difficult years but it recently reported a 25% rise in profits and industry observers say that with its focus more driven by expansion in information technology and helped by a number of acquisitions, it is now seen as a turnaround story.

Analysts at Commerzbank recently said Salvesen was "a potentially attractive acquisition target in a consolidating European logistics market".

There was speculation yesterday that P&O could emerge as a possible suitor because Salvesen would fit in well with the shipping company's refrigeration capacity.

Yesterday the Antwerp Port Authority said it had granted the concession for a third container terminal to a consortium led by P&O. The British group said its consortium would invest some £150m in the new terminal.

webTitle: One2One pays £73m to Pocket Phone pair

fields.headline: One2One pays £73m to Pocket Phone pair
fields.trailText: One2One may have unintentionally sealed the fate of Crystal Palace football club yesterday when it bought the Pocket Phone Shop, making its co-founder Simon Jordan £36.5m richer.
fields.body:
One2One may have unintentionally sealed the fate of Crystal Palace football club yesterday when it bought the Pocket Phone Shop, making its co-founder Simon Jordan £36.5m richer.

Mr Jordan, 32, a self-made millionaire and former schoolboy player for Crystal Palace, is one of two bidders for the financially troubled football club.

The new owner of the club is expected to be announced tomorrow, with Mr Jordan up against a consortium led by Chinese businessman Jerry Lim. Both men are understood to have offered bids over £10m.

"At the moment Mr Jordan's bid is on the table with the administrators," a spokesman for the football club said. "All being well we will have a decision by the end of this week."

The Pocket Phone company was established in 1994 by Mr Jordan and colleague Andrew Briggs, who had both worked together at Charles Dunstone's Carphone Warehouse chain.

They each invested £15,000 to start the company and sold it yesterday for £73m.

It is Britain's second biggest independent phone retailer behind Carphone Warehouse.

One2One intends to take the 167 stores, keeping the Pocket Phone Shop brand and add it to its existing portfolio of 155 dual-branded stores.

Richard Shearer, One2One commercial director, said the operator had paid a fair price for the retailer.

In the year to May, the Pocket Phone Shop's turnover was over £52m. "As mobile phone products become more complex with technologies such as WAP and GPRS we saw the necessity to increase our reach to customers through the stores," Mr Shearer said.

Mr Jordan, who drives a silver Ferrari 550, declined to comment yesterday on the sale of his business or the bid for the football club.

The club was owned by Mark Goldberg, a recruitment industry entrepreneur , before it was placed into the hands of administrators.

fields.headline: Publicis targets Zenith
fields.standfirst: Saatchi brothers consider sale of new agency
fields.trailText: The conspiracy theorists who believe that Publicis may seek a rapprochement between the Saatchi brothers and the newly acquired agency that bears their name were given further cause for excitement yesterday when the French firm said it was interested in reuniting one of the cornerstones of the brothers' former empire.
fields.body:
The conspiracy theorists who believe that Publicis may seek a rapprochement between the Saatchi brothers and the newly acquired agency that bears their name were given further cause for excitement yesterday when the French firm said it was interested in reuniting one of the cornerstones of the brothers' former empire.

Publicis chairman Maurice Levy, a long-term ally of brothers Maurice and Charles Saatchi, said yesterday that he was looking to buy Cordiant's 50% stake in media buying firm Zenith Media.

The French firm has agreed to pay $1.9bn (£1.1bn) for Saatchi & Saatchi which jointly owns Zenith with Cordiant. "We think the media buying businesses make an excellent fit," Mr Levy said. "We don't want to sell our share but we will be looking at a lot of possible combinations".

Cordiant declined to comment.

Zenith has been at the centre of bid speculation ever since Cordiant and Saatchi split in 1997.

The firm, which buys advertising space, was entirely owned by the Saatchi brothers before they left the business in 1995.

Since then they have had nothing to do with the firm and have formed a new business, M&C Saatchi.

Speculation that the brothers, both approaching 60, may look to sell their new business to Publicis has been fuelled by its recent acquisition spree. Mr Levy is an old friend, who in 1995 lent the brothers office space to support their winning bid for an £80m account with British Airways. The possible reunification of Zenith has fuelled the rumours.

Analysts say a combination of Zenith and Publicis's Optimedia buying agency would have billings of $16bn (£10bn) annually.

webTitle: Girl pays the price for letter to Putin

fields.headline: Girl pays the price for letter to Putin
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A grammar school student in a tiny village deep in the Russian countryside who made the mistake of sending a letter to the president, Vladimir Putin, found herself stripped of the graduation honours she deserved and enrolled in a dairy academy instead of heading for medical school.
fields.body:
A grammar school student in a tiny village deep in the Russian countryside who made the mistake of sending a letter to the president, Vladimir Putin, found herself stripped of the graduation honours she deserved and enrolled in a dairy academy instead of heading for medical school.

The letter was not political, and its author, Anya Provorova, certainly meant no disrespect. She and five graduating classmates of the little school in Vorobyovo, about 250 miles north of Moscow, had only fallen back upon centuries of Russian tradition and sent the Kremlin a request for help.

It wasn't that crucial - all they wanted was a video camera so they could record their graduation - but it seemed worth a try. It couldn't hurt to ask, could it?

It could, and it did.

The problem was this: in her salutation to "The Esteemed Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin", Ms Provorova neglected to finish the phrase with an exclamation point. Moreover, she used the Russian word for "you" in referring to the president, without giving it a capital letter.

As a result, her grades were lowered and she is heading to the local dairy institute.

"I don't think it's fair, especially because the medal commission had already confirmed my marks," she said. "I don't think these mistakes should be enough of a reason to lower my score."

She learned of her reprimand on June 15, at her graduation, after the school commission had condemned the letter to Mr Putin, and chastised the students for their immaturity.

There the story might have ended had not the regional correspondent for the national newspaper, Izvestia, learned of what had happened.

After the story appeared on Tuesday, school officials in the northern district denied that the withdrawal of the medals had anything to do with the letter. Baltimore Sun

fields.headline: Hoon's arms admission
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Inadequacies in Britain's military equipment highlighted by the Kosovo conflict will take years to put right, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, admitted to MPs yesterday.
fields.body:
Inadequacies in Britain's military equipment highlighted by the Kosovo conflict will take years to put right, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, admitted to MPs yesterday.

Constraints in his budget meant the Ministry of Defence had to decide on priorities, he told the Commons defence committee. He singled out the government's recent decision to lease four Globemaster transport aircraft from the US.

A list of shortcomings identified by the MoD and the national audit office include insecure communications systems, a critical shortage of skilled airmen and troops, poorly equipped navy Harriers, and a shortage of precision-guided bombs.

Though Mr Hoon told MPs he was confident the shortcomings could be put right within the planned defence budget, that would happen only in what he called "the course of time".

He also defended use of cluster bombs by the RAF in the Kosovo campaign, but acknowledged there had been a number of civilian deaths from "bomblets" contained in the bombs which had failed to explode when they were dropped. Labour MP Harry Cohen claimed that the decision to drop the bombs from 30,000ft, to ensure the safety of the aircrews, meant more bomblets had failed to explode, resulting in the "slaughter" of civilians on the ground. "How many innocent refugees is one pilot worth?" he demanded.

Mr Hoon insisted the failure rate of the cluster bombs - estimated by the manufacturers to be 5% - was not affected by the altitude from which they were dropped. He said targets in Serbia were attacked by Nato on the basis of "carefully considered legal advice".

fields.trailText:
Good day

Scottish first minister Donald Dewar has told of a surprising benefit to having major heart surgery - discovering the joys of walking.
fields.body:
Good day
Scottish first minister Donald Dewar has told of a surprising benefit to having major heart surgery - discovering the joys of walking.

Mr Dewar, recuperating at home after a three-and-a-half hour operation in May, is getting back into the swing of work reading the "odd paper" delivered to him by aides and using his laptop. He added: "I am doing things I have never done in my life, like walking. I have lived in this area of Glasgow for 40 years and I have to tell you I have now inspected streets I never knew existed."

Blunder of day

Junior minister Beverley Hughes. She inadvertently told MPs when they can go on holiday, a date traditionally announced by the leader of the Commons. During a debate on supermarkets she was asked why a competition report could not be published while the Commons was still sitting, instead of in September. Her answer: "I think that this is preferable to the 31st of July with Parliament rising on the 28th of July." Oops.

Today

Commons: Treasury questions. Debate on security and intelligence agencies.Lords: Child support, pensions and welfare bill, report.

webTitle: Policeman gets 18 years for sex attacks

fields.headline: Policeman gets 18 years for sex attacks
fields.standfirst: Women raped and assaulted in cells to satisfy 'squalid sexual depravity'
fields.trailText: A police sergeant was sentenced to 18 years in prison yesterday for raping and indecently assaulting women while on duty, to "satisfy his squalid sexual depravity".
fields.body:
A police sergeant was sentenced to 18 years in prison yesterday for raping and indecently assaulting women while on duty, to "satisfy his squalid sexual depravity".

Paul Banfield, 33, a custody sergeant at Parkside police station in Cambridge, broke down in tears at Nottingham crown court as a jury found him guilty by majority verdicts of raping two women, indecently assaulting a third, and committing burglary with intent to rape. He had earlier pleaded guilty to three indecent assaults on two further victims.

The court heard Banfield had committed most of the assaults while on duty, including raping one woman and indecently assaulting two more in police cells while he was the custody sergeant in charge of their care. He also indecently assaulted a former girlfriend at her home. None of the victims can be named for legal reasons.

In court, the five victims had painted a picture of a man who routinely abused his position of trust and authority to exercise sexual power over women supposed to be in his care. Yet he showed no awareness of the suffering he had inflicted, often phoning and visiting his victims after his attacks, and even delivering flowers and a birthday card to one woman.

Mr Justice Morland told Banfield he had shown no remorse, adding: "You subjected them to humiliating and terrifying experiences to satisfy your squalid sexual depravity."

He said: "I appreciate that the serving of a prison sentence is an ordeal for an officer, but as a sergeant you must have realised what an ordeal these five women endured."

Banfield had targeted vulnerable young women, and the victims assaulted in police cells were "naturally upset and scared".

"For them, you were a person of authority responsible for them as custody sergeant," the judge said. "You had the affront to suggest that in most cases it was the women who took the initiative to make sexual advances upon you."

The court had heard that Banfield's first victim was a 45-year-old divorcee he met while on duty as a patrol sergeant in Cambridge city centre in September 1998. He raped her after breaking into her house at 4am.

Banfield's parents, Tony and Angela Banfield, who attended court every day, heard that the woman, identified as woman B, awoke to find the officer on top of her.

Banfield claimed she had invited him to her home and he had climbed in through a window because he feared she had taken an overdose.

The woman was too frightened to make a formal complaint but her friend notified a police officer and an investigation was launched, which identified Banfield as the likely culprit using computer records. Yet Banfield was never informed about the complaint or interviewed to give his version of events, while a police file on the case sent to his police station at the time has gone missing.

It was not until woman A made a formal complaint in October 1999 that Banfield had raped her in her police cell that officers contacted his first rape victim and persuaded her to press charges. Other victims later came forward following a police appeal but some complained the police had not taken their allegations seriously.

The year between these offences enabled Banfield to continue in his job and to transfer to the post of custody sergeant last July, allowing him to continue his assaults between August and October last year.

The court heard he flattered and flirted with three women prisoners being held in his custody suite, repeatedly visiting their cells to grope and sexually assault them. He made one woman change into a white boiler suit, telling her to remove her underwear before raping her and then cleaning the cell to remove all evidence. A closed-circuit TV videotape of the suite on that night was later found to be blank and unused. The original tape has never been found.

Investigating officers have contacted most of the 300 women who passed through the custody suite during the four months Banfield was a custody sergeant and, although DNA testing of Banfield has revealed no link with any unsolved sex attacks, a senior police officer said he feared his known victims may be just "the tip of the iceberg".

Banfield, of St Neots, Cambridgeshire, enjoyed a privileged upbringing as the son of an RAF flight lieutenant, attending the £11,000-a-year Bedford Modern private school from the age of 10. He worked briefly in a builders merchant's yard before joining the Metropolitan police as a cadet based in Kensington in 1985, transferring to Cambridgeshire four years later.

His 10 years with the Cambridgeshire constabulary included three years as a community beat officer on the deprived Oxmoor council estate in Huntingdon and a stint with CID. He was promoted to sergeant in July 1998, just before his first attack.

Banfield carried out the assaults while living with his girlfriend of three years, Tracey Smith, 29, a civilian worker in the finance department of Cambridgeshire police. She was herself arrested and briefly suspended from duty for activities allegedly related to the charges against him. She has since sold her story to a Sunday tabloid.

Police revealed a number of Banfield's female colleagues have since made formal complaints about sexual harassment and inappropriate remarks made by him, while his friends testified to his bragging about his sexual conquests.

An internal police investigation into how Banfield's crimes were able to go undetected for so long concluded that there had been "serious lapses in procedure" in the custody suite at Parkside police station but that the officer's colleagues had not acted to protect him.

fields.headline: Planetary pools
fields.standfirst:
Did Nasa probe find water on Mars?

Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Nasa scientists are believed to have told the White House that they have spotted evidence of a liquid form of water on Mars.
fields.body:
Nasa scientists are believed to have told the White House that they have spotted evidence of a liquid form of water on Mars.

The revelation - not confirmed by Nasa officials and believed to be secret until publication in a scientific journal next week - raises once again the possibility of life on the Red Planet.

The implications of the discovery of living creatures, however primitive, would raise the almost abandoned prospect of a manned mission to Mars. It would also be a sorely needed coup for Nasa, which lost two spacecrafts last year as they ended long journeys to Mars.

Britain would be thrust into the space spotlight: the planet's next visitor will be the European Mars Express, which will set down in 2003 a British lander called Beagle 2, designed to sniff for evidence of water and life in the Martian subsoil, the layer of soil beneath the surface overlying the bedrock .

Mars is apparently arid. It is cold and its carbon-dioxide atmosphere is too thin to support a liquid form of water. But the Martian landscape is scarred by what look like drainage patterns - and even ancient shorelines - indicating water in some warmer past era.

After claims in 1996 by Nasa scientists that they could see fossil microbes in a meteorite from Mars, a series of robot space probes began heading for the mysterious landscape.

Several space websites were carrying reports yesterday that the Mars Global Surveyor, which has been orbiting the planet since 1997, had apparently detected seasonal deposits of ice in regions far from its poles.

Ice on the planet's surface would evaporate and disappear but, if it appeared again, it would indicate a permanent source of water below the surface.

The same spacecraft has apparently also seen pools of water at the bottom of Valles Marineris, a giant canyon which runs for thousands of miles near the Martian equator, one of the few spots on Mars warm enough for water to be liquid. Because of the canyon's huge depth, it could have high enough atmospheric pressures to support a liquid form.

Colin Pillinger, of the Open University, heads a group which is building Beagle 2, Britain's first Mars probe. It will drill into the Martian subsoil and try to detect traces of biochemicals that could only have been made by living things.

"The way I hear it, the guys that are involved are saying 'no comment', and everybody else is saying, 'what could they have seen?' There is a story about the possibility of streams, and the possibility of something which has changed from when they looked at it before.

"[Nasa] might even be about to say that they have seen something volcanic, but I wouldn't have thought they would call Bill Clinton to say they had seen a lava flow," he said.

The US space agency lost its $125m (£82m) Mars Climate Orbiter mission in September because of a mix up between metric and imperial measures in its command software. In December, the £109m Mars Polar Lander disappeared mysteriously just as it should have begun to brake to begin a slow descent. Two micro-probes worth about £20m were supposed to plunge deep into the Martian subsoil, but those were also lost.

Nasa's spokesman Don Savage would only confirm yesterday that there would be a press conference on June 29. But later he promised reporters a press conference later today.

webTitle: ITV chiefs ready for court battle over News at Ten wrangle

fields.headline: ITV chiefs ready for court battle over News at Ten wrangle
fields.trailText: ITV is prepared to face court action in the row over the axeing of News at Ten rather than cave in to the demands of television regulators at a crucial meeting today.
fields.body:
ITV is prepared to face court action in the row over the axeing of News at Ten rather than cave in to the demands of television regulators at a crucial meeting today.

The independent television commission, which has criticised the network for the loss of 1m viewers since the news schedule changes last year, is meeting to discuss a final set of proposals by ITV to bolster the ratings of ITN bulletins.

It is understood the regulator wants ITV to bring forward its 11pm news to 10.30 but, in their proposals to the committee today, ITV chiefs are refusing to back down. Chief executives of the three main ITV companies - Granada, Carlton and United - have told the network head, David Liddiment, they are prepared to go to court rather than give in.

The commission has the power to force a judicial review, but ITV believes the regulator does not have the nerve to go through with a highly damaging court action.

It was the commission, ITV sources say, that gave permission for the schedule change more than a year ago, and they believe it has moved the goalposts in introducing ratings as a criteria by which to judge the performance of the bulletins.

"They know that all our legal advice shows that they don't have the power to regulate for ratings," an ITV source said. "This is such a parochial debate - you can't stop the march of digital television and 24-hour news channels."

In the compromise package, ITV would bring back News at Ten for election campaigns, and extend the problematic 11pm news by five minutes. It has pledged to plough £20m into programmes to bolster the peak time schedule in the run-up to the late night news: the 11pm show gains more viewers when the programmes preceding it are popular. It will also invest an extra £3m into regional news programmes, whose audiences have suffered the heaviest decline.

ITV asked permission to move News at Ten so it could boost the peak-time ratings for long dramas and films. It also wanted flexibility to experiment with edgier drama and comedy for the lucrative younger audiences later at night.

As network and regulator prepared to lock horns, ITN, which produces the news bulletins for ITV, announced the line-up for its 24-hour news channel to be launched this summer. Julia Somerville, John Suchet, Carol Barnes and Daljit Dhaliwal are to be the faces of the new channel.

The broadcaster has also poached Andrew Harvey, from BBC News 24, and Leyla Daybelge, from Sky News, to be regular presenters. Channel 5's Simon Vigar and ITN reporter Ros Childs will also present on the new channel.

fields.headline: Northern slights
fields.standfirst:
Scotland, which may seem to be the poor relation of the wealthy south-east of England, actually spends more than the hard-pressed north-east

North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Three people understood the Schleswig-Holstein question, Palmerston once said. "One died, one went mad. I'm the third and I've forgotten." So with the arcane methods by which money gets distributed from the centre of government to its periphery. One is the "standard spending assessment" which gives English councils their money. Another is the "Barnett formula" used by the Treasury since 1978 to parcel the budget to Scotland and Wales. Today at an Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) conference its author, Joel Barnett, chief secretary in Jim Callaghan's Labour government, will set the cat among the pigeons by saying he only meant it to be a stop-gap and that he is not at all happy with the way it works, especially since devolution.
fields.body:
Three people understood the Schleswig-Holstein question, Palmerston once said. "One died, one went mad. I'm the third and I've forgotten." So with the arcane methods by which money gets distributed from the centre of government to its periphery. One is the "standard spending assessment" which gives English councils their money. Another is the "Barnett formula" used by the Treasury since 1978 to parcel the budget to Scotland and Wales. Today at an Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) conference its author, Joel Barnett, chief secretary in Jim Callaghan's Labour government, will set the cat among the pigeons by saying he only meant it to be a stop-gap and that he is not at all happy with the way it works, especially since devolution.

The formula is not so complicated. It apportions increases in spending pro rata to Scotland and Wales on the basis of their population as a proportion of the British total. It is not even original - it is a revamp of a scheme devised by a bewhiskered Victorian chancellor called George Goschen. The Barnett formula throws an anorak around an old political ploy - buying off political trouble. For 22 years it has protected levels of spending in Scotland and Wales that are higher than an objective assessment of their needs suggests they should get. Which is no accident. Subsidising the periphery is the price you pay for political union when nationalists bark. The trouble is, devolution has made the whole thing more transparent and the anomalies bulk large.

We do not in all truth know that much about where public spending ends up. At least £34bn of UK annual spending is "non-identifiable": no one has ever traced the geographical incidence of spending on defence, scientific research or MI5. Regional statistics have not always been reliable. Until recently, the Inland Revenue could not allocate 12% of its tax records, which under-counted the wealth of the south-east relative to other regions - with malign effects on the distribution of EU money (this is written up in the Economic Journal, gavin.cameron@economics. ox.ac.uk).

What is known is that spending bears only a loose relationship with need. The "neediness" of Scotland as a whole has diminished; GDP per head is now about 4% below the UK average. That might not lessen the case for higher spending, for example meeting the cost of services in sparsely-populated Sutherland. Someone has got to pay for the historic failure of Scots to eat properly, which results in poor health. Better-off Scots, for example: we certainly need a more precise calculation of where in Scotland the poor and sick live.

Not long after the Barnett formula was put in place, the Treasury did try to measure the needs of the different parts of the UK. What the exercise showed was that if Scotland's needs at the end of the 70s were about 16% above England's, Scotland's spending was 22% higher. At the end of the 90s, Scotland was spending 7% more per head than it needed. The imbalance is greater in Wales, where there is an 11% gap between need and spending.

It is wrong to blame a formula for this. Forget the arithmetic, says Iain Maclean of Nuffield College, Oxford in a paper in the journal New Economy (www.ippr.org.uk), the sole rule is what is politically acceptable. But if that is right, there is not much scope for moving spending allocation to a more objective basis, perhaps taking it out of ministerial hands. The Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions has been toying with an independent commission to oversee council grants - something like this exists for federal grants in Australia.

Instead, all the signs are that the distribution debate is going to get more fraught. It is not the difference between England and the other countries in the UK - English political consciousness continues, despite Charleroi, to be the dog that doesn't bark - but between Scotland and needy regions of England. Especially the north-east. Here is an area which has suffered all the torments of de-industrialisation experienced by west-central Scotland, where poverty is rife and the health record is none too good. In 1997 GDP per head in the north-east was some 13% below Scotland's. But government spending is less than in Scotland, on a per capita basis nearly 20% less. Take death (standardised mortality rate) as an index of ill health. Scotland's is 5% higher than the north-east's. That justifies higher health spending. Scotland, however, spends 23% more per head on health than the north-east. The chart captures other areas in which Scotland does better - in Glasgow pupil-teacher ratios are about a fifth lower than in Middlesbrough. The differences do not stop there. Locate in Scotland has just secured a record number of jobs while a new academic study of business networks shows the competitiveness of the north-east (along with Yorkshire and the Midlands) is falling relative to other parts of England. Yet spending on trade and industry is again less in the north-east.

Such figures will remain of academic interest unless they become the subject of political mobilisation. Unless, in other words, there is a "Geordie rebellion" similar to that in the late 70s, differences will not be addressed. Perhaps the stirrings in Labour's heartlands and the attention being paid to a new regional structure in England presage changes in distribution of funds. Now is the time to get it sorted, says the IPPR's Peter Robinson. After the election, a Labour government with a reduced majority could be held hostage by northern MPs.

But if that is right, there is not much scope for moving spending allocation to a more objective basis, perhaps taking it out of ministerial hands. The Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions has been toying with an independent commission to oversee council grants - something like this exists for federal grants in Australia. Instead, all the signs are that the distribution debate is going to get more fraught. It is not the difference between England and the other countries in the UK - English political consciousness continues, despite Charleroi, to be the dog that doesn't bark - but between Scotland and needy regions of England. Especially the north-east. Here is an area which has suffered all the torments of de-industrialisation experienced by west-central Scotland, where poverty is rife and the health record is none too good. In 1997 GDP per head in the north-east was some 13% below Scotland's. But government spending is less than in Scotland, on a per capita basis nearly 20% less. Take death (standardised mortality rate) as an index of ill health. Scotland's is 5% higher than the north-east's. That justifies higher health spending. Scotland, however, spends 23% more per head on health than the north-east. The chart captures other areas in which Scotland does better - in Glasgow pupil-teacher ratios are about a fifth lower than in Middlesbrough. The differences do not stop there. Locate in Scotland has just secured a record number of jobs while a new academic study of business networks shows the competitiveness of the north-east (along with Yorkshire and the Midlands) is falling relative to other parts of England. Yet spending on trade and industry is again less in the north-east. Such figures will remain of academic interest unless they become the subject of political mobilisation. Unless, in other words, there is a "Geordie rebellion" similar to that in the late 70s, differences will not be addressed. Perhaps the stirrings in Labour's heartlands and the attention being paid to a new regional structure in England presage changes in distribution of funds. Now is the time to get it sorted, says the IPPR's Peter Robinson. After the election, a Labour government with a reduced majority could be held hostage by northern MPs. david.walker@theguardian.com

Fiji's new military rulers and the gunmen holding the deposed government hostage said yesterday that they expected a prompt end to the standoff.

webTitle: Coalition reprieve may not save Barak

fields.headline: Coalition reprieve may not save Barak
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israelis began sounding the death knell for Ehud Barak's government yesterday, despite the prospect of a last-minute reprieve from the coalition partners who quit the previous day.
fields.body:
Israelis began sounding the death knell for Ehud Barak's government yesterday, despite the prospect of a last-minute reprieve from the coalition partners who quit the previous day.

Ministers from the Shas party may withdraw their resignations before they come into effect today, sparing the coalition from collapse. But they have cut short the expected lifespan of Mr Barak's year-old government and jeopardised his slim chance of reaching a peace agreement with the Palestinians.

Almost overnight Mr Barak has been transformed into a picture of desperation, capitulating to almost all Shas's demands.

"The countdown has now begun, and this looks like one clock he does not know how to take apart," wrote Chemi Shalev in the Ma'ariv newspaper. "The coalition is now in a state of total chaos."

Even if Shas, which voices the resentment of Jews of Middle Eastern origin, stays, Mr Barak's coalition remains dangerously unstable. Members of the secular Meretz party said they would hand in their resignation today. They object to the most contentious of Shas's demands, to make its religious schools independent of the education ministry.

The crisis comes at an exceedingly sensitive moment, when Israelis and Palestinians are moving closer to the endgame in their seven years of negotiations.

Yesterday Mr Barak told reporters: "The trouble in the coalition is at least partially a result of our decision to move forward. We could easily have a government that is much more comfortable in Israel, that is much more stable, if we did not move towards peace."

Members of Mr Barak's One Israel party fear the price of coaxing Shas back would be a harder line on the negotiations.

"Even if we do get a deal, it is going to be more modest than we would have liked, because now we will have to take into consideration Shas opinion," said Yuli Tamir, the immigration minister.

webTitle: Boy falls victim to town with no scents

fields.headline: Boy falls victim to town with no scents
fields.trailText: When Gary Falkenham ran a few smears of Dippity-Do gel through his hair it was simply with the intention of enhancing his appearance. Not unnaturally, the 17-year-old also applied a dab of deodorant under each armpit.
fields.body:
When Gary Falkenham ran a few smears of Dippity-Do gel through his hair it was simply with the intention of enhancing his appearance. Not unnaturally, the 17-year-old also applied a dab of deodorant under each armpit.

Almost anywhere else these events might have passed without attracting undue attention, but Mr Falkenham lives in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Halifax has what its city council calls a "no-scent encouragement programme".

The schoolboy was expelled for two days after a teacher complained about the aroma he brought with him to the classroom. She said that it made her feel ill.

The elected representatives of the city - noted for the pungent fragrance of newly landed fish - believe that commercially produced scents contain untested carcinogenic chemicals and have banned them in public places.

The perfumes industry says their policy stinks.

Betty Bridges, a nurse from Virginia who travelled to the Canadian city to bolster the war on cologne, said: "The end result is that you have products that are being used by virtually the entire population but nobody knows what they'll do."

Ms Bridges, who often wears a breathing mask, has suffered for the past five years from multiple chemical sensitivity. She says that substances from perfumes have been found in breast milk and are linked to neurological disorders.

Conversely, Charles Low, the president of the Canadian Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association, said: "The question we're here to answer fundamentally is: 'are fragrances and scented products safe for human use?' Our answer is yes."

As for Mr Falkenham, he was arrested by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police - who always get their man, whether or not he is wearing Dippity-Do - and released without charge.
