fields.headline: The Iron Queen
fields.standfirst:
Hywel Williams on the Queen Mum who, in her 100th year, is about to share her thoughts with the nation

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams on the Queen Mum who, in her 100th year, is about to share her thoughts with the nation
fields.body:
The artful wave is still in place. Her spectacles are rarely seen. Norman Hartnell and Cecil Beaton - England's other queens - have a ghostly afterlife as she recycles the images they crafted for her 60 years ago. They obscured the dumpy reality and created a Fragonard image, shimmering in an English late-afternoon light. Here was Gloriana down from the glens.

For the first time, most of us will get to hear what she sounds like when she addresses the nation at her 100th birthday celebrations on July 19. Looking back on this centennial roll, it sometimes all seems a question of japes and stunts, of games and charades, of fun and laughter. It has all been aristocratic "fun", of course, with an exclusivist edge to it, and the laughter has been that oddly manic laughter of royalty, which wills the acquiescent, nervous grin but fears it might be found out.

Listen to Lady Elizabeth telling her father's guests at Glamis Castle: "I shall call myself the Princess Elizabeth" as they allot their parts at a house-party entertainment. "Buffy" was always the one to watch. It didn't start out as fun, exactly. Elizabeth wanted craggy James Stuart of the Royal Scots, who went on to be Winston Churchill's Scottish secretary. It is easy to imagine her as a 1950s Tory cabinet minister's wife. Destiny took a while to re-pattern itself. Bad-tempered Bertie was hopeless. He wouldn't propose to her in person because princes can't run the risk of refusal. So she refused him. Five months later, he came to heel. The photographer caught her leaving for the Abbey in 1923 and looking into the lens with the contrived intimacy of an early motion-picture star.

It didn't prove to be fun, in fact, for a very long time. She got fatter - but also, oddly, sexier. Out went the fringe and in came the centre parting, which made her look like a Sicilian mama. The Mother of the Nation role was in the making, though not yet in the can.

In the gothic house of horrors the Windsors call home, it was all very difficult, even before the 1936 abdication crisis unexpectedly propelled Bertie on to the throne as George VI. Among her brothers-in-law, George, Duke of Kent, was druggy and gay, while Henry, Duke of Gloucester, just couldn't stop his nervous giggle. There was a lot to be nervous about, with born-to-be-king David - subsequently, and briefly, Edward VIII - already embarked on his extensive collection of shoes and check suits. Queen Mary was kleptomaniac (or just greedy, according to the observer's taste in charity) as she wound her way round the country houses of England vacuuming up the Meissen.

It became even odder after Elizabeth became queen. But it was also dull. In the Windsor of 1938, friends describe her as staying in bed until 11am and reduced to spending her evenings drinking home-made wine with the king.

War changed all this. Self-absorbed Bertie still didn't get it. He thought a German cousin with a grudge was at the controls of the plane that bombed the palace. But Elizabeth allied herself with another aristocratic cynic with a taste for media manipulation, Winston Churchill. She created "New Windsor". For her, 1939-45 was Elizabeth's war - and Bertie eventually had to come too. European royals might have jumped ship but, she said, "I will not go down like the others."

"Poor Christian of Denmark and Charles of Norway," said Queen Mary in 1940. Like her son, she thought of war as a family quarrel among the dynasts. But Elizabeth saw that this was a right royal photo-opportunity. So she made virtuous propaganda out of a necessity and stayed in Buckingham Palace. There were restorative Windsor weekends and, thankfully, plenty to drink. George V's first-war decree of a dry palace was deemed a step too far second time round.

Elizabeth's intuitions built on Bagehot's dictum that British royalty depends on the "credulous obedience of enormous masses". Here there was a national grain that was ready to be stroked. The first Labour government in 1924 was a nasty shock for the palace. But George V was prepared to laugh at cabinet minister Jimmy Thomas's jokes - so much so, indeed, that he once got a seizure in that act of regal gratulation.

Labour leaders returned the royal compliments. So the myth was confirmed that sons of arduous toll are complicit with heirs to broad acres, joined by an umbilical cord that excludes the middling sort. Here Bertie was again a bit slow on the uptake. In 1950, he wanted to dissolve parliament when the Labour majority was only eight. But Elizabeth, cooing away with Ramsay MacDonald, got the point years before. After all, wasn't she the queen who ordered Durham and Welsh miners to make dressing gowns for the princesses after seeing an exhibition of their quilts?

The role she has played since 1952 has been that of "Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother" a title of her choosing whose chief advantage is that it forces people to call you "queen" twice. Besides, 52 was no age to start being a "Dowager Queen". Better to carry on being a queen on the make than stay on as one on the shelf.

On the evening of Queen Mary's funeral in 1953, the royal family went ahead with a dinner for Paul of Yugoslavia, a prince famed for wartime treachery. Such swift oblivion will not be her fate. The Windsor cosa nostra owes her a lot. But her legacy is a mixed one.

She brought into the royal family a very 1920s style of brittle suppression, which was part of a wider culture. Embarrassed by Victorian ardour and emotion, its ancestors in literature are Oscar Wilde and Ronald Firbank. Suddenly, it was smart to be hard. The Queen Mother's coeval and friend Noël Coward developed the style as a clipped heartlessness that has sunk deep into Windsor consciousness. Princess Diana was the nemesis of this bogus charm. But its legacy is etched deep on the Prince of Wales's furrowed brow.

She is an emasculating femme fatale. True, the prince she married was emasculated by life itself. More artfully royal than the royals, her job was to put some regal lead into his pencil. But, in other respects, she shows how Windsor woman has been centre stage since the death of George V in 1936. Windsor man has had to survive in an era when being a prince seems pointless, even unmanly. Perhaps royalty is best left to queens. Clarence House's bachelor courtiers would certainly agree.

Prince Charles is both close to her and overawed by her. The women of the family are more wary. Both the Queen and Princess Anne are more loyal to the Mountbatten takeover of "the Firm", a grim affair of obtrusive duty and Outward Bound activity.

But Elizabeth's lens-led tartiness was the more successful ploy. Bismarck said that democracy, being government by the nursery, requires the playing of games. Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon has been our Iron Queen because she realised that royal games are no laughing matter when the suffrage is universal. Get the rules right - and the ermine will stay in place.

 Hywel Williams is a historian; his latest book is Guilty Men: Conservative Decline and Fall 92-97 (Aurum Press).

webTitle: This ex-head teacher abused these women when they were his pupils. So why didn't he go to prison?

fields.headline: This ex-head teacher abused these women when they were his pupils. So why didn't he go to prison?
fields.standfirst: Sally Weale  meets the victims of Robin Peverett OBE, the man who ran Sophie Rhys-Jones's preparatory school
fields.trailText: Sally Weale  meets the victims of Robin Peverett OBE, the man who ran Sophie Rhys-Jones's preparatory school
fields.body:
Jo Evans has not seen her ex-headmaster's study for almost a quarter of a century, but she can remember it as clearly as if she had been summoned there this morning. It's the smell that comes back most vividly - leather, and the sharp scent of polish rising from Mr Peverett's mahogany table. She remembers the slip-on shoes he wore and his perma-crease trousers. And she remembers how he routinely sexually abused her there. Day after day. Again and again.

She was 10 years old when the abuse began. She was shy and quiet, and in the academic shadow of her three elder siblings who were also at the school. Mr Peverett (she still uses the polite title like a schoolgirl responding to the class register) called her to his study after she had a poor report and told her she needed some extra tuition. The abuse began gradually - taking her out of class perhaps once a month for some one-to-one tuition in his office. Then he began to summon her daily.

"Pervert Peverett" as he was known by his pupils (he was always twanging girls' bra straps and knicker elastic) chose victims who were pretty, physically well developed and easily intimidated. Each time Evans was called to his study, she knew exactly what to expect. She never came out of that room without being abused.

The more he abused her, the worse her work became and the more reason he had to summon her for "extra coaching". She couldn't talk to anyone, least of all her parents, who were friends with the headmaster. She was not even safe at the weekend. Peverett told her parents she needed extra coaching on a Saturday, so she was taken to her abuser kicking and screaming and begging not to go.

She felt frightened, powerless, and utterly under his control. If he had told her to walk on hot coals she would have done it. And her life has never been quite her own since.

It was not until years later that Evans, now 35 with three children of her own, learned she was not Peverett's only victim. An unknown number of children who were in his care were abused by him in the same way. They were called to his office for so-called punishments. They were made to lie across his knee either naked or with their clothes and underwear pulled down and he would rub their bare buttocks in a circular motion and spank them.

The consequences of his actions will last a lifetime for Evans and others like her. Yet on June 8, Robin Peverett OBE, former adviser to the Thatcher government, Ofsted inspector and headmaster of Dulwich College preparatory school, in Cranbrook, Kent, was sentenced to 18 months in prison suspended for two years. He admitted nine charges of indecently assaulting seven pupils - six girls and one boy - between the ages of 10 and 13, dating back to the late 60s and 70s, yet he walked free from court. The maximum sentence for indecent assault is 10 years. A further seven charges remain on the file.

Peverett's case was originally listed for a three-week trial at Maidstone crown court - police and witnesses realised there would be considerable media interest, mainly because the Countess of Wessex, Sophie Rhys-Jones, was a pupil at the school, though she played no part in the police investigation. Peverett's victims were looking forward to their day in court. "The trial was going to be our chance to say 'Hello. I'm back. I'm going to tell those 12 good men and women of the jury exactly what you did to me,' " says Evans.

In the end, after lengthy legal wrangling, the public hearing lasted less than an hour and a half and as a result of a bit of nifty plea-bargaining, Peverett, 66, pleaded guilty and got to go home that night. The headmaster's crimes were, Judge David Griffiths said, a serious breach of trust which would normally warrant custodial sentence, but because of Peverett's achievements in the field of education - there were glowing testimonies from former pupils, staff, parents, fellow heads and even one ex-cabinet minister - his was an exceptional case.

So the former headmaster, who worked at the popular Dulwich Preparatory school for 30 years until his retirement in 1990, never had to face a jury and he never had to listen to his victims describe his crimes and the anguish they caused. Most of his accusers were not even in court to see him sentenced - Evans, by chance, was there expecting to be called as a witness. "When I saw him in the court, for a split second I was back in his office. That's the power he had."

As children they were betrayed by the man in whose care they had been placed; as adults they feel they have been cheated by the judicial system in which they put their faith. "The sentence will be of great comfort to other headmasters, past and present, who assault children in their care," says another of Peverett's victims, Vicky Bennison, 41. "On the other hand, victims of such abuse will be thinking, is all the emotional upheaval worth it if I go to the police and this is the result? They would conclude that it was not worth it and they would be right."

Evans and Bennison, who were not identified in court, but have agreed to be named here, are now contacting the crown prosecution service (CPS) asking for the case to be referred to the attorney general, who could in turn refer it to the court of appeal to consider whether the sentence was unduly lenient. However, a CPS spokeswoman said there were no plans to refer the case on. The CPS view, it seems, is that at the time the offences were committed the maximum sentence was two years - taking that into consideration an 18-month suspended sentence does not seem unduly lenient, with the emphasis on unduly. Bennison and Evans, who have lived with the consequences of his actions for the best part of their lives, would disagree.

It was Evans who sparked off the original investigation into Peverett, a father of three, after watching a Channel 5 programme about the marriage of Sophie Rhys-Jones to Prince Edward. "Sophie was a good friend of mine. She was in my class. We had had contact up to her engagement. I watched it out of curiosity. Twenty minutes into the programme Mr Peverett came on to the screen. Seeing his face, I just lost the plot. I was inconsolable. I frightened myself. I started chucking things around the room. I frightened my husband. I couldn't believe he was still out there."

She didn't eat or sleep for four days as she struggled to reach a decision about whether she should report him. She plucked up the courage and the inquiry began. "Physically he did the same thing every single time. I got to expect that. It was humiliating and degrading. It was the mental abuse that shattered me at the time and has affected my life ever since. That's what they don't take into account in court."

After Peverett's violations, her subsequent school career was unimpressive; she was deeply distrustful of male teachers and men in authority, worried that one of them would pick up where Peverett had left off. Why didn't he go to prison?

"I would have been happy if he had lost his liberty for just a short period of time. So maybe, just maybe, he might have had time to look back on his life and think about what he has done to us."

fields.headline: Jobs for the boys
fields.standfirst: A new report reveals that men with sons earn more than those with daughters.  Andrew Martin does some sums
fields.trailText: A new report reveals that men with sons earn more than those with daughters.  Andrew Martin does some sums
fields.body:
Two economists from the University of Washington are currently en route to the European Association of Labour Economists' Conference in Milan with their new findings. They have discovered (a) that American men work longer hours if they have children and (b) that the effect is even greater if those children are boys.

The first bit I could have told them myself. I sit in my study looking out into the garden. I see my children in clothes they're growing out of, breaking toys, demanding ice creams and computers, and the speed of my typing tends to increase.

As the father of two sons, though, I find the second part more interesting. The study, which looked at the careers of 1,200 men between 1968 and 1993, found that the birth of a first son generated an average rise in the time a man spent working of 84 hours per year after the boy's birth, compared with 31 hours for a girl. This led to an increase in earnings and the birth of each subsequent son caused the father's pay to rise by 3% more than each daughter.

Frustratingly, the economists have postponed considering why until the next stage of their research. "We can only guess that having a son increases the value of marriage and family for men," says Shelly Lundberg, one of the report's authors.

Certainly, I thought having two sons was a result. It was exciting, like picking up consecutive cards of the same suit in a poker game. I've always thought - based entirely on Mick Jagger - that men who have a lot of girls are feline, while those who have sons, being incapable of gender deflection, are more manly. It made me feel good to have boys. I had effortlessly achieved something Henry VIII spent 30 years straining after and I hadn't had to murder a single wife in the process.

So, I had my heir and my spare. But that did beg the worrying question: what are they actually going to inherit? Boys do tend to focus your mind on these dynastic issues. The male money nexus in a family is also strengthened by a boy's interest in his father's career, the way a son will breathe down your neck as you try to make a living in a way that daughters, as far as I can see, do not. I've read my boys' many PC books in which, if a plumber is summoned, it usually turns out to be a woman and no big deal is made of it because it's meant to be normal. But I haven't been able to root out their identification of dads with doing. This appears a triumph of nature over nurture - or maybe it's because I'm forever shouting: "I can't, I'm working!"

When I am working, I retreat to a room accorded special reverence by the boys: "Dad's study". My wife also works from home, in what the boys dismissively call "Mum's room". The understanding is that she is to be interrupted at any time, while much of my writing is carried on with the boys outside my door, shrieking at each other in a very disturbing way: "Don't disturb Dad, he's in his study!"

As they get older, my sons' interest in the world of work increases and they have long since moved on from such elemental aspirations as farmer, fireman, etc. Worryingly, my elder son wants to be a PR. Last weekend, he was sitting by the sea, boring to death a six-year-old friend - a girl - on this very subject. All she wanted to do was look for fossils.

Knowing I make my living as a writer, the boys insisted on acquiring an old typewriter. When they were three and four, they would sit at it writing nonsense, like that monkey who is supposed eventually to come up with the complete works of Shakespeare. The ironic thing is that, sometimes, I'd sit in my study doing exactly the same. Not writing Shakespeare but writing nonsense, not getting anywhere.

On these occasions, I'd be listening to the clackings of their own writing machine and feeling terrible because they were playing their game in homage to my earning skills. To them, it's as if I'm sitting in my study typing out banknotes. They seem to think I'm rich and I keep having to tell them: "I can't afford it!" - words that produce an ambiguous feeling in me. On the one hand, these boys have to be told money doesn't grow on trees; on the other, it's important I don't look like somebody who can't deliver on the money front ... Because otherwise, what am I good for?

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: Quotes in the press
fields.body:
"Tony Blair is wrong to dismiss the protest of the matriarchs of Middle England ... The WI was not impressed with rhetoric and neither are the rest of us. In her pamphlet, Winning With Women, former social security secretary Harriet Harman outlines the concerns of the traditional Tory voters who believed New Labour was up for something more substantial than a few Babes. They see their children's crumbling schools, they're paying for elderly parents to get operations the NHS can't do fast enough, they're helping with tuition fees, and they're not impressed. Unlike some of her colleagues, Harman hasn't turned over to have her tummy tickled and toe the party line. She's been the model for the sacked and passed over, good-naturedly working in what she believes is her party's and the country's interest. The prime minister would do well to bring her back from banishment" Jenni Murray, Daily Express

"None of us wants to look our servitude in the eye because then we can't dodge the truth that men's continued dominance is achieved by our voluntary submission. By serving them in this way, we are showing them and the world that they and their leisure (seven times greater than ours) are more important than anything in our own lives" Rosalind Miles on figures from the Office of National Statistics that show even when both partners work full-time, the woman does three times as much housework as the man, Aura

"You don't see many girls among the English fans. It is as if they prefer to leave their girlfriends at home so they can fight. If they were with them, maybe the girls would stop them" A female football fan in Brussels argues that girl power could halt the hooligans, Daily Telegraph

"It has taken a weekend of vicious hooliganism abroad to make us wake up to what is going on day in and day out in our towns and cities. Young English males - I won't call them men - are gripped by an urge to get drunk and violent. The events in Charleroi and Brussels are not so different from what happens every Saturday night in Yeovil, Otley, Wakefield or Swindon. By late evening the streets are awash with drunken 'lads' - snarling, yelling football chants and itching for a fight. Often egged on by equally drunken girls" Ah, maybe not then ... Paul Routledge gives an opposing view, Mirror

"It's a licence for lechers. If our tops were off, they would pull up chairs" A sunbather in London on why she won't go topless, Evening Standard

fields.headline: In-fight catering
fields.standfirst: BA and Virgin patch it up over tea
fields.trailText: Friendship between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic was formally inaugurated yesterday when Sir Richard Branson met his new rival Rod Eddington, BA's chief executive, to bury their differences over a cup of tea.
fields.body:
Friendship between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic was formally inaugurated yesterday when Sir Richard Branson met his new rival Rod Eddington, BA's chief executive, to bury their differences over a cup of tea.

Mr Eddington, turned up at Sir Richard's home in west London for a well publicised 25-minute chat. But the lunch which had been originally announced turned out to be a fleeting visit.

Sir Richard, owner of the Virgin Atlantic airline, said afterwards that he had been greeting "an old friend" and hoped that the "days of dirty tricks were well behind us".

This was a reference to Virgin's battle with BA 10 years ago when the smaller airline eventually won more than £600,000 in damages.

Mr Eddington replied that he thought it was already well understood that those days were long gone.

Sir Richard said he realised that both companies differed on a number of issues. "We want full open skies, but BA wants a deal with American Airlines. We also do not believe that a merger between BA and KLM is in the interests of the consumer."

The two men have agreed to arrange a cricket match between the two companies, the first for a decade. They emphasised that while there are business issues on which they will be on opposing sides, there is a need for a sensible working relationship.

fields.headline: Eye of the beholder
fields.standfirst: Everything is beautiful, from a cuddly kitten to a sleek new bridge. But what is beauty? In the first in a series of articles,  Jonathan Jones asks the painter Patrick Caulfield
fields.trailText: Everything is beautiful, from a cuddly kitten to a sleek new bridge. But what is beauty? In the first in a series of articles, Jonathan Jones asks the painter Patrick Caulfield
fields.body:
What does beauty mean to us today? Patrick Caulfield's After Lunch (1975), which might just as well have been called After Beauty, is a painting that perfectly captures the disillusionment with aesthetic experience that has made beauty hard even to talk about.

The place is a Swiss-themed restaurant, with a fondue set on the table, heavy wooden beams and a colour photo-mural of an Alpine lake. There's a lack of fit to the decor, which betrays a lack of belief. The modernist chairs sit oddly under the baroque Swiss-chalet ceiling, the goldfish are imprisoned in their tank in front of a picture of a real lake. Ironies multiply, and the hilarity has a sadness to it, felt by the gloomy waiter leaning over the wooden rail.

This is the landscape of pleasure today, full of kitsch stylistic references that mock the old idea of "beauty". We have so many reasons for being suspicious of beauty. Beauty is elitist, divisive, it implies other things are ugly. Beauty in modern thought is tied to a notion of "correct" aesthetic judgment whose founding text, Kant's Critique of Judgment, argued that the only true taste is one that is unaffected by the pressures of real life and hence free to recognise the beautiful. This may have been a good career guide for the ambitious cultural functionary in 18th-century Germany, but doesn't seem to have much relevance for us now.

In the 20th century beauty has been discredited because it is associated with an authoritarian, oppressive outlook on life. We revile this authority; we loathe this beauty. Visual pleasure, argues the feminist theorist Laura Mulvey, is bound up with a disciplinarian male gaze. The beauty of still life paintings and Gainsborough's landscapes, argued John Berger in his seminal TV series Ways of Seeing, is no different from the glossy photography that advertises cars. It is the pornography of capitalism.

Everyone today has absorbed these ideas. We are all relativists and we are all suspicious of "beauty". Yet the aesthetic doesn't go away. Kant defined an aesthetic, in contrast to a logical, judgment as "a judgment whose determining basis cannot be other than subjective". We're making those kinds of judgments all the time, liking this, hating that. Indeed, as cultural entertainments multiply, you might call this the golden age of the aesthetic. But it's also an age of radical relativism in which we're not sure if all those films, CDs and designer vacuum cleaners are worth anything at all.

Beauty today means everything and nothing. Norman Foster's millennium bridge is said to be "beautiful" even though it is technically flawed; the architects of the modernist era, for whom form must follow function, would have found that baffling. Paradoxically we can talk about beauty like this because we are less, not more, convinced of its value. We say something is beautiful lightly, as a judgment without weight.

Sitting in his front room, a high, airy space in a Belgravia house with a big glass-topped table and a drinks trolley to hand, Patrick Caulfield sighs at this word "beauty". It's become nothing but cliche. "People think that if you paint a bowl of flowers or a little fluffy kitten that's beauty," he says, "but flowers can be the ugliest things and kittens can be quite irritating too."

To find out whether beauty matters, or exists, I will, over the coming weeks, ask the experts: a painter, an art historian, whoever might help. Beauty, I discover, is a word we can't deal with, that even a painter in the studio files away as unusable. You can't think about creating beauty in the studio, says Caulfield, because you can't create it from a priori principles; you can't think, "I am making a beautiful painting."

Caulfield does not paint the beautiful. He paints the ludicrous makeshift aesthetic we have instead. He paints tacky restaurants, phoney-looking travel posters. His contribution to the National Gallery's Encounters show, which he made in response to the 17th-century Spanish painter Zurbaran, is called Hemingway Never Ate Here. He laughs that it's the name of a real restaurant in Madrid. He just loved the joke.

He paints everyday scenes, glasses on a table, bottles. He emerged in the 60s and has been seen as a Pop artist, but he is really the poet of a certain kind of London piss-elegance. His restaurants are places with nice tables but filthy kitchens, with decor that's ever so slightly desperate.

"When I was teaching at Chelsea School of Art," he remembers, "we used to go to a restaurant in Kensington that had this big photo-mural on the wall, a sort of coniferous forest. It was Swedish food. That was creating a false kind of atmosphere, you know - Scandinavian food and clean living and everything. I bought the photo-mural that I used in After Lunch from this builder's merchant in Chiswick High Street, and the guy said 'Ooh, these have gone out of fashion now' - it was just the right time to buy it."

If the Swiss lake in the photo-mural in After Lunch was retro when he bought it in 1975, it's almost, he jokes, on the point of rediscovery now. "I may be putting down a bit of social history here, the photomural - you don't actually see them these days. They'll probably come back in a different guise - these things always do. I couldn't put this thing down - I was going to stick it on the canvas but it didn't work so in the end I had to copy it."

"The seen walls of lost Eden could not have been more beautiful to us," he remembered. And here is that same scene, but in Caulfield's painting Eden is just a false memory.

After Lunch is a painting of a fallen world, at several removes from any redemptive grace. The waiter is desolate in this false environment, as far from home as the goldfish in their tank are from real, fresh water. The Alps? The Alps are a cliche, just like a kitten.

Patrick Caulfield's After Lunch (1975), which might just as well have been called After Beauty, is a painting that perfectly captures the disillusionment with aesthetic experience that has made beauty hard even to talk about. The place is a Swiss-themed restaurant, with a fondue set on the table, heavy wooden beams and a colour photo-mural of an Alpine lake. There's a lack of fit to the decor, which betrays a lack of belief. The modernist chairs sit oddly under the baroque Swiss-chalet ceiling, the goldfish are imprisoned in their tank in front of a picture of a real lake. Ironies multiply, and the hilarity has a sadness to it, felt by the gloomy waiter leaning over the wooden rail. In the 20th century beauty has been discredited because it is associated with an authoritarian, oppressive outlook on life. We revile this authority; we loathe this beauty. Visual pleasure, argues the feminist theorist Laura Mulvey, is bound up with a disciplinarian male gaze. The beauty of still life paintings and Gainsborough's landscapes, argued John Berger in his seminal TV series Ways of Seeing, is no different from the glossy photography that advertises cars. Kant defined an aesthetic, in contrast to a logical, judgment as "a judgment whose determining basis cannot be other than subjective". webTitle: Sartre wrote songs for her. Miles Davis loved her. But no one ever upstaged her

fields.headline: Sartre wrote songs for her. Miles Davis loved her. But no one ever upstaged her
fields.standfirst: Juliette Gréco, singer, film star and all-round icon, talks to  Eddi Fiegel
fields.trailText: Few singers can claim to have inspired not one but several of the great writers, philosophers and songwriters of the 20th century. Juliette Gréco, singer, film star and all-round icon, talks to Eddi Fiegel
fields.body:
Few singers can claim to have inspired not one but several of the great writers, philosophers and songwriters of the 20th century. Few can justly claim to have become international icons. Juliette Gréco can. As muse to Sartre, Camus, Cocteau, Prévert, Serge Gainsbourg and Jacques Brel, and lover of jazz legend Miles Davis, Gréco came to personify Paris's Left Bank chic. More than a singer, she came to embody rebellion, freedom and individualism. Both she and the songs she sang have become an integral part of French culture.

From the late 40s, through the 50s and 60s, Gréco's records were the sound on a thousand bedsit turntables, and her face adorned a thousand garret walls. She created the style of a generation, with her jet-black sweep of long, straight hair, short fringe, black eyeliner and ivory pallor. "You moonbathe while others sunbathe," Picasso once told her. Black sweaters and pedal pushers completed the look, which became the paradigm of bohemian chic. Her voice was no less dark. This was Edith Piaf with the elegance and femme fatale allure of Marlene Dietrich, singing songs that were part Kurt Weill, part jazz and a large part French chanson.

Gréco was also a success as an actress. By the 50s Hollywood had recognised her glamour and she appeared alongside Orson Welles, Ingrid Bergman and Errol Flynn. But perhaps her most memorable and deservedly famous role was as the leather-jacketed gang leader - Queen of the Bacchantes - in Cocteau's Orphée, with Jean Marais.

Cocteau had based the character on Gréco's own persona. Although only in her late teens when she first met Sartre and Cocteau, Gréco already had a self-possession beyond her years, an anti-establishment disdain and a tendency not only to stick two fingers up at her adversaries but frequently to offer her fists. "I was a very difficult young person and I was very violent. I used to fight," she recalls in a voice that sounds at least 20 years younger than her 73 years. "When you have a stupid person in front of you, or someone who's a little fascist, when you feel there are no more words, you feel like hitting them. So I did. And that's how Cocteau saw me."

It was this anti-authoritarian stance, coupled with the literary pedigree of her songs' lyrics, that made Gréco a star. Her life mirrored that of the French as a nation during and after the second world war. Her Corsican father had left the family home in the Dordogne when Gréco was a child, and her mother and sister were sent to concentration camps for Resistance activities when she was 15. A year later Gréco herself was arrested and spent a month in a prison cell that she shared with three prostitutes. After a strict convent upbringing, it was a rude awakening.

But on her release, finding herself alone in Paris, Gréco was taken in by a friend who introduced her to Sartre and his circle. Sartre was already a cult hero by this time, and the older man quickly became her friend and mentor, captivated by what appeared to be a genuinely free spirit.

Hers was the spirit of the time, and that was to be part of Gréco's great fortune. The years immediately after the war saw an enormous unleashing of pent-up emotions and frustrations, and the centre of the new-found freedom was the area of Saint Germain des Prés on the left bank of the Seine. The area's cafés, bars and nightclubs quickly became a magnet for writers, artists, musicians and philosophers.

"It was absolutely magic," says Gréco. "Freedom happened, and suddenly we could talk and we could speak loud and we could walk in the street without having eyes in our back. We were free, and to be free is the most precious thing in life."

Sartre subsequently based the singer in his Roads to Freedom trilogy on Gréco, but it was his decision to write songs for her that had the greatest impact on her career. Handing her a newly finished song before she went on her first tour outside France, he told her, "Here - this will be your passport." "And," she agrees, "they were my passport, those songs. My whole life."

Sartre's idea to write for Gréco came in 1949 when she was asked to sing at the reopening of the famous prewar night club Le Boeuf sur le Tot. She had already been singing in the Tabou club - the centre of Saint Germain nightlife, but she needed new material for the venue. Sartre offered her some poems to adapt and suggested the composer Joseph Kosma could provide the music.

Gréco and her material proved a sensation, and over the next few years she recorded songs by virtually every major writer of the time. The idea that such revered names as Sartre, Camus and Prévert could write lyrics for a chanteuse seemed revolutionary. But to Sartre it seemed entirely natural. "Playwrights write for actors," he said, "so why shouldn't one write poems for a singer? The writer often forgets that words have a sensual beauty. Gréco's voice reminds us. Gentle, warm and light, her voice rekindles their fire. I wrote those songs because of her and for the pleasure of seeing my words become precious stones."

The lyrics talked of love, life, death and freedom, but while the non- conformity of the Left Bank set reflected the feelings of many French people, others were scandalised when rumours spread about the extent of Gréco's free-living. "I am different," Gréco said later. "I was born liberated and scandalous. I am not vain, I am proud, and yes, I have the right to have a body." Some of the more conservative sectors of society were shocked further still when Gréco began a lengthy relationship with a black man - Miles Davis, who had newly arrived in Paris. "We just fell in love, you know. It was just one look and it was quite amazing. It was a coup de foudre," she says. Gréco's courage gained her further fame as she stood up to the prejudice, spitting in the hand of a restaurant matre d' who refused to serve her and Davis.

Her songwriters played up to her reputation for scandal, and numbers such as Déshabillez-Moi (Undress Me) and Je Hais les Dimanches (I Hate Sundays) became her signature tunes, along with classics such as l'Eternel Féminin (The Eternal Feminine) and Prévert's Les Feuilles Mortes (Autumn Leaves).

By the end of the 50s, when Gainsbourg offered to write for her, she was an international star. The two had dinner and the next day Gainsbourg arrived at her door with La Javanaise - a song now so ingrained in French culture that it is learnt by children at school.

Gainsbourg went on to write many more songs for her over the next few years and, despite the arrival of the Beatles and the "yé yé" boom, Gréco remained a national heroine.

Forty years later she is still revered - as much for what she stood for as for her songs. And this is at least part of her enduring appeal. It is the independent spirit that inspired Sartre et al, the woman who was not afraid to live her life in the way she wanted. "Je suis une femme debout," she says. "I don't lose my dignity."

Juliette Gréco is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), on June 30.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Tracy-Ann Oberman, actress
fields.trailText: Tracy-Ann Oberman, actress
fields.body:
I'm currently filming series two of the LWT comedy drama Bob Martin, starring Michael Barrymore.

It's great to be back. Last year it was just us and the Royle Family rattling around Ealing Studios, now there are six production offices. We've got a competition with the Royles: they've got a "closed set" saying "No Southerners"; ours says "Absolutely No Northerners". There's a catering war too. On our tuck wagon it reads "chip butties next door"; theirs says "p(h)easants over there". Michael Barrymore has put signs up saying "Bob Martin Street", "...Boulevard" and "...Square", with one saying "Royle Family Common". Oh how we laugh.

We're a close team, thanks mainly to Bob Mills and Jeff Pope's brilliant writing. I play Beverley, celebrity booker, mistress of the withering putdown and snappy dresser. This morning was spent in bed with "Vinnie" (Keith Allen) in my first ever sex scene, which must rank as the least erotic in comedy history. Keith has the devil's hands: after a slap on her posterior, the body double had a red welt which needed medical attention.

I love this show, with its eclectic mix of people and great social life.

This week's celebrity guests have included Stephen Fry, Eddie Large and Claire Rayner.

Next Thursday I'm doing a TV pilot for The Way It Is. We've done four series on Radio 4 and "the suits" see a possible transfer to BBC1. I have created cheerily bland cable news presenter, Lolly Swain, solely interested in how the news affects the monarchy. Also, my writing partner Mel Hudson and I must crack on with our comedy drama for Granada. It's about two women working in a Garden Centre who seem horribly familiar to each other - they are, having been burned at the stake as witches in 1614. It's sort of about karmic connections and terrible choices in hairstyles.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Gattaca/Pulp Fiction/Nil By Mouth/Red Firecracker, Green Firecracker
fields.body:
Gattaca

(Andrew Niccol, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

An unusually intelligent sci-fi thriller set in a genetically correct futureworld where people are rated at birth as Valid or In-Valid. Ethan Hawke is one of the latter, who bucks the system - with the aid of Jude Law's crippled, bitter Valid, who sells him his blood, hair and urine - to enter the Gattaca corporation, which will open his way to the stars. Uma Thurman is another citizen with a secret. It's beautifully produced, but curiously muted - emotionally, dramatically, even in its autumnal hues.

Pulp Fiction

(Quentin Tarantino, 1994)

11.40pm, FilmFour

Tarantino's follow-up to his stunning debut, Reservoir Dogs, is just as savagely amoral, but funnier. It takes three staples of the thriller genre - the gangster and the boss's wife; the pug's One Last Chance; the lovers' doomed heist - and interweaves them with giddy pace and complexity. The characters are vividly 90s-Runyonesque: Uma Thurman's icy femme, Mia; Harvey Keitel's Mr Wolf; Tim Roth's Pumpkin; and John Travolta, rescued from acting with babies, a revelation as gunman Vincent Vega.

Nil By Mouth

(Gary Oldman, 1997)

1.35am, Sky MovieMax

Clearly an act of catharsis for Oldman in a brutally honest picture of a dysfunctional southeast London family. Shot with hand-held camera, it makes most verité look like wild flights of fantasy, while the performances are stripped bare and utterly convincing. Ray Winstone's savage, drunken Raymond is one long primal snarl of hopelessness as he brutalises long-suffering wife Kathy Burke.

Red Firecracker, Green Firecracker

(Ping He, 1993)

2.10am, FilmFour

Sparkly romance in which Ning Jing's firecracker-factory boss, coming on tough in men's clothes, is disconcerted by the arrival of male artist Wu Gang, a sort of walking Roman candle.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Egg man to retire from Pru
fields.body:
Egg man to retire from Pru

Derek Higgs, a key player in the flotation of Prudential's internet bank Egg, is to leave the Pru in November when he plans to retire. However, 56-year-old Mr Higgs will remain on the board of Egg, which was floated on the stock market earlier this month, raising £1.3bn.

His departure clears the way for Michael McLintock, chief executive of the M&G fund management that the Pru bought last year, to join the board.

Unions exploit Tory reforms

Britain's unions are increasingly exploiting Conservative laws forcing them to ballot members over industrial action to wring concessions out of employers before any stoppages, a TUC survey published last night shows. The survey showed that unions organised 983 ballots in the period May 1999 to June this year or more than double those last year (464). But industrial action resulted in only 32% of cases compared with 40% in 1998-99. More than half of the ballots (51%) were for a full strike only - compared to just 31% a year earlier -and unions secured 95% backing for strike action. They used this to win all or some of their demands in further negotiations in nine out of ten cases.

Blue Circle to cut 350 jobs

Britain's biggest cement maker, Blue Circle Industries, said yesterday it planned to cut up to 350 jobs over two years on a voluntary basis. The company, which recently fought off a hostile takeover bid by French rival Lafarge, said the job losses were aimed at improving overall performance.

Vodafone UK restructures

Vodafone AirTouch, the world's largest mobile phone company, has reorganised the management structure for its Vodafone UK subsidiary.

It will be organised on a functional basis incorporating sales and distribution, customer operations, commercial, and networks, along with finance, human resources and strategy.

HSBC links with Merrill

Merrill Lynch and HSBC's new online investment and banking service will set up its main customer service centre in Britain, creating 400 jobs over the next two years, the banks said yesterday.

The centre, in Leamington Spa, will provide 24-hour telephone support for customers. Merrill and HSBC formed their internet venture in April aimed at providing online investment and banking for affluent customers.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will be the new 'face of Asda'?
fields.trailText: Who will be the new 'face of Asda'?
fields.body:
Dermot O'Leary 16-1

Lisa Rogers 50-1

Pauline Fowler 66-1

Curly Watts 66-1

Robbie Williams 100-1

Family Beckham 500-1

Supermarkets are increasingly keen to sign up stars to market their brands. Prunella Scales and Jane Horrocks have long been associated with Tesco's, and Delia Smith was a Sainsbury's gal. Now, it's Jamie Oliver who will be getting naked with Sainsbury's, and his price tag (rumoured at £1m) shows there's plenty of gold in celebrity endorsements. But which personality could promote the majorly unglamorous, but well-loved Asda?

"T4's Dermot O'Leary is a relatively fresh face and is going places - he would be in my top 5 for the Big Breakfast role when Johnny Vaughan goes. Asda could use his youthful appeal", says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler.

"Robbie Williams says he's never been in love - but wouldn't it be a great advert if he said he has always been in love with Asda? He would get publicity, but I doubt very much that Asda could afford him."

"Lisa Rogers is the sassy lap dancer in Lock Stock the television series - and seems to have her finger in a lot of media pies. She would certainly turn heads in the aisles, but it doesn't seem likely that she will become their spokesperson."

At present Asda are using the normal-bloke-in-the-street approach. "That seems to be a popular trend, and although personalities do tend to spring up, I wouldn't be surprised if they continue this theme by going for a celebrity who has that appeal. Curly Watts was a supermarket manager in Coronation Street, and Pauline Fowler (Wendy Richards) would get the empathy vote. But I would love to see Joan Collins or Dolly Parton used."

And finally, with the supermarket catering for the whole family, what better role models than the Beckhams? "Victoria and David could shop to their hearts' content, while baby Brooklyn would look great in one of the company's uniforms."

webTitle: Spanish PM: key player and No 10's special friend

fields.headline: Spanish PM: key player and No 10's special friend
fields.standfirst: Portugal Summit
fields.trailText: When the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, scraped into power four years ago he badly needed friends to dispel the distant shadow of General Franco's dictatorship, which still hung over his People's Party, and the nearer one cast by his charismatic socialist predecessor Felipe Gonzalez.
fields.body:
When the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, scraped into power four years ago he badly needed friends to dispel the distant shadow of General Franco's dictatorship, which still hung over his People's Party, and the nearer one cast by his charismatic socialist predecessor Felipe Gonzalez.

Who better as a chum, he thought, than the other new kid on the block, Tony Blair? Brushing ideological differences aside in the hope that some of Mr Blair's panache would rub off, Mr Aznar began to woo his northern counterpart with steadfast zeal.

The Anglo-Spanish alliance is now an accepted force in Brussels, based on shared liberal attitudes to economic and social affairs and a tacit desire not to let France and Germany rule the European roost.

The two leaders work to advance their views on tax harmonisation and their reluctance to accept a citizens' charter which might overshadow the existing European convention setting out basic rights.

Meanwhile Mr Aznar's wife, Ana Botella, popped into No 10 for lunch with Cherie and Leo Blair. Her comment that Leo was a lovely baby was widely broadcast back in Spain.

It is all a far cry from Easter 1998, when Mr Blair, in the throes of a crisis on Northern Ireland, had to be persuaded to join the Aznars for a scheduled family get-together in the Spanish prime ministerial retreat in Andalucia.

At that stage Mr Aznar had more to gain from the photos of the fortysomething couples, each with their three children, than Mr Blair. Two years later, after a return visit to Chequers, frequent phone chats (in French), and Euro meetings, that is no longer so.

Mr Aznar is comfortably ensconced after winning the general election last March, his democratic credentials are no longer in question, and his former lack of charisma is now seen as a healthy disregard for media hype and a welcome break from Spain's tradition of paternalistic strongman leaders.

The economy flourishes, safely in the euro system. Now Mr Aznar can talk to Mr Blair as an equal; warn him that there is a downside to devolution and boast of a better health service. In return, Mr Blair will support him on issues like obtaining more votes from the European Council so that Spain can move from being a medium-rank country to a semi-large one.

But Mr Aznar's ambitions go further. His friend-winning and influence-building efforts are designed to put Spain back where he feels it belongs and at the head of a Hispanic counterattack on the Anglo-Saxon dominance of business and culture in the new global structure. Yesterday's wannabe friend could be tomorrow's powerful rival.

fields.headline: Only in America
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: W ho Would Want To Marry A Millionaire?/Wilderness Man
fields.body:
"What was it first attracted you to the millionaire, Paul Daniels?"

- Mrs Merton to Debbie McGee

W ho Would Want To Marry A Millionaire? (Channel 4), the background story of how a big blonde married a balding stranger on TV with disastrous results, started with a clip of the wedding of Prince Charles and Princess Diana. You know you've hit rock-bottom TV when your teeth rattle.

It was the success of the British show Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? which galvanised Mike Darnell at Fox TV to go one worse. Mike is a windswept whizz kid with more teeth than seems plausible, who dreams up programmes like When Animals Attack! (Or, as The Simpsons put it, When Animals Attack Magicians! The Simpsons, though they are on Fox TV too, like to tweak its big, red brush whenever possible).

Mike Darnell's buttock-clenching brainwave, Who Wants To Marry A Multi-Millionaire? may be almost impossible to parody. Fifty very available women competed to marry a multi-millionaire they had never met on live TV. He turned out to be Rick Rockwell, a fading comic whose sense of humour would soon come in handy.

By the time the bride and groom were waltzing on rose petals, one in five sets switched on in America was switched to Fox.

The bride's first words punctured the groom's bubble. She said her feet hurt. The contestants had lived in high heels for 16 gruelling days of rehearsals, publicity and fittings. "When called, hug the girl next to you to allow the camera to find you. Show excitement! Run!"

No, towards him!

Jay Thomas, the hardboiled host, ("I'm in it for the money. If you're not in it for the money, get out of this business") bounced on. The women paraded in beachwear ("NO thongs!"), wedding dresses and Vaselined teeth to stop their smiles sticking. Backstage, Jay was warning Rick, "don't pick the platinum blonde!" This was Darva Conger ("A self-proclaimed Gulf War veteran") with legs like scissors. The show psychologist had told Rick that lowered eyes indicated shame and a sideways glance meant evasion. Darva's double-barrelled gaze never wavered. It reminded me strongly of When Animals Attack!

"Of course," said Jay, "he picked Darva like a complete idiot."

At the door of their hon eymoon suite she said "I'm out." He said he wished she'd mentioned it before he carried the bags in. "The tape", he added, "wasn't even cold in the camera."

When the whole thing blew up, everyone caught a bit coming down. Darva accepted an offer to pose naked for Playboy. Two losing contestants got $5,000 for stripping on the Howard Stern Show ("Come on, baby! Oh, everybody's clean-shaved!") Rick, who increasingly reminds you of John Wayne Bobbitt, sobbed some then set off on a stand-up show, The Annulment Tour. "I think", he said damply, "there was a reason the Big Guy Upstairs put me in this position."

This is believed to be a reference to Rupert Murdoch, who owns Fox.

You can't cut off Shackleton at the knees and put his feet of clay on display. Wherever you slice the man, he still shows hero. Wilderness Man (BBC2) - gloriously filmed, like all this series - showed how he saved his whole ship's complement from the jaws of antarctic ice . As they never doubted he would. After a year and a half of brutal hardship cheerfully borne, he set out for South Georgia to get help. Tony Bullimore, whose boat was thrown upside down by these seas, described them as looking like a monstrous motorway bridge rushing towards you. Without the hole, of course. As Shackleton's party crossed the mountains of South Georgia to reach the whaling station on the other side, all three had a strange sensation. A fourth seemed to be walking with them. The extra man is only seen by travellers at the end of their tether. Sir Edmund Hillary, not a fanciful man, once went into Shackleton's old hut and thought he saw Shackleton walking towards him with his hand outstretched in welcome. It seemed characteristic of that warm and reassuring man...

"Never a dull moment in this street, is there? Better than watching the telly."

- Curly in Coronation Street

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Material World/Night Waves
fields.body:
Do you recall the days when we were assured that nuclear power would be so efficient and cheap that they wouldn't bother sending us electricity bills? Well, hold your breath just a little longer while the boffins work out how to do it with salt instead. Yes, good old sodium chloride. The secret, according to the two scientists interviewed in Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4), lies in harnessing the heat produced inside salt domes - maybe.

The oddly contradictory attitudes towards our ageing society are explored in Night Waves (10.0pm, Radio 3). We know perfectly well that there are more over-65s in Britain than ever in history, and that their ranks are swelling. Yet the social and political emphasis remains firmly on the young. Laura Cumming looks at a newly published study which establishes that unusually large clusters of oldies have occurred periodically over the past two millennia, and that their social impact was both important and benign.

webTitle: Pious words that hide a double penalty for the poor

fields.headline: Pious words that hide a double penalty for the poor
fields.standfirst:
A disgraceful piece of legislation ought to be thrown out by the Lords today
More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: A disgraceful piece of legislation ought to be thrown out by the Lords today
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Jack Straw set much store by something called the contract with society. Every Briton has one. We're all contracted to do our duty. The contract is especially visible in New Labour sentiment about both law and order and social security. All benefits, says Labour, are conditional on people fulfilling their side of the social bargain. All law-breakers violate not only the criminal code but this larger civil contract, on which social order depends and through which citizens must learn to respect their obligations.

This may be a useful way of expressing the principle of community. As metaphor, it has value. But now the government wants an extension. Breach of contract is being deemed fit for a penalty which is, in its way, unique. The extension is breezing through parliament. The House of Lords has a last chance to stop it today. The issue is narrow but deep, the case for the government seductive - but ultimately repellent. What does society really want from these contracts? New Labour refuses to recognise that they can be poisonously oppressive.

The issue arises low down the ladder of contractors, among the very poorest. Community service orders, imposed by the courts for a range of mostly petty crimes, are, as is well known, sometimes not obeyed. The community work is not done, offenders fail to clock in when they should, and so on. When this happens, the court that imposed the order looks at the circumstances. Maybe the order is reimposed, maybe the offender is reassessed, maybe he goes to jail. This is a messy world, full of inadequates, of people going missing, of social chaos. The probation service, along with the magistrates courts, does its best to keep control.

Meanwhile, pending further adjudication, the alleged breaker of a community order receives social security benefits. Enter the new revision of the social contract. Benefits are now to be removed, peremptorily, without court intervention. Breaches are often contested. That's what courts are for. But now the diktat of the Department of Social Security will replace the court, after a probation officer has reported an alleged breach. Forty per cent of income support and 100% of jobseeker's allowance will immediately be docked. If it takes six weeks, the average, for the court case to come up, that means six weeks on starvation rations or, quite possibly, nothing - unless "hardship" money has been allowed, itself a process that takes a minimum two weeks.

This, remember, is to be the fate of the very poor, against whom no new offence has yet been proved. Wealthier breakers of CSOs won't suffer, until the court hears the case. The unemployed will have double penalties: first the removal of benefit then, if guilty, the further punishment, all this to take place in a context whose purpose is supposed to be getting damaged and otherwise hopeless people back into work and society.

That version of the social contract has powerful supporters. It's all about message, they say. The breaker of a CSO is typically a chronic menace, terrorising housing estates, vandalising neighbours' lives, scorning the very concept of community order. Lord Warner, a former Straw adviser, is incredulous of critics. Such offenders mustn't keep on getting benefit, he said. They've broken a contract, one of the terms of which is to abide by court orders. In any case, the punishment "will be no more than a four-week deprivation of benefit. . . This does not seem to me to be a very onerous set of circumstances." To another government peer, backwoodsman reborn, the issue of benefit-loss was even simpler: "Why can't these people toe the line when they know the issue with which they are faced?"

Such ruthless dispensing with existing rights rests, however, on a grotesquely one-sided view of contract. First, a valid contract can exist only between two parties that both know what they are doing. The kind of people commonly subject to CSOs are too often irrational, unaware, reckless and cruelly pressured by their lives. The idea that a change in the law that hits them hardest will make them more aware of their personal contract is the invention of politicians desperate for quick fixes. But second, no contract with society can exist that excludes the court as prime adjudicator. It's elementary. By breaking that term, the government not the miscreant looks more like the law-breaker, refusing to acknowledge a fundamental contractual duty.

The social crimes that CSOs address are serious. Failure to comply is widespread, though not so rife as some government propaganda suggests: only a minority of non-compliers, when caught, are sent to prison. The probation service has toughened up its act. Within the skein of social breakdown that most of us never see, the issues are complex and the remedies often inventive. This initiative, hitting a lot of hard nuts where any law-and-order populist must think entirely justified, surely just breaks a fragment of innocuous new ground. That's the argument.

There are two objections. They seem to me overwhelming. The first is practical. The Penal Affairs Consortium, representing 41 organisations concerned with the penal system, says the measure is "retrograde, counter- productive and bound to increase crime". Offenders who find themselves suddenly without money are likely to reoffend. That's their impulse, what they're good at, the only way to survive when left in limbo. Nobody has come forward to rebut this probability, save some Labour stoolies in the Lords rabbiting on about it being an insult to the unemployed to say they're more likely to offend than other people. It is just about universally agreed that the price of making this big public statement, that reoffenders must not get social benefits, will be an increase in reoffending.

Second, the principle of punishment before conviction is being too smoothly accepted as quite proper for people already on their uppers. The CSO is not an administrative condition, but a judicial penalty. Its breaching should be not for civil servants but judges to decide. Pious language about social contracts doesn't address that point, any more than sanctimonious ranting about the socialist case for protecting victims of lawless housing-estate marauders.

Lady Hollis, the minister who will lead today, almost admits that withdrawal of benefit is being used as punishment. She claimed this was "not our primary intent", but didn't deny it was a common perception. She also said she "would not on principle rule out further extensions". The conditions of benefit, in other words, might well be extended as swiftly as this one has appeared. The culture of administrative decision slowly glides to dominance over that of judicial propriety - as long as you're poor enough to be so easily victimised. Is it for this that Lady Hollis and her boss, Alistair Darling, became Labour politicians?

If it takes six weeks, the average, for the court case to come up, that means six weeks on starvation rations or, quite possibly, nothing - unless "hardship" money has been allowed, itself a process that takes a minimum two weeks. This, remember, is to be the fate of the very poor, against whom no new offence has yet been proved. Wealthier breakers of CSOs won't suffer, until the court hears the case. The unemployed will have double penalties: first the removal of benefit then, if guilty, the further punishment, all this to take place in a context whose purpose is supposed to be getting damaged and otherwise hopeless people back into work and society. That version of the social contract has powerful supporters. It's all about message, they say. The breaker of a CSO is typically a chronic menace, terrorising housing estates, vandalising neighbours' lives, scorning the very concept of community order. Lord Warner, a former Straw adviser, is incredulous of critics. Such offenders mustn't keep on getting benefit, he said. They've broken a contract, one of the terms of which is to abide by court orders. In any case, the punishment "will be no more than a four-week deprivation of benefit. . . This does not seem to me to be a very onerous set of circumstances." To another government peer, backwoodsman reborn, the issue of benefit-loss was even simpler: "Why can't these people toe the line when they know the issue with which they are faced?" Such ruthless dispensing with existing rights rests, however, on a grotesquely one-sided view of contract. First, a valid contract can exist only between two parties that both know what they are doing. The kind of people commonly subject to CSOs are too often irrational, unaware, reckless and cruelly pressured by their lives. The idea that a change in the law that hits them hardest will make them more aware of their personal contract is the invention of politicians desperate for quick fixes. But second, no contract with society can exist that excludes the court as prime adjudicator. It's elementary. By breaking that term, the government not the miscreant looks more like the law-breaker, refusing to acknowledge a fundamental contractual duty. The social crimes that CSOs address are serious. Failure to comply is widespread, though not so rife as some government propaganda suggests: only a minority of non-compliers, when caught, are sent to prison. The probation service has toughened up its act. Within the skein of social breakdown that most of us never see, the issues are complex and the remedies often inventive. This initiative, hitting a lot of hard nuts where any law-and-order populist must think entirely justified, surely just breaks a fragment of innocuous new ground. That's the argument. There are two objections. They seem to me overwhelming. The first is practical. The Penal Affairs Consortium, representing 41 organisations concerned with the penal system, says the measure is "retrograde, counter- productive and bound to increase crime". Offenders who find themselves suddenly without money are likely to reoffend. That's their impulse, what they're good at, the only way to survive when left in limbo. Nobody has come forward to rebut this probability, save some Labour stoolies in the Lords rabbiting on about it being an insult to the unemployed to say they're more likely to offend than other people. It is just about universally agreed that the price of making this big public statement, that reoffenders must not get social benefits, will be an increase in reoffending. Second, the principle of punishment before conviction is being too smoothly accepted as quite proper for people already on their uppers. The CSO is not an administrative condition, but a judicial penalty. Its breaching should be not for civil servants but judges to decide. Pious language about social contracts doesn't address that point, any more than sanctimonious ranting about the socialist case for protecting victims of lawless housing-estate marauders. Lady Hollis, the minister who will lead today, almost admits that withdrawal of benefit is being used as punishment. She claimed this was "not our primary intent", but didn't deny it was a common perception. She also said she "would not on principle rule out further extensions". The conditions of benefit, in other words, might well be extended as swiftly as this one has appeared. The culture of administrative decision slowly glides to dominance over that of judicial propriety - as long as you're poor enough to be so easily victimised. Is it for this that Lady Hollis and her boss, Alistair Darling, became Labour politicians? hugoyoung@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Opec promises more oil
fields.trailText: Opec ministers last night struck a compromise deal to raise output by around 3% in an effort to rein in an oil price which has soared beyond $30 a barrel.
fields.body:
Opec ministers last night struck a compromise deal to raise output by around 3% in an effort to rein in an oil price which has soared beyond $30 a barrel.

But industry watchers remain divided over whether the 708,000-barrel-a-day rise will be sufficient to bring the oil price back within the Opec target range of $22-28.

Most of the Opec members had sought to restrict the increase in output to around 500,000 barrels fearing that a bigger rise could lead to a rapid rise in oil stocks and a sharp fall in the price.

But Saudi Arabia - the cartel's biggest producer - had been pressing for an increase of around 900,000. The country, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates are the only Opec producers with significant spare capacity.

The result reflects the problems facing Opec in trying to juggle the price. Though the cartel is keen to avoid a return to the days of $10 a barrel it is aware that rising energy costs feed through into inflation, higher interest rates and slower economic growth in many of the world's developed economies. It is concerned that the high price of oil is persuading consumers to switch to other fuels, such as gas.

There is also concern that the oil price has been dragged higher by new environmental rules on petrol in the US which have restricted supply.

Opec's president, the Venezuelan oil minister Ali Rodriguez, said last night that market stability was Opec's prime concern. "Left to itself instability breeds instability and is disastrous for the industry," he said.

He accused governments of levying "excessive taxation" and said they, not Opec, should be blamed for the high price of petrol.

In the US last night oil futures added some 70 cents to $31.35 a barrel amid disappointment about the size of the output increase. Critics who believe the deal is too cautious argue that the increase takes Opec's target output up to 25.4m barrels a day at a time when actual output was already 25.3m barrels a day because of production running in excess of official quotas.

The US has lobbied hard for higher output as prices at the petrol pumps in the US have soared to unprecedented levels and sparked an investiga tion by the federal trade commission.

Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in New York, said it would take some time for any reduction in the price of raw oil to feed through to the pumps in the US.

But, he said that while the oil producers have not increased production by as much as some analysts had hoped - many were forecasting a 1m barrel a day increase in output - it would have been dishonourable for the producers to raise production by much more. "I can't see that it is in their self interest for this situation to continue," he said.

fields.headline: My friends the skinheads
fields.standfirst: Leo Regan  wrote a book about a gang of neo-Nazis he became close to - despite finding their views abhorrent. Now, 10 years on, he's made a film about how three turned out
fields.trailText: Leo Regan  wrote a book about a gang of neo-Nazis he became close to - despite finding their views abhorrent. Now, 10 years on, he's made a film about how three turned out
fields.body:
The first time I met the gang was on a summer afternoon and I had just walked into a dangerous-looking bar in Cardiff. The bar was full of skinheads getting drunk. I wasn't really prepared. Two cameras hung from my shoulders and I clearly looked out of place.

Everyone in the room stopped and stared. I scanned the room, trying not to look desperate. I had a contact, a good one. I was working on a magazine article about neo-Nazi bands and had photographed Ian Stuart, lead singer with the infamous neo-Nazi band Skrewdriver. He told me about the gig, said he'd be there. And of course, he was somewhere else, far away, probably laughing. Four large, mean-looking, tattooed, bald men surrounded me. The scariest one (Nick, I later learned) yanked a camera strap and asked: "What the fuck are you intending to do with this?"

My policy in such situations is to risk honesty and hope for the best. I want to document your lives. I'm not a supporter. I'm not out to promote you. I just want to see who you are beyond the public image. It doesn't always work, but this time it did. They invited me in. They didn't believe me, but I guess they were baffled and intrigued. For the next two years this gang became part of my life.

They were based in Milton Keynes and travelled hundreds of miles each week to neo-Nazi concerts, rallies, meeting, marches: anywhere there was a platform for the promotion of race hatred, or racial pride as they called it - and the chance of some violence. Race and violence were their creed, the glue of their lives. For some gang members their beliefs were more important than their families.

I kept my head down, photographing and tape-recording their private thoughts and rhetoric. I was trying to comprehend what attracted them to this bizarre and estranged existence. I didn't particularly like many of those I met. But then I did warm to some and started to build friendships, outside the politics. That made things complicated.

Neo-Nazis are inherently paranoid. They live in an underworld of infiltrators and informers, and are expected to adhere to a strict code of gang loyalty. They never fully believed my story and suspected I was either an undercover police officer or a "red" (anti-Nazi). I was constantly fed false information about individuals and events, to see if it ever came back to them.

Sometimes I questioned the wisdom of my self-inflicted assignment. I became used to the police videotaping my car, which was inevitably stuffed with skinheads responsible for crimes I didn't want to think about. Once, after a fight between anti-Nazis and neo-Nazis in the outskirts of a northern town, I heard the police were looking for the fourth gang member - the balding one with the camera.

After my book, Public Enemies, was published, the gang fell out and went their different ways. I received the occasional letter from a lonely prison cell and a few phone calls but we drifted apart. I have always been curious about them and, 10 years on, I set out to discover what had become of their lives. They're not easy to find. Some have vanished and don't want to be found. Others now hold responsible positions which they would probably lose if their employers knew about their murky pasts.

Most said their extreme views hadn't altered, they just keep them to themselves. One man, who even his fellow gang members thought was psychotic (no small achievement), told me he had joined a Parent Teacher Association. Eventually three members, Nick, Neil and Colin, agreed to take part in a film, to be called 100% White. I spent 12 months following their lives. My relationship with them deepened. We ate together. I got to know the children, slept on the sofa. We became friends again - friends with dramatically opposing views.

Nick is a huge man with a fearsome reputation and many friends in far-right organisations. After our tense introduction 10 years earlier, Nick took a liking to me and saved my neck more than a few times. At gatherings, I was constantly harassed and he would step in. Of the three, he has changed the most. In prison Nick was attacked by black gangs for being a known racist. Amazingly, from this experience grew a respect for black people and their camaraderie; unlike white prisoners, they stuck together.

Like the others, Nick doesn't deny his past and treasures his neo-Nazi memories. Since leaving prison he has formed close friendships with black people and was very apprehensive about "coming out". But I think he wanted to demonstrate his loyalty to his new circle. Loyalty and honour were always a gang obsession.

Neil was also someone I had got close to while doing the book. He's been in hiding for six years after falling out with high-ranking characters from the extreme organisations he belonged to. A death threat was issued against him and, despite having more than 40 convictions, he sought police protection. Two months into filming, a series of nail bombs exploded in London and Neil wanted out of the film. Even though he had no connection with the bombings, the hunt for perpetrators made him paranoid. He only agreed to continue after a man was arrested and charged. I was shocked to hear Neil's support for the bomber. He admitted having harboured similar feelings and intentions during his time with the gang. "I just didn't have the bottle," he told me. "But I can understand what he was thinking."

Neil has some of the most offensive opinions I've ever heard. He has also been responsible for brutal crimes. But I have a lot of feelings for the man. Figure that one out. Throughout filming, I was repeatedly moved as he candidly tackled painful and difficult questions with honesty. It's also difficult not to be impressed by his survival instinct, given his history and horrendous upbringing.

Colin - tall, wiry and heavily tattooed - can look terrifying. He had spent the previous year in prison for fraud and theft. Soon after being released, his marriage to wife Karla disintegrated violently. He admits to assaulting her repeatedly during their eight years together. But without her he is lost. Karla, a striking woman with a capacity for tenderness, believes Colin hides behind his fierce image. Unknown to him, she told me details about his past that were staggeringly contrary to this image.

After confronting Colin about the contradictions in his life, I saw what it's like to be on the receiving end of his rage. He stormed out of the film. Later, after a phone call I'd rather forget, he warned me never to contact him again. A few days later he agreed to meet and, surprisingly, after a few weeks he continued filming and spoke openly about his apparent hypocrisy.

I've shown the film to Nick, Neil and Karla. They all thought it was a fair representation of their lives and didn't look for changes. Colin refused to watch it, not wanting to relive the torment. He still doesn't know if he'll watch it when it's broadcast.

100% White is on Channel 4, Monday, 10pm.
